text: This is a great place to work and study quietly that has free wifi with little interruption! Even on the weekends!<br><br>The food is a little on the pricey side, but solid and though thier coffee lacks flavor, it does give you that caffeine kick! They also have a nifty thing where you can print an image in the foam! Only in one color though. <br><br>The music isn&#39;t very loud and the crowd here is usually very chill and quiet. There are plenty of places to sit and some have power outlets to do work in. <br><br>The space is fairly clean and the large windows bring lots of light into the cafe without it scorching your skin! I can&#39;t say anything about the desserts, as I havent had any of them yet!<br><br>Though the staff members are friendly, they don&#39;t seem to be on top of everything. The bathrooms are not checked regularly and the tables take hours to get cleaned up- even of there are little to no patrons currently in the store. The staff members are relatively young, which I understand, but I think they may need to work on just maintaining the space at a more accurate timetable is all.<br> Also, whenever I&#39;d ask for recommendations, the employees would always be unsure or try to upsell me the most expensive items which feels disingenuous.<br><br>They also have messed up an order of mine, and though I was fine with it, they didnt seem very apologetic in the least. That left me wondering if they really had any customer experience.<br><br>The cafe is connected to a hotel and if you let them know and show your room card, they give you 10% off your order.<br><br>Mostly a good place to work, since all the cafes around seem to be more of a social spot- with a small maintainence and employee issues. <br><br> But overall a solid 4 stars for me!

text: Simple and easy place which I like to come for fresh juice and European little foods.

Call me a Starbucks addict if you must, but it&#39;s not really the drinks that keep me coming back to Starbucks, but the location and the environment are the most important factors in choosing where to get that hot cuppa coffee, or where I should hammer that essay. <br><br>The Delfi outlet that has recently been added to the Starbucks chain is my favourite thus far. Aside from the prime location in the heart of orchard road, what I like about this outlet is the laidback atmosphere of the cafe. Further, there are powerplugs freely available under the wooden tables both inside and outside. Aside from that, the long wooden table on the outside is perfect for group discussions. <br><br>If you&#39;re feeling bored, sit by the ledge, and you can people-watch. There are many interesting characters around this part of town, where the infamous Orchard Towers is located at. Time passes by very quickly at this Starbucks outlet. There&#39;s something about this outlet (of which I can&#39;t put my finger on) that just keeps me coming back for more.

View on a weekday afternoon', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'View on a weekday afternoon'}]
text: I&#39;m a social coffee drinker, and I like coffee just fine. I&#39;m not very particular about it; of course I wouldn&#39;t say McDonald&#39;s, Starbucks, and Nylon coffee are all the same, but if you were to press me about the differences it&#39;d be a bit difficult for me to say what they are!*<br><br>That being said, I was looking for an air conditioned cafe in Tanglin that had free wifi, but didn&#39;t have any luck finding something &#34;Yelpy&#34;. Not wanting to waste time, I decided to just visit the man and stop by this Starbucks in Delfi Orchard.<br><br>As other reviewers have said, this outlet is in a prime location on Orchard Road. Not only do they have a spacious air conditioned interior, but they also have a nice covered patio if you&#39;d like to be outside. But what makes this outdoor area better than Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf across the road is that 3 sides of the patio are enclosed in glass so there are less chances of pigeons flocking on the tables.<br><br>Since they jump the gun here and start holiday season in October, I enjoyed sipping a peppermint mocha while mooching off the free wifi and getting some WERK done. Wifi expires every 30 minutes, so just be prepared to reconnect each time. <br><br>My only complaint is that no one seems to bus tables here. When I arrived mid-day there were so many plates and dirty tables, and for the 1.5 hours I was there, not one employee went out to clean anything until I was about to leave.<br><br>--<br>*Judge me. Judge me all you want.

Caramel Macchiato in a cup :)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Caramel Macchiato in a cup :)'}]
text: Prices are really high in Singapore (small latte cost about US$6). But otherwise I really liked this Starbucks. Great customer service, tasty lattes and great location. I love that they give you coffee in a real cup - looks so great. However most of the times I prefer to have my latte in a paper cup just because the size is a bit bigger! I don&#39;t wanna waste any drop of my latte!

text: I am a Starbucks junky! I love visiting locations outside of the US to see how the brand holds up in various countries/cultures. This location was a great break from the rigors of the many business meetings I attended during my visit to Singapore. The staff was very nice and polite and my order was exceptionally crafted! It is always comforting to visit a place that is familiar to me like Starbucks and receive the same levels of quality and service no matter where I am in the world. Starbucks is my &#34;third place&#34; and I appreciate the Partners at this store for what they do to create a comforting and welcoming environment!

Last few weekends I came it took 20+ minutes to get a coffee. One coffee was in hand I had to find a dirty table, clean it myself, and then finally sit down to enjoy.<br><br>Food and beverage are precisely what you would expect, however I just don&#39;t understand the staffing manager&#39;s decision to consistently put on 2 staff to handle the weekend crowd. <br><br>There are too many coffee shops in the area to deal with this.

text: I like Starbucks, because they have a set of products and business model that work. This isn&#39;t a review as much as an amusing observation. My daughter loved getting the store made chocolate milk back in the States. We attempted to order that at a Starbucks here, and things went sideways. We got hot chocolate. I tried to explain that we just wanted cold milk mixed with chocolate sauce, and twice we were told &#39;yes, that is our signature hot chocolate.&#39; A couple of minutes went by, during which time the poor staff appeared completely befuddled by my request, and finally asked if I would just like the SHC over ice...I succumbed and said yes. At least we had a good laugh about it, and picked up some chocolate syrup at the store that night.

text: Lovely cosy coffee bar with its own coffee roastery. The enthusiastic coffee crew brewed me an delicious flat white for a competitive price. <br><br>You&#39;ll find an elegant hardware line-up with a Dutch Kees van der Westen Speedster design espresso machine and a line-up of high end grinding machines. The roasting equipment is equally interesting. <br><br>Although this place may be a little hard to find it&#39;s certainly worth going the extra mile.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/K8-IMvrv-8CLx01-0aHsTA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/reload-singapore?reviewid=Cp783n2flcKk2pK_wyWP9w&select=K8-IMvrv-8CLx01-0aHsTA', 'altText': 'Photo of Reload - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: It would be an understatement to say that I frequent here. This place is incredible! Though I am not vegetarian, which is what is on the menu here, dishes served here are delectable! The caesar salads here are scrumptious and doesn&#39;t come with any guilt. You won&#39;t spend over 13 dollars here, the prices are very reasonable.<br><br>The service isn&#39;t too bad either! They are always catering to my needs and making sure everything is in order. The design of the restaurant can be improved though. It doesn&#39;t much look like a restaurant, rather a juice bar.

text: Lovely little spot in Everton park. Perfect place to kick back and enjoy a coffee and some cakes.  Interesting collection of books too.  Spoke with the owners - two architects that walked away from their profession to pursue this labor of love. Their passion shines through the perfectly balanced cakes. Glad I stopped in.

text: I had a lovely time visiting the cats at The Cat Cafe. <br>Entry is $15, which includes one soft drink, I upgraded to an iced latte for an additional $3.50 and ordered a slice of red velvet cake with cream cheese frosting which tasted like red velvet cheesecake. Total with taxes was about $26, I spent about 4 hours here. Given that most cat cafes in Singapore charge about the same and have a one hour limit, this was pretty comfortable. <br><br>There are tons of cat, and all of them for the most part are pretty well behaved. The patrons on the other hand were not.  I kid you not... there was a grown man who went around annoying all the cats and made the staff take pictures of him posing. It was pretty ridiculous.  He even changed his shirt at one point... in front of me. Annoying and inappropriate but whatever. None of the cats liked him.<br><br>Mr. Tommy was my favorite. He was such a little cutie pie.

text: Jiejie had been wanting to visit cat cafes in sg since she visited the ones in Malacca and Tokyo, so was checking them online. Stumbled upon this cafe which is really central, just opposite Bugis. Easy to just park there and crossover as it&#39;s just above BK.<br><br>At first, the girls thought it may be a dodgy place as we were climbing up the stairs but it turned out to be a really cozy place to hangout!  It&#39;s $15 per entry incl 1 soft drink. As it was nearly tea time for the girls, Jiejie had her eyes on the red velvet... Cost $8 a pc but she practically swallowed it before I took a pix... Sorry guys! She said it was really moist and not too sweet. Trust a 12yo?<br><br>Can u believe we stayed there for 4+ hours?!?! The lady boss and staff were really friendly and patient with answering all the questions from the kids. Not sure how they can do it the entire day though.  We ordered the lasagna and baked chicken rice with chips $8.90 each.  The quality surprised me, pretty decent really! Again, forgot to take pictures..... Oops! Will definitely go again with the girls!! Of course not so much for the food but for the company of 14 furry friends!!! Love them all!!

Warning: Don&#39;t come on weekends. Menu is limited. This not available, that not available... also weird tables. They have this bench table but the seats are too low with the table top or my body is too short. I&#39;m 5&#39; 8&#34; and the table is almost at my chest level, I feel like I&#39;m in a hospital, with the  table too near you. <br><br>The dishes were ok, we had eggs and toast and a sausage. <br><br>Filled my tummy and that&#39;s good, but the service and furniture needs to be improved.<br><br>Latest Update 21 Nov 16: I got a message thanking me for the feedback that I gave (above). What really surprised me was that the business owner actually took the time to update me on the changes that they have done since my review. <br><br>This shows that they are very positive in taking negative feedback and changing it to suit their customers. <br><br>I salute your management style. Keep up the good work!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/p-pGL3veW5_6raFxRRYkVQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/waterfall-cafe-singapore?reviewid=8sKih7VE-R3mttOIahqPGQ&select=p-pGL3veW5_6raFxRRYkVQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Waterfall Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. main course of fish and side salad', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'main course of fish and side salad'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/UvuDV7bU6ef0eSB53T3Rug/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/waterfall-cafe-singapore?reviewid=8sKih7VE-R3mttOIahqPGQ&select=UvuDV7bU6ef0eSB53T3Rug', 'altText': 'Photo of Waterfall Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. the buffet spread (and a greedy steffi)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'the buffet spread (and a greedy steffi)'}]
text: wholesome, chichi, yummy-mummy-abound buffet of antipasti and salads at this cafe in the rather-tough-to-get-to shangri-la hotel (they serve up some fantastic mains too). I have finally made my way to this place, and it couldn&#39;t be sooner - the food is light and clean (on the palate; hygiene here taken for granted) and varied in both flavor and color, and there&#39;s a relaxing vibe to this place that lends itself to lazy weekend brunches.<br><br>great service too, and reasonable prices given the quality and type of food served - it&#39;s worth the drive/ trek.<br><br>shangri-la is one of those chains that&#39;s sort of familiar and posh without trying too hard - and it always has this languid vibe about it that&#39;s rather reflected in this restaurant - filled with lunching ladies in flowing dresses, set by the pool side.<br><br>the mostly mediterranean-styled food is laid out on a long, gorgeous wooden table - <br>many different flavors and all well-balanced-and-seasoned - but it&#39;s a light flavor profile that seems much better suited to women. but to bulk things up, the lunch sets also offer the option of an additional set course - anything from fish to beef.<br><br>my main courseof  fish was properly seared - the skin was suitably crispy, the meat flaky, and the little salad on the side of baby carrot and corn was plenty tasty.<br><br>but you don&#39;t need the main course - we were just being greedy - the salads are pretty much sufficient for a satisfying, sating weekend lunch, without any of that usual heft that necessitates a post-meal siesta (though you can still take one, if you&#39;re so inclined). delicious food - tastes and feels almost like you&#39;re in a leisurely holiday town - well worth the almost unbelievably reasonable price for lunch.

text: I attended a wedding dinner here not too long ago. The food and service were good, but nothing to scream about. Recently returned for lunch, when I had the festive menu. The main pasta dish was very good, but the Caesar salad or the dishes ordered by my lunch mates were quite meh. Prices are not exorbitant, but there are LOTS of restaurants in Singapore that serve better Italian food. Convenient for guests of the Shangri-La, but definitely not a gastronomic destination.

Head on over for a taste of the crisp and refreshing flavors of South Italy over at The Waterfall, Shangri-La Singapore. Chef de Cuisine Marco De Vincentis has curated a refreshed menu with 27 new a la carte creations and six new desserts including homemade pastas, fresh seafood and Southern Italian signatures.<br><br>Fresh and seasonal produce is the highlight at The Waterfall, using authentic cooking methods and heirloom recipes. We enjoyed the Manzo Black Angus Marinato salad which features marinated Black Angus beef with pine nuts, rocket and pecorino cheese, drizzled with a delectable honey balsamic.<br><br>Canestrato Pugliese e Pomelo was a refreshing mesclun salad with black olives, canestrato cheese, white balsamic dressing with fresh pomelo wedges for a citrusy tang; <br><br>The pastas are made fresh at the restaurant and you can pick from one of the 18 different flavors; and there are also egg-, dairy- and gluten-free pastas as well! New highlights include Spaghetti Al Nero Di Seppia, Scampi E Datterini, homemade squid ink pasta flavoured with rich scampi sauce and cherry tomatoes with a hint of chili for added spice. I enjoyed the garlic seafood sauce but the pasta was a tad overcooked imo. <br><br>For mains, The Baked Pink Snapper was delicious. I loved the sweet firm flesh with a nice golden crust all around and that pretty herbed mashed potato lightly tinted pink with beetroot juice. The caveman sort can go for the Slow-cooked Lamb with verbena-scented celeriac root puree, and Bistecca Alla Fiorentina with rosemary oil accompanied with baked potatoes.<br><br>Other than the refreshed dessert selection which includes cakes and cookies, there&#39;s also a gelato section by Alfero Gelato! Love love love their super intense gelato. You must certainly have the nutty Pistachio, salty sweet Coconut Sorbet, nutty Bacio, and more. There&#39;s a special Waterfall flavor that is specially created by Alfero. <br><br>A la carte dishes at The Waterfall are priced from $14. Expect other Italian favorites of cured meats and artisanal cheeses, as well as handmade pizzas!

text: Outstanding!!<br><br>To put in words how delicious the food is will be a challenge, so you must come to try it for yourself!  Fresh, high quality ingredients you can taste.  <br><br>Went for lunch with family to celebrate a birthday and every person in our party of 12 people had a wonderful meal, including the vegetarian!<br><br>This is some of the best Italian food I&#39;ve ever eaten!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=tieQ1FQ3BdXO7PjShPE28g', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Bern T.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Bern T.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=tieQ1FQ3BdXO7PjShPE28g', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 1, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 80, 'eliteYear': None}
text: It seems the breezy little spot is fast discarding its image as an in-house-guest-only destination, and coming into its own. The Southern Italian fare is excellent; hearty and soulful yet refined. Although the restaurant was a full-house at the revisit, service was surprisingly efficient and gracious.<br><br>We had:<br><br>1) Spaghetti alla Chitarra con Ragu di Crostacei ($29) - homemade chitarra pasta laced with shrimp and tossed with garlic, chilli, and extra virgin olive oil, and lemon: it&#39;s very saucy, but that&#39;s the best part, aside from the swimmingly fresh prawns and perfectly al dente pasta. So good, you&#39;ll ask for a spoon to wipe this clean off. <br><br>2) Spigola all&#39;Acqua Pazza ($36) - Neapolitan-style seabass served with cherry tomatoes, olives, and capers, in a white wine sauce: exquisite and delicate. I only wished they&#39;d drown this in more of that white wined broth, it was that outstanding.<br><br>3) Agello Arrosto con Timo e Patate ($36) - roasted lamb rack flavoured with thyme and served with new potatoes and sauteed vegetables: the husband thought it was lusciously cooked, and robust in flavour, I thought it was too full-bodied.<br><br>4) Sharing Dessert ($32): great sampler of their greatest hits. In descending order of preference, I liked the Tiramisu, Ricotta cheesecake, Biancomangiare, and Profiteroles

text: If you still recall, I have reviewed the dishes at Waterfall Cafe sometime in August. Today, I brought my sista to make a discovery on their less-known breakfast menu. Naturally, only in-house guests will pop by for a breakfast but we drove our way there intentionally.<br><br>With a third of the menu presented with egg dishes, I was coaxed into having an egg white omelette by Kelvin who succeeded in uplifting my energy level with a light touch. I would think that the egg Benedicts make a good classic morning dish for most but you could opt for a more refreshing plate with a negligible 17 calories (approx) in each absolute white. I liked the finished egg with a soft curdy interior loaded with confetti mushrooms, fresh tomato dices and a handful of baby spinach. The 2 egg whites melded to form a very consistent texture and fastened with gold trimming that crisped in each mouthful. The opaque mass is made lighter with a less noticeable seasoning. If the notion of a perfect omelette is a moist and tender yield, then this came close except for some traces of slight weeping. Not to worry about the empty spaces in your stomach, it can be easily filled with the accompanying sautéed mushroom, a few baked potato wedges, some green salads tossed in vinaigrette; along with 2 crusty toast.<br><br>For a more elegant egg dish, ask for eggs in varied Cocotte version; Chorizo, Mushroom or Roast chicken that comes with toast as well.<br><br>If you are game for a eggless morning ritual, then the Pancakes and Waffles make good options, other than Asian selection - Chinese rice congee and Nasi Lemak. Here, I am trying out Buckwheat waffles. Instead of chowing down nothing but a few traditional buttermilk pancakes, these rustic-looking girdle cake not only serves for healthier option but a new wholesome taste. As we know, buckwheat contains no gluten and so it can be quite tacky when buckwheat flour is called for in a recipe. Without ruining the dish, this old-fashioned recipe has evolved into a fashionable fare with crispier outside and a more complex texture. I fear having that intense earthy after-taste often found in the Japanese buckwheat soba, this one was more easy-going. Rather than an airy dough, the buckwheat cake makes a coarse statement with a dense texture. One may frowned at its dull appearance, but the caramelised banana and a swirl of gula melaka make it a toothsome dish. Don&#39;t pass up the opportunity to have one.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=7sNLNv5gpwr9F0eUWBbImQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/y9oN4q1t_6ph6gNVkzBD5g/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/y9oN4q1t_6ph6gNVkzBD5g/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/y9oN4q1t_6ph6gNVkzBD5g/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/y9oN4q1t_6ph6gNVkzBD5g/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/y9oN4q1t_6ph6gNVkzBD5g/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/y9oN4q1t_6ph6gNVkzBD5g/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Daniel A.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Daniel A.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=7sNLNv5gpwr9F0eUWBbImQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 73, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 11, 'eliteYear': None}
text: More reviews at <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2FDanielFoodDiary.com&amp;s=aadb67628bc71251566acb424586dbd60c6133f9a2602da0d7fce455e3a41bac" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">DanielFoodDiary.com</a><br><br>One of Singapore&#39;s top hotel, tropical greenery, poolside view, dim yellow lighting, colonial interior, comfy furniture, lovely chocolates and desserts... checked, checked, checked. <br><br>The mains consist of healthy yet creative and colourful-looking dishes inspired by Mediterranean flavours, created by Chef de Cuisine Stephane Cocu. <br><br>The Seared Sea Scallops ($24) in hazelnut crust, crushed potatoes, port win jus sets the tone right - light pan-fried, crispy on the outer crust, and fresh and moist on the inside. Easily the most memorable dish of the evening. <br><br>I had the Atlantic Cod ($38) which is served on barley risotto, an interesting take as most would have been cooked with rice. The barley gives the dish a light sweetness, and has slight foam which adds a more varied texture. Probably two can share this if both are light eaters. <br><br>Full review: <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fdanielfooddiary.com%2F2012%2F09%2F19%2Fwaterfall-cafe%2F&amp;s=6e5bc1193aa3bfaafc10a784e252e52c06f356dc57c463113bc202959f59f42d" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">danielfooddiary.com/2012…</a>

The Waterfall Cafe is part of the Shangri-La and has been very convenient. The menu has a good variety and will please most tastes. I did find it tough to find Paleo options here, but the place is pretty gluten-free friendly. The ambiance is lovely, especially on the patio in the evening overlooking the pool. The lighting is soft and the fans along with the breeze make it pretty cozy. The place is a bit pricey, but if you&#39;re staying at the hotel and looking for something convenient, Waterfall Cafe hits the spot.

Gourmet fare prepared the healthy way? Surely that has to mean that taste and flavour will be comprised, doesn&#39;t it? <br><br>Well, the Waterfall Cafe have certainly managed to work out the kinks. The slow-baked veal cheek and grilled Iberico pork chop together with Parma ham and chorizo that I had certainly made me realize that eating healthy isn&#39;t impossible, just pricey. But I have to say, it&#39;s worth every cent you spend here. Not only is the food good and healthy, you get to enjoy a pleasant balance of class and casualness that the Shangri-La is renowned for. A great place to have a first date.

text: This is a wonderful place to have a relaxing breakfast or lunch. The menu is very limited but all of the dished that we ordered were all delicious. I thoroughly enjoyed my mushroom soup and salad, and all of the dishes from my party. Definitely this western/mediterarian (spelling) food is not catered to typical Singaporean palate, but to their international hotel guests.

text: In the middle of a mall so it is quite a busy location but with ample seating so you&#39;re not waiting too long for a seat. I decided to take a break here before hitting up the supermarket downstairs.<br><br>Great place for a quick drink and bite or not so quick depending on your mood and if you want to linger around. <br><br>Highly recommend the kaya toast- iconic and must eat in Singapore.

text: I just stopped here for a quick breakfast. I really wanted to try the Kaya toast, and ended up also getting a peanut butter toast. It was perfect for my craving.<br><br>I would describe Kaya as like a sweet buttery cream. fun to try once!

text: The Mee Rebus was so good here - the noodles soaked up the curry. The toast was okay but the hot food was the standout.  I&#39;d come back for the hot food.  This is a popular place but the pastry cabinet had ants in them and most people just had a coffee and toast.  They have plenty of seating so I think that&#39;s why it&#39;s also popular.  Fast and efficient!  Good place to grab a quick bite.

text: Meh breakfast. It turns out there are a ton of other restaurants in this huge shopping complex. I loved the milk tea and the coffee here was also really delicious. I had the thick egg toast with cheese. It was basically thick toast with a fried egg and cheese on top. It wasn&#39;t bad. Other dishes were the ham and cheese toast. The were basic and mediocre at best, not something I would purposely eat. Overall an ok breakfast stop, seems pretty chain like.

text: Serve a good cup of Singapore coffee and traditional kaya toast and eggs.  A nice morning treat for a traveler passing through and wanting to experience a little local breakfast tradition.

text: Walked in to a shopping complex in Chinatown and this spot had a line outside that led to the next store so definitely had to try!<br><br>The milk tea with grass jelly was REALLY good. The Yuan Yang drink was ok, but definitely preferred the milk tea. We also ordered the thick toast with ham, egg and cheese on top (order #2) and a bun (I can&#39;t recall the name of it but it was order #4) that came with 2 soft boiled eggs. Both were really good to dip in the mixed soft boiled eggs.<br><br>Worth trying since they open early and food was a goos start.

Laksa and Mee Siam with barley tea', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Laksa and Mee Siam with barley tea'}]
text: Wandered into this place while looking for a late dinner in Chinatown our first night in Singapore.  Most of the surrounding shops in the mall were already closed, but this place was a bright beacon of light that beckoned us into its cute, pristine white cafe.<br><br>The set laksa menu for SGD 6.10 pulled us in for our first taste of authentic Singaporean food.  But alas, they only had one portion left, so we had to settle for the SGD 5.00 Mee Siam set as the second option.<br><br>Both noodle soups were creamy with a heavy taste.  The Mee Siam was quite sour with scary-looking greyish noodles that looked like squid tentacles to me.  :O<br><br>Both sets came with a refreshing barley tea.  I would say this is a nice place for a light meal or snack, and it&#39;s a chain around town, so really convenient to drop by for a visit.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=gVMKAw-byO7AFHEqRhDmnA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/nZn__Qr2crxcatFZjRrH5w/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/nZn__Qr2crxcatFZjRrH5w/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/nZn__Qr2crxcatFZjRrH5w/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/nZn__Qr2crxcatFZjRrH5w/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/nZn__Qr2crxcatFZjRrH5w/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/nZn__Qr2crxcatFZjRrH5w/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Darrell R.', 'displayLocation': 'Yadkinville, NC', 'altText': 'Darrell R.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=gVMKAw-byO7AFHEqRhDmnA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 28, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 3, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Loved this place. If it weren&#39;t 9,000 miles away I would go again!

Cutest little place which is great for breakfast or a snack located in a small mall. I ordered the Toast with Kaya, eggs, and Milo Dinosaur drink. So my Toast with Kaya was basically toast with butter...yummy toast &amp; butter I might add. My eggs were hard boiled still in shell and very, very runny like raw which is they way they eat them, I tired to but just could not. My dinosaur drink was a cold overly chocolate kind of almost frozen milk drink with powdery kind of chocolate shavings on top and so amazingly good I had a few though out my stay in Singapore. <br>My aunt had Toast with Floss which was meat very finely shredded and I tried it and it was good too. She liked it as well and ordered it again later again when we went there.<br><br>I miss this place and can&#39;t wait to go back.

text: Someone recommended that I should try Toast Box but was a little disappointed. Service was rather slow and some table does not have black sauce and pepper. When I asked the staff, they just ask me to grab from table which is occupied by customers.<br><br>The toast is 0 stars and not even close to YaKun kaya. They have more choices for meal and food but I did not tried. The half boil egg was ok and coffee was 2 stars. I suggest that you skip this place and go for original Yakun. Also, the store at Bugis is outdoor and no AC.

Not a bad option if you are looking for an indoor place to escape the Singapore heat &amp; have a quick meal. You can certainly get better kaya toast in one of the other hawker centers nearby though, so be aware.

text: Located just 5 minutes sheltered walk from Commonwealth MRT is The Milky Way Homemade Ice Cream and Coffee. You may have remembered Aw&#39;s Signature Noodles where Terence served up delicious lard-filled noodle bowls in a hawker centre nearby. He has since taken over this cafe to serve his signature noodles along with ice cream, waffles, coffee in a cosy air-conditioned cafe!<br><br>Signature Noodle $5.80 is a bowl of soup filled with spinach, pork balls, minced pork, fish dumplings, egg dip in pork broth, served with your choice of noodles such as Rice, Bee Hoon, Kway Teow or the Yellow Noodle.<br><br>So for each of the mains you order like the Signature Noodles $5.80 or Braised Pork $5.80, you can pick this yellow noodles which is my personal favourite. I generally don&#39;t like yellow noodles, but for some magical reason I love the noodles here, could be the way they cook the consistency and texture of the noodles isn&#39;t too clumpy and the noodles is able to absorb the sauces. EVERYTHING WITH LARD tastes good, so same here for the yellow noodles! Happy to see that Terence has carried over the tradition.<br><br>Scissors Cut Rice $5.80 Yummy curry chicken that is family friendly, super tender, the chicken meat falls right off the bones, braised pork, quail eggs and lemak curry sauce drenched rice and cabbage. Very hearty dish for anyone who needs a filling meal with a variety of ingredients!<br><br>Freshly Made Full Waffles @ $7.80, Half Waffle @ $5.<br><br>The waffles here are some of the best I&#39;ve had in SINGAPORE! Extremely crisp on the exterior, light and fluffy on the inside, with a nice buttermilk aroma.<br><br>The colour of &#34;Smurf&#34; caught my eye, it was indeed a very pretty looking blue! With ingredients sourced from Italy, The Milky Cafe ensures that their ice cream is made with love and quality  ingredients! <br><br>The Royal MSW Durian was damn shiok, you can literally taste the real durian you&#39;re eating as you enjoy your ice cream. The pistachio also had a lightly nutty taste that lingered which I enjoyed!<br><br>Overall : I love all their lard-filled noodles, especially their yellow noodles. Their ice creams are so worth the calories. Not to mention, Best Waffles in Singapore!<br><br>Other notable ice cream flavours are Rocher *Highly Recommended*, Cookies &amp; Cream, Madagascar Vanilla, Irresistible Triple Chocolate!

text: Came here on a Saturday night around 9pm. Was pretty crowded and it took awhile before tables for 7 was set up at one of the corners of the store. Most of the seating arrangements are indoors but there are a few tables and chairs on the outside of the storefront.<br><br>Tried sampling a few flavors of the handmade ice creams - Straciatella, strawberry cheesecake, smurf and matcha. Decided to get a scoop of matcha as it was pretty addictive after it melted in the mouth. This is one of the best matcha ice creams I&#39;ve tasted so far. Tasted more like the authentic matcha beverages. It is light in taste but had lingering impact just after a small bite. Some of my friends tried the salted caramel and rum and raisin.<br><br>The space was pretty compact. Not so suitable for more than 10 people as you might need to wait for awhile before they connect the tables together. The staffs are pretty friendly and they don&#39;t mind letting us try the different flavors they had on that day. <br><br>Wanted to try the waffles too - in fact you can tell them how you want it made (crispy or softer). The homemade ice creams were definitely delicious. Will be back for more waffles and gelato soon :)

text: Nice setting and service. Probably the biggest portion I have ever received just for sampling a flavour. My friend had the eye-catching blue-coloured smurf flavour and I had the nutty pistachio flavour. Half a waffle on its own costs $5 and a full waffle costs $8.80. When we ordered 2 half waffles, the waitress offered to let us split the full waffle in two plates instead. Good job in helping customers save money! The waffle was crunchy but not spectacular. Everything else though adds points and I recommend dropping by this charming place.

text: We got here a little before they opened and there was already someone else waiting. From what we&#39;ve seen there can be some pretty long lines! <br><br>Luckily we were second, however it still took a while for our drink to come out. <br><br>Best bubble tea ever though, worth the wait!

Pearl milk tea - 50% sweet', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Pearl milk tea - 50% sweet'}]
text: What would I do without boba... I don&#39;t know.  Not live?  Hahaha, just kidding.  Even in Singapore, I had to have my weekly dose of bobalyfe!  Was recommended to come here by some of the locals, and although a chain, it did not disappoint!  <br><br>I would warn that you get less sweet (especially if you don&#39;t have a sweet tooth, and even if you have a minor one, I&#39;d still recommend less sweet).  There&#39;s something about the people in Asia, but their love for sweets far exceeds mine.  According the the locals, their current 70% sweet used to be the original 100% sweet... meaning, they diversified their sweet scale to accommodate a larger spectrum of less sweet and more sweet.  If I remember correctly, it ranged from 0% to 120%.  O_O  I got 50% sweet and still found it a tad bit sweeter than I like, but definitely anything over that and I would&#39;ve been unhappy with my drink.  I had the plain milk tea with boba and found a well balanced drink and plenty of boba!  I didn&#39;t get a chance to try the grass jelly but I hear that&#39;s quite popular as well.<br><br>If you&#39;re in Singapore, give it a try!  I had to, it was #milkteasunday.

Passion Fruit Green Tea', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Passion Fruit Green Tea'}]
text: This Koi Cafe is located on the 1st floor of Bugis Plus and they&#39;re just an outdoor counter. We were hoping to relax and rest for a bit after walking around, but there&#39;s no seating area at this location. <br><br>I got the passion fruit green tea here and I thought the tea itself tasted slightly watered down. It was nice that there were real bits of passion fruit inside though!

text: better than gong cha! To taste is to believe. Can&#39;t be in SG and not queue at koi. Their tea is very flavorful, the boba not hard nor half cooked.  I like the lemon black tea and the milk tea variants.

I love Koi! It&#39;s my favorite tea place. I always get the milk tea, no sugar and no toppings, for a healthy treat. The milk always tastes so fresh and even though I don&#39;t add sugar it somehow manages to taste slightly sweet. Please open a location in DC!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/lv4UVdJqFNIj2zZ_fD2QcQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/koi-cafe-singapore-2?reviewid=kVxzf3QkVjc66Mo5OfmTeA&select=lv4UVdJqFNIj2zZ_fD2QcQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Koi Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Milk tea with bubbles', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Milk tea with bubbles'}]
text: Regular and large sizes available. The pearls are fresh and have a mild chew. You can get varying degrees of sweetness. I liked the milk tea barely sweet and also the passion fruit green tea. Every time I went they had a queue so be ready to wait for just a few minutes.

text: The golden pearls don&#39;t taste different than other pearls, but it makes Koi unique. The tea itself was very good --not too milky and the texture and consistency of the pearls was spot on! <br><br>Would definitely come back here when I&#39;m in Singapore again!

text: I first bought my koi tea drink  in Phnom Penh at the mall.  Since then, I just can&#39;t forget the flavor. Super delicious! Oolong milk tea with grass jelly. Loved it. The grass jelly was super fresh and the milk and the tea was just perfect combination. I can&#39;t wait till it franchise to USA.
Love, love love the bubble tea here and so do many others as the line is always long.  They have every type of tea you can imagine.  Great location.

Really good milk tea right outside Bugis +.<br><br>Pro: They offer a large size while a lot of the Gong Cha&#39;s in the area do not.<br>Con: There&#39;s no seating unless you want to be a dick at sit at the MCD tables.<br><br>Warning: &#34;golden bubble tea&#34; is not made from a magical golden tea. It refers to normal tea and their golden colored pearls.  The lady said they taste like caramel but I couldn&#39;t really see that.

Very long line, I tried the regular milk tea with 25% sweetness. Nice milk tea flavor, and the lower sugar level kept it from being cloyingly sweet. <br><br>For $2.90 you get a decently sized milk tea. I would come again to try other flavors.

text: I stopped by to try the bubble tea of this place for some Singaporean friends told me not to miss their bubble tea when in Singapore. The taste was regular, can&#39;t say it&#39;s better than Gong Cha or other bubble tea places. But this Koi Cafe was satisfying my thirst that afternoon. Don&#39;t mind to get another big glass of their bubble tea again next time I&#39;m there.

text: Review is for milk tea with pearls- this is my my new favorite place!!!! I have tried a few other places and the pearls have a great texture and the tea is well balanced! ^_^

text: I can still remember the first time I tried Koi bubble tea! It was so different from the usual ones you can get around the neighbourhood. The tea tasted so smooth and the pearls were really &#39;Q&#39; and chewy. Koi began with only one outlet at Toa Payoh a few years ago, and now there are several outlets and the one at Bugis+ is definitely one of the most popular ones.<br><br>But the question is, is it worth the queue? The queue at Bugis+ outlet is almost always very long. The wait can be about 10-15min. To be honest, this isn&#39;t a very long wait for a delicious drink that you can indulge in once in a while, but what I am most disappointed with is the service at this outlet. My friends and I had bad experiences at this outlet. The aunties at the counter are pretty hostile and arrogant. There was once my friend made a minor mistake in ordering because she mixed up the name of the drink and sugar level with the other one offered by another popular bubble tea chain, and was given condescending remarks. Even though the drink at Koi is delicious, such bad service is unacceptable. Avoid this outlet!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/k5uBUv9tny3vyXQvH3pTaQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/koi-cafe-singapore-2?reviewid=Im9zZZP5nmheLT-YTsk3Bg&select=k5uBUv9tny3vyXQvH3pTaQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Koi Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: The queues are long but the drinks are &#39;meh&#39;. I&#39;ve drank KOI a number of times but I honestly dont know what the fuss is all about. I cant put a finger on why there are so many snaking queues around and why people bother to stand in line for so long.<br><br>Maybe its something about the pearls are something I havent ordered before but as far as I know, its not my favourite bubble tea outlet. Maybe the queues put me off abit but that&#39;s just how it is i guess. <br><br>The longer the queue, the higher your expectations are of the drink/food.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=TsbkNTS0_AzCaRbhhe4C5A', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/hZG8vzSMCExjKy01q2OBIg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/hZG8vzSMCExjKy01q2OBIg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/hZG8vzSMCExjKy01q2OBIg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/hZG8vzSMCExjKy01q2OBIg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/hZG8vzSMCExjKy01q2OBIg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/hZG8vzSMCExjKy01q2OBIg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Lindsay N.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Lindsay N.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=TsbkNTS0_AzCaRbhhe4C5A', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 5, 'photoCount': 3, 'reviewCount': 30, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Koi, I miss you!!! I haven&#39;t found any Boba tea in SF that can compare D:<br><br>Koi is amazing. The have a huge selection of teas, their boba is perfect consistency and taste, and they let you adjust the percentage of sweetness you would like in your drink. I must&#39;ve subsisted mainly off of teh tarik, roti prata, kaya toast, and Koi milk tea the whole time I was in Singapore.

This Koi cafe is located at the first level of Bugis + (its new name) just next to Macdonald&#39;s, and it faces the main road so not easy to miss it. I particularly like this outlet as although sometimes the queue can be pretty long, like all other koi outlets who put service as their priority, the staff would come out of the counter to take orders. <br><br>Even if the staff doesn&#39;t do that, the queue still manages to clear quite fast and customers just have to wait a maximum of 10minutes or less to get a thirst quenching drink. I have been to other outlets and the queue is long too but the waiting time can go up to 20-30 minutes which is madness. <br><br>I like their variety of drinks and coffees, and particularly the bubble milk tea which is the most basic drink there. The tea just tastes so natural and once you try the tea from this stall you wouldn&#39;t want to buy any other bubble tea from other stall cause they just don&#39;t taste that good anymore. The yakult green tea and black tea macchiato are also must tries.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=L7zt8jZEE1Xj3ZT2fgO79w', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/J-zbhKy1MLJDWaZBiXAPrw/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/J-zbhKy1MLJDWaZBiXAPrw/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/J-zbhKy1MLJDWaZBiXAPrw/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/J-zbhKy1MLJDWaZBiXAPrw/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/J-zbhKy1MLJDWaZBiXAPrw/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/J-zbhKy1MLJDWaZBiXAPrw/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Kathryn B.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Kathryn B.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=L7zt8jZEE1Xj3ZT2fgO79w', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 242, 'photoCount': 41, 'reviewCount': 350, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Koi Café is my favorite bubble tea spot in Singapore. When I first had bubble tea in the states it was just too weird and popular for me to enjoy.  However, now that I am at home in Asia bubble tea seems perfectly natural and downright delicious.  I alternate between straight up milk tea and the other awesome flavored teas at Koi.  The line is absolutely horrific in length so make sure you plan ahead.  The Bugis+ location offers delivery to your office.

5 stars for the coffee, 3 stars for the food. The coffee here is exceptional. I tried the raspberry candy coffee, which surprisingly had the flavor of raspberry. I&#39;ve never had anything quite like it.<br><br>The baked egg was their supposed &#34;signature&#34; and was pretty tasty, but not something I&#39;d go out of my way for. It came with salmon and raw kale. If they had baked or fried the kale, that might have tied everything together.<br><br>Love that they provide the wifi password right at the cash register. That&#39;s what a good internet cafe should be like. The ambience was quite adorable with a cozy, cottage-like feel. Since you order first, it&#39;s easy to split the bill with a big group. Prices were also quite reasonable, so no need to break the bank for brunch. If you arrive before noon, there&#39;ll be plenty of seats on the two floors.

text: This is another one of those coffee shops, but I really didn&#39;t like it all that much. The tea was okay, but the service wasn&#39;t really all that crash hot. Mind you, it was one of those places that I was specifically looking for, namely because the name sounded pretty cool and I was expecting a London coffee shop experience. Well, a part of me felt that they tried, but it really didn&#39;t work all that well. The other thing was that it was pretty difficult to find the sugar, and the upstairs area was pretty ordinary as well. In the end, its not really a place I&#39;d be hurrying back to any time soon.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hr29Efa2KtxkIAPo85EmsA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/drury-lane-singapore?reviewid=MtYMCRsFLyM9unYzJmro9Q&select=hr29Efa2KtxkIAPo85EmsA', 'altText': 'Photo of Drury Lane - Singapore, Singapore. Itty bitty breakfast. So little avo. Very disappointing.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Itty bitty breakfast. So little avo. Very disappointing.'}]
text: Came for breakfast two days in a row. <br><br>First visit: Sunday breakfast/ brunch, ordered eggs royal and was pleased. Happy to return the next day as I was going to be in the same area. <br><br>Second visit: Monday morning at around 9am. Ordered one of the breakfast sets, toast with avocado and coffee. This was incredibly disappointing. The toast, while good quality, was tiny. And the worst bit, the portion of avocado was unacceptably small. Not even 1/8 of an avocado was provided - just three and a half (barely) Super thin tiny slivers of avo which I had to strategically spread out in order to get some in each bite. After eating I felt like I hadn&#39;t even had breakfast. Really a shame they scrimp on this and ruin an otherwise great potential breakfast option. <br><br>Would have been 5 stars but after my breakfast I cannot rate this cafe so highly.

text: Honestly, Drury Lane isn&#39;t particularly bad. It just isn&#39;t great. Everything is sorta...average-ish. <br><br>Let&#39;s start. First of all, it&#39;s located in an old shophouse which generally is fun cos it adds to the ambience. However, methinks they never changed the electrical wirings because the first time I went, power tripped SIX times during my meal. In fact, the dishes were so underwhelming I thought I would never return. <br><br>I only went back as a friend wanted to try. <br><br>This time, I had a salted egg prawn eggs Benedict. Uneven dish. Prawns? YUMS. Poached eggs&#39; yolks were sufficiently runny. But serving it on a slice of white bread?? Come on! And the salted egg could be saltier. <br><br>My friends ordered a Big Breakfast. Honestly, the presentation was terrible. See photo attached. I think it was sufficiently yummy cos my friends finished it?<br><br>Our dessert - turkey bacon pancakes - was the best. Pancakes were sufficiently fluffy yet slightly dense. Turkey bacon was nothing to scream about. And I think I enjoyed it simply because there was maple syrup. <br><br>Its cheaper price point means they attract Uni students. Honestly, if you can afford a more expensive meal, please go there. <br><br>Overall, I don&#39;t hate this place. I just think...it is very blah. Servers aren&#39;t too friendly and importantly, the food is very uneven in terms of taste and quality. <br><br>So. There are better cafes in the vicinity. Try Souper Sarnies.

text: The coffee is ok, the fruit juices are good but I went there because it was supposed to be a place favourable for laptop use as they have powerplugs and free wifi. Well... It wasn&#39;t the best idea I&#39;ve had. The seats are not really comfy and the music was a bit too noisy for me. <br><br>However I must admit that they have some breakfast-y items which smells really good from the open kitchen and the service is one of the best I have experiment in Singapore so far! It&#39;s worth a 3,5***.

text: Nothing Dreary &#39;bout Drury Lane <br><br>Located across the road from Singapore&#39;s famous wedding street, Drury Lane is a cozy little cafe offering a range of classic dishes along with some innovative creations. <br><br>I&#39;ve heard of this place for months but was never able to get myself free to try it.... Until now.<br><br>I&#39;ve read the mixed reviews for this place but still decided to give it a chance. Innocent until proven guilty right? <br><br>It was a really scorching day so for one, we were just happy that the air-conditioning was working very well.  <br>I&#39;ve been to a few of the wedding shops across the street (as a best-men and not as a groom) and I know how temperamental some of these old converted buildings can get, trapping heat in the strangest of places. <br><br>Not too much of a smell going on as there was barely anyone when we came. <br>Staff were nice and friendly, offering a menu the second we stepped in. Only thing was, I wished she stood in front of the counter instead of behind it. More pleasant to the eye and easier for her too, not requiring to stretch across the counter to provide me a menu. <br><br>Decided not to go into the many details of their coffee today but concentrate more on the food. <br><br>Steak Sandwich<br>One word. Awesome! Beef was done medium rare and was really juicy and tender, cheese was strong enough to add to the saltiness of the dish while the onions (and I don&#39;t normally like raw onions) added a greater depth to the dish, giving it a bit of pungentness and cutting the richness making it more even and enjoyable. <br>And at $8.00, it was worth every cent! Although I would have loved the option of a fried egg. What&#39;s better than eggs and streak right? <br><br>Salted Egg Yolk Eggs Benedict<br>Now this was a pleasant surprise. Sitting on top of steamed buns (like those used it stewed pork buns or kong ba bao), and layered with vege, prawns, poached eggs and finally, a salted egg yolk sauce, this dish was true east meets west. The prawns were well seasoned and not over cooked, the eggs were perfectly runny and the salted egg added such a nice dimension to the dish that we were hoping we could have asked for more sauce! <br><br>A wonderful take on an otherwise overdone and over promoted Eggs Benedict. <br><br>Mandarin orange and pineapple cake <br>And what better way to end the meal (we actually started the meal with this instead, but let&#39;s pretend we ended with it since it&#39;s a dessert) than with a generous slice of mandarin orange and pineapple cake. <br>At a glance, it looked like a regular carrot cake with cream cheese topping but one bite would bring all the festivities and firecrackers of Chinese New Year bursting in your mouth! The mandarin orange is the star of the cake, with the slight acidity coming through. The pineapple (which was more of a pineapple tart paste than the fruit) adds a good amount of sweetness and tartness to the cake, elevating the flavours of the mandarin. A harmonious blend to welcome in the new year! <br><br>Iced Chocolate. <br>Now THIS is what a chocolate milk / ice chocolate should taste like. Unlike the bottled one from my previous post, this was a pretty good ice chocolate (my favourite still goes to the frozen chocolate drink from the now closed au Chocolat at Marina Bay Sands).<br><br>Bottom line? Drury Lane knows what they&#39;re doing and on my next trip, I&#39;ll try their much raved coffees and Beef Ribs which I heard were amazing. <br><br>Now to close my eyes and imagine that succulent steak sandwich.

text: Tasty and reasonably priced food. I had the salted egg benedict which was a nice combination of egg, English muffin, kale and prawns. The salted egg&#39;s flavour and portion were just right. The portable air conditioner next to our table had a thick layer of dust and the towel-like table cloth had stains. Luckily hygiene of the food was better. Service was good and they accept credit cards which was a nice surprise.

text: My family and I came to this modern little cafe after reading on Ho Ching&#39;s list of 15 must eats in Singapore that the salted egg prawn eggs benedict at Drury Lane was to die for. We looked forward to this weekend brunch all week, and sadly, were quite disappointed.<br><br>THE DRINKS<br>I had an iced white, which was very cute and tasted nice. Had a good amount of caffeine, but not too much.<br><br>THE FOOD - fusion-esque, but missing the synergy to make it work<br>We were excited to try some awesome-sounding fusion dishes, but none of them hit the mark. Fusion is hard - it sounds exciting, but often the mix of different cultures, tastes, and techniques makes the food lose the appealing factors from its constituent bases. I think that&#39;s what happened here. We tried the chili crab pasta with kale, topped with a poached egg. This was ok - the chili crab was a little sweet with the spaghetti. Spaghetti texture was nice, not too mushy. We also had the kale salad with red onions, avocado, cherry tomatoes, and quinoa, with a lemon vinaigrette. This was probably our favorite dish of the ones we tried, as it was the least fusion-y and most basic. The flavors were good and the ingredients were fresh enough. Finally, the infamous salted egg prawns eggs benedict served on a Chinese bao. This just was trying too hard. The bao didnt have the crunch that a traditional english muffin does, and therefore lacked texture to compliment the poached egg. The prawn and salted egg tastes were good, but got lost amongst the large bao and the poached egg. Overall, it was a pricy and unimpressive meal.<br><br>THE WIFI<br>Spotty at best.

text: Just a couple of days old and yet already geared with great vibes/coffee/food. <br><br>Their coffee beans are from Toby&#39;s Estate but with a special customized blend and a few single origin for the brew bar. I had a brew coffee which was slightly too dark for my liking but had a quiet toffee finish. The current blend is no 94 which has a strawberry finish. <br><br>Only had a chance to grab a banana bread to go and was greeted with a sweet surprise of espresso butter. There is a wide range of muffins/sandwiches. <br><br>The space is unique and chill. I like the extra space upstairs! Plus, there is free wifi, so I can definitely see a crowd coming here to work/study. The location is very convenient. A five minute walk (or less) from the MRT. Owners are very friendly and passionate about coffee &amp; food. Add this place to your list pronto! <br><br>More next time.

Went back again and it was equally awesome. <br><br>Food was amazing - tried the Yogurt Granola thingy this time... I like my yogurt on the sour side, and they delivered.The berry compote was perfectionnnn.<br><br>Paired that with hot chocolate... their hot chocolate comes in blocks of chocolate that they melt apparently ( I asked ) and HOMYGAWD it was amazeballssssssssss.<br><br>Also, the service has been consistently ...comfortable. and I&#39;m really fussy so trust me.  :)

text: It&#39;s very rare that I feel compelled to write a review, particularly a bad one. I came to Drury Lane after reading a well-known blogger that listed it as one of the best brunch places in Singapore. To say that I was disappointed was an understatement. <br><br>First the environment and ambience. Others have commented on the ground floor being stuffy. Upstairs was equally bad. There was no air conditioner, just a few fans and on a hot day like today, it was almost suffocating. I also found the place very dirty. While some have described this place as &#34;chilled&#34; and &#34;laid back&#34;, I&#39;d say it lacks any soul. <br><br>I ordered an iced white and an salted egg shrimp eggs benedict. The coffee was good but I&#39;m not sure how some could describe the eggs benedict as &#34;to die for&#34;! I could barely taste the salted egg. The shrimp still had shells on their tails but you wouldn&#39;t know since they were smothered in the super bland salted egg &#34;sauce&#34;. The whole dish was horrible. <br><br>Some have commented on bad service. I actually didn&#39;t found the service ok. The only comment is I could barely hear the lady who took my order who seemed like she was whispering to a mouse.

text: A new little coffee joint I was hoping to love! Alas, my heart remains with Group Therapy though I wouldn&#39;t mind being a frequent visitor of Drury Lane! I was told this place has a British vibe...not sure what that means since I&#39;ve never been to the Motherland. The store is rather deep and there&#39;s also seating upstairs on the 2nd floor.<br><br>Food wise, Drury Lane specializes in baked eggs: tomatoes and beans baked with an egg on top. Then, topped with salmon, chicken, or whatever else is preferred. I thought the baked egg was meh...too bland for my liking and needed lots of salt and pepper.<br><br>Service was excellent! A large party came before my small party of three, and to thank us for waiting 20 additional minutes, they gave us a carrot cake on the house! I&#39;m not a fan of carrot cakes, but this one came with earl gray frosting!!! Def. worth the wait! Walnuts were also baked into the batter...Yum!<br><br>I&#39;ll be back for the decor and earl gray frosting with carrot cake!

I&#39;ve been going to Drury Lane rather regularly, and while I usually sit upstairs I thought I would choose a high-top on the ground level this time &#39;round right next to the kitchen - and I&#39;m glad I did!<br><br>They microwave 95% of their menu items! I kid you not!!<br><br>Poached eggs, banana bread, baked beans... you name it, it&#39;s being zapped and you are eating nutrition-less plastic food filled with radiation.<br><br>I am amazed that in this day in age kitchens are still being equipped with microwave. Have we not learnt anything over the past 40 years?<br><br>You will never see me venture into Drury Lane again - ever.

I&#39;m with Timothy S - what could have been a really wonderful first impression (a wall showcasing bags of hard-to-find speciality coffee they&#39;ve served? This is going to be damn good!) was quickly squashed not by the delicious smell of freshly pulled espresso, but by a rather shocking pungent smell that engulfed the entire downstairs area. I have no doubt whatever they were cooking up was delicious, but I wasn&#39;t ready to smack head first into an olfactory brick wall when all I really wanted was a long black and a place to relax for a bit.<br><br>Once I found the back staircase leading to an upstairs seating section (and that there was a fast, free internet connection showing up on my list) I was set. And the coffee was delicious.

This is the best place in Singapore for a traveller to sit down, have good quality coffee, and get some work done . The staff is the friendliest we&#39;ve encountered during our entire time here. The lead barista has a great singing voice and was covering Neyo at closing time. They generously poured us a giant pitcher of water when we came in with our luggage, dying of thirst. Two floors, lots of seats, chill music, plugs, and fast internet. Come here and you will be taken care of. One last thing -- do you know the muffin man?

text: i love this place!<br><br>named after the famed street in london, it&#39;s cute, small, charming cafe located in the pretty hipster tanjong pagar area. been there 4 times, so far, and have never been disappointed. i quite like the upstairs, which has a cool courtyard and a really nice vibe. it also has a long communal table which can accommodate bigger groups of up to say, 8 people. they take reservations, which can be a boon if you don&#39;t want to spend your weekends waiting endless for a table at your favorite no-reservation brunch spot. <br><br>the coffee was decent ($4.50 for a long black), but the bunch didn&#39;t really blow me away. they do their own homemade baked beans, which their pair with most their egg dishes ($10-$14), but i found it way too sweet and wish they&#39;d gone with some good old-fashioned heinz. i&#39;d recommend sticking to the sandwiches, which were good and noticeably cheaper ($8).    <br><br>the real winner, for me, were the desserts. the chocolate tart ($4) was delicious and so were the &#34;pay as you wish&#34; muffins. yes, free muffins! though, i think most of us would be obliged to give something (...or not). anyway, tried the peanut butter one, which was divine. overall, if you&#39;re looking for a chill place for coffee/desserts and don&#39;t have high expectations for mains, definitely check it out.

text: perhaps one of the loveliest of the hipster cafes I&#39;ve been to in singapore - it joins the lonely department of caffeine in that estimation - really good food, and friend-certified coffee near chinatown.<br><br>well worth a visit, and repeats at that.<br><br>it was packed on a saturday afternoon, as most these places are, but we scored a seat on the lovely wooden crate of a table outside - brilliant for photography, and a good way to escape the rather stuffy non-ventilation indoors.<br><br>the caramel chocolate tart was a lovely yin-yang type confection of buttery crust and flowy filling, and my muesli parfait a small portion (with similarly small price) of lovely oats in thick, sour yogurt and a swirl of berry compote. I really don&#39;t appreciate coffee much, but my javaholic friends gave this place the thumbs up - and so I pass on their recommendation.<br><br>it&#39;s a lovely space, manned by lovely people - service is a tad slow on account of their crowdedness, but it&#39;s sincere, and the food is both reasonably-priced and tasty. <br><br>a shiner in its class.

Do not be deceived by the crowded 1st level, i was deterred once but decided head on back to check them out. The cafe spans 2 storeys so head on upstairs to escape the oily food smells as cooking and brewing are all done in that little space. Oh but do note that you gotta come down to place your orders still. <br><br>It was a terribly hot day and we headed up to level 2 as W had already gotten us a reservation. I was hoping for a cool reprieve from the crazy heat but there was none. The AC was super weak and hardly cooled the heated 2nd storey of the shophouse. It was obvious that they have issues with the power rating as well because we had 2 blackouts in the short span of an hour.<br><br>Well brunch was meant to be a birthday gathering for Cliff and i felt so bad for suggesting Drury at that point. It was also impossible to hear each other because the acoustics were terrible. Throw in 20 other people and it&#39;s just deafening. Not a good place for a date certainly.<br><br>So i had the Iced Mocha because it was simply too hot to have a hot drink. The drink was pretty good imo with melted chocolate instead of bottled syrup and it didn&#39;t overpower the mellow coffee. <br><br>We had one of the specials which is the Garlic toast with sausage patties, sauteed mushrooms, spinach and truffle scrambled eggs ($18). This was the best savory dish out of the lot due to the garlic spread i guess. Scrambled eggs were too runny in my opinion and that sausage patty was just a joke with its bland flavor and dry nature. Eeks. For $18, it&#39;s not quite worth it. I&#39;ve just had the pulled duck with apricot croissant at Symmetry and it was way better than this at the same price.<br><br>The sandwiches are at least decently priced at about $8 ish. The Steak and Cheese Sandwich was supposed to be awesome but they didn&#39;t have that when we visited. The Smoked Salmon and Mushroom alternative were just alright.<br><br>DO NOT EAT the Sausage Baked Eggs ($12) with spinach, homemade baked beans and cheese. We saw that familiar cardboardish sausage patty. Well this pot of food is terribly bland and pedestrian. I&#39;m sure i make better stuff than this. I thought the baked beans were more canned than homemade though.  <br>Maybe try the Cloud 9.4 which is bacon infused pancakes with honey if you please.<br><br>Well, would i go back to Drury Lane? Not for the food certainly. But the desserts were quite divine. Not to sure about the &#39;Pay as you wish&#39; muffins but the Banana Bread with Espresso Butter ($2.50) had W and i takeaway a portion each.<br><br>The moist bread with chunks of banana was naturally sweetened and i&#39;m glad they didn&#39;t add more sugar. The espresso butter wasn&#39;t that good because it was oily (not the good kinda butter way) and lacked espresso flavor.<br>The Carrot cake was also one of the best i&#39;ve had as well. It&#39;s of medium density but very well flavored with spice. We liked that there wasn&#39;t too much cream cheese because they didn&#39;t ice the sides but those between the layers were just sufficient for the added flavors and moisture.<br><br>Verdict of Drury Lane- I may drop by again for the sweets and a quick drink but certainly not for the food.

text: A new little coffee joint I was hoping to love! Alas, my heart remains with Group Therapy though I wouldn&#39;t mind being a frequent visitor of Drury Lane! I was told this place has a British vibe...not sure what that means since I&#39;ve never been to the Motherland. The store is rather deep and there&#39;s also seating upstairs on the 2nd floor.<br><br>Food wise, Drury Lane specializes in baked eggs: tomatoes and beans baked with an egg on top. Then, topped with salmon, chicken, or whatever else is preferred. I thought the baked egg was meh...too bland for my liking and needed lots of salt and pepper.<br><br>Service was excellent! A large party came before my small party of three, and to thank us for waiting 20 additional minutes, they gave us a carrot cake on the house! I&#39;m not a fan of carrot cakes, but this one came with earl gray frosting!!! Def. worth the wait! Walnuts were also baked into the batter...Yum!<br><br>I&#39;ll be back for the decor and earl gray frosting with carrot cake!

Was not super impressed with the espresso on offer, which I understand is roasted especially for the cafe by Toby&#39;s Estate. They had some interesting beans from Mecca Espresso in Sydney available on filter which I didn&#39;t have a chance to try. Maybe that would be better.<br><br>The big brekkie was better, although not mind-blowing. Eggs were well-scrambled, bread was good quality but could&#39;ve done with some toasting, sausage was rather tasteless and baked beans were smothered in so much tomato sauce that few actual legumes could be found in the mushy mix.<br><br>Given the increasing competitiveness among new cafe openings in Singapore, I see little reason to return.<br><br>And by the way, the downstairs seating is all stools with no back support. They lose a point for this from me. But there is free wifi.

a really not bad coffee in the tanjong pagar neighbourhood.<br>its a big competition for drury lane, as d.o.c , the plain, group therapy its all nearby.<br>and dont forget about kiasu espresso in am 100.<br>but i like the fact that they serves food as well as some cakes and they open v early.<br>its really good for me to have a cuppa aft my yoga/gym class in morning before heading out to office.<br>good job guys !

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Uo1XcsUzGKw2ZnAvji-Ssw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/drury-lane-singapore?reviewid=hAeWmuQ5M9xqNjEMYbp_JQ&select=Uo1XcsUzGKw2ZnAvji-Ssw', 'altText': 'Photo of Drury Lane - Singapore, Singapore. this is the spirit!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'this is the spirit!'}]
text: Just a couple of days old and yet already geared with great vibes/coffee/food. <br><br>Their coffee beans are from Toby&#39;s Estate but with a special customized blend and a few single origin for the brew bar. I had a brew coffee which was slightly too dark for my liking but had a quiet toffee finish. The current blend is no 94 which has a strawberry finish. <br><br>Only had a chance to grab a banana bread to go and was greeted with a sweet surprise of espresso butter. There is a wide range of muffins/sandwiches. <br><br>The space is unique and chill. I like the extra space upstairs! Plus, there is free wifi, so I can definitely see a crowd coming here to work/study. The location is very convenient. A five minute walk (or less) from the MRT. Owners are very friendly and passionate about coffee &amp; food. Add this place to your list pronto! <br><br>More next time.

Cappuccino at its finest', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Cappuccino at its finest'}]
text: I&#39;m very fond of Baker &amp; Cook since my arrival in Singapore and it is a short walk from our residence.<br><br>They do perfect cappuccino with diligent consistency.<br><br>I&#39;ve also tried their smashed avocado on toasts which was a delight.

October 2018<br><br>Soy latte - 4 stars<br>Still good thankfully!<br><br>French toast ($18) - 1 star<br>The toast was burnt and wasn&#39;t sweet at all (good or bad depending on your taste). The lemon curd and mascarpone were too dense and seemed to come straight out of a jar/tub. An unimpressive overpriced dish.<br><br>=============================<br><br>2017<br><br>Pear and almond slice ($6.20) - 3 stars<br>Bit too sweet and the crumbly bits, well, crumble.<br><br>Hot chocolate - 2 stars<br>Too sweet. Tastes like it&#39;s from a Swiss Miss packet.<br><br>Soy latte - 4 stars<br><br>Pancakes ($17) - 3.75 stars<br>The pancakes themselves aren&#39;t great - they&#39;re a bit too dense and gummy unlike the fluffy Clinton St ones. But they more than make up for it with their incredible toppings! Caramelized bananas, apples, Greek yogurt, toasted almonds and toffee! Absolutely divine and puts the Clinton St ones to shame (I don&#39;t like the greasy maple butter they come with and there just aren&#39;t enough of the berries they come with). The best part is that the toffee isn&#39;t sickly sweet. I&#39;d have to get a large cappuccino instead of the regular to wash this down the next time.<br><br>Scrambled eggs ($14) - 1 star<br>Overpriced, and there were shells in the eggs! Unacceptable really.<br><br>Ambience - 4 stars<br>They have wifi. Plus I love how it opens at 6.30am.

text: Baker &amp; Cook is one of my favorite bakeries so far. Was around the Greenwood area and passed by this place so decided to give it a try during tea time.<br><br>What &#34;sparkled&#34; me at my first look was the Chocolate Raspberry Cupcake. And while looking for other baked goods, chanced upon Raspberry macaroon. I then flipped the menu to get myself a beverage as well and ended up with Very Berry smoothie. Can find out more here: <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bakerandcook.biz%2Fproducts.htm&amp;s=430a80889a5cff7eacdcc39b67a0b72fbe76b5d853ff4eb76056f090f3e408fd" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">bakerandcook.biz/product…</a> (list not fully updated - baked goods changed according to its availabilities).<br><br>First off, ate the macaroon. It has a crunchy outer layer and the jam was not too sweet. Took 3 bites and poof, it was gone.<br><br>Next up, chocolate raspberry cupcake. The cream was deli-sh. The cupcake itself was moist and not too sweet. Was thinking that it will be too much of chocolate in between the cupcake during purchase but ended up at the right amount. Sugar level wasn&#39;t too high either for this cupcake. Glad that I got it!<br><br>Very berry smoothie. Not too thick, not too runny. Perfect blend with right amount of fruits. Was a little on the pricier side but glad that I did try it. <br><br>Customer service here was excellent. Staffs were friendly and smiling all throughout the transaction. They also repeated order in case they misheard the customers. When customers leave the cafe, they will clean up in a quick manner.<br><br>After munching on my goodies, I decided to get a bagel back for the next day. It was onion bagel. Also saw the gingerbread cookies over the counter. Decided to grab that as well. <br><br>Second day arrived. Tried my bagel - was pretty good without even heating it up after almost a day. Gingerbread cookies are not too sweet as well. <br><br>Third visit - very berry donut and raspberry rage smoothie. The very berry donut has a berry taste at the top topped with fluffy donut texture and citrusy fillings. Great sweet and sour combination with an addition of mini malt balls on the top to make the dish crunchy. For the raspberry rage smoothie, more sour than sweet. Good for tea break.<br><br>Overall, excellent cafe/bakery in town. Will be back for more smoothies &amp; baked goods.

text: Whizzed into this shop hidden amidst the private housing estate in Bukit Timah for their almond croissant, only to find out that they were sold out.<br><br>Their plain butter croissant did not look appealing and thus I opted for the Cinnamon Swirl ($3.50) since they are of the same croissant dough. I am not too sure if the plain croissant usurped the TBB throne, but this one was light, flaky and satisfying. But the Chinese 5-spice Chocolate Macaron ($2.50) scores points for creativity but not for texture. <br><br>Meantime, the Canele ($3) did not pass muster for the dry interior and one can find definitely spot better ones elsewhere.Similarly, the Milllefeuille ($5) was disappointing. The custard was too gluey and had an synthetic vanilla smell. The sheer amount of filling was too heavy for the wilted paper-thin puff pastry to handle. <br><br>But it was not all too bad when it comes to the lemon tart ($5). In fact, it was the best, thanks to the buttery and crumbly pastry shell with occasions sparkles of salts. The creamy lemon interior had the right balance of tartness and sweetness. A strong contender against TBB&#39;s lemon tart. <br><br> With the location not easily within reach by MRT, I would probably return when I meet a Good Samaritan who can give me a car ride.
