Quiche', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Quiche'}]
text: The latest addition to the Greenwood eateries is Baker &amp; Cook, an artisan bakery and food store opened by Global Baker Dean Brettschneider. The bakery produces its own brand range of jams, cookies, cakes, homemade granola and more. Just the selection of breads alone will leave you stupefied. It took me a long while to finally decide on what i want. <br><br>The set up kinda reminds me of Simply Bread which is located at Guthrie House at 6th Ave but B&amp;C has more of a pastry and dessert selection. The 20-odd seater fills up pretty quickly and space in the air conditioned section is hard to come by. <br><br>I had a blind taste test of their bagel prior to coming to the bakery and it is the best i&#39;ve tasted in Singapore. It is chewy without being overly tough on the jaw and i love how there is this tinge of saltiness to the dough. Very New-Yorkish. The blueberry bagel ($2.35ea) is a dessert in itself. The berries would simply burst when you sink your teeth into the bagel and act as a fresh jam to sweeten each bite.<br><br>Sandwiches are available at $8.50 and what&#39;s available is dependent on the Chef&#39;s mood. There were only 2 options and that makes life a lot easier for indecisive eaters. Ham And Cheese Turkish Pide Sandwich ($8.50) was my choice for my Tinner (Tea+Dinner). The bread is tough on the outside, the toasted part is almost like a pizza crust and it crackles with each bite. However, it&#39;s pillowy soft on the inside. Love the black sesame seeds on top. They added on a smoky dimension that is oh-so-fragrant. Eat it fast though. It really gets the jaw going when it&#39;s colder.<br><br>Z was raving about the quiche even before we got to the bakery. For $7.95, you get a slice of the pie with a salad of your choice. I&#39;m not a big fan of vegetables but this is very fresh. The burst of colors of the fresh greens and reds really helped whet our appetites. The eggy centre was extremely moist and creamy. I&#39;ve hit the Quiche jackpot! The pastry is not very crispy because it has absorbed all the essence of the fillings. <br><br>Before leaving, i simply had to express my disappointment at missing out on the meat quiche (Only the Veg was available). A Quiche Lorraine would be oh-so-perfect. The Chef immediately went to check if there&#39;s another pie for the next day and WALA! Wish granted! It always helps to look extremely sad and pouty. Heh. Anyway, it was equally moist, so it&#39;s not purely the contribution of the vegetables.<br><br>The wide array of colorful desserts were hard to resist. We started off with the lemon tart. I like the crumbly and buttery texture of the crust. The curd is a little more fluid and sticky and also leaning towards the sweet side. I would prefer it to be a tad more sour (it&#39;s a lemon tart afterall!). In the end i emptied the golden cup of its content and focused on the tart while Z happily ate the curd. <br><br>Had the mochaccino and it was a liquid chocolate-expresso fantasy. For $5.50, a huge mug of fragrant chocolatey dream is served. The texture is smooth and the foam was really thick and it held up the sugar for a really long time (i&#39;m gonna start timing next time). Anyway, it&#39;s almost like drinking hot chocolate but the sneaky caffeine gave me an energizer-bunny buzz for the rest of the night. This is like downing cocktails without realizing how strong the drinks are and then getting pretty drunk. Caffeine is my alcohol.<br><br>The cakes look very yummy, especially the cheesecakes. They look especially moist and dense. Whole cakes go for about $23-25. <br><br>Z doesn&#39;t like cheesecake so we settled for the chocolate cake which was quite a disappointment. There is no denying that the texture was quite perfect- dense and thick. However, it seems to lack in the chocolate department, it just wasn&#39;t rich enough. On the whole, it was pretty dry.<br><br>Packed the shortbread home. Every mouthful was a cranberry explosion. Z thought it was too much as it&#39;s hard to enjoy the true taste of the shortbread. I thought the shortbread was a little bland and the taste fell flat. Thankfully the cranberries revived it a little.

text: Love everything that I&#39;ve tried here so far. The quiches, western-style carrot cake, hummus and so on. The vanilla (popcorn?) rooibos is a great complement to the food too.

text: Okay so it&#39;s early days in Singapore but this was the first cafes here that gave me a taste of &#39;home&#39;. Allpress coffee with a distinct flavour and reasonably priced, a simple yet varied menu, and great bread! So good we now buy the bread on a weekly basis, getting it sliced on the spot and freezing it at home... eggs bene and the chicken and bacon pastry roll from the cabinet hit the spot for his and her. <br><br>On this particular visit I did witness some mistakes being made by the cooking staff (open sandwiches not being toasted as advertised on the menu and being sent back on two separate occasions by different visitors), however the staff were very apologetic and polite (not sure why they repeated the mistake again though?). <br><br>Prefer this one to the Martin Road outlet - but convenience of Martin Road wins out in the end!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XFYG6LBwfQpwq9J8ffUIuw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/baker-and-cook-singapore?reviewid=he13g-W-mJvWsGuopBjd3g&select=XFYG6LBwfQpwq9J8ffUIuw', 'altText': 'Photo of Baker & Cook - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FtIjV0ngFYYruMgWaLKxiw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/baker-and-cook-singapore?reviewid=he13g-W-mJvWsGuopBjd3g&select=FtIjV0ngFYYruMgWaLKxiw', 'altText': 'Photo of Baker & Cook - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/dtgYab59JHlaRV82wE969w/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/baker-and-cook-singapore?reviewid=he13g-W-mJvWsGuopBjd3g&select=dtgYab59JHlaRV82wE969w', 'altText': 'Photo of Baker & Cook - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WEoivlVObGE03PiWvVvXYA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/baker-and-cook-singapore?reviewid=he13g-W-mJvWsGuopBjd3g&select=WEoivlVObGE03PiWvVvXYA', 'altText': 'Photo of Baker & Cook - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: One of the newest european bakeries to set up shop in Singapore, Baker &amp; Cook offers quite a nice spread of cake, pastries and breads. The shop space is pretty tight, with only one long, communal table plonked in the middle of the seating area. As the indoor seats were all taken up, we sat outside. Thank God it was a rainy day and it was cool enough.<br><br>They have a pretty strange rule that they stick by such that people sitting outdoors can only be served food in takeaway packages. It was quite a spoiler to receive my egg benedict in a cardboard box and $17++ seemed a little too much to pay for such a meal all of a sudden. The food was otherwise pretty good, eggs poached to perfection and a slightly spicy hollandaise sauce accompanied by toast and crisp back bacon. I had a flat white to go along and was pretty pleased with it. They do a pretty good cherry pie and raspberry tart too.<br><br>I guess the main thing that pulled the overall experience at baker &amp; cook down for me was the lack of indoor sitting and the fact that the food was served in cardboard boxes to customers seated outside. You don&#39;t exactly get much service although you are paying for it.

This corner bakery, with plenty of street parking ( if you count the illegal lanes as well) is a great hang out spot, with some sun and shade, with a good selection of breads, pastries, salads and dessert. You could sit there for hours and the good thing is they open rather early! Right after the morning school chauffeuring, if you&#39;re around the area, you can pop by as early as 7am for coffee and some pastries. With european bakeries flooding into town these days, $4 for approximately 2 feet long of baguette, I find breakfast rather affordable and satisfying as their soft crumb yet thin crust is as good as it gets for a tasty baguette with just some butter and jam. <br>The croissants are good too, flaky and buttery especially if they are fresh out of the oven. If you are taking them home, you might want to reheat before devouring it is alot better when I did that the second time I took it away and left it for the following morning. The space to queue up and order is a little tight, if you have a big crowd, it&#39;d be good to decide first and send someone to order, otherwise, it can be rather chaotic.

An excellent place for tea break and all the pastries just look and taste so heavenly. The thing i liked about this cafe was the relaxing and friendly vibe that it gave me when i stepped into the place. And then i saw the array of pastries which were so tantalising. <br><br>I love the raspberry tart as it has a lot of fruit jam on it and tastes fresh, with the tart being just nice not too crumbly or hard. It goes superbly well with the iced mocha, which had a sweet chocolate aftertaste and tasted so refreshing.<br><br>Service was alright but it did take some time to get a seat due to the limited seats available and the space constraint.

text: I just come here for the canales. Each crunchy and chewy nibble is worth every penny (or rather each 20 cent if you add up the number of nibbles)!

good coffee, croissants, danish, and quiche.<br>i feel bad that the outdoor seating has &#39;changed&#39;.<br>the last time i was there, all the seats outdoor have been removed, due to some complaints from the residents. so they said ura etc were trying to figure out what to do. so that&#39;s why they have to serve the people outside with the takeaway packaging.

text: I&#39;ve been here a few times since I discovered Jimmy Monkey. Each time for breakfast on the weekend. Grab a menu and order at the counter, then the wait staff will bring out the food. The coffee is excellent, and I love the vibe of the place. The staff is friendly and attentive. Yes, the food is a little price-y, but not too far out of range for this kind of place. My favorite so far is the hash. Just a little bit of spice and just satisfying enough for brunch.

text: its pricy but i love the ambiance. get the tea, they serve it in separates and let you do the mixing. they&#39;ve also got a great selection of books. the window seat is the best!

Great coffee and good quality food. <br><br>Deducting one star for the location  (quite a walk from the nearest mrt station) and one star for the price (you leave wondering if you really got what you paid for). Definitely not a place you&#39;ll pass by unless you make an intentional effort to visit it. May or may not come back

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oP8-pu-u0Ztd8HGt9W8Qng/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jimmy-monkey-cafe-and-bar-singapore?reviewid=0Od0jeaiBV29-pSqR5dBzA&select=oP8-pu-u0Ztd8HGt9W8Qng', 'altText': 'Photo of Jimmy Monkey Cafe & Bar - Singapore, Singapore. Note the massive avocado toast in the background', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Note the massive avocado toast in the background'}]
text: While the seating isn&#39;t the greatest, the coffee is outstanding and the food is delicious. <br><br>Grab a table and place your order at the counter when you&#39;re ready. Eggs &amp; toast was SG$10 which seemed reasonable (for the area). The avocado toast was an absolute mountain of avocado!<br><br>I really loved my latte (for the first time in Singapore) - finally one that wasn&#39;t overly bitter. Melbourne folks continue to meet the stereotype of being coffee experts. <br><br>We also had a vanilla-Nutella milkshake. I was a little surprised that it was watery like milk (instead of thick like american shakes) but it was still super tasty!<br><br>Free wifi - just ask for the code.

At this point, I&#39;m no longer shocked by prices in this part of town. Anywhere in one north is almost exclusively catering for ex-pats and high-income locals. Jimmy Monkey is no different. Egg&#39;s Benedict will run you a whopping $24, pancakes are $14, and the french toast is $17.<br><br>They had run out of pancakes on a Sunday at noon so I went with the french toast, and added on a chocolate, peanut butter, speculoos shake for good measure. This was not a wallet-friendly brunch but I was happily surprised by how tasty everything was. The french toast comes in a healthy serving, and includes berries and crème fraîche. By the end I was actually struggling to finish my serving because everything was so sweet.<br><br>I wouldn&#39;t be opposed to returning but this place is definitely a treat, and not a joint for regular meals. Seating is fairly limited, but somehow sufficient for the number of patrons. It gets a little warm, and the space does feel a little cramped. Nonetheless there are a variety of seating options depending on what you&#39;re up to.

text: Located at the ground of a block of private housing is this tiny cafe. The dine in area was limited. Menu was a simple clip board, some sliced cakes on the display shelf. Although it was air-con indoor, we could barely feel the air-con, so we did try to adjust the standing fan next to us.<br><br>Mocha<br>The drink was quite rich and thick, but not enough coffee taste.<br><br>Carrot cake<br>Quite a huge silce but I would prefer it to be more moist.<br><br>Dom Pedro ($18)<br>Fresh Milk, Vanilla Ice-Cream + Black Nikka Whisky<br>It looked just like another plain vanilla milkshake. In just a single taste, I could feel the heat of the alcohol down my throat. Feeling high fast. It was rather strong drink to have.<br><br>Overall the drinks were great. But in the warm dine in area, one tended to feel sleepy easily.

Jimmy Monkey came highly recommended for its coffee and that was the main reason behind my visit to this off location. The space sort of screams hipster in name, design and look of the staff. That is not necessarily a bad thing as it often can deliver some good food and beverages.<br><br>The coffee was pretty good and clearly better than any random place but still not really impressive wither. If it would have been around the corner I could have visited again but not at all worth traveling this far for. Also had a decent brekkie muffin and a pasta with mushrooms. Not bad but also a bit overpriced.<br><br>What was however a pleasant surprise was that the staff were friendly and helpful. Service was also smooth and fast despite the place being packed.

text: I googled for free-wifi AND power plugs and found this place. <br><br>What&#39;s lovely about it is you can manage to comfortably get lounge seats on a weekend evening. And there&#39;s no queue, not much of a crowd throughout the night. Yes, it&#39;s QUIET. A rare gem I would say.<br><br>I also really admire the fact I could drink coffee, look up and there you are, a TOILET BOWL complete with toilet paper right above my head. It&#39;s so randomly ridiculous yet genius that I LURVE IT. I even took a picture of it, go see.<br><br>I ordered the banana bread pudding, - $14, and coffee. The presentation of the bread pudding was very cute, it came in a pot, on a wooden slab. Coffee was better than most cafes I&#39;ve been to, and service was... Let&#39;s just say that they let you do your own thing, and they do theirs, and if both lines should intersect, colourful unicorns will bloom. Pricing is on the high side.<br><br>One thing that made me feel like getting up to leave, was the glaring red neon lighting fixture, that engulfed me and my companion. It reminded me of an episode in Seinfeld (who else still watches this?!) where Kramer&#39;s entire room emitted a red glow because Kenny Rogers moved opposite his room and their crazy signboard faced his window.<br><br>Check out <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Featlikeawhale.blogspot.sg&amp;s=073078668bba0d0a43c2d19980dbd9384767b13a2e1457c8da39273937aa332c" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">eatlikeawhale.blogspot.sg</a> for more pictures and reviews.

text: I&#39;ll just get this out of the way first. I&#39;m probably one of five people in the world that doesn&#39;t drink coffee. I know how to grind beans and make coffee in a french press for my mum, I love the smell of coffee brewing and when it pops up in savory food and sweets...but I just hate the taste of coffee as a drink. No matter how much milk, sugar, nothing, best beans, kona beans, any beans, my man has tried to get me to drink it and the most I&#39;ve tolerated is 2 sips. The one time I drank a caramel latte in Japan because I totally misread the menu, it was really sweet and suddenly I was talking non-stop for an hour. <br><br>Since this IS a coffee joint, my dude has his two cents in this review. He had a decaf black and in his words &#34;it&#39;s wonderful. very smooth&#34;. So there.<br><br>Now on to the food. We&#39;re really brunch people so we were looking for food more than coffee. When I say I&#39;m a brunch person it&#39;s not because I like to dress up to eat a meal I can cook at home. I&#39;m actually a hungry person, I like brunch foods and someone always wakes up too late to fire up the pan. Anyway, we had the french toast and a breakfast sandwich (can&#39;t remember the exact name) and both were pretty good.  My french toast was made of 3 thick slices of brioche sliced up, drizzled with a caramel sauce with bananas and nuts drizzled over. It was beautiful to see and a hearty portion for my rumbling tummy. Here&#39;s the problem: the egg wash wasn&#39;t soaked through the bread. Whhhhhhhhy? It would&#39;ve been perfect otherwise. If there&#39;s a monkey jimmy listening - please soak the toast, turn the heat low and cook that baby.<br><br>The breakfast sandwich was a standout. A generous, fluffy omelet sandwiched between avocado slices, ciabatta and a sweet-ish tomato chutney. It was brilliant, huge and I would eat it again. And again. So that&#39;s a winner right there.<br><br>What didn&#39;t I like? The guys on shift probably partied until 4am and decided to bring their music to work. Bad trance music in a coffee shop is just wrong. Especially at 2pm on a Saturday. That gave me a headache and I shouldn&#39;t be getting one at a place where there&#39;s a toilet bowl watching me eat.

At this point, I&#39;m no longer shocked by prices in this part of town. Anywhere in one north is almost exclusively catering for ex-pats and high-income locals. Jimmy Monkey is no different. Egg&#39;s Benedict will run you a whopping $24, pancakes are $14, and the french toast is $17.<br><br>They had run out of pancakes on a Sunday at noon so I went with the french toast, and added on a chocolate, peanut butter, speculoos shake for good measure. This was not a wallet-friendly brunch but I was happily surprised by how tasty everything was. The french toast comes in a healthy serving, and includes berries and crème fraîche. By the end I was actually struggling to finish my serving because everything was so sweet.<br><br>I wouldn&#39;t be opposed to returning but this place is definitely a treat, and not a joint for regular meals. Seating is fairly limited, but somehow sufficient for the number of patrons. It gets a little warm, and the space does feel a little cramped. Nonetheless there are a variety of seating options depending on what you&#39;re up to.

4-stars only for the coffee.<br><br>I normally order a flat white or cappuccino here. They have a Slayer(tm) coffee machine and do their shots right.<br><br>Come here only for the coffee. For dessert, you&#39;re better off wandering over to Rochester or Star Vista.
Coffee was good, food was decent. Portions were slightly too small. Service was spotty although staff were sincere.<br><br>Prices could have been slightly lower, especially given the location.

The food is delicious and uncomplicated. The staff is friendly and unpretentious. The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming. Free wifi if you need it. Quirky &amp; clever little bits all around to show you that the proprietor &amp; his staff enjoy what they do.

text: They neither serve Jimmy nor Monkeys.... But for a quant place to grab a smoothie or cup of coffee and a light bite this might be a good stop.   Tried the pulled pork sandwich on a buttered bun served with potatoes lyonnaise and also tried the tartine called &#34;the hulk&#34; - open face rustic bread sandwich covered in avocado and feta served on a bed of arugula.  The banana-strawberry smoothie was &#34;nice&#34; (says the SPG) and the mocha was delightful!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=o5zFFfO6ELMvUdcxPaIWFA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/RF-Dc9a2PdnMfTs7aNUrPA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/RF-Dc9a2PdnMfTs7aNUrPA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/RF-Dc9a2PdnMfTs7aNUrPA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/RF-Dc9a2PdnMfTs7aNUrPA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/RF-Dc9a2PdnMfTs7aNUrPA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/RF-Dc9a2PdnMfTs7aNUrPA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Jon H.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Jon H.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=o5zFFfO6ELMvUdcxPaIWFA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 4, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 6, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Imagine a hipster cafe with above average prices and decidedly average food.<br><br>Congratulations, you&#39;ve successfully imagined Jimmy Monkey Cafe &amp; Bar.<br><br>In all seriousness, I found the food to be decent but not worth raving about or coming back for.  It seemed as though JMC&amp;B was trying to get that Saturday morning breakfast cafe feel, like the ones that you&#39;d find by the beach in California or Hawaii, but they fell a bit short.  If they&#39;re going to charge the prices they do, I feel there should be something special that sets them at least a little bit apart, but I didn&#39;t think there was anything that special here.<br><br>Last mark against them is the lack of space.  JMC&amp;B feels very cramped, as we were slotted into what felt like a tiny corner of a wooden shack.

I love this place for its quaint-ness. <br><br>Out of the place (a short walk from One North MRT) but convenient if you have a car.<br><br>Good place to chill out on a weekend afternoon but it might be a bit crowded to get some reading done.<br><br>Absolutely love the washrooms as it was decorated so beautifully with bookshelves (my absolute dream intention to my own bathroom) with books and cards!

Piccolo Latte', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Piccolo Latte'}]
text: Espresso - this was a potent, robust and strong shot with a lingering aftertaste, but also a good balance of taste and flavours. This is not surprising - Jimmy Monkey&#39;s Ironbark blend is a combination of beans from Brazil (Cerrado), Papua New Guinea (Sigri), Columbia (Kachru), Guatamala (La Laguna) and Peru (Amazonas). There is also a Columbian single origin blend available, which works well in pourover coffee. Each bean variety contributes something unique to the shot - hints of citrus, and even some chocolate notes. Ironbark is a blend that is still evolving, and is now on it&#39;s third iteration. The experimentation has paid off, leaving a full bodied shot with a lingering aftertaste.<br><br>The cappuccino that I ordered was notable for the initial strong hit of coffee flavour, complemented by smooth, light foam and finished with well executed latte art. The microbubbles in the foam add the smooth, silky mouthfeel that I look for, and is seen in quality cafes. This is where Ironbark is used to good effect - the lingering aftertaste is a strong base for a milk based drink, ensuring that the fundamental coffee character is retained.<br><br>I had a Piccolo also, which is characterised by a more robust coffee taste, with the aftertaste lasting through the milk and foam. The milk complements the robust coffee flavour, smoothing it but not smothering it, creating a hybrid which retains the best characteristics of each - its just right and well executed. Their original place in the piccolo latte hall of fame post is deserved, and retained. There are also pourover, syphon and chemex coffees available. <br><br>This is a good choice for anyone in the West of the island, and worth a quick trip on the MRT for coffee lovers elsewhere.

Fantastic food, great friendly staff.<br><br>Coffee, sourdough, bacon, Hemmingway, even the apricot marmalade is perfect. What a great delight for sunday brunch save for it being a little expensive.<br><br>One customer left 10 bucks behind accidentally and the staff ran out to return it, when he could have pretended its tips and pocketed it. <br><br>Excellent place!

The little brown monkey sits above you watching you enjoy your meal only leads you to wonder if he is envious of the food or merely just a guardian for the space. Whatever the case is, I hope he is envious. For the food and coffee is always excellent. For it&#39;s location, they have the concept right. A bit of fusion but casual substantial food. I really enjoy their couscous salad and homemade dips. Steak sandwich is juice and delicious as well. <br><br>The coffee has always been consistently great. I trust the baristas and kitchen staffs are passionate with their food and coffee. They are always friendly and outspoken. So feel free to have a casual chat with them and feel right at home here.

text: The JFDI cafe at Blk 71, Ayer Rajar Crescent, has longer been servin&#39; up their wonderful coffees made with Jimmy Monkey&#39;s beans! Initially, I thought &#34;Jimmy Monkey&#34; was a supplier of coffee beans. To my surprise they are a cafe which roast their own beans (and hence name it after themselves)! A very hipster one in fact! My friend brought me there after lunch to grab a Soya latte which I was skeptical about at first. My prejudice against Soya lattes stems from the fact that their drinkers are commonly stereotyped as dieters. Refusing to be labelled as one of them, I have abstained from ordering a Soya latte... until today. My friend was raving about their Soya latte so much - how light &amp; nutty it was... etc - that I knew I had to give it a try (at least just this once). Anyways, it was a quick-in-&amp;-out dash not long enough for any snooty purist coffee drinker to give me the stink eye for ordering a Soya latte. So I did it. <br><br>To my surprise... the Soya latte was really GOOD... even better than normal latte! I am a convert. It had a nice nutty flavor (just as my friend promised) and doesn&#39;t taste like the sweet stuff you get from Mr.Bean or at soybean packet drinks from NTUC. The Soya milk didn&#39;t overpower the coffee flavor. In fact, it tasted a lot like milk ... only less creamy (which I prefer) ... &amp; thus help enhance the coffee ( I think). I was pleasantly surprised. The brand of Soya milk they used is called - Silk - which I am told is one of the best. Can&#39;t wait to grab a pack at the nearest cold storage on my way home.<br><br>My next coffee will definitely be a Soya Latte!

Piccolo Latte', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Piccolo Latte'}]
text: Espresso - this was a potent, robust and strong shot with a lingering aftertaste, but also a good balance of taste and flavours. This is not surprising - Jimmy Monkey&#39;s Ironbark blend is a combination of beans from Brazil (Cerrado), Papua New Guinea (Sigri), Columbia (Kachru), Guatamala (La Laguna) and Peru (Amazonas). There is also a Columbian single origin blend available, which works well in pourover coffee. Each bean variety contributes something unique to the shot - hints of citrus, and even some chocolate notes. Ironbark is a blend that is still evolving, and is now on it&#39;s third iteration. The experimentation has paid off, leaving a full bodied shot with a lingering aftertaste.<br><br>The cappuccino that I ordered was notable for the initial strong hit of coffee flavour, complemented by smooth, light foam and finished with well executed latte art. The microbubbles in the foam add the smooth, silky mouthfeel that I look for, and is seen in quality cafes. This is where Ironbark is used to good effect - the lingering aftertaste is a strong base for a milk based drink, ensuring that the fundamental coffee character is retained.<br><br>I had a Piccolo also, which is characterised by a more robust coffee taste, with the aftertaste lasting through the milk and foam. The milk complements the robust coffee flavour, smoothing it but not smothering it, creating a hybrid which retains the best characteristics of each - its just right and well executed. Their original place in the piccolo latte hall of fame post is deserved, and retained. There are also pourover, syphon and chemex coffees available. <br><br>This is a good choice for anyone in the West of the island, and worth a quick trip on the MRT for coffee lovers elsewhere.

Yes it&#39;s a toilet bowl', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': "Yes it's a toilet bowl"}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Fw-3-wvc3DvwqJ3kQSaRyg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jimmy-monkey-cafe-and-bar-singapore?reviewid=w94_GkSmXRw3QRxuCkn8Og&select=Fw-3-wvc3DvwqJ3kQSaRyg', 'altText': 'Photo of Jimmy Monkey Cafe & Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Qe-7ChvL8NUqVTm3z5WA5g/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jimmy-monkey-cafe-and-bar-singapore?reviewid=w94_GkSmXRw3QRxuCkn8Og&select=Qe-7ChvL8NUqVTm3z5WA5g', 'altText': 'Photo of Jimmy Monkey Cafe & Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: I googled for free-wifi AND power plugs and found this place. <br><br>What&#39;s lovely about it is you can manage to comfortably get lounge seats on a weekend evening. And there&#39;s no queue, not much of a crowd throughout the night. Yes, it&#39;s QUIET. A rare gem I would say.<br><br>I also really admire the fact I could drink coffee, look up and there you are, a TOILET BOWL complete with toilet paper right above my head. It&#39;s so randomly ridiculous yet genius that I LURVE IT. I even took a picture of it, go see.<br><br>I ordered the banana bread pudding, - $14, and coffee. The presentation of the bread pudding was very cute, it came in a pot, on a wooden slab. Coffee was better than most cafes I&#39;ve been to, and service was... Let&#39;s just say that they let you do your own thing, and they do theirs, and if both lines should intersect, colourful unicorns will bloom. Pricing is on the high side.<br><br>One thing that made me feel like getting up to leave, was the glaring red neon lighting fixture, that engulfed me and my companion. It reminded me of an episode in Seinfeld (who else still watches this?!) where Kramer&#39;s entire room emitted a red glow because Kenny Rogers moved opposite his room and their crazy signboard faced his window.<br><br>Check out <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Featlikeawhale.blogspot.sg&amp;s=073078668bba0d0a43c2d19980dbd9384767b13a2e1457c8da39273937aa332c" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">eatlikeawhale.blogspot.sg</a> for more pictures and reviews.

text: Once upon a time, a little card advertised a list of independent coffee shops on an island.  A girl picked up that card and memorized it and spent the next two years of her life visiting each coffee shop in turn.  Her last coffee shop was Jimmy Monkey Bar.<br>It is so in the middle of nowhere. I am sure the residents and nearby laborers appreciate this coffee shop but it is just too out of the way for anyone else to get here.  I finally made the effort because I had to have a meeting near Holland V.  I was struck by the strange interior; it doesn&#39;t match the vibe of the website.  Call me crazy, but consistent branding is something I pay attention too.<br>When I first ordered they were charging me $15 for a beet salad so I negotiated for a smaller salad at 2/3 the price and was a little happier but it still seemed expensive.  I wasn&#39;t going to argue with the iced latte.  I love it and would pay every penny for it. The coffee flavor was strong and nutty and they used the good milk.  My beet salad was fine and my friend seemed to like his banana muffin.  <br>We sat undisturbed for two hours sipping coffee and chatting.  Sort of sad such a quiet place isn&#39;t a little closer to me; but then it wouldn&#39;t be quiet.

text: its pricy but i love the ambiance. get the tea, they serve it in separates and let you do the mixing. they&#39;ve also got a great selection of books. the window seat is the best!

I absolutely love the coffee and the laid back vibe at Jimmy Monkey. But their food is really nothing to shout about and rather over priced if I must say. Have tried a couple of their brunch options and the only thing I will re order is the bowl of muesli. Although after having said that, Jimmy Monkey is a place I will keep visiting because their coffee is just quite so amazing. And I also really love their cute blue cups (which you can actually buy!).

Since I live in the west I was super happy to find that I now had a proper coffee place near home.<br><br>It&#39;s near, but still not near enough: finding it for the first time can be a daunting task, especially if you&#39;re not too familiar with the one-north/Biopolis areas.<br><br>It&#39;s located in the one-north Residence condo near Slim Barracks Rise, so it&#39;s about the same walking distance from one-north and Holland Village circle line stations. <br><br>The cafe has a Melbournian vibe going for it. No surprise as it&#39;s owned and run by a guy from Melbourne who craved a slice of home. They make a big deal out of how they have a Slayer machine. I&#39;m not that much of a coffee geek although I drink a lot of it.<br><br>Their coffee is above average. And pretty strong, stronger than most others&#39;. I know because coffee tends to have no effect on me although I drink gallons of it, but I do visibly perk up a bit from Jimmy Monkey cafe. Taste-wise they have a stronger, slightly more bitter profile to their coffee.<br><br>They&#39;re probably the only coffee place to do &#39;serious&#39; food, as in they have a huge food menu. Most of it is executed quite well. I wouldn&#39;t go as far as to say the food is great, but it&#39;s comforting and quite unique. They have toast soldiers, good tarts, decent desserts, savoury pastas and a lot of sandwiches. All of those things are, I feel, better than their breakfast sets. But I don&#39;t like eggs and meat for brekkie so I guess I&#39;m not the target demographic. The pastas are quite good though.<br><br>They also have Asahi and some other alcohol, but I haven&#39;t had a good time or reason to drink here. I remember them being quite affordably priced though!
The eggs benedict (only on the weekends) and a cappuccino (which seem bigger than the latte) is probably the best breakfast I have had in Singapore. Their coffee is impressively good.

text: I was looking forward to this place after reading the positive reviews. Unfortunately my experience was not as good. The coffee was over-roasted and every. single. item. on the daytime menu had some kind of bread or wheat in it. Even the only salad had couscous. No love for the gluten-free.

text: Very nice! Good brunch, with options for adding sides (still annoyed with Wild Honey about that!)

I&#39;m not a vegetarian but this place was fantastic. The waiter was very friendly and really made an effort to make sure that everything was to my liking. He also explained that they make their dishes fresh. That&#39;s a big thumbs up. I ordered the strawberry mint lassi to begin. I was skeptical at first, but it was delicious. I then ordered the spinach ricotta ravioli. YUM! I definitely want to go back and try their soups.

text: While the food was good and the service was attentive, the prices are high for a cafe style restaurant. A quick dinner for two here cost us about as much as in a fancy HV restaurant.

text: I was checking for Vegan indian restaurant that serves different cuisine than regular North or South Indian dishes and i found cafe salvation. Reviews were good but i wasn&#39;t feeling confident to visit the restaurant since i was quite far from race course road. I still decided to give it a try and take my words, it was worth travelling so far for me. They have pretty extensive menu of items. We ordered 3 dishes and 1 desert and all were awesome. We even spoke to the owner and gave him few suggestions on adding new dishes. Overall : Perfect joint for food. ( Replacement of delhi&#39;s big chill restaurant for me in Singapore :) )

text: A newly opened cafe offering beverages such as Matcha, Houjicha and Genmaicha. <br><br>Military Latte ($6.50)<br>Ronin matcha shot, dark chocolate, milk<br>The chocolate overwhelmed the matcha taste. Could only taste the matcha at the finish part.

text: A pretty decent Pizza place in Dempsey. Due to Covid i think they are seating customers inside the neighboring  cafe (which looks great in its own right!). We tried the lamb meatball, leek and garlic pizza. The toppings were great, it&#39;s good to see places take risks with a bit unconventional toppings.  The only thing lacking was the sourdough crust.. it was a tad undercooked. For a pizza oven, it probably meant spending just 30 seconds to a min longer in the oven. APart from that.. its a decent pizza place.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=rawWFcMMIyrfz8Lq9rwsxQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WFD4uxonWQFGKplClHTIzw/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WFD4uxonWQFGKplClHTIzw/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WFD4uxonWQFGKplClHTIzw/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WFD4uxonWQFGKplClHTIzw/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WFD4uxonWQFGKplClHTIzw/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/WFD4uxonWQFGKplClHTIzw/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Sheer E.', 'displayLocation': 'Sixth Avenue, Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Sheer E.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=rawWFcMMIyrfz8Lq9rwsxQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 2, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 1, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Order a bowl of Bak Kut Teh from the friendly towkay and be greeted by tender meat that slides off easily from pork bones which have been boiled and simmered in flavourful stock. <br><br>You know you&#39;ll be asking for soup refills. (at no extra cost)

Most of Bukit Timah feels like an upscale neighbourhood, mostly because it&#39;s true. I have spent all my life going to school around these parts and cannot think of anywhere else that comes so close to feeling like a heartland neighbourhood. The start of Sixth Ave has a couple of kopitiams once you pass the bars and restaurants. I like it. <br><br>The prawn noodle shop here is very good and you can personally witness the maestro cooking the stock and prepping the ingredients most evenings after he closes (if you didn&#39;t already know, making prawn stock is an elaborate task). The drinks situation is a little odd, because it doesn&#39;t actually have its own drinks stall. You can order the zi char and drinks from next door. But it&#39;s still a nice, relaxed spot to have dinner. They also open till late, so that&#39;s a big plus. Dinner for 3 with drinks and beer cost under $30 the other night, which is usually the price of one entree down the road. So I&#39;m a happy girl whenever I&#39;m here, because the food is also quite good.

text: Really liked the ambience of the place! Visited on a Tuesday evening &amp; it was busy but not annoyingly loud. It doesn&#39;t hurt that the staff were very friendly too! <br><br>Got the fresh tagliatelle &amp; a cup of chai latte- I frankly expected more from the tagliatelle but the chai latte was very enjoyable. A wonderful blend of cream &amp; spice. I&#39;ll definitely be back, maybe not for the food, but for that chai latte!

text: The cafe was located just a 5 minutes walk from the MRT station. The place was packed during weekend with limited indoor and outdoor dining in area. They ran out of bread soon after I ordered. Remember to collect a poker card number tag after making payment.<br><br>Omelette with cheddar, mushrooms &amp; onions ($21)<br>Served in a metal plate, with a slice of bread underneath.<br>A bit tough to slice the bread. The omelette left behind a layer of oil. Somehow reminded one of pan fried egg with onions at home with its char edges. Could not taste the cheddar in it.<br><br>Latte ($5)<br>Quite rich with a slightly chocolaty and bitter taste.<br><br>Overall the food was not bad. Place was crowded and quite noisy too.

Busy kitchen', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Busy kitchen'}]
text: It&#39;s my 50th review! , <br><br>Sarnies definitely brings me back to Australia. From the décor, to the vibe, to the food - rustic, unpretentious and delicious with the use of fresh ingredients, portion is HUGE and the coffee is good. The cafe concept is hassle free too. Just walk straight to the counter, grab the menu and order right there. You will be given a card which is also your order number so grab a table and the friendly staff will bring your food over once it&#39;s ready. If the weather is not crazily hot, I will always opt to sit outside, away from the open kitchen inside the café. <br><br>I came here twice - first on a busy weekday for lunch and second on a quieter weekend brunch. The sandwiches here are to die for and totally value for money. On the first visit, I had the smoked salmon sandwich while my boss had the steak with mushroom and caramelised onions sandwich, both selling at $13.90 and $15.50, respectively. Both sandwiches came with generous portion of filling (mine with lots of smoked salmon pieces on creamy dill sauce) and it sure filled me up until dinner. Unfortunately, the sandwiches are only available on weekdays and they have an entire different menu on weekend and dinner. <br><br>On my second visit, it was a Saturday post gym brunch with my friend. I ordered the smoked salmon (again!) and scrambled eggs served on sourdough, while my friend ordered bacon and egg served on a mini baguette. While the dishes were executed perfectly, I thought the price was slightly on a higher side for brunch food. We paid almost $30 each for a main and a drink, hence I minus one star for this review. Even the dinner price ranges from $10 to $15 only. That&#39;s bizarre when it should be the other way around.  <br><br>The café is open every day - Mon to Fri until 9pm, and weekends until 4pm, so swing by if you&#39;re around the area and give it a try. I&#39;m sure you&#39;ll like it as much as I do.

Steak Sandwich, Sarnies', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Steak Sandwich, Sarnies'}]
text: Sarnies - Known in my neck of the woods (Straya) as a sanger or sambo - is a cute nickname the Brits have given to sandwiches.<br><br>And Sarnies is a great incarnation of this moniker in Singapore. The sandwiches are cute and tasty and served fresh even during the rushiest of lunchtime rushes.<br><br>My companion and I couldn&#39;t go past the steak sarnie. Let&#39;s face it, who can?<br><br>This bad boy features grass fed cut steak, amazing sautéed mushrooms, onion, mixed greens and an in-house tangy steak sauce to round out all those flavours.<br><br>To finish up we shared the Coconut cocowhip (think low-fat ice cream/yoghurt) which was a perfect end to the meal to cleanse the palate and refresh us both from the simmering SG heat.<br><br>For a lunchtime haunt Sarnies is highly recommended. Just be ready for the queues and the no-available-tables blues! (You snooze you lose!)

Tandoori Chicken Sarnie', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Tandoori Chicken Sarnie'}]
text: I came here at 11am for lunch on a weekday and the service was very fast! Ordered, paid, sat down at a table and my sandwich came out within a few minutes. <br><br>I ordered the Tandoori Chicken Sandwich and it was very delicious. The bread was nice and soft, with a rougher crust. The chicken was very tasty and the yogurt dressing tasted like the yogurt from Indian restaurants. <br><br>Overall the sandwich read really tasty. I can only comment on coming for lunch before the crowd, but it&#39;s perfect at this time and I would definitely come back. <br><br>My foodie coworker says the Grass Fed Steak sandwich was really good, so I will try that one next time.

Pesto salad without the bread', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Pesto salad without the bread'}]
text: Did a take away for lunch and dinner, so I got the aubergine and hummus sandwich for lunch and pesto chicken salad for dinner.<br><br>The lunch crowd was still strong at 2pm so I ordered and came back to collect. Staff remembers faces so you don&#39;t have to keep your receipt, very convenient for people in a hurry.<br><br>The aubergine and hummus sandwich had a generous spread of hummus on both side of the bread, and the aubergine was cooked until soft and tender. Overall the sandwich was huge and tasty, I could have this everyday if I were a vegan.<br><br>The pesto salad was even better. Maybe I just needed some meat! The chicken breast was nicely cooked and mixed with the pesto dressing so it was not dry at all. The mixed greens inside was coated with olive oil which we&#39;ll complemented the pesto dressing. Definitely a big portion that can fill you as a meal!

Thai disco spaghetti - chili, beef, basil', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Thai disco spaghetti - chili, beef, basil'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/e2Ohu9mv7dNN4q6KvQ7vmw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/sarnies-singapore?reviewid=M1RsnnNp9Pw5hP_ZI6fSBQ&select=e2Ohu9mv7dNN4q6KvQ7vmw', 'altText': 'Photo of Sarnies - Singapore, Singapore. aglio olio', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'aglio olio'}]
text: I really wanted to like this cute hole-in-the-wall gem with the whole package of dim lighting, exposed kitchen, cute decor, large tables...but it was unfortunately quite subpar for dinner, at least. If I come here again (though I probably will not), id just get coffee &amp; hang out here! <br><br>Seating is limited as mentioned in other Yelp reviews with 2 longer benches &amp; tables seating 6 ppl, and a few more tables for 2. Service was friendly, and the iced latte ($5) I ordered was good!! It had a strong espresso taste, the way I like it. <br><br>The food unfortunately was lacklustre. We ordered 2 Thai disco spaghetti &amp; 2 aglio olio. I expected a fusion dish of Thai basil beef with pasta but unfortunately it wasn&#39;t great. The texture of the spaghetti was kind of rubbery, and perhaps another type of pasta would be better suited to enhance the taste more. The beef was the sort of minced beef in bolognese, and was quite salty. The spiciness and vaguely tom-yum taste was there, but that was all. <br>From trying my friend&#39;s portion, the aglio olio seemed pretty solid and garlicky with a generous serving of prawns, so perhaps it&#39;s the better choice. Another table ordered the satay chicken and it was three sizable slabs of grilled chicken (with no sides though). <br><br>We also tried to use the Entertainer 1 for 1 app for main courses, and they only allowed 1 use of it I.e only 1 dish was free for the 4 of us (not 2 dishes).

text: The food is good, but you better confirm the prices before ordering. Today they had a list of lunch specials - 3 salads at $16, and a Chef Special. As these items were advertised in the same side of the wall - weekly lunch specials - and there is no price for the Chef Special, I asumed it was also $16. The price was $19 - written nowhere - and they have no paper or iPad menus. And when you ask why there is a price difference they tell you oh this item is $19, no apologizes. The customer is expected to guess and agree with the price. <br>I did not appreciate this experience.

text: Phenomenal cafe &amp; coffee shop in the heart of Telok Ayer. <br>And in a country where pleasant service is often lacking (sorry SG, I still love ya) the staff here is ALWAYS pleasant, happy, and up for a fun conversation. Love this spot. <br>Oh, and they play great music on the regular.

text: Sarnies is a small coffee shop next to a relatively busy road. The coffee is excellent, and all drinks are made with real foods (eg the ginger ale is made with real ginger). The staff are polite and quick, and the coffee art is excellent. The food and drinks menu are full of variety and can bend to any taste. However, it is small, and you can easily walk straight past it. Heck, we almost did. Inside, it&#39;s a bit dim in terms of lighting, and it&#39;s a bit cramped so it&#39;s best to sit outside. The seating is a bit uncomfortable, but is easy to sit in long enough that it shouldn&#39;t be too much of a problem. A pretty good spot for a quick coffee, but probably not best to stay for a long time. Smokers will sometimes smoke near the area, but it doesn&#39;t happen often. Definitely recommend it.

text: This place is without a doubt one of the best brunch places in Singapore. The cafe has a really small and cozy indoor dining area which can be a little claustrophobic at their peak period. But fret not, their outdoor dining area is pretty spacious and being located along Telok Ayer Street, you get to appreciate the well-restored, heritage shop-houses that lined the street as your dining view.<br><br>When I&#39;m there, I get my usual Bacon &amp; Egg Sarnie with Tomato Relish with an add-on of Avocado! The combination of all that is just heavenly (I am even thinking about it right now as I&#39;m typing this!). The serving is really generous; if you&#39;re a female, you could easily share it with another girlfriend of yours. Some of the other recommended dishes will be the Either the Homemade Granola or Pancakes with Berries, Honey and Greek Yoghurt.<br><br>And before I forget, their coffee is fantastic too so don&#39;t missed that out! I&#39;m can&#39;t wait to go back there again for brunch already. x
Great coffee and friendly crew. Coffee here never disappoints. Plus in the evenings they serve cocktails. Nice range of healthy dishes and gluten-free ones too!

Great place for brunch....if it was raining. <br>Suuuuper small location but I gotta admit I love the food. To start, they know how to cook BACON!!! Which is FRIGGIN RARE! <br><br>They big breakfast or whatever they call it was a awesome plate of food. Prices are crazy high but at least portions can claim to justify it. They serve a good cup of coffee and overall is a great place for a nice brunch or brekkie. <br><br>The place is so small you most likely won&#39;t get a seat if you came in a group of three or more. Prices are no joke so make sure you already got this month&#39;s pay in the bank before you head down there!

text: Ever since i moved to telok ayer for work, I notice there is always a lot of people enjoying their coffee outside Sarnies when I walk to work in the morning.  Putting aside the question of why so many people can have a sit-down breakfast during normal working hours on a weekday, I am curious about Sarnies&#39; breakfast offerings. I have allowed my curiosity to build up until one morning last week when I found myself particularly free and decided to venture inside Sarnies.<br><br>As i pushed the door and stepped in, I seem to have walked from Telok Ayer to England, perhaps some cute little cafe in East London. I could not help notice that the overwhelming majority of the clientele is angmoh and just a second ago, I was surrounded by the laughter of uncles enjoying their kopi at the kopitiam next door so wow! that was a bit unexpected.<br><br>The set up is simple, there is a huge counter where you order and get your food and drinks and then a few tables and chairs against the wall and filling up the rest of the limited space.  A lot of people seem to opt for the outdoor seats which is a pretty good spot for people watching on the busy strip of telok ayer.  <br><br>Having quickly scanned the menu on the board, I decided to get the salmon cream cheese bagel since I have not had a bagel for a while (actually never in Singapore to be accurate).  I was a bit disappointed that I could not choose the type of bagel. It is definitely not cheap, my bagel came at a cost of almost S$10 and with a flat white that brings the total damage to 14. I mean, to be fair, the bagel is huge and if you are willing to pay 10 for a sandwich in the cbd this is acceptable but still, $14 for breakfast seems a bit on the high side.  I opted to bring my bagel back to the office since the place is too packed.  Delighted to find that they have taken the time to wrap my bagel up in foil so by the time I sat down at my desk and opened the wrapping, it&#39;s still nice and warm.  The bagel itself is pretty good, soft and smooth cream cheese that blends well with the salmon and the portion is quite generous.  I really enjoyed it so quality wise I cannot complain. I heard their brunch menu is pretty good so will come back and try.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=Z9z67ChosXkTjjNAtFmN7w', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1BDUer6OnYbzsh94E8acHw/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1BDUer6OnYbzsh94E8acHw/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1BDUer6OnYbzsh94E8acHw/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1BDUer6OnYbzsh94E8acHw/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1BDUer6OnYbzsh94E8acHw/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/1BDUer6OnYbzsh94E8acHw/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Anastasia P.', 'displayLocation': 'London, United Kingdom', 'altText': 'Anastasia P.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=Z9z67ChosXkTjjNAtFmN7w', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 7, 'photoCount': 1, 'reviewCount': 60, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I have some mixed feelings about this place.<br><br>The cafe is in a prime spot of telok ayer, a cute little street with loads of character and just an overall pleasant part of SG.<br><br>The outdoor seating is definitely preferable, as it can get VERY cramped inside.<br><br>Food: the food is good, but I think it&#39;s definitely too pricey for what it is. I have tried both the Caesar salad (good yoghurty dressing with some herbs) and the Halloumi salad (too salty!) here, and I have heard the bread is great too.  The Caesar portion is large but I still do not think it is worth the price, unless you&#39;re itching to spend $15-$17 for a salad! <br><br>My main concern with this place is that the last time I ate here (had the Halloumi salad), I got food poisoning!  Regardless of their fancy spins on salads, I don&#39;t think I will risk it again and definitely not for the exorbitant cost!

Always decent coffee. But the thing though, is this; you hire young hipster wannabes that make eye contact upon you walking up to the counter and don&#39;t follow up with taking an order. Apparently it&#39;s cool to be snobbish. This was on a lazy weekday evening with a thinning crowd and not much going on. Stood there for almost 4 minutes. Just me. No one else. <br><br>Looks like my friendly smile was too much and too uncool for these punk ass kids. <br><br>I&#39;ll take my business elsewhere, thank you very much. I hear &#34;FREE THE ROBOT&#34; makes decent coffee around the corner. I work around here and tend to drink a lot of coffee. Wait up for a review.

Came here after work on a mission to fulfill a sudden craving for Caesar salad, and... Missed the day menu by 2 hours (I was there at 6). But the dessert special (churros) convinced me to stay. It&#39;s one of those treats that are so difficult to find in Singapore that I always jump at the chance to try some whenever the opportunity arises, although previous attempts have been somewhat dismal.<br><br>Churros took a bit long to arrive (from my seat facing the kitchen, it seemed as though this applied to all the food in general) but exceeded my expectations. For just $8 (disclaimer: I consider any reasonably-sized dessert priced below $25 affordable.... Unless its just a slice of cake), I got 5 large sticks of churros. These were nice and crisp on the outside and perfectly moist within, substantial but not too dense. It came with a generous cup of chocolate sauce for dipping in, and some salt at the side. Tip: dip the churros in the chocolate, then dab on a bit of salt. The interplay between the sweet and savory flavours when you do that makes the dessert so much more interesting!<br><br>Appreciated the service, I was there alone and the staff went out of their way to make me feel welcome, by engaging me in polite conversation and constantly checking if there was something else I needed (and sharing their thoughts about the churros!) Although the cafe was getting crowded, not once did I feel like I was being rushed to complete my meal.<br><br>Will return soon for the sarnies and that elusive Caesar salad!

text: Had the matcha and regular brownies which are both very tasty, though they are on the sweeter side. The cafe is quite small, but pretty cozy. There are also ample seats outdoors which is great for those who want a little more space to breathe. Will definitely go back to try their brunch items.

text: Yum! We arrived here just before they closed in between lunch and dinner. Though I only had the yogurt, fruit and muesli I was happy with the quality and coffee and enjoyed a few bites of my fellow diners sandwich. Good for a quick lunch.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=MTQAGVEdfXjvFRPwsqvnlQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/rVCG0eh2p3R6rPX57-ijGw/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/rVCG0eh2p3R6rPX57-ijGw/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/rVCG0eh2p3R6rPX57-ijGw/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/rVCG0eh2p3R6rPX57-ijGw/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/rVCG0eh2p3R6rPX57-ijGw/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/rVCG0eh2p3R6rPX57-ijGw/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Claire H.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Claire H.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=MTQAGVEdfXjvFRPwsqvnlQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 19, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 52, 'eliteYear': None}
text: A very Australian reminiscent spot not just in name, but in coffee and sarnies (sambos, sammies, sandwiches.... whatever you want to call it) too. <br><br>The sandwiches are MASSIVE with each bread slice the equivalent of 3 normal slices of bread I estimated. Hence the $12-15 price tag. I recommend sharing a sandwich and having heard rave reviews about the brownie, sharing a sweet &#39;something-something&#39; too. <br><br>My roast chicken sandwich was yummy, with LOTS of chicken. I wish the guacamole was a bit more chunky than thinly spread, but hey you win some you lose some. The chicken schnitz and also the ham sarnies looked appealing. Soups and salads too.<br><br>My flat white was pretty damn good. $5 a pop. <br><br>Have to walk kind of through the kitchen to get to the toilets, which is a bit naff, but it&#39;s a small shop... service is fast and friendly. <br><br>I&#39;ll definitely go back if I&#39;m craving a blemmin good sandwich or carbo loading for a marathon (who am I kidding, only the former).

It was my first time at Sarnies and it certainly lived up to the high praise from my friend. I ordered the bacon, eggs and tomato relish breakfast sarnie and a white coffee. Everything is made in-house including the bread, roasting of coffee beans, relish, bacon etc. <br><br>The sandwich came and it was humongous!!! I was a little worried I won&#39;t be able to finish it but when I took one bite, I knew I&#39;d finish the whole thing (and I did!). The sarnie was AMAZE-BALLS! The bread was crispy on the outside and light and fluffy on the inside. The bacon...oh my word...the bacon was all kinds of yummy! It was crispy without being oily and was sweet &amp; savory at the same time. Best. Bacon. Ever. The tomato relish brought the whole sarnie together. <br><br>The white coffee was delicious. It packed a flavor punch without having the typical bitter aftertaste of coffee.  <br><br>All in all, what a great food experience! My friend raved about the pesto. I can&#39;t wait to go back and try that!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=k4B4gZFiZscBR9yFFUsc6Q', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/N9odUC2l-kWNjHWp_YyhyA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Zhi Hao Y.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Zhi Hao Y.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=k4B4gZFiZscBR9yFFUsc6Q', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 2, 'photoCount': 180, 'reviewCount': 178, 'eliteYear': None}
photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9wGlzNwE_KtUNNtTbG2BpA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/sarnies-singapore?reviewid=MlSbUye3KW_zIK260xrLCw&select=9wGlzNwE_KtUNNtTbG2BpA', 'altText': 'Photo of Sarnies - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: This is a great sandwich joint (serves other foods as well) that serves awesome and wholesome sandwiches with fresh ingredients and most importantly at very affordable prices. My favourite has got to be the steak because they added mustard and makes the meal so tangy and yummy especially with my favourite mushrooms too.<br>Moving on to desserts, the brown little square of brownie is my favourite as it is so chewy and full of flavour, and they sized it just right so you would not get sick of the cake after awhile. Best of all it is not too sweet, just the right amount of chocolate and sweetness.<br>Overall i think they sell value for money food with the right portion and price. Very good choice for a good dinner.
My favorite place in the area, hands down. Nice outdoor seating, very chill. Has alcohol, food, coffee, sandwich. Very good for groups with different preferences! And such friendly folk :))))

I love Sarnies. The bread is great, the sandwiches are huge, the salads are substantial, the breakfast is spot-on. The only thing I don&#39;t love is the (slightly) expensive nature of the dishes...$20+  for a brunch entree? Sigh... But I can&#39;t knock off a star for this because I still keep coming back. The food delivers, and the service is way above-par for Singapore, especially for a casual spot.<br><br>My favorites include:<br>- Pesto chicken salad (I have this for lunch on a weekly basis)<br>- Brunch muesli bowl with yogurt and honey (it is to DIE for)<br>- Steak sandwich (or any of the sandwiches, really)<br><br>The Sarnies folk have also been kind enough to put together a hodgepodge of side dishes into one breakfast entree for me: scrambled eggs, sliced tomato, grilled mushrooms, avocado, and the fabulous Sarnies toasted bread. Best breakfast I&#39;ve had in a long while.

First time here, but no photo can be post, because the experience here was not so nice. Ordered breakfast..... 2 sunny side up eggs, bacon, sausage and mushrooms. Eggs were over cook and become tough, bacon was dry and too salty. Then coffee was low end one. Sorry I would not recommend to my friends

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=6sRkV6dUa2TigWeVi4P9FQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/izGN81PKD8__T8Px5fwVPQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/izGN81PKD8__T8Px5fwVPQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/izGN81PKD8__T8Px5fwVPQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/izGN81PKD8__T8Px5fwVPQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/izGN81PKD8__T8Px5fwVPQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/izGN81PKD8__T8Px5fwVPQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Sharon L.', 'displayLocation': 'Yio Chu Kang, Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Sharon L.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=6sRkV6dUa2TigWeVi4P9FQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 1, 'photoCount': 4, 'reviewCount': 42, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Interesting place. Quite a short food menu but it has wonderful atmosphere. Aussie joint

I&#39;ve been to Sarnies now, and with my office just around the corner, I&#39;ll probably be back a few more times. <br><br>Prices a little steep. A sandwich or salad ranges from about $13-$15, and an iced tea is a staggering $7. That said, the sandwiches and salads that I&#39;ve had have been HUGE. Like, too big to put in your mouth HUGE for the sandwich (yeah that&#39;s what she said) and I was surprised I was STILL EATING HUGE for the salad. <br><br>So I&#39;ve seen the steak sandwich, the roast chicken sandwich, and the chicken pesto salad first hand, and they&#39;re all huge. A main in and of themselves huge. Worth the price? Ehmmmmm close. Portions wise definitely, quality wise really on the border definitely.<br><br>I highly recommend the pesto chicken salad. Chicken pesto salad. Whatever. There&#39;re mushrooms, pesto, TONS of chicken, plenty of greens, cherry tomatoes, and a big slab of bread. You&#39;ll notice I&#39;ve been using a lot of capitalisation in this review. Portions here just FEEL LIKE THAT. IN YOUR FACE. <br><br>As for their $7 iced teas, it&#39;s pricey, but they are quite delicious. The green tea with honey and ginger, the orange with cinnamon are both subtly flavoured and very thirst-quenching. Okay, a little wallet hurting, but I like iced tea so I&#39;ve usually been able to convince myself that it&#39;s worth it. (It&#39;s not, not really... I&#39;m really good at lying to myself.)<br><br>The coffee&#39;s decent, but the staff. The staff are friendly, and really cool. They really try to engage you, they make sure to smile, and it really feels like they&#39;re having fun as they work through the lunch crush. <br><br>So if you&#39;re in the area and a little stumped for what to eat, I&#39;d give Sarnies a try. They&#39;re a little pricey, but it&#39;s a very very pleasant experience.
Fresh food with good portions meant that as a work lunch spot Sarnies excelled. <br><br>I will definitely be back, there are so many yummy things on the menu

Sarnies was recommended by many friends before i eventually went to it. I wasn&#39;t wowed. The best friend&#39;s soba salad was really jnsubstantial, mangoes were sour and. I&#39;m not too. Sure how it could constitue a hearty salad. My greek salad was mot well spun resulting in alot of water in the bowl, making the vegetable soggy and unpleasant. However, the service was commendable. We reflected the problems, and they were taken back, and replaced. We even had a free muffin on the house with a staff checking if the replacement was okay.<br>Perhaps it wasn&#39;t a good day that we had visited since most items sold out by the time we reached there. It does have alot potential though, and i would try it again if i were in the area.

text: ZOMG. How did I not know that Yelp had hit the shores of Singers? Well, this can only mean one thing -- I&#39;m returning with a vengeance!!!! <br><br>To commemorate, today&#39;s lunch choice gets a bit of Yelp love... if only because I&#39;m currently wired from the espresso and happily chomping down on my chicken pesto salad from Sarnie&#39;s. Just take it as I&#39;m in a good mood. <br><br>This cozy little shop is a reliable lunch spot -- with classic salads and sandwiches to get your mid-day fix. The bread is addictively good so don&#39;t complain when your sandwiches come with massive slabs -- you&#39;ll thank them, I promise. Oh, they make their own coffee blend -- so a perfect caffeine fix for the sleep-deprived. <br><br>Staff is friendly so even when it gets busy, you never seem to mind. The steady stream of expat regulars seems to attest to this. I&#39;m fast becoming one of them.

text: Sarnies is a cute sandwich shop along Telok Ayer Street. Since opening almost a year ago, the place has really grown and has a strong following with the office crowd around the neighborhood, most of whom are expats. They serve great breakfasts here. Try their homemade muesli with vanilla yogurt. The yogurt is super yummy and made with real vanilla pods. <br><br>Lunch can get pretty crowded here and they have a variety of sandwiches served on brown or white bread. They even sell alcohol here and after work, they serve some bar food like quesadillas They also recently started serving brunch during the weekends, which I have yet to try. Staff here is super friendly as well, and really get to know the customers.
Recommended to me by a mate, had a roast chicken salad with guacamole and was very impressed. Will definitely be returning. Great coffee as well and near my office. Win

text: i would eat the roast chicken sandwich again... and again. comes with the crispy house-cured bacon, flavourful chicken and a darn good bread. (rustic white and good solid bite)

text: This branch is located in Bugis Junction near the Hotel Intercontinental. I&#39;ve tried to patronize this place for the pass 3 occasions but always has to wait. Today I was there with my son and a friend. Perhaps they brought me luck. Even though the place is air conditioned it can be quite warm because of the glass ceiling letting the sun in. On a cooler day this place is great. Seats are comfy and the dessert looks good. <br><br>My son had the Caramella Mixed Fruit Crepes and Raspberry milk shake. I had the cold brew <br>coffee and my friend ordered the Dome Surprise. All these taste good! I liked the coffee and the Dome Surprise. The milkshake is a bit too sweet for me and my boy. <br><br>The staff is available when you summoned them. They have 3 to tend to the whole place on a Sunday afternoon and yes they forgot my cold brew and milkshake. Had to remind them. <br><br>Other than that it&#39;s been good to escape the crowd of the shopping area. Will try again when it&#39;s not so warm, maybe at night.

text: First time here, recommended by some shop around when I ask for a place with good coffee......  Well the environment was quite nice,  with some smooth music. Quite relaxing here. Good place to chill or relax. The coffee was OK. But is quite pricey with the taste and quality of the coffee they provided.  Ordered a brew black coffee. Next time will try others.

text: The service was quick, but coffee was really average, and the latte was more like a cappuccino, and it was extremely weak. The &#34;Chocolate of Wealth Frappé&#34; sounded like it had no coffee, with the description &#34;for those who can resist our coffee&#34;, but there was an EXTREMELY strong taste that tasted like coffee, or super bitter chocolate, and i think the staff believed that a few centimetres of cream can balance out the big glass of bitter chocolate. They are out of their mind. It was more a crappé than a frappé. They focused on making the food and drink look fancy to make the price more expensive, and don&#39;t focus on taste, so your paying more for a good looking drink that tastes different to what is described. The only reason this is two stars instead of one is the fact that the service wad quick and atmosphere was nice, with jazzy music in the background. I would not recommend coming here for a drink or meal.

text: If you don&#39;t need aircon, this is a nice place for coffee. It&#39;s quiet and not crowded. It&#39;s a covered outdoor place and has nice setting with sofa and tables. It serves gourmet coffees, desserts and light meals. I tried Sumatra Mandheling coffee and pumpkin cheese cake. The coffee is not bad and the cake is ok. The only thing is that it&#39;s a little bit pricy if you compare it with Starbucks, but you get nice environment there. Service fee and GST are charged.

Located near one of the entrance of Bugis Junction. When I was here the traffics isn&#39;t high. But I do think is very under staff for this outlet.<br><br>The whole experience is not that great, it take them about 15mins to come to us to take out order. For 2 drinks we waited for more than 20mins. <br><br>The drinks are fine, but I will try to avoid here as possible in the future.

Seafood Aglio Olio ($23.5 exc tax/$27.66 inc tax)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Seafood Aglio Olio ($23.5 exc tax/$27.66 inc tax)'}]
text: This is right opposite to National Library and easy to find as it is facing to the road. <br>I only tried one main meal which is Seafood Alio Olio. <br>Generally speaking, oil pasta can be either good or too oily -not a middle. <br>This one consider quite good oil pasta among the others that I&#39;ve tried so far. <br>It can be &#39;slightly spicy but well harmonized with oily food.

After grabbing a bite over at Tiong Bahru, we wandered around the neighborhood a bit and ended up at Plain Vanilla Bakery. It was a nice place to stop and hop out of the rain for a little bit. The front is open-air with artificial turf that kids can (and do) run around on a little bit; there&#39;s also an ice cream cart that you can get indulge yourself at (with the help of a barista from inside the shop). Inside, the ordering area is lined with lots of different bites, especially cupcakes. The enclosed seating area is to the left of the outside area; we didn&#39;t actually make our way in there as we wanted to enjoy the (mild) relief that the rain brought. We didn&#39;t have to wait too long for our drinks, and they were both solid - mine was a very refreshing agave lemonade that I housed in about a minutes&#39; time; my wife went with a fruity iced tea that was still quite unsweetened and was a much more subtle flavor. We did grab a brownie to share as well; while the texture was a tad chalkier than I like, I did like the faint hint of fruit (think it was blackberry, or something similar) that was baked into it.<br><br>While it&#39;s a tad out of the way, Plain Vanilla is on a street that has a few other hipster-y shops as well, and it&#39;s a solid place to grab a brew (or another beverage) and relax/work.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5z8x63IEId6UeMXwaV7faQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/plain-vanilla-bakery-singapore-2?reviewid=ZvGlsPdYSLt4tiAyFoFeQw&select=5z8x63IEId6UeMXwaV7faQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Plain Vanilla Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: This marble loaf cake was absolutely amazing! As always, I needed something to satisfy my cravings for sweets and stumbled upon this little gem. The collection of pastries and small cupcakes are so aesthetic, and they also serve drinks as well. The worker was very friendly and patient with my indecisive self as I decided what to get. After deciding and paying, I brought my cake over to their sitting area which is calm, serene, and perfect for just relaxing and reading a book! The cake was moist, yet not too dense, and the chocolate flavor was not too overwhelming. The icing on the cake wasn&#39;t too sweet either. It was a perfect combo and definitely satisfied my cravings for chocolate. Check out this little gem if you&#39;re in the area, it deserves some recognition!

text: Bought a dozen cupcakes to go.<br>They are definitely pretty but to be honest they are very plain tasting.<br>The red velvet was okay, the cream cheese wasn&#39;t too sweet, the cake itself was moist.<br>The dark chocolate cupcake had crunchy little bits in there, so it was a very interesting bite. It is also not very sweet, or gerlat tasting which was good since I had this right after dinner.<br>The cinnamon cupcake frosting tasted very doughy and again very moist.<br><br>The cupcakes are reasonably big and you definitely cut them up to share

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/UdJPCbcbsJmh0p3A7qSeNg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/plain-vanilla-bakery-singapore-2?reviewid=AV8kL4JlAd36eQkfEkIYFg&select=UdJPCbcbsJmh0p3A7qSeNg', 'altText': 'Photo of Plain Vanilla Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/12w7nkLcCpG9qY26e-6OIg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/plain-vanilla-bakery-singapore-2?reviewid=AV8kL4JlAd36eQkfEkIYFg&select=12w7nkLcCpG9qY26e-6OIg', 'altText': 'Photo of Plain Vanilla Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Love the looks of this place :) and once you see their cakes and cupcakes, you would fall in love with this place. Open kitchen for you to look at how all the sweet delights are prepared. They are shelves of kitchen items and cookbooks for sale too. <br><br>No wifi, as I see this as a trend now a days... Either their are being cheap about it or maybe they use to greater-good excuse that people are suppose to socialise more rather than having their head bend down and stuck to their phones. Either way, they have a very limited sitting area - one large square table to share, one Long side seat with cushions and a Long table Infront. Ok if you are just there to get a cuppa coffee and read your papers or just enjoy a cup cake or pastry, for bigger groups of people, maybe not. <br><br>They use wooden forks and styrofoam plates (not a big fan of their plates - very Unenvironmentally friendly...) and paper cups. <br><br>Still , beautiful place to be at. I see people doing take away of their cupcakes in very large numbers. I would say that the cupcakes are pretty but fairly much on the normal side of things. Have yet to try their delicious looking cakes and pastries. <br><br>Saw a poster recently to say that they do breakfast/brunch now. Look forward to going back :)

Cupcakes!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Cupcakes!'}]
text: This place has a great setting. It was what first attracted us into stepping in. Then comes the aroma of freshly baked goods. Mmmm... A bakery cum cafe, the place is decorated in a way that allure you to instagram every single corner. They have seats in front of the bakery; even a swing if you prefer. <br><br>Step further in, you&#39;re brought to the food display! Loved the look of everything! Even the glimpse of cake pans and baking tools in their huge cupboard was instagram-worthy. Haha! Kudos to whoever the interior designer was.<br><br>They sell, tarts, cakes, brownies and etc. Even cookie and cake mixes in jars. How wonderful! But what captivated us the most were the cupcakes on display. Me being the salted caramel lover ordered 2 of those, vanilla and hazelnut chocolate ones. <br><br>Prices for the cupcakes were alright, standard. But the drinks! Blimey! $7 for a cup of lemonade? Eh?! And oh! You might as well know that they don&#39;t offer you any paper bag to stuff your cake boxes. They&#39;ll just tie them up with a string to act as a handle. Quite the hassle if you&#39;re already holding many things in hand.

text: This is perhaps the best cupcakes Singapore has to offer. No trip to Tiong Bahru is complete without a visit to this quaint little cafe tucked in a corner. My recommendation will be to try the Strawberry White Chocolate cupcake and Lavender Earl Grey cupcake.
