What a beautiful space!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'What a beautiful space!'}]
text: Tiong Bahru has fast become one of my favourite little precincts in Singapore and Plain Vanilla&#39;s cupcake shop definitely tops my list of places to dwindle away your afternoon in. <br><br>The charming entrance greets you warmly with an army of vintage aqua bikes, an open communal dining space and a glass tankard of lemon scented water (they understand the effects of humidity!) The shop itself is lined with daily specials, old favourites and row upon row of Plain Vanilla&#39;s famous cupcakes - to me, these are definitely the best cupcakes in Singapore!<br><br>They have a great texture and deviate away from being outlandishly sweet; I love that every flavour says what it means and means what it says. Must-trys are the Earl Grey and Cinnamon! The cupcakes start from $3.50 each and I usually grab a box of 6; just like the Sound of Music, they&#39;re adorably tied up with string! (A useful handle for when you&#39;re commuting with cupcakes!) <br><br>I love the ritual of hopping a few doors down to Books Actually to grab some reading material and then settling myself into a quiet corner at PV Bakery. Although the seating is limited and they don&#39;t do coffees (yet!), it&#39;s none the less a beautiful space to wind down in. Be sure to check out their mini concept store for little trinkets and gifts before you leave!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XUTZX3GZ3zCv58lFLearRw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/plain-vanilla-bakery-singapore-2?reviewid=F8zZ7O7n3oXwu0Zv5eMj6g&select=XUTZX3GZ3zCv58lFLearRw', 'altText': 'Photo of Plain Vanilla Bakery - Singapore, Singapore. Flowers', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Flowers'}]
text: If you ever had a Kinfolk Fantasy, PV Bakery is going to be more than you&#39;ve ever imagined. Picture wooden tables filled with flowers, a store front overflowing with natural light, turquoise bicycles with baskets out in the front, water jugs filled with citrus and cucumber... I could go on and on and on about how perfect everything is but lets cut to the chase. <br><br>These are one of the best, if not the best cupcakes in Singapore. Love Vanessa, love the quality of her bakes, and most importantly, love how rustic this store looks!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/jCIvkz0lczXPKCaalQIaWg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/plain-vanilla-bakery-singapore-2?reviewid=oUTZm0V4P9RgvI3K-mF0Ng&select=jCIvkz0lczXPKCaalQIaWg', 'altText': 'Photo of Plain Vanilla Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: New outpost in the new hip town, and just like before, they&#39;ve kept things simple - a super-wide counter/display,  and now a coffee machine, and a couple of benches. I love the open look to this spot, and you really get to feel the space as you walk in. You don&#39;t need that much more when all you want is to eat a cupcake, right?<br><br>The flavours are stellar as always, and I&#39;m a big fan of the dark chocolate cupcake with Varlrona chocolate nibs, maybe because I think it&#39;s the manliest cupcake there - dark chocolate, and brown, muted colours - but then again, it&#39;s just so dang delicious. And those nibs add that crunch and a touch of that bittersweet raw chocolate finish... I think I&#39;m saying too much.<br><br>In fact, every one I&#39;ve tried is tasty as heck, and with well-made classic flavour pairings like cinnamon brown sugar, strawberry white chocolate and milk chocolate banana, it&#39;s hard not to like everything you eat.<br><br>This new store in Tiong Bahru is on the same street as the massively hip bookstore BooksActually, and also picturebook mecca Woods in the Books, not to mention earlybirds 40 Hands, you&#39;ll have your weekend needs covered just wandering down this stretch.

This lovely looking little bakery and pastry shop is located on the ever popular Yong Siak Street in Tiong Bahru. The place is fairly small and the space a bit narrow but they do have some space outside, still covered by a roof so possible to use when raining as well. They actually also have a big swing there for people to play in. It is however also a lot of people who take the cupcakes and other pastries with them.<br><br>The focus seems to be cupcakes in many forms and shapes. In general not one of my favorite pastries or baked goods but here they actually make some really good ones. They are not on the fantastic side of the scale but well worth to stop by if you are in the neighborhood but would not travel out here just for this.<br><br>They also offer some beverages, would not recommend the coffee but the tea is decent as well as the cold beverages. The prices for the beverages are however a bit steep.
Best cupcakes in Singapore. Nuff said. The salted caramel and the earl grey lavendar ones are INSANELY good, and I&#39;m not even a dessert person!

Yumm yumm !!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Yumm yumm !!'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/xX2hUab9FxqBZQDgOYrmPg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/plain-vanilla-bakery-singapore-2?reviewid=Xk3hYoVaKRGZtUJgf9LikQ&select=xX2hUab9FxqBZQDgOYrmPg', 'altText': 'Photo of Plain Vanilla Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: As a pastry lover kind of guy, I do always find my way into local bakeries, patisseries and cafes wherever I go and this time it not an exception here in Singapore. Plain vanilla just attracted us from far, with it&#39;s pretty Scandinavian-European kind of concept. I love their so well done cake display as well as how beautifully made their pastries are. Prices are pretty average for this kind of place but slightly pricy  for our expectations (we spent around 25 € in coffee and cakes for two) it is definitely worth a visit while in this area of the city though. We had a red velvet cupcake (good one btw), lemon tart, flourless chocolate cake, ice latte and ginger lemonade (quite refreshing one). I would definitely come back !. As mentioned before I particularly loved the whole concept.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=UIJOUAY8hYY8QYzup6QtQg', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/v7C14MmAE3fAiin3OYgwug/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/v7C14MmAE3fAiin3OYgwug/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/v7C14MmAE3fAiin3OYgwug/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/v7C14MmAE3fAiin3OYgwug/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/v7C14MmAE3fAiin3OYgwug/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/v7C14MmAE3fAiin3OYgwug/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'May L.', 'displayLocation': 'Tiong Bahru, Singapore', 'altText': 'May L.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=UIJOUAY8hYY8QYzup6QtQg', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 49, 'photoCount': 183, 'reviewCount': 118, 'eliteYear': None}
text: This is my go-to place when I want to spend some time alone, reading a book. The space is so pretty! I mean, ok, I thought gentrification in Tiong Bahru is bad but it&#39;s not all that bad.  I love the storefront with the large square communal table where people just sit there going on about their own business.  It&#39;s not air-conditioned but usually there is a nice breeze.  It&#39;s good for people watching on weekends since a tonne of visitors come to Tiong Bahru and Yong Siak street is their no. 1 destination.  Besides, what&#39;s better than sitting there being immersed in the smell of warm butter?<br><br>I have bought their cupcakes and they are pretty good.  A whole range of flavors to choose from and not too sweet.  Besides cup cakes, they also sell cakes but I have yet to try, they all look too big for one person.  There are also other peculiar home goods on offer here, as well as cook books, which I don&#39;t think are a whole lot practical or necessary but nevertheless interesting to look at. <br><br>This is a place that leaves a memory on your senses.  As I am writing I can recall the warm breeze brushing on my skin and the aroma of sugar and butter.

Cute little bakery shop with a nicely decorated outdoor patio. We tried a couple different desserts there including cupcakes, raspberry cake, dark chocolate with filling, and a brownie. I thought the desserts were all ok, but not spectacular. The drinks were a bit expensive for what you get. <br><br>There is limited seating which consists of just one huge communal table and one high top table. This isn&#39;t a good place for groups, but a perfect place to hang out and read if the place is not busy and you can find a place to sit.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RDEHlbDH2TvBVIsSgyIjCQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/plain-vanilla-bakery-singapore-2?reviewid=sUWHJLwViysYBudJ74xlGA&select=RDEHlbDH2TvBVIsSgyIjCQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Plain Vanilla Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: A great treat to the neighbourhood. I&#39;ve followed Vanessa from Holland V to Tiong Bahru and even to some of her pop-ups. She has been consistently fabulous at her baking. <br><br>She keeps things simple and in this day and age, it&#39;s the most welcoming approach to bakeries. While her HV store is small and cosy, this is welcoming and enticing. I love the wide space and benches. The counter space allows us to stand in front and ponder. Her selection as always, spoils us like an only child in the family. I am always drawn to a salted caramel or special of the day. <br><br>A new old favourite is earl grey lavender cuppie. An old because I always had it in USA but never in Singapore. Thank you for bringing it here. <br><br>Have yet to attend her events. Plain Vanilla has a line up of events through out the month so pop over to their facebook for more details.

Only take away items and everything in paper plates. Not a Café. Bad seating. Over priced for what you get. Had a funny smell when I walked in - should have been my clue to exit. Server was very sweet.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=ntlvfPzc8eglqvk92iDIAw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/PlekFUmxtLp__6JEDYOd2A/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/PlekFUmxtLp__6JEDYOd2A/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/PlekFUmxtLp__6JEDYOd2A/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/PlekFUmxtLp__6JEDYOd2A/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/PlekFUmxtLp__6JEDYOd2A/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/PlekFUmxtLp__6JEDYOd2A/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Rafael R.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Rafael R.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=ntlvfPzc8eglqvk92iDIAw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 50, 'photoCount': 77, 'reviewCount': 562, 'eliteYear': None}
text: There is nothing plain about Plain Vanilla.  Delicious baked items as well as a small assortment of home goods and a nice covered patio makes for a nice break from the midday heat and humidity.

Great ambiance and decent coffee however we were not at all impressed with the pastries / cakes we ordered. Blueberry cake was overloaded with sugar it was all you can taste. Too bad the food wasn&#39;t better because it is a nice venue to hang out for awhile

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=YUB60ublKhL0N3sMMYh6aQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/30KnumVoXBKLm2ngM71upA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/30KnumVoXBKLm2ngM71upA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/30KnumVoXBKLm2ngM71upA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/30KnumVoXBKLm2ngM71upA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/30KnumVoXBKLm2ngM71upA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/30KnumVoXBKLm2ngM71upA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Aa S.', 'displayLocation': 'South Barrington, IL', 'altText': 'Aa S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=YUB60ublKhL0N3sMMYh6aQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 14, 'photoCount': 8, 'reviewCount': 14, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I ordered the Dark Chocolate Ganache and a Raspberry Pink Lemonade for a meal closer. Loved the lemonade. The cupcake was fine. Not a fan of the crispy texture but the cupcake could use a little moistness. I would want to try the Red Velvet next time.

This place is the bomb! They treat you so nice... not to mention the drinks and food selection are a full 360 from NYC! They have unique things like pomegranate boba tea and such cool merchandise that I&#39;ve never seen in NYC. Food selection is awesome and when you purchase a souvenir cup they give you a free drink. Wish all Starbucks in New York were half as good!

Super crowded but still. Staff were really friendly and efficient. Feels like a US Starbucks. The prices are:<br>0.69SGD to 1USD right now and a venti coffee was about $7.60, so about what you&#39;d pay in Seattle.

text: Decent local dishes, coffee and tea served in a comfortable seating at the same prices as Lau Pa Sat. Extremely friendly and helpful staff. That&#39;s their formula for success!

text: My mornings now have a new ritual: getting a Kopi-o to go from The Old Tea Hut, with the friendly and very efficient staff, for less then 2 S$. Amazing value for a strong, sweet cup that keeps me going for (nearly) the whole day :-)

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/nyfvFaC_oqkEciaQ9QQ1oQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/old-tea-hut-singapore?reviewid=ymwtf4YTIlF2vN-EOgqU5Q&select=nyfvFaC_oqkEciaQ9QQ1oQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Old Tea Hut - Singapore, Singapore. Kopi di lok siu dai (coffee straight down) - just add 20 cents to the usual dollar, and you&#39;re good ad infinitum!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': "Kopi di lok siu dai (coffee straight down) - just add 20 cents to the usual dollar, and you're good ad infinitum!"}]
text: My go-to place for my daily dose of &#39;kopi tilok siu dai&#39; &amp; ice gula melaka teh. Do not be intimidated by the ridiculously long queue because the crew is quite efficient. Though it helps with the smooth flow if you already know your order. Their default recipe tends to fall on the sweet side so I recommend to &#39;siu dai&#39; your drink especially the teh halia.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/gECJT4cpwu8fcTAlDSNJuA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/old-tea-hut-singapore?reviewid=XFe3SpOWFPrW8WFCkK9Srg&select=gECJT4cpwu8fcTAlDSNJuA', 'altText': 'Photo of Old Tea Hut - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Introduced by my lunchmate to a new tea experience at Old Tea Hut. I was not impressed from the first time I had the drink and was not a fan who buys everyday but once in a while whenever I passby the place, I will take sometime to get a cup of tea. The first reason being its huge cup size (bigger than bubble tea cup size) accompanied by the low cost.<br><br>Once, when the next time I pass by the place, I was shocked to find queues as long as 4-5meters. I hardly see queue that long and just for a cup of tea and mind you, it is not bubble tea. So why? Later I found out the more popular drinks are the  Gula Melaka Tea and Iced Honey Lime Tea

text: Nice place. Absolutely unique gula melaka tea. The tea leaves they use are of a very high quality - and it&#39;s paired with good quality gula melaka. The long queues at almost any time of the day is testament to the quality of the product here. Always ask for less sweet if not you&#39;d really be ... sugarified in no time.

Poke bowl!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Poke bowl!'}]
text: I&#39;m honestly a fan of their black pepper wagyu bowl going for $22+ , there&#39;s 10% service charge but no GST. Stray by fatcat was initially on entertainer for like Jan 2018 and after which they decided not to be part of the promo. Sad, but oh well! I guess their business is doing too well?<br><br>Their salted egg softserve is just right for me, savoury, sweet, smooth, swirled into one. Skip their calamansi dessert. $10+ for 3 chocolate shelled balls filled with calamansi juice? It&#39;s a palate cleanser that&#39;s it. <br><br>Their charcoal waffle is crisp and holds a light sweet taste with every bite.<br><br>I like their fusion dishes and though the menu looks small, each item seems to have gone through, thorough thought and care!

First impression waitress was a little irresponsive don&#39;t smile so nor exactly welcoming.   So that is a slight minus. Ordered salmon Yusheng, beef bowl and the claypot.  Now the Salmon Yusheng was not impressive as it is nothing usual though it did come in a nice bowl.   The beef bowl got to say the beef was done just right.   just a little too small.   claypot again the meat was done very well. but overall the price points are way off.   Would i be back? hmmmm.....

text: It&#39;s quit surprised by few of their dishes, all of them are really unique and great. I&#39;m a tourist so I can&#39;t really judge by their pricing, it&#39;s a little bit expensive for me. But overall 4 stars, I would love to return for more dessert

text: I happened upon this place a few weeks ago while they were still setting up for business. <br><br>I was pleased to see them open today. I ordered a Nitro Coffee and the Black Pepper Beef Bowl. Both were very nice. <br><br>The coffee was rich &amp; strong, but super smooth. Delicious. <br><br>The beef was tender &amp; tasty and the seasonings were just right. The ginger foam gave it an extra something special. <br><br>It&#39;s a soft opening with a limited menu until sometime in February. Also, they will be closed from 27-30 January for CNY

text: Interesting twist on some traditional dishes. But the menu is too short, the atmosphere too casual (tables set in a corridor of a mall!), and the dishes not good enough for people to go back on return visits. Of the dishes we tried at lunch, only the salmon Yu sheng bowl was good. The rendang carrot cake and the wagyu beef bowl were interesting, but too rich that one must struggle to finish the small serving. Only young people might go hete more than once, and prices nay be too high for many of them.

text: A cosy, decent cafe with good coffee and food. The miso waffle was an unexpected good combination with the saltiness of the miso sauce (which looks like kaya) and the sweetness of the caramelised bits and ice cream coming together in a perfect union :) it was also really a steal at it&#39;s price of $12 (excluding gst&amp;service charge)<br><br>Had the flat white ($5.50) that was smooth and slightly above average-meeting the standards of oriole coffee. The selection of drinks here is limited compared to that of Somerset&#39;s, which serves alcoholic beverages and their amazing death cream. <br><br>Overall, a nice place to get some work done or catch up with friends especially on weekdays, where it&#39;s quite quiet. Do note that the seating near the counter is quite limited and most seats are in the middle of the mall in a slightly more open area!

text: I stopped here briefly for a community meeting and only had tea, so I can&#39;t comment on the coffee or food. But I can tell you that you can still find the best sellers here (Taisho Black, Taisho MAD Milk.) Also, I really enjoyed the ambiance though I wouldn&#39;t say it&#39;s as cosy as their flagship in Somerset (that one will always be my favourite!) <br><br>However, if you&#39;re looking for a not-too-corporate cafe to meet up with someone, in a very convenient location, this one fits the bill. <br><br>I also noticed a lot of freelancers chillin&#39; with their laptops and werkin&#39; away in the open area, so this is also great for werk x 5 (just... sing the Rihanna version for me, please!)

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/pzwGLnu4qBnLmatYyW4SQw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/oriole-coffee-bar-neue?reviewid=vKdmCjIQtwr_VNqMRUnMGQ&select=pzwGLnu4qBnLmatYyW4SQw', 'altText': 'Photo of Oriole Coffee + Bar - Neue, Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/i0rlg7g321nyLTorwZ2aRg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/oriole-coffee-bar-neue?reviewid=vKdmCjIQtwr_VNqMRUnMGQ&select=i0rlg7g321nyLTorwZ2aRg', 'altText': 'Photo of Oriole Coffee + Bar - Neue, Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: The restaurant is surrounded by clothing stores, at one end of level 2. <br><br>It is rather odd, I would say. <br><br>The crabmeat spaghetti is quite a large portion, granted it costs $26 for a cafe.<br>The service is fast and the food tastes good.<br><br>The fish and chip is rather packed with spices, thus it depends on your preference. <br><br>Since Oriole is a coffee place, I find that the coffee is just okay. Again, I could be biased since I prefer a stronger and nutty flavour for coffee. <br><br>Still, it is rather crowded, almost all tables are taken for a weekday&#39;s lunch. I will come back if I am in the vicinity and need a cuppa coffee.

text: Got the coffee and pastry set for $6.<br><br>Tried the pour over, it came out in 15 seconds which raised some red flags. It was lukewarm tasted like the bottom of a Starbucks pot that had been sitting around for hours. Pastry also tasted like it was 3-5 days old, I won&#39;t go into the details. <br><br>Had the taisho white on previous visits which was not bad though. Skip the set.

text: I love being able to go to another country and still get access to a wide range of juices and other healthy fads that I buy right into!<br><br>Guac And Go could really be in any big city. As well as a range of juices they do a few guacamole dishes, a few egg dishes and some design your own salads and wraps.<br><br>Let&#39;s be honest if I lived in Singapore I&#39;d spend a lot of time (and money) at this place.<br><br>The juices took a while to get to our table, but I can only presume they&#39;re cold-pressing them on the spot? You only need a small size juice, the large is huge!<br><br>Staff were positively lovely.

text: Good ambiance cafe in Tanjong Pagar area with good Wi-Fi. I ordered the avocado milkshake which was tasty but a bit pricey. Minus one star for (lack of) value for money.

text: I discovered these folks while on a leisurely walk around Tanjong Pagar on a Sunday. If it weren&#39;t for their chalkboard sign on the main road, I would&#39;ve never known they were at Maxwell Chambers since they&#39;re located in the back.<br><br>They have a bright, happy interior, and the immediate conversation piece is their wall with painted avocados. They specialise in guacamole (though I have yet to try it!), cold pressed juices, and cold brew coffee.<br><br>Lately, I&#39;ve been sticking with the cold pressed juice as it&#39;s the phase I&#39;m going through! I really like their green juice, as it has an unexpected kick (in a good way!) Their spin on the local ABC juice (Apple Beet Carrot) is also delicious. However, as they make all juices to order, it will take time (maybe 10-15 minutes) so I don&#39;t suggest ordering it if you&#39;re in a rush.<br><br>They also offer free wifi, which just makes this place a lot more sweeter!

text: I&#39;m in Singapore on a study abroad program, but leaving for Vietnam on June 17, so this is one of the last spots I decided to hit up for Singapore! I documented my experience here: <a href="/redir?url=https%3A%2F%2Fyoutu.be%2FmgPivRg9Lag&amp;s=07cd1816ed56795a1ac2000190d9a70a42d299a942646913d192594c4dc2e7f9" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">youtu.be/mgPivRg9Lag</a><br><br>This brand new character cafe just opened up on June 7, and it&#39;s right next to the Gudetama Cafe in the Suntec City mall. There are nearby MRT stops at Esplanade and Promenade on the Circle Line, and it&#39;s pretty easy to find.<br><br>The cafe itself is super cute but kinda small, and its decor is very very pink, with a My Melody statue outside and a garden-type theme going on inside. There isn&#39;t a lot of room, but the ambiance is comfortable and there are lots of good photo ops. They don&#39;t sell toys or other Sanrio merch here, so the main thing is getting cute pictures.<br><br>Unfortunately, there was a massive queue, even though we went at 3pm on a Friday. We arrived at 3:15pm and waited until 5:15pm before we got a table. There was a staff member named Melody who did a great job communicating with those in the queue and was doing her best to keep everyone happy and entertained, and there was another staff member, Kendrick, who was doing the same and also taking pictures for customers by the statue and outside the cafe. We definitely went on a busy day, and the rest of the cafe staff were a little overwhelmed, but they did a great job keeping everything running smoothly, and were very nice and cordial.<br><br>The food exceeded our expectations for a themed cafe...after all, you usually visit these places for the theme part, not the cafe part. My friend and I both ended up ordering the same things - the Princess Bunny curry for SGD$18.90, and the strawberry yogurt parfait for SGD$16.00. It was about a 15min wait for the curry to arrive. It came with a generous serving of rice, naturally colored pink with beetroot, and the chicken in the curry was perfectly crispy on the outside and hot and delicious on the inside. It had a subtle spicy flavor and was just plain delicious. We requested the yogurt right after we tore through the curry, and it was a LOT of yogurt! The macaroon on top was a cute finishing touch, and it was super filling. It&#39;s on the sour side, kind of like Greek yogurt, and the strawberries themselves are extremely fresh, but if you&#39;re not used to the individual flavors, you may want to mix all the layers together.<br><br>Overall, you should definitely come here for both the theme and the food, but as of now, the line to get in is long, and you may end up with a one- or two-hour long wait before you sit down. The menu size does leave something to be desired; there are only a few main course options available, with no sides or snacks, and there are only three signature beverage options, two of which are sugary milkshakes that really should be considered desserts (but there are really cool and unique tea options and a nice coffee selection). Hopefully, as time passes, the initial hype crowds will shrink to a much more manageable size, the wait times will drop, and the menu will see more variety.<br><br>Glad to make this one of my last Singaporean experiences for the near future!

visited 3/4 cat cafes in Singapore and I can confidently rate this the highest.<br><br>-Great interior. This cat cafe best represents a comfy living room settings with cushions, coffee books and cats!<br><br>-There&#39;s a good mixture of local longkang cats and fancy cats. My favourite is Bella, heard she was used in Korean dramas before. Too much cuteness to handle.<br><br>-Location wise, they are located extremely near Chinatown MRT and in a shophouse.

text: This was my first visit to a cat cafe but I&#39;ve owned 2 cats for about 10 years now. Let&#39;s start with quick tips for first timers:<br><br>1. Cats are not dogs. If you keep dangling the toy and they&#39;re not taking the bait, it&#39;s not going to happen. Also, some cats are just not into petting so if you&#39;re trying to touch it and it&#39;s shying away, please stop<br><br>2. Let the cat come to you. Sit down near it, on the floor. Let them smell your hands before touching them. Respecting the cat will allow you to earn their trust the quickest.<br><br>3. MOST IMPORTANT TIP: Try to ask the employees if you can see the cats and the room before signing up for an hour. You should see if the cats are in a napping mood, or if the other patrons are interacting in a way that you can enjoy. I actually ended up leaving 10 minutes early because a pushy group of 10 people came in and started being loud and bothering the cats. Before, it was myself, and a local couple and a German couple, and we were totally fine. Check the situation before you commit! This is the single most important piece of advice I can give you for enjoying your cat cafe experience.<br><br>Alright, as for the experience itself:<br><br>PRICING: I don&#39;t think S$14 is expensive for an hour and a drink (the complimentary drink can be mineral water or coke). Think about how much it costs to raise a cat and realize some of your money goes to support causes to take care of cats<br><br>DRINKS: I got the special, a Thai Iced Tea. It was an additional $2.50 on top, but I think it was fairly priced. Was it worth it? Not really, nothing special here. The latte art for the coffee based drinks seemed decent. And for some other hot drinks, they give you a nice ceramic cover to keep your drink warm and the cat hair out.<br><br>CATS: Definitely a range of characters here. Elliot was my favorite, a long-haired softie. There are a few cats that seem like not really people cats, cats that would naturally avoid everyone. It would be great if people could not think of cat cafes as petting zoos, but as cafes that happen to have cats. So enjoy doing something else while appreciating cats while you can. Overall, there were about 7 cats when I visited but at least 3 were sleeping basically the entire time. AGAIN, CHECK THE ROOM BEFORE YOU COMMIT- if it&#39;s nap time, come back later.<br><br>INTERACTION: They do appreciate cat treats, and the staff will occasionally give people cat treats to give to cats. I think it&#39;s a good thing that you can&#39;t buy unlimited cat treats because people would ultimately overfeed the cats to get their attention. This isn&#39;t good for making $$$, but it&#39;s definitely better for the cats. Well done, management.<br><br>ROOM: Nicely decorated and ventilated, not too cold. You can hear noise from the street but it&#39;s not bad. There&#39;s a number of seats, I bet the room could seat 10 max. However, due to the distribution of cats, people will naturally concentrate in certain areas. There are plenty of cat structures.<br> <br><br>Overall, I&#39;m giving 3 stars. To be honest, it&#39;s not the fault of the management per se as to why I felt that this was a 3 star experience. Here&#39;s why: <br><br>First of all, half the cats were asleep when I came (Saturday afternoon), but I know cats sleep for over 14 hours a day, I have cats. I should have checked the room before I committed.<br><br>Second, of the cats that were awake, there were a few that just weren&#39;t really into interaction. I think it&#39;s food that the cats are sourced from bad situations, but perhaps they could select more of the cats that are proven to be forwardly-friendly. I&#39;ve met cats like this before, I know they exist. <br><br>Third and most importantly, the group that came in during my last 20 minutes. A group of 10 Chinese kids (probably college age) that were fairly loud, shoving around to take photos of the cats. I was sitting there just chilling with this cat and one of these guys started taking pictures of me with the cat and I just felt really awkward. Again, for my first half hour, I was here with a German couple and a Singaporean couple and we were all polite and respecting each others&#39; space and it was great. This really soured the experience for me and this is why I left a bit early.<br><br>OVERALL - an A-OK experience. I might swing by singapore again and visit the other cat cafe nearby Bugis and give some comparison feedback.

Great atmosphere, super clean, and their price includes a standard drink that can be topped up to cute lattes with cat foam for a few dollars more! $10 on weekdays and $15 on weekends. The cats are very shy and not all of them will like being petted but that&#39;s to be expected. Overall I thought it was a great first experience and cannot wait to visit the others around the city.

I was excited to come here but then learned on arrival that you have to pay a $14 cover charge to play with the cats.  I don&#39;t think that&#39;s the right business model.  I&#39;d be much happier to drink coffee and order food (spending significantly more than $14) than pay a cover charge. It&#39;s not a night club.

text: Purrrrfect way to relax and make some feline friends! This cat cafe has a great layout, very friendly staff, drinks, treats, and (of course) kitties! All of the cats are rescues and a portion of their profits are donated to Animal Lovers League which makes me feel even better about coming here vs other cat cafes I have been to. I highly recommend this furry find to any cat lover!

text: Great little cafe to get some coffee and do some reading or work. Wifi is great and outlets are also available, though limited to certain spots. The shop has that Pinterest/hipster/cute aesthetic to it. The staff is also very nice and responsive. A breath of fresh air from The Daily Press, a nearby cafe we went to where they didn&#39;t even acknowledge our existence.

text: Atmosphere: cute, hipster-ish, bright lighting <br>Service: decent but took awhile to receive my order. But they were nice and said goodbye when we left. <br>Pastries: almond croissant was over-baked making it a little dry. But I appreciated that it wasn&#39;t ridiculously sweet like many cafes do now and the amount of almonds too! So that&#39;s a plus. <br><br>Seating can be limited friends that people take a table for studying, laptops, etc. But there&#39;s an okay amount of seating. <br><br>Selection of pastries, pretty good. Everything is supposed to be housemade which is nice as well. <br><br>People seemed to be ordering the Swiss rolls of different flavors. Earl grey was out but matcha looked yummy. I did not order it but maybe another time if I come check it out. <br><br>Tip: there&#39;s wifi! <br>Tip2: you can order swissrolls in advance for pick up :)

text: LOCATION &amp; AMBIENCE 3/5<br>Located along Simon Road just off the junction of Simon Road, Upper Serangoon Road, and Tampines Road, opposite Stars of Kovan condominium. There are limited open car park lots (~10 lots) in front of Lola&#39;s. Else you&#39;ll have to drive further into Simon Road where there are additional open car park lots but you&#39;ll have to take a 5 minute walk over. Make sure you&#39;ll got valid parking or you might risk getting a parking fine from the parking wardens. <br><br>There are limited seating also at the cafe (~20+) especially due to the covid19 restrictions. There are also 2 outdoor seating (al fresco style) tables (from refurbished/repurposed old Singer sewing tables) which seat 4 people each, you can request for the fans above to be switched off if you find it too strong. There is also a 1 hour dining duration so patrons will have to leave after their 1 hour is up.<br><br>It&#39;s relatively quiet from opening time at 10am on weekdays but they are busiest in the evenings when there is a queue just to get a seat.<br><br>SERVICE 3.5/5<br>Hard to get service during busy periods. Sometimes also hard to find staff on low peak periods. Could be better. <br><br>FOOD &amp; DRINKS 3.5/5<br>Can be a hit and miss, depending on what you order. The bangers and mash is good, with a nice snap to the sausages and goes well with the potato mash and sauteed onion gravy. Eggs benedict was so so.<br><br>OVERALL 3.5/5<br>Overall a nice place to drop by during off peak hours/days, unless you like to hang out with the crowd during their busy periods.

text: Place was quite small. Not a lot of seating. Decor was cute. <br><br>Customer Service could be better. On a weekday around 2 pm, there were 3 servers just standing around. Not very welcoming. Tables and seats were not properly cleaned as there were crumbs on the seats and table was wet.<br><br>They did top up our water cups which was good.<br><br>Egg croissant was okay. The scrambled eggs were cooked and seasoned perfect but the croissant was flaky but too soft so eggs made it soggy.<br><br>Chocolate mint drink was not bad.<br><br>Desserts could be better. Took a while to get it - perhaps had to wait to get it from next door sister bakery. Got the hazelnut tart and the &#34;hummingbird&#34; cake which is basically just banana bread with tiny pineapple chunks in it.<br><br>Just another cafe in the area which is a nice option but nothing special.

Avocado eggs Benedict ($14) - 3 stars<br>I was a bit surprised and disappointed that there was no fresh avocado - rather it was a sort of avocado smear at the bottom of the sandwich. Taste-wise nothing spectacular.

text: Been here once and it was slightly after lunch so there wasn&#39;t much of a wait. Although I hear it can get quite long of a wait. <br><br>The atmosphere was nice, feels a little small. I feel like the tables should be slightly wider. <br><br>I had the chicken avocado salad. A whole half avocado and the chicken was okay. The dressing was a little sweet but fine. Overall a good salad. <br><br>Tip: They have an iPad booking system so you can put your name down ahead of time<br>Tip 2: it&#39;s near Kovan mrt so taking that would be better than driving as parking seems limited

text: The glut of cafes that opened in Singapore within the last year has left me in a spot of disconnectedness with the people who are actively involved in &#34;cafe-hopping&#34;. So I did some research before heading to Lola&#39;s Cafe which was suggested by Ms K. Strangely, it seems like the entire nation is heading for the brunches instead of the dinners (perhaps the fetish for egg bens has yet to subside). <br><br>One of the most tried-and-tested dishes here is the Avocado Egg Bens ($15). Nothing much astonishing about this but the excellently toasted brioche was so crunchy and ideal for mopping up the mixture of runny egg and sweet salad dressing that collected on the plate.The Honey and Paprika Wings ($10)  were indeed so popular that customers who couldn&#39;t snap a seat, were ordering it for takeaway. Juicy and sweet, these chickens would definitely be even satisfying with more spice. <br><br>The dark chocolate tart with coffee cream ($5) could be the best bet out of the three sweets we&#39;ve had. Speckles of sea salt tempered the bittersweet cacao ganache within a thin chocolate tart shell, though I couldn&#39;t recall tasting baileys or espresso in the cream. Meanwhile, I failed to comprehend an Earl Grey Tart ($5) whose filling resembles mudflow. Not sure if it was intended to be of such loose consistency or to be curd-like as those of lemon meringue tarts. The Black Tea Prune Brownie with Vanilla ice cream ($7) might not win brownie points on its looks but the clever use of tea-soaked prunes injected another dimension of sweetness to an otherwise archetypical baked chocolate cake.

text: For those of you living in Kovan, you got lucky! Lola&#39;s Café has only been around for about 3 months, it surely added more liveliness to the area. This vintage café is also easily accessible - it takes you less than 5 minutes to walk from Kovan MRT (the exit opposite Heartland Mall).<br><br>This café is set up by 2 young entrepreneurs, Choo Kiat and June. Besides being the boss, Choo Kiat is the chef cum barista. On the other hand, June is responsible for the pastries that you see in the café. By the way, &#39;Lola&#39; is actually June&#39;s middle name.<br><br>This small and quaint café is filled with a variety of vintage furniture and mood lightings. I was particularly attracted to their tables - they are all made from our traditional sewing machines! Furthermore, most of the vintage furniture here are for sale - Do check them out if you&#39;ll like to add a bit of character to your room! <br><br>The most unique part of the cafe is their beer menu consists of a good variety of carefully drafted beers from boutique breweries in US, UK and Belgium. <br><br>I went for their Matcha Latte which costs $5.00. The latte was pretty smooth and had a sweet aftertaste. It&#39;s a little sweeter over here compared to other cafes, you might want to ask for less sugar. I also tried their Banana Earl Grey Tart ($4.00) which is one of their specialties. It&#39;s topped with a layer of sugar and pistachio nuts which tastes very crunchy. The Earl Grey paste was a little too moist though.<br><br>My favourite was their Wasabi White Chocolate Mousse ($7.00). Never would I have expected wasabi to go well with white chocolate! An exotic mix of ingredients, it&#39;s a surprising recipe and very delicious! Don&#39;t worry about the spiciness of the wasabi; it&#39;s very gentle and not too overwhelming. The sweetness of the white chocolate complements the overall taste and it melts in your mouth! It&#39;s so unique I can&#39;t describe it with words. You have to try it for yourself!<br><br>Lola&#39;s cafe is very conducive for reading and for studying. You could also reward yourselves with some savoury desserts while working your brain cells! It&#39;s also a good place to hang out with your friends in the late evenings over some beer and honey wings. Service was great, staff were all very friendly. I will certainly come back again to try out their brunch and beers!<br><br>P.S: This cafe is free of GST and Service Charge!

text: The salad was great! +$3 for grilled chicken is definitely worth it! 7/10 the Chai tea latte however has a very strong over powering cinnamon taste, if you don&#39;t like cinnamon, do not order! Truffle fries taste 6/10 not the best I&#39;ve tasted but quite a generous serving! Braised pork (dinner menu) is great too! Very generous with the meat serving! Earl grey banana cake is perfect for people that doesn&#39;t like cakes that are too sweet! have bites of banana pieces in there which is a bonus! Overall great cafe!

Quality was worth the money. However, taste was lacking the punch and resulted in unsatisfactory meal. Both types of pasta were soaked in sauce although the serving was very generous. Definitely recommend their nachos fries and pulled pork burger, they were SUPER DELICIOUS!! I love what they have done with the buns. Unlike the usual toasted, it&#39;s baked until shiny golden brown. I was sold for its&#39; presentation. Thumb down for the chocolate tart though, it wasn&#39;t the ending I had hope to have. It&#39;s worth the first try, but not convinced to visit for the second time.

text: One of the best cafe that I&#39;ve tried so far. Downside is the waiting time ard 2 hrs or more.

Awesome place. Great food, great staff. I live right around the corner and would go all the time, but because its the best place in Kovan its always packed. Ive only eaten there a few times over the last year, cause when I want to eat, I rarely have enough time to get a table. Its very rare to see the wait time to be less than 90 mins. But if you have the time, and aren&#39;t busy, Lola&#39;s is as good as it gets in Kovan. Take away is always an option, but they have a great beer selection, so sticking around is better, if possible.

text: I do not understand why on earth do people queue up for 2 hours for this? Yes the fries are good, the wings favorable, but other than that, i didnt find anything worth going back for. The service staff were great though! Despite being shorthanded, were able to keep the queue and diners under control.

text: The glut of cafes that opened in Singapore within the last year has left me in a spot of disconnectedness with the people who are actively involved in &#34;cafe-hopping&#34;. So I did some research before heading to Lola&#39;s Cafe which was suggested by Ms K. Strangely, it seems like the entire nation is heading for the brunches instead of the dinners (perhaps the fetish for egg bens has yet to subside). <br><br>One of the most tried-and-tested dishes here is the Avocado Egg Bens ($15). Nothing much astonishing about this but the excellently toasted brioche was so crunchy and ideal for mopping up the mixture of runny egg and sweet salad dressing that collected on the plate.The Honey and Paprika Wings ($10)  were indeed so popular that customers who couldn&#39;t snap a seat, were ordering it for takeaway. Juicy and sweet, these chickens would definitely be even satisfying with more spice. <br><br>The dark chocolate tart with coffee cream ($5) could be the best bet out of the three sweets we&#39;ve had. Speckles of sea salt tempered the bittersweet cacao ganache within a thin chocolate tart shell, though I couldn&#39;t recall tasting baileys or espresso in the cream. Meanwhile, I failed to comprehend an Earl Grey Tart ($5) whose filling resembles mudflow. Not sure if it was intended to be of such loose consistency or to be curd-like as those of lemon meringue tarts. The Black Tea Prune Brownie with Vanilla ice cream ($7) might not win brownie points on its looks but the clever use of tea-soaked prunes injected another dimension of sweetness to an otherwise archetypical baked chocolate cake.

Kovan is becoming a hipper place for people living in the North East! I know we have Serangoon Gardens and all but that area is seriously too congested for my liking. Recently, the brothers and i checked out Lola&#39;s Cafe, a fairly new joint located at Simon Road, just a stone&#39;s throw away from our regular Punggol Nasi Lemak haunt (i don&#39;t like it btw). <br><br>Lola&#39;s Cafe is a cheerful cafe with a limited seating capacity. I reckon it sits about 20 to 30 pax. And they are really popular. Go early, put your booking down on the iPad booking system and be prepared to wait.<br><br>I&#39;ve heard good things about the brunch menu (available from 10am - 3pm on weekends) but i&#39;ve yet to try it. Friends that i&#39;ve sent in Lola&#39;s way enjoyed the Avocado Eggs Benedict very much. All my favorite ingredients in 1 dish, you bet i&#39;d order that next time.<br><br>We met late for supper and picked from the bites section. The Truffle fries with grated Parmesan cheese ($12) was MEH. I&#39;m a fan of soggy fries but this style is simply not compatible with truffle oil. The fries were bland and lacking in the truffle aroma.<br><br>My favorite is the Honey and Paprika Crispy Wings ($9). You have to order this! This is an order from the Tummy Ministry. I loved the light crispy batter which stayed crunchy throughout the meal. The meat was nicely marinated and went perfectly with the light touch of honey which coats it.<br><br>Their homemade desserts are apparently quite popular here but both desserts that we tried were less than satisfactory. The Dark Chocolate Sea Salt tart with Kahlua coffee cream ($5) sounded more delicious than it tasted. Filling to tart ration was off (too much tart) and the tart lacked in the butter department and was simply too crumbly (and i don&#39;t mean it in a good way). The tart tasted like one of those factory manufactured pastry shells. Meh. <br><br>Sticky Honey Apple cake with French Vanilla ice cream ($7). According to the brothers, who aren&#39;t very picky with food,  Swensen&#39;s apple crumble tastes better and i concur. <br><br>I had the Matcha green tea latte ($6) which was worse than Starbucks. It was terribly bland. Will never order this again.<br><br>I was hoping that i would be head over heels in love with Lola&#39;s Cafe but i wasn&#39;t. Hopefully their brunch will change my opinion about them. Till then.

neighborhood hipster-type cafe with pretty food and mostly decent flavors - this I would rank amongst the middling ranks of hipster joints.<br><br>is it a sign of age that I can&#39;t seem to abide bad service these days? I&#39;m not quite fastidious (but of course it&#39;s not something one just admits to), but the number of untrained staff that I&#39;ve encountered at new eating places is baffling: is it me, or is it them? this place was staffed primarily by students - young, and not quite well-trained - something I expect we&#39;ll see more often now that school&#39;s out and they make for low-cost labor, especially with these small cafes.<br><br>when you do sit down (not so implicitly implying a wait), the food is decent. it&#39;s not the best cooking, but good-enough renditions of brunchy egg dishes and fried breakfasts. the portions are reasonably-sized, too, so you won&#39;t leave hungry.<br><br>the draw of the place are their tarts - and some are really pretty good. we had the lime meringue, banana earl-grey brulee and salted chocolate tartlets (in order of increasing appeal) - tiny and adorable and thankfully tasty in fluted butter crusts.<br><br>stay away from the nutella tart though, for it had a strangely jellyish filling that tasted barely of that dark brown magic - insubstantial both in flavor and taste. I have a weakness for nutella (eataly, won&#39;t you open here please?) and so my expectations were highest for this slice, and consequently most deflated. spreading a thick layer of the spread would have sufficed, really.<br><br>in short, adequately decent and great as a neighborhood cafe - but it&#39;s not a destination worth too much effort in travel. although.. that salted chocolate tart might just about singlehandedly make a good enough point to visit.

Went back again that night as planned...<br><br>Their Iced Latte is realllllly good, and so is the lemon meringue tart. Then again, I do love all things lemon meringue.<br><br>Also, consistently good service. On Edge waiter was less on edge, so that&#39;s a plus. <br><br>:)

text: For those of you living in Kovan, you got lucky! Lola&#39;s Café has only been around for about 3 months, it surely added more liveliness to the area. This vintage café is also easily accessible - it takes you less than 5 minutes to walk from Kovan MRT (the exit opposite Heartland Mall).<br><br>This café is set up by 2 young entrepreneurs, Choo Kiat and June. Besides being the boss, Choo Kiat is the chef cum barista. On the other hand, June is responsible for the pastries that you see in the café. By the way, &#39;Lola&#39; is actually June&#39;s middle name.<br><br>This small and quaint café is filled with a variety of vintage furniture and mood lightings. I was particularly attracted to their tables - they are all made from our traditional sewing machines! Furthermore, most of the vintage furniture here are for sale - Do check them out if you&#39;ll like to add a bit of character to your room! <br><br>The most unique part of the cafe is their beer menu consists of a good variety of carefully drafted beers from boutique breweries in US, UK and Belgium. <br><br>I went for their Matcha Latte which costs $5.00. The latte was pretty smooth and had a sweet aftertaste. It&#39;s a little sweeter over here compared to other cafes, you might want to ask for less sugar. I also tried their Banana Earl Grey Tart ($4.00) which is one of their specialties. It&#39;s topped with a layer of sugar and pistachio nuts which tastes very crunchy. The Earl Grey paste was a little too moist though.<br><br>My favourite was their Wasabi White Chocolate Mousse ($7.00). Never would I have expected wasabi to go well with white chocolate! An exotic mix of ingredients, it&#39;s a surprising recipe and very delicious! Don&#39;t worry about the spiciness of the wasabi; it&#39;s very gentle and not too overwhelming. The sweetness of the white chocolate complements the overall taste and it melts in your mouth! It&#39;s so unique I can&#39;t describe it with words. You have to try it for yourself!<br><br>Lola&#39;s cafe is very conducive for reading and for studying. You could also reward yourselves with some savoury desserts while working your brain cells! It&#39;s also a good place to hang out with your friends in the late evenings over some beer and honey wings. Service was great, staff were all very friendly. I will certainly come back again to try out their brunch and beers!<br><br>P.S: This cafe is free of GST and Service Charge!

text: Toast Box makes the easiest breakfast in Tiong Bahru. The coffee and tea are very good, the eggs are consistently prepared well, and the kaya toast is alright.<br><br>Their black soy sauce and pepper is what gives Toast Box 5 stars!

text: Good, quality bread and pastries at this under-rated bakery in Kampung Glam. This very tiny bakery is slowly getting a lot of glowing reviews, especially the croissants (original and almond croissant) as well as other baked goods. Check out the small board at the counter for daily specials, they&#39;re usually sold out very quickly. <br><br>As mentioned, the bakery is extremely small, so coming in and finding a table or a seat by the side bench is like winning a lottery. If you don&#39;t mind, there&#39;s always takeaway and trust me, people just come in, grab a loaf or two and then off they go. <br><br>I had the almond croissant and it&#39;s equally as good as TB Bakery&#39;s if not better. Buttery, flaky croissant topped with almond cream and crispy almond flakes, I &#34;inhaled&#34; the entire croissant in minutes. I would return to try their other offerings - Brioche, Baguettes, and Quiches, and a variety of cakes (Lemon Cake, Banana Walnut Cake, Dark Chocolate Cake, and Fruit &amp; Nut Cake) any other time. <br><br>Trust me, I&#39;m not a bread-y bread person, and if I say i would return, it means a HUGE DEAL!

text: I was here after a late Lunch sometime back in July 2019.  I thought I have written about this establishment but after checking my YELP reviews I have NOT!  My bad!<br><br>It was about 15:20hrs ish when we went there.  Thankfully we managed to squeeze in to seat at this tiny establishment.  YES, during the Weekends, indeed I cannot deny this establishment is packed to a brim.  They only offer like about 8 seating in the Air-Conditioned Room.  Hence do plan accordingly, if you intend to have your desserts or Coffee/Tea beverage here.<br><br>My friend opt for Cappuccino and the Caramel Sticky Pudding of some kind.  I also forgot to take the picture of my Cold Beverage that afternoon.  *MY BAD &amp; SIGH*<br><br>Anyways, I do not mind returning when needed and perhaps I can make a proper review and definitely need to remember to take picture of the items I am going to have here soon.<br><br>Mother Dough is a Muslim Owned Establishment which was established sometime in May 2018.  The lovely Head Baker, her name is Naadhira Ismail.

Sticky pecan and hazelnut bun ($5.50) - 3.75 stars<br>It has the puff pastry sort of exterior, which I don&#39;t quite like - a bit too dry and hard rather than light and crisp. The interior was like a cinnamon roll but not soft and fluffy. Still a bit too dry. The pecan and hazelnut topping was a tad sweet. Not sure I&#39;d get this again.<br><br>Almond croissant ($4.30) - 3.25 stars<br>Sorry, Tiong Bahru Bakery&#39;s one is better! This was too dry for me even though it had quite a bit of filling. I liked that the filling wasn&#39;t too sweet.
Amazing pastries and bread. Friendly service. Awesome atmosphere. Definitely recommend. The croissant and almond croissant is a must try! Oh and their cappuccino too!

text: Oh my gosh this place is phenomenal. The pastries are beyond delicious and the coffee was great too. Very unique and yummy flavors. I went back here multiple times while staying in the neighborhood. If I lived near, this would definitely be my go to weekly spot.

text: A rather pleasant and quiet shop. The soup broth is utterly tasty. Recommending the miso and soya broth. Some say the soya broth is a little blander than the rest. To add Matcha ice cream ($3.90) is a worthy choice. Huge cone and very good matcha flavours. <br><br>You can have a choice of udon or Japanese rice inside the broth. We chose the rice and it may make it look like porridge. But very delicious and comforting. Matcha tea also helped us end the meal well. <br><br>Ala carte prices are around $12-13 (excluding GST and svc charge). Sets are around $16. A great place if you&#39;d like a Japanese-esque light and comforting meal for lunch without the crowds

text: Went for late lunch but nowhere on the website did it say that kitchen closed at 2:30 pm as we just missed it.<br><br>We were seated for cold cuts though. Ordered a cheese and bread platter and burrata and ham and was able to get the spaghetti and meatballs.<br><br>Meatballs were nice.<br><br>They do make their own pasta and you can have a taste of their cheese.<br><br>Nice wine selection. Great ambiance.<br><br>Pistachio Tiramisu did not look too presentable as it was liquidy but taste was good.<br><br>Service could be better as there were a lot of servers just walking around and talking to eachother but lacking in filling our water glasses and clearing plates.<br><br>This place is not bad but not necessarily anything special.

text: Service is a bit lacking here which is the absolute only reason this is only 4 stars and not 5 because the croissants are really on par with some of the best bakeries anywhere! Mo and I have had croissants and baked goods from Paris to NYC and I was pleasantly surprised by how good they were here.<br><br>*Note: Do yourself a favor and SKIP the toasties here though. While the sourdough bread itself was good. The execution of the toppings was not great and very skimpy. Attached pics for reference.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/c9cAyw1Lw-1VquDy2-Dj7Q/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore?reviewid=pCosMRhcyYjf_qT5BQKK4g&select=c9cAyw1Lw-1VquDy2-Dj7Q', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/PsLan2eL3Z1YXwos3tdEzQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore?reviewid=pCosMRhcyYjf_qT5BQKK4g&select=PsLan2eL3Z1YXwos3tdEzQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Recently the outlet had gone through a makeover. Gone was the fountain in the centre. Now the bakery had turned into a full flag cafe with table service. One did not have to find a table by ownself anymore. Just wait at the entrance and a staff will assist you to a table with the menu presented to you in a jotter book. Besides the usual pastries and drinks, the menu now also consisted of hot meals.<br><br>Ebiko Crab &amp; Prawn Toastie ($19++)<br>Cheesy crab &amp; prawns, grilled sourdough, crunchy ebiko &amp; chives. Served with a fresh sprout &amp; cress salad topped with mixed seeds.<br>The bread was quite difficult to slice through with the knife provided. In end it was sent to the kitchen to be sliced into soldiers, so one can easily eat it without using the cutlery. The crust of the slice of bread was quite hard to chew, making my jaw quite painful. The topping was quite tasty and creamy but not cheesy at all.<br><br>Rainbow Rice Bowl ($16++)<br>Brown &amp; wild rice bowl, poached NZ organic egg, spicy pineapple kimchi, purple potato chips, mixed sprouts, &amp; salsa verde<br>Topup $3++ for chicken<br>The dish was presented in a wooden bowl with a wooden spoon. It was a very colorful looking dish. The rice was moist and flavourful but a bit difficult to digest. The chicken was cooked in sous vide style, thus it looked pinkish but it was moist and tender. The pineapple kimchi was quite appetizing.<br><br>Overall the food was not bad but the standard of bread seem to have gone down a bit.

Fig and honey ice cream 3.50', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Fig and honey ice cream 3.50'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/q6d8N3PS_V_XmrvN6MUBrw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore?reviewid=3akbnindYdh-0koqwPLjGg&select=q6d8N3PS_V_XmrvN6MUBrw', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore. Taken by the flip flop tart', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Taken by the flip flop tart'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/_EYhJs4L8Xcaej_B1NCZjg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore?reviewid=3akbnindYdh-0koqwPLjGg&select=_EYhJs4L8Xcaej_B1NCZjg', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore. Honey and fig ice cream in a cup if you don&#39;t want the croissant version', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': "Honey and fig ice cream in a cup if you don't want the croissant version"}]
text: They have a modern take of the ice cream uncle peddling his $1 ice cream bread, Instead of your regular Walls or Magnolia ice cream bar tucked between two wafers or a slice of bread, Tiong Bahru Bakery does it with a petit croissant instead. <br><br>There are only two choices of ice cream. You can also request for just ice cream in a cup which was what we did. The honey and fig ice cream was delicious and at $2. it was quite a steal in the city center area. It will be $3.50 for the ice cream in the petit croissant. I hope they will retain the price for a long time. Sometimes you just want something simple and easy on the pockets. <br><br>The pastries are not bad though I find them a bit too hard for my liking. So I will stick with the ice cream over here in future.

text: Lemon tart was awesome as it tastes creamy, a bit sour but very refreshing. <br>Latte was good and smooth and the latte art on it was so beautiful

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/PThO8CuwTI6i-4T56lGNWA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore?reviewid=Cpomr81h1QXD4j2qcqov_A&select=PThO8CuwTI6i-4T56lGNWA', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore. Flat White for $5.50', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Flat White for $5.50'}]
text: Probably not my cup of coffee... (See what I did there) ahaha<br><br>Ambience was alright - casual. Good place to get together with friends or colleagues. <br><br>Had somewhat a variety of pastries/ sandwiches. They looked good but did it taste as good? I can&#39;t say. <br><br>Ordered the flat white for $5.50. Looked bitter, smelt bitter and what do you know? It was bitter - big surprise. <br>I wish they had a wider variety of drinks besides coffee i.e. Chai tea latte or hot chocolate.<br><br>On the bright side, service was fast.<br><br>Returning customer? Probably not. Definitely not worth the &#34;hype&#34;.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/QYlbnPv2eP_8xltA4bPqOw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore?reviewid=jES1n4MmVMzsZDlACeRkGw&select=QYlbnPv2eP_8xltA4bPqOw', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore. Only from 11am. Torturous for those with young children', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Only from 11am. Torturous for those with young children'}]
text: No longer a select croissant/etc and pay-at-the-cashier, it&#39;s a sit down affair with an extensive brunch and lunch menu. However, part of the draw of TBB is its early opening at 8am, and only the usual croissants etc are available from 8. The avocado toast is available from 9, and other brunch food like pancakes only from 11am. Ugh. <br><br>Still, I&#39;m not complaining, as the croissants are delicious (as ever) and they open relatively early at 8am -- no waiting about for cafes to open at 9 or 10! Grateful for that.

I recommend this place since it&#39;s convenient to get here from nearby hotels (Swiss &amp; Fairmont). But during my week long stay, I am not a fan of the overall food quality nor the overall service.<br><br>The layout is cramped and can get very loud around lunch time. Some of the seating area is caked with dust, and it stayed that way my entire trip. <br><br>The food isn&#39;t very fresh, or at least half of the time. The baked goods in particular show this. During my stay, I ordered from them a raisin bun, kouign amann, berry tarte, petit antoine, canele, paris brest. Half of those were either stale or dried out. <br><br>The service leaves more to be desired. Sometimes they&#39;re always around, and sometimes they&#39;re nowhere to be found. It takes FOREVER to get the check, so long that I regret not ordering takeout. They don&#39;t like to take dirty plates away, and instead just leave them on your table. I ordered a croque monsieur and a sunny-side-up egg on top (hence making a croque madame), and they just didn&#39;t understand the combination!! 10 minutes later, I received a salmon quiche. I tell them that&#39;s not what I ordered, and they ask &#34;would you like to keep it?&#34; Yeah No! <br><br>They have calorie bombs, such as their pancake breakfast sandwich/burger with tater tots, and yet they also have healthier alternatives, such as juices and salads. <br><br>So on the bright side, the servers &amp; manager are super friendly, and the coffee is made well. I recommend their coffees and their raisin bun. <br><br>For better quality, I recommend Gastronomia Di Paolo down the hall.

I haven&#39;t visited in a long time as the service was bad. Sad to say service has not only not improved but has deteriorated. My breakfast came first. By the time is finished my husband&#39;s breakfast still has not come. We cancelled and left. It&#39;s a shame as the food is actually quite good.

It&#39;s been too long!  I have been in this place many times over the last few years, and it never disappoints. As I remembered great coffee, and even better sweets/pastries. <br><br>If late morning on the weekends, good luck finding a seat!  Yes, it&#39;s that good... :-)

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/qpnbtzSWIAoRORLt6QaVlg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore?reviewid=1EFtYcTyqBzrcG40cBM_Zg&select=qpnbtzSWIAoRORLt6QaVlg', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore. Almond brioche and piccolo latte. $8 total', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Almond brioche and piccolo latte. $8 total'}]
text: 3.5 stars rounded up to 4.<br><br>I&#39;ve (literally) stopped by the original location, and thought to myself &#34;What is the deal with this place?! It&#39;s 10:45 AM on a Friday, I&#39;m not really near CBD, and this place is packed.&#34;<br><br>So I guess it was fate that a few months later, I&#39;d be a bit early for my Browhaus appointment, end up wandering aimlessly around Raffles City&#39;s basement level, and discover the second location of this famed bakery. <br><br>It was around 9:45 AM on a Friday, so the crowd was minimal. Ordering was easy and my coffee was delivered to my table within a reasonable time frame. <br><br>I tried the almond brioche, which was a bit dry. Overall, not mind blowing, yet pretty edible. Since I was a bit pressed for time, I ordered the piccolo latte which was absolutely adorable. It&#39;s served in an espresso shot glass thingy, complete with great latte art. I found it pricey for $5, but it tasted awesome.<br><br>Great place to have a meeting, as there&#39;s a fountain in the middle that always shoots water randomly. So if you get stuck in an awkward conversation, everyone in the table can just listen to or look at the fountain and hope that the awkwardness will eventually subside. Oh, and excellent coffee, obvs.

I missed you oh curled up round of flour.... :)'}]
text: Admittedly I only decided to come here cos this is the only place I know they sell Kouign Amann that I craved for since my return from the States. It&#39;s alright, bread stuff is fairly alright but appreciate the range of bake goods this place offers (hence the ability to find said Kouign Amann). <br><br>If you follow my check ins, I&#39;m a person who seeks out places for awesome coffee art. Though the taste of the mocha was nothing special but the art is elaborate enough for my fancy without me requesting for it. <br><br>Service staff is prompt, always willing to lend a helping hand. The manager (presumably cos he was not in uniform) tonight even offered to help get my utensils and serviettes seeing that my hands are full. His service was so awesome to a point that i thought he had only eyes for my table of 1 but in actual fact he was helping to serve the whole floor. Top notch service for a simple place.<br><br>So come here if you are a exotic bread fan or maybe want to see some cute coffee art or just wanna bask in the quality service to feel like a boss after a day of work feeling like a rat in a rat race. :D

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/C6eJNofzl4SBSrlu_mCh0A/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore?reviewid=9Q8oKwaITn1rHLn2JK0qGw&select=C6eJNofzl4SBSrlu_mCh0A', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore. One word to describe this thing: HEAVENLY.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'One word to describe this thing: HEAVENLY.'}]
text: During one of my many strolls around City Hall MRT, I saw a huge advertisement for a croissant at Tiong Bahru bakery. Something about that ad made me crave a croissant so bad. Whichever marketing agency Tiong Bahru bakery engaged with for their ads, they should retain them for life.<br><br>I walked about 100 meters and found the location nestled next to many other food options. I queued up, placed my order, and found a seat so that I could partake in this bakery item. My first bite lived up to expectations. The croissant was amazing. I cherished every morsel, and after it was over, I was so hooked that I had already made future plans to visit this place. Singapore has many bakeries on the island, but not many specialize in Western bread items. Tiong Bahru bakery gets it, and I&#39;m glad they exist. If you happen to walk by one of their locations, make sure you queue up and grab one of their many deliciously looking baked goodies.

This place is a regular stop for me. I try not to eat too many carbs but this bakery remains one of my peccadilloes. They are vying for first place for best croissants (plain, almond, chocolate-almond) in Singapore. The kouign amman is justifiably famous-- it&#39;s a buttery, carmelized, salty-sweet gooey bunch of deliciousness. Have that with a cup of the really good coffee and you&#39;ve made a damn fine start (or end!) to your day.  The baguettes are also up there at best-in-Singapore level so take one of those home with you. Most of the baked goods are delicious with the exception of the brioche which, as a previous reviewer mentioned, is dry and makes you kick yourself for not ordering the kouign amman you had your eye on to begin with. <br><br>I was in Orchard yesterday and saw a new outlet in Tang&#39;s. That makes me happy. Two suggestions for the owners:  1) please get rid of those awful pencil-legged tables at the Raffles City outlet and 2) keep it real--don&#39;t let the success go to your head!

The signature croissant (eaten up before any photos could be taken) lived up to my expectation partly because I had reheated it in my oven till the crispness I want. But I doubt it will be the same eating in the shop unless they are straight out the oven. <br> However, I think their Almond croissant with Chocolate filling (left) and Kouig Aman (right) are equally competent , if not better than its croissant if you prefer something sweet. <br><br>Both flaky and fragrant, the almond croissant was heavenly while the latter, despite its ugly appearance, was swirled with salted caramel remains my personal favourite. <br>If you don&#39;t like chocolate, do try the Plain Almond Croissant. It was consumed at room temperature but remained crispy.<br>However, some of the pastries left me in a blur. The Raisin Roll (right) was average while the Pandan Flan (Bottom Left) lacked any distinct pandan aroma or flavour and the pastry was soggy. Meanwhile, The Rapsberry Crumble (Top Left) was underbaked resulting in a slightly chewy lacklustre pastry and the crumble toppings were too little.  <br><br>Just as I thought there would be no new items anymore, it&#39;s Christmas specials- A Chocolate Snowball Globe tart took me by surprise. Filled with sweet milk chocolate mousse and the tangy pineapple and passionfruit compote, the chocolate ball sat on a crumbly almond tart whose sweetness was just right.<br>At the centre sits a mini delicate red balloon of salty raspberry sauce which burst open at the poke of a fork. This is not something new but still very interesting to have in local bakeries.

At Raffles City, the retail space measures three times that of Tiong Bahru&#39;s. It has a very roomy dining area with cushion sofa seats against the wall and movable wooden chairs. Dressed in a self-serviced concept, you will help yourself to a common corner with cutlery, sugar sticks, drinking glasses &amp; bottles of tap water. Facing the bustling Din Tai Fung restaurant, this bakery is no lack of patrons. Spontaneously I joined the line for my order at the counter. In the queue, you could quickly scan through the options  in the glass display. Categorized in 3 sections, sweet &amp; savory buns/breads being the first; ready-made sandwiches in the middle; cakes &amp; pastries selection the last, before reaching the cashier. Be sure to note your table number so that any beverages/food that requires time to prepare, can be delivered to you efficiently.  <br><br>It pays to be aware of the chef signature most of the time although it may not be a hit every time. Here, croissant is the trademark of Cherrier. I have seen mixed reviews on this viennoiserie bread - some find it excessively rich and buttery while others are hooked on them. I agreed with the latter, it was very good. One could tell the difference at first sight - very distinctive thick airy folds. The crust is very tenderizing and instead of being crumbly, each flake held firmly to the dough pretty well. Lesser mess on the table as a result. Unlike other French style croissant, this one taste less buttery than those &#34;ultra-rich&#34; dead-oily ones. The one at Paul Bakery perhaps should stand aside and I gladly choose them over Wild Honey&#39;s. Even though, I still love the ones at Maison Kayser, Cherrier&#39;s suit me better - seriously a balanced and less weighty taste.<br><br>I see many eulogizing the breton cake - Kouign Aman; strangely, I idolized the Almond Brioche for its endearing taste. It didn&#39;t appear catchy but somewhat burnt and stiff. Don&#39;t belittle this slab that arrives massive. I am surprised by its light fluffy texture when I knifed it. Encircled by a crisp crust, the middle was moist and almond-rich with a gentle sweetness. While people next to my table were busy chatting, my dining partner saw me busy gnawing on the slab!

Er, no it ain&#39;t halal. I just went there with a Chinese friend during fasting month once. She was hungry and wanted to fuel up, so we ended up in this popular bakery. <br><br>It&#39;s self-service at this store, so while my friend scrambled off to pick some bites, I made a quick inspection of the premises. The bakery oozes a casual vibe and boasts such a wide array of breads, even I was tempted to try some. Prices are mid-range.<br><br>My friend returned to our table with a cup of hot chocolate, a croissant and a Squid Ink Bun with Smoked Salmon and Ham sandwich.The Squid Ink bun does look exotic with its jet-black appearance.  She said the hot chocolate was chocolatey enough. She loved the croissant - it was crunchy but did not splinter to little pieces. Her sandwich was piled high with heaps of fresh greens and slices of smoked salmon and ham. My friend could not sense any distinct squid ink flavour but found the bread very soft and buttery. I was just sitting at the table, watching her eat. Evil woman.<br><br>I do hope some day Tiong Bahru bakery sets up a halal outlet somewhere. Then I could try their mouth-watering offerings myself!
always get my breakfast here! definitely a must try cafe in SG. although the store is a bit noisy and usually quite busy during the weekends

Tiong Bahru Bakery at Raffles City is the second outlet of the very popular Tiong Bahru Bakery at Tiong Bahru. The location might be less quaint, but it&#39;s way more accessible for us city folks. The new branch takes over the space that was formerly Aerin&#39;s and is triple the size of its first outlet. <br><br>The croissants are, I&#39;m pleased to report, as good as the ones from the original outlet, and there seems to be more variety here. I still love the almond croissants but reckon other places offer a better lemon tart, this one was a bit too tart for my liking (largely prefer the ones from Canele, PS Cafe and Wild Honey) and the crust not as crumbly as I normally would have liked. <br><br>A lunch and dinner menu will be available soon, so it&#39;ll be interesting to see what they are offering then.

Located at a much more convenient location, and being way bigger, there&#39;s no need to head to Tiong Bahru to squeeze into long queues or the cramped 40-seater outlet. <br><br>Three times bigger than the original outlet, what this means is that you can finally sit down and enjoy your croissants and kougin amans in peace without having people bump into you or trying to yell over the din. Everything&#39;s the same here, from the menu right down to the delicious bread on offer. While the level and quality of bread is good, I still feel they aren&#39;t as good as the ones I had from Maison Kayser, but that could just be biased views at play.

text: Spacious venue in Raffles City for tea break. Wide variety of pastries and drinks available! Food is so so though.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=VmStr1LtLkl67olwm1JHOQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5NznhdhNkFVYXsOEvvHY-Q/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5NznhdhNkFVYXsOEvvHY-Q/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5NznhdhNkFVYXsOEvvHY-Q/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5NznhdhNkFVYXsOEvvHY-Q/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5NznhdhNkFVYXsOEvvHY-Q/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5NznhdhNkFVYXsOEvvHY-Q/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Alissa W.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Alissa W.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=VmStr1LtLkl67olwm1JHOQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 8, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 27, 'eliteYear': None}
text: My husband and I stopped in hoping for a nice snack and we were not disappointed. He had the signature croissant and I ended up choosing pastry with a caramelised sugar glaze on it after trying a sample offered from the friendly staff. The croissant had a nice buttery flavour and the pastry was sweet without being overbearing. Both were very enjoyable, would have gone nice with a cup of coffee. Overall it was an enjoyable experience though I felt perhaps a tad overpriced for what you get.
