text: I&#39;ve been to both the original outlet at Tiong Bahru and the new one at Raffles City several times and think TBB is slightly overhyped.<br><br>Croissant: delectably crispy shell which flakes off in layers, and a smooth buttery inside. <br>Pain au chocolat: nothing special, they aren&#39;t super generous with the chocolate inside. <br>Kouign amman: delicious on first bite but I couldn&#39;t finish it, it was too sweet.  Chocolate brioche: the bread didn&#39;t taste like much, and was too soft. the chocolate chips on top smeared off a little too easily<br>Chocolate Viennoise: rather soft, didn&#39;t make much of an impression otherwise<br>Catalan: a good level of savoury to balance out all the sugar in the other breads.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/b0OCMRx443-Axgo7tGZuwg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/rich-and-good-cake-shop-singapore?reviewid=or8iAVU1J9ZLiOhiMjPhIg&select=b0OCMRx443-Axgo7tGZuwg', 'altText': 'Photo of Rich & Good Cake shop - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: So delish.  After admiring their sleek new shop at the Jewel, my cousin surprised me with a durian swiss roll during my stay in Singapore...and it was incredible.  Fresh durian with lots of flavor, the fluffiest cake, and plenty of whipped cream.  Since then, I&#39;ve been to their old school (original) Kompong Glam shop twice to buy a number more rolls for family and gifts for others.  I&#39;ve still only tasted durian since I&#39;m durian obsessed but have heard very good things about kaya as well.  <br><br>Cash only, and the nearest ATM is at the Raffles hospital.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=2arW6KJ-BAoAfNrYC7zaPA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yllt8_KXyyZskUN93mlRbg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yllt8_KXyyZskUN93mlRbg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yllt8_KXyyZskUN93mlRbg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yllt8_KXyyZskUN93mlRbg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yllt8_KXyyZskUN93mlRbg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yllt8_KXyyZskUN93mlRbg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Joe N.', 'displayLocation': 'Bukit Timah, Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Joe N.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=2arW6KJ-BAoAfNrYC7zaPA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 58, 'photoCount': 2152, 'reviewCount': 279, 'eliteYear': 2022}
text: Rich and Good refers to their signature kaya roll.  Everything else I say after this is just in support of this one point...just so many more words to make sure you understand that it&#39;s the kaya roll that rocks!  Another success in the form of a mother ship that spawned  babies that are just as good.  Of course, these babies are just retail outlets for the products of the one kitchen that bakes all that goodness.  Rich and Good is also a small enough concern for the name to have some cache and garner you some foodie cred if you happen to show up with the kaya roll as a present.  Trust me, it&#39;ll always be welcome, and not in the way that a fruit cake or a tub of ice cream might be, with a rictus of a grin, but with genuine delight.  Ok, let&#39;s talk product.  The kaya roll is a dense  comforter of pandan sponge wrapping a generous layer of unctuous kaya. Consider this fair warning!  The kaya roll is Category 1 Medication addictive.

text: After going on a tour of the Kampong Glam district, our guide pointed out the Rich &amp; Good Cake Shop.  Not really promoting it, just highlighting that it was kind of an institution of sorts.  <br><br>Grab and go, after waiting about 10 minutes in a line, cash only, $8 a roll.  When they are out, they are out.  It is like the soup nazi...be ready when you get to the front to know your order, pay and go!  They do not have a sitting area.  <br><br>When I got my mango swiss roll back to my hotel roll, I launched right in.  I think it is ideally meant to be kept cold via refrigeration, but it was fine for the hour and half it was in my bag before getting back to my hotel.  <br><br>Simply delicious!  I mean creamy, but the real deal, good kind of cream.  I mean light and airy, knowing the cake part was freshly made that day.  Fruity and tasty with real mango filling.  Now I know it is only a little dessert, but for quality, this was an exceptional swiss roll (save your calories for the good stuff!).  I have never really had so many kind words to say about a swiss roll.  Little Debbie has nothing on the Rich &amp; Good Cake Shop!<br><br>If you are in the area, do yourself a favor and pick one up.

Kaya roll', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Kaya roll'}]
text: I love it when my sister brings home these delicious Swiss rolls!! So small and yet so awesome!! I definitely would grow addicted to these if I could get them everyday!! <br>The strawberry roll has strawberry jam in it, the jam itself is sweet but the butter cream gives it a slight tinge of buttery bland to it, offsetting the sweetness! I just can&#39;t get enough of that buttercream...<br><br>The kaya swiss roll is what the rich &amp; good bakery is famous for... however, I found the kaya pretty bland.. it wasn&#39;t as sweet as the strawberry swiss roll.. I mean, even the kaya spread for my bread tastes more &#34;kaya-ish&#34; than this.. but it is a very soft swiss roll smile and I still enjoyed it.. But I would definitely get more strawberry roll next time!!<br><br>Since, takeaways are a must at Rich &amp; good bakery, they provide you with really long boxes to accomodate the swiss rolls and don&#39;t forget to visit them again!! smile I need more strawberry swiss rolls in my life!

Didn&#39;t know about this place until a friend insisted on getting some because she was in the area. out of curiosity i bought the durian roll. it was a couple hours later till i got home and that was the recommended time it should be outside the fridge once you buy it from them. the expiration on these rolls is 2-3 days. <br><br>the roll itself was fluffy and the texture was nice. not the best durian filling but it was good enough for my first try. there were many other flavours so if i am back in that part of town i would give it another try.

text: I went to the shop at Changi airport but this Kaya Swiss roll is the best I&#39;ve ever had. It&#39;s not overly sweet. Really flavorful Kaya flavor. Soft and great worth tea. LOVE IT!
watch out arrogance will have its karma.   negative customer service will be back to bite u sooner or later.   no customer should be humiliated to enjoy a wonderful thing as a cake.

text: The softest swiss roll I&#39;ve had in Singapore. Not talking about the Japanese roll, but swiss rolls. The aunty was also in an okay mood, no angry outbursts or snappy replies. I got the pandan kaya and strawberry. The pandan kaya was fragrant, and the sponge cake itself was soft. I liked the strawberry too. A lot. The buttercream was not too sweet, but sweet enough. The strawberry bits were fresh and they had a really nice sweet smell. It makes me want to go back and try the other flavors. It&#39;s very addictive too. I bought two rolls, and finished half within the hour after reaching home. Of each roll.

text: Full review and photos at FoodieFC&#39;s blog. <br><br>Rich &amp; Good Cake Shop is located in Arab Street next to Kampong Glam Conservation Area. This place has gotten quite a lot of positive word of mouth (WOM). Despite its location; at least 15 minutes away from the nearest MRT station (Bugis), this place was packed when I went there twice during lunch time. And it will not be easy to find this shop if you are not familiar with the area. In case you are wondering, this shop specialises in Swiss rolls. <br><br>Stacks of unroll Swiss rolls. Yes, they make it themselves and they sell it in a whole roll; uncut.<br><br>Wide variety of Swiss rolls and the prices. <br><br>Nothing fancy about their packaging. Looks simple and dull.<br><br>I ordered  a Kaya Swiss Roll and a Coffee Swiss Roll  for $13.00. The packaging and swiss rolls look simple. But appearances can be deceiving. The swiss rolls were soft and spongy.<br><br>The Kaya Swiss Roll which is their best seller. The kaya was tasty, rich and fragrant. This is really a must try. Totally fantastic. The owner say that to keep the cake in the fridge and finish it up by 3 days. Well, it was so delicious that we finish it up within 24 hours.<br><br>The Coffee Swiss Roll was quite delicious too. Soft, rich tasting coffee flavoured swiss roll.<br><br>If you have not tried this, you will not know what you are missing. They sell lots of other flavours too such  as Blueberry, Chocolate, Durian, Green Tea, Mango, Strawberry and Orange. As as it&#39;s shop name shout out, it&#39;s swiss rolls are really rich and good! <br><br>Full review and photos at FoodieFC&#39;s blog.

text: &#34;I bought some rich and good cake.&#34;<br><br>&#39;Oh really? Where did you get them from?&#39;<br><br>&#34;Rich and good.&#34;<br><br>&#39;Stop kidding me! Just where did you get them from???&#39;<br><br>#truestory<br><br>For the unfamiliar, you would probably not know Rich &amp; Good Cakes, which is tucked along one of the streets near Arab Street. It&#39;s a swiss-roll cake speciality shop, that sells nothing but swiss-roll cakes. As good as the signboard says! &#39;Rich &amp; Good&#39; ;)  I love both the durian and kaya ones. Best and fresh!

On the front door: Swiss Roll Price List', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'On the front door: Swiss Roll Price List'}]
text: A retro little storefront is all that marks this hole-in-the-wall bakery along Kandahar Lane, where it&#39;s stood for 14 years to date. While it calls itself a cake shop, Rich &amp; Good really only specialises in one type of cake - the Swiss Roll, a flat sheet of sponge cake with a layer of flavoured cream all rolled up. <br><br>While it&#39;s the only cake you can get there, it is available in several delectable flavours; what&#39;s available is dependent on your luck because they only make certain quantities every day, so give them a call to reserve or pop by early if have particular cravings, because stuff can sell out quickly.<br><br>What makes the Rich &amp; Good Swiss Roll so good is the soft spongy texture of the cake, and that they use actual fruits in the cream which makes this treat super yummy without tasting too artificially sugary. My personal favourite is the Mandarin Orange flavour (which makes a great Chinese New Year snack), but the Kaya, Mango and Durian are quite popular as well. Ok who am I kidding, all the flavours are good, but I&#39;m a little let down by the chocolate flavour because it&#39;s not as rich as I generally like it.<br><br>It comes in a long roll about the length of your arm (my arm length at any rate) and are great for sharing if you&#39;re feeling generous. Anytime I&#39;m in the area, I end up getting 2-3 rolls... just because!

Buying cakes from the Rich and Good Cake Shop is truly an experience. Famous for their delicious swiss rolls, you can choose from a few flavours and order from the counter.<br><br>Personally do enjoy the swiss rolls but I cant say that Im totally blown over by it. Some favourite flavours of my family includes the kaya, mandarin orange and the durian. As what I have written in my tips, do make sure you decide what you&#39;ll like to order before you enter the shop cos the aunties dont have much patience. Also, always have a back up flavour in mind if you must leave the shop with a cake, cos some flavours may be out at time of purchase and it&#39;s better to just call out the next flavour that you want than to stand there and think.<br><br>Overall, a great dessert for the family to share or to bring to group gatherings (cos each swiss roll is about the length of a 30cm long ruler). They dont cut the cakes for you so do ask for a plastic knife if you need one to cut the cake yourself later.

A good Swiss roll by any standard. It has a wide variety of favors to satisfy any cravings.<br><br>We chanced upon this little traditional cake shop while roaming the little streets here. Cute enough for us to join the constant stream of customers. The lady boss proudly told us her most popular favors are durian and kaya. When we asked how many people per roll, she confidently told us &#34;one person can finish one roll, my rolls are very light!&#34;.<br><br>Ok, I wouldn&#39;t buy one whole roll per pax. While they are moist and light, they are not exactly something that you can finish by yourself. At least by my standard. I am not a Swiss roll person, so this is interesting and quite good, but not something that I will crave. My friends all enjoyed it, especially the kaya one.<br><br>Love it for its old school charm though!

I loveeeeeeeee Rich &amp; Good.<br><br>I, however, hate and despise durian. So I guess it&#39;s saying something when I actually look forward to eating the durian swiss rolls from here.<br><br>Rich &amp; Good specializes in rolls. Their rolls are the right amount of soft and spongy, sweet and delicious. The flavours are to die for. The kaya, especially, and even the durian as I said. <br><br>It&#39;s become a must-do tourist attraction for me whenever I bring friends from out of town. I practically force feed them swiss rolls from here because I love it so much.

A gem of a find, most people find out about this bakery through word of mouth. Which is good really, cos only the genuine people will visit. <br><br>Located amidst the cafes and bars along the culturally rich Kandahar Street, Rich &amp; Good have been churning out deliciously soft Swiss rolls for decades. With a host of flavours to choose from (kaya, mangao, blueberry, coffee and durian), this Swiss rolls are priced incredibly cheaply and come in just one size - foot long.  <br><br>Packaged in retro long pink boxes, this soft pillowy cakes are packed with dense fillings that make it a perfect tea time treat to have. As kaya is one of the most popular flavours, be sure to get there early or you&#39;ll have to wait till the next day to get them once it sells out.

Rich and Good Cake shop as the name suggest sells rich and pretty good cakes. I would have to say that their hot selling Swiss Roll cakes are some of the best I tasted.  The come in assorted flavors, I had the coffee and Kaya ones. Lovely! Not too sweet and not too heavy on the cream. The sponge is soft and truly moist, a real treat with a good cup of coffee for your afternoon break.<br><br>The shop is tucked away in a row a shops and if you&#39;re not looking hard enough you might just miss the nondescript looking front door.
Awesome spot for a quick and casual breakfast or cuppa.  Well prepared, fresh ingredients and lots of variety. One of my favorite spots for a morning wake up.

text: The shopfront is something out of a dream or a movie.  It is a bakery and sweet lover&#39;s paradise - even outside the entrance you can spot the mounds of pastries and breads baked to perfection, so much so that they look fake! <br><br>I was reeled in straight away and had a croisssant. It was everything I had hoped it to be.  Flaky and crispy on the outside, and soft, fluffy and airy on the inside.  The pastries and cakes looked picture perfect and I wish I had bought one!

text: One of my favorite hotel bakeries in Singapore. The cakes, pastries, and bread here are always so pleasing to the eyes and delicious. Give Dolcetto a try if you haven&#39;t!

text: If you happen to spot a white color mousse cake studded with dried fruits called &#34;Cassata Siciliana&#34; at any local patisserie, don&#39;t think much, just get it. It is such a traditional and peripheral cake that few pastry chefs in Singapore would ever think of making one. The rarity drove me to get a slice at Dolcetto by Basilico, despite being already full to the brims. <br><br>This Italian pastry shop used to be my to-go place for takeaway pastries when it was still under the name of &#34;Something to Go&#34;. The interior and menu have been revamped, but the signatures like Strawberry Torte, Praline Torte and Espresso Tiramisu still stay. In the spirit of all things Italian, all the pastries here that involved chocolate are made with Tuscany&#39;s organic chocolate brand Amedei, which is perhaps also one of the world&#39;s most expensive chocolate.<br><br>Take for example the Amedei Chocolate Pumpkin Tart ($9) that took a sinful detour from the usual pumpkin pie. The mastery of the cacao tones is virtually undisputed, so does the crisp tart shell which not overworked and perfect in volume with the filling. Pumpkin is one of my favorite ingredients but the taste seemed to have wandered off to elsewhere and did not meld together with the chocolate<br><br>The Praline Torte ($9) is hard not to love with the appealing crunchy base. But I was craving for something less milky, something more intense and I figured that the other option of Amedei Dark Chocolate Cake would have satisfied my lust for chocolate.<br><br>Bright juicy and sweet, the soft chunks of pineapple rested amidst the delectable vanilla baked custard in this humble Italian Crostata ($9). But instead of being served the traditional family way in big, rustic free-form version, it has been elevated to the fine ranks of French gateaux with mild &#34;Violette perfumes&#34; and a touch of gold on top of the dainty raspberries.<br><br>The Espresso Marsala Cake ($9) was our unanimous pick. It might seem like a messy pile of various textures (crunch, custard, sponge, ganache, gelee) but I loved the sweetness from the Marsala wine even though the espresso kick wasn&#39;t assertive as I had imagined. And of course the delightful sound of the crushed chocolate pearls is music to the ears.<br><br>One can&#39;t miss the conspicuous fresh-baked pane (breads) that are stacked along the wall. We&#39;ve finally got a taste of the famous squid ink panini with fresh king crab and prawns ($13), a hearty dense and chewy sandwich that seemed a little deprived of tantalizing juices from the filling. The Roasted Chicken &amp; Cheese Foccacia might not be brimming with luxury ingredients but the flavors were simple and comforting. <br><br>Many may raise eyebrows at the sight of Squid Ink Salmon Macaron but it is quite a success. In fact, a good step to convert those who usually steer away from these sugary meringue bites. The chewy shells appeared rather flattened but the flavors were spot on, especially the Vanilla Prosecco and Cassis.

text: Sometimes you have to treat yourself. Because why not?! I got the cake and coffee combo for $14SGD. I mean for a boutique patisserie that&#39;s not a bad deal not for everyday but, you know what YOLO!! So yeah I did it because I missed out on dessert last night at the epic dinner I had. So I got the wild berry limoncello cheesecake because I love cheesecake and it was beautifully displayed. I also got a soy cappuccino that was very delicious. Back to the cheesecake, I take my first bite and surprise it&#39;s filled with wild berry filing! This blew my mind. All these years having cheesecake and I&#39;ve never had a berry filled cheesecake. My life has been a complete sham! So yeah that&#39;s why it&#39;s 5 stars. Not a place to frequent everyday but remember you are worth it!

I was looking for a good donut place in Singapore like similar to Bob&#39;s donuts in Los Angeles Farmers Market near The Grove, and I did some reviewing and found dolcetto. I got 2 donuts (one chocolate and one blueberry cream cheese filled) and a cafe latte. I must say the donuts were way too dense. Chocolate was not chocolate, it was like candy chocolate if you know what I mean. The blueberry cream cheese donut was only better because of the filling, but the donut was just not fluffy. It was too think and heavy. Coffee was from illy so that was fine. I came back for an afternoon tea and had one of their sandwiches with prosciutto and I recommend that. But donuts were a miss for me. Maybe their pastries are better?

text: Speaking of deli-counters, everyone knows which is their heart&#39;s desire. I seldom frequent a pâtisserie, at most a boulangerie. Most commonly seen these days, are either tagging a European heritage or a Japanese label, anchoring at some malls - majestic or humble. Another group will hole up at some remote or bustling hotels, sometimes an extension of the main restaurant while others are stand alone without parentage. When the now-defunct Something-To-Go at Regent Singapore finally vacate itself from the lobby, the unit is quickly replaced by another gourmet Italian pastry shop; serves artisanal bakeries/pastries &#34;bites-on-the-GO&#34; from Basilico kitchen - the Italian buffet restaurant on level 2. Confession I must, I have never been to Regent Singapore, at best, driving past. So, when others mentioned about the takeaway deli over at the hotel, I couldn&#39;t visualize where and how to get to it. Until today, I finally left FOODprints at Dolcetto after a trip to St Regis, Singapore.<br><br>Once you enter the hotel main entrance, head towards the lobby at 12o&#39;clock, until you reach the far end which is walled in glass panels. Dolcetto is just on your 9 o&#39;clock - sit tightly in a corner. With a few round tables and long sofa in the lobby, one simply shop in the deli - scan the display, place your order and make the payment before pulling your tray of items off the cashier to any available seats. Barely any soul, except a few in-house guests waiting to check into their rooms. The time was 2.30pm, a Friday. I found myself a decent table to interrogate my subject, though I wish it has been a date.<br><br>Spoilt with choices, I cherry-picked the elegant looking mini tart - Forest Berries. This beautiful treat enchants you with its sweetness that was meant for the faint heart - mild and calming. A very thin layer of delicate custard was seen cushioned between a bushel of huge plumpish strawberries &amp; its cousins and a less buttery crisp shell. Though the silkiness of the custard won me over, I still prefer they rubbed in more butter for a richer tart shell. Perhaps a few more scoops of fillings to satiate my greed. Prior to that, I think it has been overpriced for its content, $9 a piece.<br><br>Then comes the savory. Less attractive, something that you wouldn&#39;t care for a second look probably. Many may pace up and down the display and thought it was just another sweet mini French burger treats - Macaroon. Stay close and read those tags which spelled their names in flowing strokes, you will realized that they ain&#39;t all sweet treats. I asked the lady for a Smoked Salmon classic, and the dusky cookie make it to the plate, alongside the jeweled tart. A complete contrast between a beauty and the beast from afar! Instantly, prejudice sets in when confronted with visual appeal but it turned out to be an unfair judgement. If you think a sweet shell is at odds with salmon fillings, reconsider that please. I am surprised by the unconventional making, the mixture of mellow sweet crisp cookie embodied a dollop of silky creme wrapping some melting salmon with a rich savory &amp; smokey finish. No overbearing fishiness was seen marring the light, gently crackling almond meringue shell, heavenly. For once, I tasted a refined French treat which didn&#39;t put me off with its immeasurable sweetness but one that was light and playful. A $2.25 per piece is so reasonable to ask for another.<br><br>To wash down my tea treats, I had a dose of cappuccino that smoothed my throat but less lingering. I am glad that this cup was worth $5.60 instead of $15 that was charged by mistake for 3 doses at first. Please do check your bill if it sounds unbelievable, I was happy that I did.<br><br>Do not be misled by my choices, there are plenty of artisanal breads, sweet muffins, doughnuts, mouth-watering sandwiches and even tiny sweets like cookies and chocolates on the shelves. But be forewarned that the price is steep.<br><br>If there&#39;s anything that I would bond with, the freestyle squid ink smoked salmon shall be it! This classic arrives without confining rules - highly praised. I will be most happy to ask for a second piece anytime soon whenever Dolcetto is call upon.

text: Ordered take away.<br><br>Coffee -9/10<br>Croissant - 9/10<br>Bagel with cream cheese - 11/10 (OMG this is So GOOOD)<br>PanCake - 5/10 (Maybe it&#39;s just not what I like) <br><br>Should have been a rated 5, but the pancake is really not that nice.

text: Visited this quaint little coffee shop in East Singapore for the first time today- on a Friday afternoon. It was relatively empty when I arrived &amp; quickly filled up to a nice bustle. <br><br>Knee-deep in my quest for Singapore&#39;s best chai latte, I opted for their iced chai latte. It was notably sweeter than the other cups I&#39;ve tried, but no where near too sweet. In fact, the sweetness coupled with the spiciness of the ..spices was quite the experience for my tastebuds. Definitely a safe beverage choice at Dutch Colony Coffee. <br><br>I&#39;d give 4 stars- the coffee shop is rather out of the way &amp; they do close early. (especially on weekdays)

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XDY0XV1tO8cmDe-3zggTHA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/dutch-colony-coffee-singapore?reviewid=vcZ7Sx3xcw7e4BVKX5tFoQ&select=XDY0XV1tO8cmDe-3zggTHA', 'altText': 'Photo of Dutch Colony Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. From another angle bc I loved it so much!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'From another angle bc I loved it so much!'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/14I_i0cG9ScWbPc0LkQnVA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/dutch-colony-coffee-singapore?reviewid=vcZ7Sx3xcw7e4BVKX5tFoQ&select=14I_i0cG9ScWbPc0LkQnVA', 'altText': 'Photo of Dutch Colony Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. French Toast Beauty!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'French Toast Beauty!'}]
text: Dutch Colony Coffee is the coffee shop to visit in the Kembangan area, not withstanding the nearby coffee heavy weight and Yelp superstar, Penny University. The coffee is fantastic, no doubt about it. Easy to drink and beautifully balanced. Just the way I like it! Secondly Dutch Colony sources coffee beans from all around the world. The coffee selection is what you would suspect from any fine coffee locale: (i) Flat white, (ii) cappuccino, (iii) lattes, (iv) iced mocha, etc. Sorry, no specialty coffee offerings from what I remember. <br><br>The food is also great, but unfortunately there were some misses.  If you haven&#39;t noticed from my pictures, I&#39;m a huge fan of the French Toast. Probably, one of the best French Toasts I&#39;ve had in Singapore so far. What&#39;s not to love about a french toast topped with strawberry, caramelized banana with syrup and vanilla ice cream as sides?  The Espresso Bacon Baked Eggs with Wasabi Mayo was not too bad as well. Unfortunately, the Sweet Potato Truffle Fries were bit soggy. <br><br>Overall, Dutch Colony&#39;s coffee is among the best you will find in SG. I knock a star off because the food portions are a bit on the small side considering the price point, and the truffle fries were a bit of a miss.

Coffee chain in Singapore with several outlets in the city. The coffee here is pretty good but the desserts/cake can be improved. We shared several dishes and they are all average. The only good one is the cheesecake which has a good texture though also falls below expectation. Overall a good place for coffee / meet-ups but don&#39;t expect great pastries/dessert.

Ambience 4/5  - really loved the decor and space layout, almost a 5/5 except the toilet was clogged up with a lot of paper on a sunday morning before noon<br><br>Food 2/5 - huge disappointment, the brioche bread was a huge letdown. Tasted very ordinary. Omelette and bread could have done at home too. Very disappointed. <br><br>Coffee 3.5/5 <br><br>Nice place to hangout for coffee and small bite. But if you want good food or brunch, better to go somewhere else.

Remember how i was complaining about the dearth of good coffee in the East? Well well, i&#39;m glad to be wrong now because of Carvers &amp; Co, Craftsmen (they have great cakes), and now Dutch Colony Coffee Co. has also opened its outpost right here in Frankel Estate! Yay. Ok, if you don&#39;t know where that is, that&#39;s perfectly fine with me, DON&#39;T COME. Haha. You guys can just head to the one at Pasarbella. :P<br><br>It&#39;s honestly too inconvenient to get here if you don&#39;t drive. Just the way i like it. Good stuff are only meant to be shared with the right people. ;)<br><br>Well Dutch Colony beans are available at a number of places so i&#39;ve probably tried the beans before. Obviously i&#39;m not one who fancies the west and the kiosk at Pasarbella is hardly a relaxing spot to enjoy a cuppa. Thankfully, the Frankel outlet has the luxury of space, both indoors and outdoors. There&#39;s a spacious and airy skylight area at the back that will give you that lovely whitewashed IG photo. <br><br>Coffee is prepared in a variety of methods here and you could also choose from the single orgins list. <br><br>Well balanced coffee with a lovely crema. So smooth and easy to drink. It&#39;s just me being the caffeine addict but i downed my drink in no time. <br><br>A full brunch menu is availble, alongside small baked goods. Considering this is our after lunch coffee sesh, we couldn&#39;t stomach more than a piece of cake. SOBS.<br><br>I&#39;ve seen the same cakes at Assembly Coffee at The Cathay and know for sure that the Earl Grey Citrus Loaf is dry and overly sweet. From the looks of it, i bet i am right. Needless to say, one could skip the Thai Milk Tea loaf. Well, luckily for them, the Matcha Bundt cake was superb.<br><br>The cake was moist and we could taste the distinct green tea in it. The icing was a little sweet but that could be easily scraped off so no issue. Can they make this a bigger slice please??<br><br>This is certainly going to be my regular hangout from now. Gonna sample the brunch next time!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/bOEFQeYIrcCGMDu6ZAkWuA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/dutch-colony-coffee-singapore?reviewid=UMw2AfGTCSWLkeVllZHJqQ&select=bOEFQeYIrcCGMDu6ZAkWuA', 'altText': 'Photo of Dutch Colony Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Arrived just after 11am. Easily visible from main road though snugged in between the row of shop-houses with its black front door with glass. Heavy on the modern industrial look - black, dark wood and metal furnishings; but not uncomfortable. Goes very well with the coffee machines that sit along the counter. Perhaps that is what attracts the good mix of patrons. Spacious with three seating areas. We took the front porch section.  <br>Service was prompt and unpretentious. <br>Menu is not extensive. But they have a small selection of all-day sandwiches. Ordered one from the breakfast section and one from the sandwiches section. The steak sarnie was tasty enough. I wish I could enjoy it better if the bread was a little less toasted. Enjoyed the french toast with turkey bacon and caramelised banana. Well, if you are one of those who likes savoury and sweet in one bite. The coffee was good, and the tea was served in a small teapot with double wall glass tea cup. That won us over. <br>Finding parking space can be a bit difficult if you are driving.

text: Only good for coffee. <br><br>Thought the service was very slow. Out of stock of a few items despite the limited menu. Had the egg mayo croissant - croissant was not flaky and in fact a little hard. Egg mayo was tasteless. Don&#39;t think it can even compare with delifrance. ( and that isn&#39;t even that good) also had the steak sandwich which I couldn&#39;t even ask for the steak&#39;s doneness. The lady taking my order said &#39;they are all normal&#39;. What&#39;s normal? Medium or medium rare? She said &#39;just normal&#39; <br><br>Sorry but don&#39;t think I&#39;ll be back.

text: Yummy coffee, enough of a caffeine kick to open my eyes wide up on a sleepy afternoon. Nice location with your average hipster decor with ubiquitous coffee related accessories for sale. I don&#39;t care if they sell puppies (okay..maybe I would) but I&#39;m definitely come back for more coffee! Recommendations: flat white &amp; salted caramel chocolate tart...hubby liked their lavender mango cake, but it&#39;s steep at $7,50.

Great place. Fantastic atmosphere. Good service. But terrible terrible music playlist and choices. Not sure if I&#39;m coming back if they continue playing music like that. The kitchen blasts another genre of music as well. Unacceptable I&#39;m afraid.

text: The coffee here is good, but the food is terrible.<br>The menu is as you would expect, nothing with any uniqueness or creativity. When it came out it was cold and extremely undercooked. After sending it back, they recooked the same food (condiments and all) and sent it back stacked up. Very amateurish and you can get plenty of good coffee (and food) on the east coast.

text: Great cold brew coffee!! Trendy feel and nice staff. Limited food but nothing healthy!! I think they&#39;re missing a trick on this point... They would nail it as they&#39;ve got the space and ambience. In fact, the only genuinely negative aspect of this place is the parking!

text: Very cool off coffee/breakfast shop near Clarke Quay. The coffee artwork is precision done and everything was very tasty. The general place has a relaxed vibe that lets you melt in and enjoy.

text: Great spot for brunch. Friendly staff and tasty food. Smashed avocado on toast with poached eggs were amazing.

This was an unexpected find, was planning to go to another bookmarked brunch place, but they didn&#39;t have as many egg options as i wanted. So found this place close to our place with decent reviews and went to check it out. Reached at noon (bad time to go for brunch on a weekend) and the place was packed to the seams. Had to wait 30 mins for a table, but the waft of food coming from inside was delicious. <br>The wait was worth it. I got the weekender breakfast - smoked salmon over thick toast with roe and two large perfectly poached eggs. Hit the spot! Wife got the smashed avocado with sourdough which was excellent and they certainly don&#39;t skimp on the avocado like certain other places. The cappuccino and tea latte we got were exceptional as well. But the star of the day was the tiramisu, hell, I&#39;ll come back just for that. One of the few places in Singapore that I&#39;ll be returning to for sure.

text: Pretty good café located pretty much away from the hipster enclave of tiong bahru, duxton hill and outram park area. The sister café of Ronin is much brighter with an almost pastel color interior, less stuffy, lots of natural light, an open kitchen with suction / ventilation system that works and a big &#34;green&#34; wall at the outdoor seating area. The café exudes a relaxing vibe unlike the more &#34;gothic&#34; sister (Ronin) located just a short walk away.<br><br>Punch is located exactly opposite Kreta Ayer Neighbourhood Police Station and about 50 meters away from Dehesa (previously Communal). If you&#39;re coming alone or with one or two friends, getting a table is not that difficult but if you&#39;re in a group of six and above, it is better to book in advance. The kind folks will hold your table until 11am, before releasing to whoever comes first.  <br><br>The past weekend, I organized a brunch meetup with fellow yelpers and had a good meal here. The 10 of us ordered almost everything in the menu including the 2 specials. My poached eggs with mashed avocado was pretty good with nicely poached eggs sitting on top 2 slices of sourdough with a side of burnt lemon for that &#34;earthy&#34; taste. The portion is perfect for one and just right when you washed down with a cuppa joe, in my case, I chose my favorite chai latte. While some suggest that the chai latte could be more &#34;milky&#34; and the spices be more pronounced, I like the way it is. With our ever warm Singapore weather, I like my chai to me on the &#34;lighter&#34; side and less milky. It&#39;s just a personal preference and it works for me. <br><br>I took a small bite of my friend&#39;s earl grey pancakes with poached pear drenched in chocolate sauce and it was really good and addictive. Again, not too big of a portion for one. While I hope the team could come up with a more extensive brunch menu (currently only 7 items), that&#39;s not entirely a bad thing. That means the young budding chefs know their ability and only want to concentrate on a few items they do best rather than an ambitious menu while delivering a mediocre fare. If the usual waffles, porridge and eggs benny doesn&#39;t fancy you, then check with the friendly staff on the weekly specials. <br><br>Staffs are friendly and our glass of water are always filled. While we try to milk a complimentary salted caramel brownie by singing birthday song to me, it was a birthday that I don&#39;t even know! And if you wonder, we failed in the attempt. The salted caramel brownie comes with a price tag of $5. <br><br>If there&#39;s one thing that puts me off is the price that is perhaps, a tad higher than your usual cafe. But then, it&#39;s Singapore where you&#39;re expected to fork out extra at a slightly better establishment. I&#39;m definitely coming back to check out their dinner one of these days. <br><br>Punch is a solid 3.5 star, round up to 4. Good stuff

text: This is a gorgeous little spot. The staff are lovely, coffee perfect and food thoughtfully made and presented. It was so good we went twice in one day. <br>First for brunch, I had already eaten so just had a soya chai and the must delicious cookie. My husband had the smashed avocado with poached eggs and grilled lemon on toast which looked and tasted great. <br>We then returned for a very early dinner just before they closed at 6pm because we wanted to try the prawn and scallop pasta. It was worth it. The herbs and garlic in the sauce were perfectly balanced and the seafood cooked with the nice crispy crust, only available on week days. <br>Punch runs like an engine with every staff member knowing their function but also able to fill in any gaps that appear. <br>There are many other items on the menu to try and I hope we get time to go back before we take off.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/td76WQa5VEWx_SCOQbypEg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/punch-singapore?reviewid=4xEnsY2GwnWAR3udiG88YA&select=td76WQa5VEWx_SCOQbypEg', 'altText': 'Photo of Punch - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/H5Mz5zI4dj6ONVR77jYDyQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/punch-singapore?reviewid=4xEnsY2GwnWAR3udiG88YA&select=H5Mz5zI4dj6ONVR77jYDyQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Punch - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Fqkwe3G147rwWqzgbPmkAg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/punch-singapore?reviewid=4xEnsY2GwnWAR3udiG88YA&select=Fqkwe3G147rwWqzgbPmkAg', 'altText': 'Photo of Punch - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: We visited the sister cafe of Ronin and The Plain on a Saturday afternoon. If not for the fact that my friend is a frequent visitor, I won&#39;t have been able to find the place due to the lack of visible signage. <br><br>We shared the coffee, poached eggs with avocado, poached eggs with salmon and earl grey pancakes amongst the two of us. Food was unexpectedly delicious! Being an avocado fan, I was more than pleased to see a generous serving of avocado on my sourdough toast. It was a pity the toast was too hard. The brioche that came with the salmon was perfect, thankfully, and felt very Japanese with the ikura. Servings were satisfying for the eggs but the pancakes were on the smaller side, which may not suffice for big eaters. It reminded me of McDonalds hotcakes in looks but more delectable. The coffee was decent but a little sour for my liking. <br><br>I will definitely be back for the food.
Latte was high quality/upper tier.<br><br>Pancakes were delicious and egg/avo/toast thing was really good!<br><br>outdoor seating in back was really quiet/private.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=uY4jW9UuM1l0aFoWWu255Q', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/EOqOmhmbHfv4ikRUCLqxew/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/EOqOmhmbHfv4ikRUCLqxew/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/EOqOmhmbHfv4ikRUCLqxew/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/EOqOmhmbHfv4ikRUCLqxew/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/EOqOmhmbHfv4ikRUCLqxew/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/EOqOmhmbHfv4ikRUCLqxew/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Prisca L.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Prisca L.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=uY4jW9UuM1l0aFoWWu255Q', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 4, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Compared to Ronin, the decor of Punch is not as cosy. Though it is tastefully done, there was something quite clinical/impersonal about the space, which wouldn&#39;t make it a top choice for me (perhaps it was the slight aloofness of the hipster staff, but I wouldn&#39;t hold it against them, it&#39;s just a personal preference.) Though note that half the space is set up almost as if catered for the lone customer who wants to get some reading and work done, which is great.<br><br>I had the chai latte (I know, in a coffee establishment?!). Although they apparently brew it (not from some teabag), it was a lacklustre chai latte. :( A bit diluted, not rich, spicy and milky the way I like it. My friend and I also shared the earl grey pancakes, which was not bad, the roasted macademias and crumble on the side was a nice touch, but I wish the earl grey was a bit stronger. Pancake texture was so-so (erm yes, similar to Macdonald&#39;s hotcakes). <br><br>I really wanted to like the place, but I think I&#39;d stick with Ronin.

text: The atmosphere is great on a Sunday morning, with a bustling and happy crowd.<br>The food is fresh and tasty, and the serving portion on the The Weekender Egg is very generous.<br>The Long Black has excellent flavour.<br>The service staff are very attentive and polite.<br>And they have Apple Pay !

This tiny little cafe on club street serves some pretty decent espresso based coffes. They use beans from Papa Palheta (for those who are not familiar with the, it is the roaster behind Loysel&#39;s Toy, Chye Seng Huat Hardware and Pulp (in Kuala Lumpur) so the beans are high quality.<br><br>The coffee here is also well made but nothing spectacular. Charging SGD 5 for a small flat white is a bit much. They do some snacks and other beverages as well but it is a take out place as it barely fits two people. There are no filter coffees on offer so while they offer high quality coffee so would not really call it a speciality coffee place but nonetheless not bad.<br><br>If I am in the area and feel like a coffee this is a good option and if it is between 2pm and 4pm they also offer a buy 1 get 1 free special so then it is also attractively priced.

text: The Little Corner With Explosive Food <br><br>The only reason why we heard of this place was because we heard it replaced Peramakan at TANGS Marketplace. <br><br>After getting a taste of how good they were (and seeing how people constantly came by to buy their kuehs and nonya rice dumplings), we knew we had to try the food from their main restaurant at Telok Blangah. <br><br>Firstly, I&#39;d like to apologize for the lack of photos, especially of the food. We decided at the spur of the moment to rush down and take away a few dishes for a family lunch. Because of our hunger and over enthusiasm to try the food, we completely forgot about photos. Promise to upload a few the next time I&#39;m there. <br><br>Now.... back to food. <br><br>I&#39;ve noticed that there&#39;s been a lot of disagreements and &#34;arguments&#34; online lately about how &#34;authentic&#34; a Peranakan Restaurant is. Because of the many influences and different background of each family, and lack of belief in writing down recipes, there isn&#39;t really a genuine, authentic recipe for Nonya food. Sure, the basic ingredients are the same, but the way it&#39;s cooked varies from family to family. <br><br>To me, good Nonya food needs to be the following: <br>1. it has to be fragrant. A lot of Peranakan dishes depend on a solid rempah (spice blend / paste) and this should stand out in all dishes<br>2. It has to be delicious <br>3. It has to feel like it&#39;s prepare with love <br>4. It has to warm the soul <br><br>Nonya Chap Chye ($14.90)<br>After the trying so many variations of Chao Chye, from Singapore to Malacca, from home cooked to higher end restaurants, I can proudly say that this Chap Chye is up there with the best. The bean curd skin taste is not overpowering and compliments the natural sweetness of the cabbage very well and the vegetables are soft yet not overcooked to mush. Really delicious. <br><br>Assam Fish Curry ($11.90)<br>Wow..... just wow! <br>What&#39;s great about this Assam is that it&#39;s not overly spicy but it packs a punch. <br>Be warned, the first bite might feel a bit overpowering, with an explosion of sourness, tanginess and slight sweetness, with each bite feeling like mini fireworks going off in the mouth but as you keep eating, the flavours mellow down, leaving a nice, almost soothing after taste in the mouth. <br><br>Beef Rendang ($14.90)<br>Another dish cooked with a lot of care and love. The sauce was slightly on the spicy side (very spicy to the wife who&#39;s a non-chilli eater) but it certainly packed a punch. The sauce was fragrant and rich without being overpowering. Once the initial spiciness cleared, the rempah came through, showcasing the fragrant spices used, mixed in with the beefiness from stewing the Rendang. Most importantly was the beef. It was cooked to perfection. Wonderfully tender, the meat fell off the fork while we were trying to pick it up. Another very well executed dish. <br><br>Ayam Buah Keluak ($16.90 + $5.00 for 2 seeds of Buah Keluak)<br>My holy grail of Nonya Cuisine. My biggest weakness and most absolute must have for any Peranakan Restaurant and the ones here have the best Buah Keluak I&#39;ve had..... ever! <br>Firstly, it&#39;s interesting how they used a mixture of Pork Ribs and Chicken instead of just solely chicken. The proteins were cooked perfectly, juicy and tender. Interestingly, because we took away, they actually separated the protein from the Buah Keluak. This gave us the chance to taste the rempah separately and again, it was very good. Fragrant and very tasty, the sauce acted as an enhancement to the protein and not over power it but the spotlight definitely goes to the Buah Keluak. Removed from the shells, blended smooth and re-stuffed, the Buah Keluaks tasted almost like a paté, packed with that rich, delicious black gold. <br><br>Should you want the more familiar style of Ayam Buah Keluak, feel free to mix it both together. We did that eventually and the thick, black yumminess of the Buah Keluak helped elevate the rempah to another level. 2 thumbs and 2 toes up for me! <br><br>Nonya Rice Dumpling ($3.90 at TANGS Marketplace) <br>Ma little pricy in terms of rice dumplings (maybe because it&#39;s TANGS). I have to admit, my favourite is still Kim Choo but that could just be me being bias. However, it still was a pretty good Nonya Zhang. The rice is not as fragrant and tasty as other I&#39;ve tried but it did compliment the filling well, ensuring that the sweetness, saltiness and juiciness of the filling took centre stage. <br><br>Pineapple Tarts ($19.00 - we think)<br>First bite? We were disappointed. The pastry wasn&#39;t as buttery or flavourful as some of the other tarts we&#39;ve tried but once we reached the filling we understood why. The filling was very very good. The Palm sugar shone through and there was a richness and depth to it that a lot of other pineapple filling didn&#39;t have. It felt like it was prepared the traditional way, stewing hours in a copper pot and allowing the sweetness, tartness and spices to blend into a yummy, gooey mix. <br><br>On a whole, we loved the vibe of the restaurant and the food was way above expectations!

text: It&#39;s hard not to get a little sentimental stepping into a place like Makko.  The feel of the place evokes memories of happier, simpler times for me, of days past when a special treat meant walking hand in hand into a place just like Makko with a doting aunt or grandmother to have ondeh-ondeh or kueh kosui for tea.  <br><br>So for me, Makko or places like it will always have an unfair advantage of my nostalgia.  Thanks for being around, Makko!<br><br>What always does it for me...<br>Dry Mee Siam.  This is the house special and if you get there late, they&#39;re usually out.  So you might want to call ahead before hoofing it all the way out to Telok Blangah Rise.  Words are not really up to the task of adequately conveying how full of flavor this apparently simple dish is.  it It may just look like bee hoon or fine rice noodles but every mouthful is redolent with fresh lime, Kaffir lime leaf, lemongrass, fresh chili, sambal and maybe some candlenut...beyond that my palate is so happily saturated and it&#39;s more about how much I&#39;m enjoying every bite and less about what&#39;s in it.  Definitely the star here at Makko!<br><br>What did it for me this time round...<br><br>Tauhu Goreng.  Deep-fried semi-firm tofu under shredded cucumber, bean sprouts and a mountainous helping of spicy peanut sauce (satay sauce).  The veggies are hard to get wrong and Makko doesn&#39;t.  The sauce is the kicker with an unctuous nuttiness and a piquant twist, this part of the palate actually reminds me of a nice brown or amber ale. Always one of my favorite local dishes for its craftiness, where an almost overwhelmingly bold sauce is paired with tofu, cucumber and sprouts, inherently bland tasting elements.  Pure genius!<br><br>Nonya Ngoh Hiang.  Makko&#39;s version of this local Teochew classic is lightly crunchy on the outside, filled with juicy morsels of minced meat and has a nice aromatic spiciness to balance all the gravidity of this deep-fried meat spring roll wrapped in tofu skin.<br><br>Chicken Wings.  These are deep-fried as well in a batter that confers on each morsel a thick armored plating of screamingly hot, crunchy, spicy, gingery, greasy, juicy goodness.  I cannot thick of a better arch-nemesis to Korean-style fried chicken which has skin that is almost painted on and air light. I recommend having these fresh with a cold beer where you can slowly pick apart every bit of the wing and enjoy every spicy, crunchy bit of armor plating.  The subtle yellow ginger flavor suffusing every bite is pure genius.

text: A spacious and cosy cafe in a quiet neighbourhood of Opera Estate. Baker and Cook never fails to satisfy one&#39;s craving for desserts with a wide variety of cakes, pastries and tarts. My favourite are Pecan/Apricot tarts. For savoury items, the quiches are a good choice and you can get a set with a side of salad.
This is a nice cosy place with lots of variety of foo and bread. But may need to work on their coffee. Probably not a place for coffee lovers :p

text: Wife had the french toast and she absolutely love it.  Accordingly to her all the components worked and does not feel too heavy.  Boy had the pancake and tasted good too.  I had the Bagel which came nice and warm though a little too bread like for my liking and the cream cheese was not spreadable.  Sorry i much prefer the American version i suppose.  On the Croissant it was nice and airy but not overly flaky.  The table jam worked well with the baked goodies.  Waiting staff was excellently on the ball and all smiles.  One of the older &#34;Aunty&#34; waitress still bother to do a short introduction of what sauces came with the French Toast my wife had so that is a plus.  The ambiance was good too and definitely good for a lazy weekend meal.  Now the only down side is i wish the staff that took my order SMILE and be a little bit more patient with ordering definitely no &#34;good morning&#34; there!  She or a He has a terrible attitude and interaction with customers which perhaps He/She worked up on the wrong side of the bed :).  oh.. one more thing.  Can&#39;t find the operating hours any where on the website perhaps they can address that.

text: My parents brought me here for my birthday on Saturday, and I have totally fallen in love with this place! Just a heads up, it may be quite out of the way, but I think there are a few buses that go there. <br><br>The space was really clean, big &amp; bright; something I really appreciate in cafes mainly because I don&#39;t like  small spaces. <br><br>We tried almost everything on the menu; would definitely recommend the soft shell crab burger (light and crispy!), crab roll (loveeeed the croissant; was super generous with the crab meat as well), and the pulled pork Benedict (my mum polished off her plate!)<br><br>Their unicorn cake (coconut &amp; mango) is a MUST have, and it&#39;s definitely one of my favorite cakes this year. It was really light and tangy. <br><br>Would definitely come back !

text: Be careful you don&#39;t get the name of this place mixed up with an actual &#34;buffet&#34; because it&#39;s Boufe, not Buffet. Had a nice brunch at this quaint place in the midst of an office campus. It was a good 10 minutes, unshaded walk from Tanglin Road into a mixed use campus. So on a hot day, that air con is gonna feel extra nice when you step into the cool dining room. There is also outdoor seating in the back but it looked like stuff was being stored there when I took a peek.<br><br>The food was nicely presented but more importantly, it was very tasty and exceeded my expectations after having some disappointing brunches lately. The food quality was very fresh and appealing. Highlights were the fluffy scrambled eggs and the sweet cherry tomatoes served slightly grilled and still the vine. Service was good and prompt, but oddly the coffee ordered arrived halfway through the meal. The server did apologize for the delay and said it was &#34;due to the coffee being recalibrating&#34; ... I&#39;m not sure what that meant, but it&#39;s quite possible I heard incorrectly. Nevertheless, great flat white. <br><br>There&#39;s a little boutique shop in-house selling jewelry, clothing, and accessories that&#39;s worth a browse. Didn&#39;t get to try the selection of desserts, but the server did offer. It&#39;s going to have to be a rain check because there was just no more belly room.

text: Normal cafe standard food and prices! Although location is not quite accessible for people who do not drive, the staffs here are very friendly and make you feel welcomed! There&#39;s a free cake too on your birthday month!

text: Had a nice brunch in this cafe. Love their quiet little place. Its pretty and cozy. The coffee is good, brunch was yummy and good portion. Their lime tart was so good and fresh! Nice place to chit chat with ur buddy. <br>They have a pretty white marquée in the back, serounded with greenery, even i spotted some little yellow birds on the branch.<br>One thing i disapointed here, they dont have free wifi.

text: Visited here for Cosmo cake. It&#39;s really unique and beautiful. Really happy. Also ordered their egg Benedict. It&#39;s good too. Their chamomile garden tea is still my preferred choice. Once a while having lunch, breakfast or tea here is good ^^ Happy! Down side is this location isn&#39;t easy accessible if you doesn&#39;t have a car.

Previously I had a flat white, a lychee tea and truffle fries. Coffee was straightforward no complaints. Lychee tea was refreshing. Truffle fries served hot but not enough truffle. Some of the staff are young and inexperienced but quite eager to please which makes up for a lot.<br><br>My 3rd time to this place. Friend&#39;s bday impromptu brunch. We were seated on the verandah out at the back and it was a warm day but we felt cool enough and it was nice to have the greenery. The odd ant but hey when in jungle, swing from tree.<br><br>Bday girl Emma J and I got to the scene first. We ordered the truffled mushroom on house baked baguette and french toast to share. Mushrooms were great with creamy rich sauce, lots of truffle flavour and scent and the baguette looked homemade and was chewy, tasty with a darker brown crust than usual. This looked so good that our late-comer friends all picked from it.<br><br>French toast - served with some kinda caramel sauce and chantilly cream. The cream held itself together well despite the hot day. The toast was a thick cut of brioche, I think about 5 inch square. The rest of us dipped the fries in the caramel sauce but Emma J was horrified. We all liked this.<br><br>Truffle fries. Not much on the truffle flavour again but a generous portion served piping hot and crisp.<br><br>Friend ordered the big breakfast - all commented that the croissant was much smaller than expected. It really was a mini croissant. But the brek came with 2 big juicy sausages. Perhaps they are going low carb...Personally prefer if this came with a good sized piece of toast. Eggs were nicely cooked, soft layered and seasoned just right.<br><br>Breakfast mains mostly $19 to $21. We all commented that the food was tasty and seemed like quality ingredients. Pleasing and with some nice bits but I wouldn&#39;t travel far for it.<br><br>We also ordered chicken wings to share - these came in a sauce that one friend described as zingy. Served hot, crispy - the sauce was bit spicy. Comfort food but yummier if you dip.<br><br>Foam on my flatwhite was a little flat with some big bubbles so it didn&#39;t have that velvety smoothness that some of the serious boys and girls serve up. I think coffee for is me is a 3 or 3.5. But yes the free parking, breezy white look, bit off the beaten track and so near where I stay. If i need a quick cuppa, I would come..clearly I did.<br><br>They serve a lemon meringue tart which I&#39;ve had on my first visit but found it a tad sweet. Ok crust.

Nice cakes, the standard big brekkies, coffee, an indoor and outdoor seating area, an inconvenient location, this cafe has it all.<br><br>Do I like it? It&#39;s okay. I had a big breakfast and an iced mint tea of sorts. I do give them credit for their perfect scrambled eggs. <br><br>Oh, and I got bitten by a few mozzies while seated at their outdoor area, which wasn&#39;t too hot as they had sufficient fans.

text: Lovely staff who greets with a smile when you enter and says goodbye when you leave. Much different from the service staff at Thomson (please refer to my review there). <br><br>I had a lovely cup of skinny latte, which had a chocolatey, roasted and creamy profile that was right up my alley. <br><br>For the food, I had the sunny lovin. It was a generous smear of avocado guacamole on TOP each half of the English muffin and topped with a poached egg. Was under seasoned but nothing a pinch of salt didn&#39;t fix.

text: This is another one of the third wave coffee independent coffee chains in the Lion city which have become popular. We went to the siglap location which is very popular and the seating available is not all that much. Best to go a little before usual meal times to ensure a seat. Their coffee is solid and they have decent brunch and snack options. We only tried the coffee this time around but will be back to sample the food in the future as it definitely looked good (on the nearby tables!!).

text: The food was nothing special. Yes it was a big portion. What surprises me is when i ordered brew coffee. I mentioned to the cashier i want brew coffee (i assume she know house brew) Or maybe they were trained to charge a $8 basic coffee, when i asked her what is v60 she said brew coffee, so i assume it is something special i was excited. Half way finishing our big breakfast the v60 came. It was lukewarm, diluted and basic. Anyway just sharing this to let any new comer know how to order and dealt with the indie-youngsters-overhyped cafe.

text: This is a good local neighborhood coffee shop, good coffee, good food, good service. I&#39;ve been here a couple of time to get coffee and met friends for breakfast once as well. It&#39;s a bit small and can get crowded, but they tables to sit at and enjoy your breakfast with table service after ordering at the counter and they have high chairs as well. They don&#39;t have a kids menu, and their food portions are rather large. The coffee is good, the chalkboard showing all the different coffees is GREAT, you can get an coffeducation while waiting for your drink, maybe even change up your next order. The coffee price and portion seems a bit expensive, compared to Starbucks, but about on par for small neighborhood coffee shops. <br>They have free filtered water at a self service station, which is always a major plus for me.<br>Convenient parking in the Siglap V garage down below as well.

text: This is a place I drive by everyday. Either on the way to work or on the way home. What always attracts me is the soft lighting and the wood furniture. It gives me a very calm and soft feeling. So decided to finally give it a try. <br><br>Walked in and was greeted by the staff. Nothing short of what you&#39;ll expect at cafes nowadays. Didn&#39;t bother to look at the menu, as I feel to operate a cafe, a good coffee is always necessary. So I got myself a iced latte and a cappuccino. Took a whiff of the coffee, and it was strong. I remembered I had something so strong was back when I was in Greece. <br><br>But once you mix in the milk and the espresso together. It became a symphony of flavours. The coffee they use are a little more towards the acidic side. I love the flavours that linger in my mouth. <br><br>For me this is indeed one of the best coffees in Singapore. And what I love is that this is a no frills place. No pretentious staff and decor. It&#39;s nice, pleasant on the eyes and it relaxes my soul! Yes! Even with my coffee, it doesn&#39;t take long before I start feeling like I need a nap. <br><br>So when you&#39;re around the area, do drop by for your cuppa.

text: I literally drive past this café every single day after work. The fact that this place is just a 7-min drive from my home, questions my sanity. Every time my car stops at the stoplight at the T-junction facing Siglap V, I contemplate. &#34;Should I go? Should I not go?&#34; <br><br>I have read too many positive reviews about the café that it made me super curious and intrigued. So yes. Curiosity finally slaughtered the cat in me. I gave in and went today; along with my two willing colleagues.<br><br>Why didn&#39;t I come here sooner? Why? Why?!! Every single thing we ordered were brilliant. I ordered a glass of their Butterscotch Latte, whilst the rest of the food were shared amongst us three. We ordered Cinnamon Churros Ice Cream, Milo Dinosaur Waffles and Salted Caramel Pavlova. Fwoah!! If that&#39;s not enough sugar rush for you, I don&#39;t know what will.<br><br>I think these were the best churros I&#39;ve had so far. They tasted really crunchy and authentic. You could really taste the perfect cinnamon flavour. They were served in a glass with a scoop of chocolate-drizzled vanilla ice-cream in between.<br><br>As for the pavlova, I opted it since I saw the words, &#39;Salted Caramel&#39; plastered onto it. I love salted caramel. Watching the staff cut a slice off the pavlova with a big knife was an enthralling watch. Haha! My colleague and I had our eyes glued. The meringue was baked into perfection. Even the caramel was brilliant.<br><br>Moving onto our chocolate waffle, this was served to us the last. Firstly, I have to applaud on the presentation. Loved the mini marshmallows that were used as toppings. So cute! They had a dollop of vanilla ice-cream in the middle, topped with Milo powder. Another thumbs-up from all of us. Although, one of my colleagues commented that it would have been nicer if the waffle was a bit spongier.<br><br>Overall, we loved the desserts. All of us ended up feeling contented after the sugary meal; no thanks to the stress at work. The service too was commendable. The lovely staff girls were all very friendly and considerate enough to tell us that the cakes are all Halal (supplied by a young local Malay baker, Farah H. Affandi -- go google her cake creations!).<br><br>And oh! Parking slots are available at 3 convenient places. You may either park your vehicles at the basement carpark of the building itself, the lots behind the building, or the basement carpark at Siglap Centre located right across.<br><br>For now, I think a hot glass of green tea is in order!

Understandable if you&#39;re a bistro that makes mediocre coffee. But when you call yourself a &#34;speciality coffee house&#34; and with a name as &#34;craftsman&#34; and serve up slush that they do... Food is average but exorbitant. But the coffee here is a complete joke.<br><br>Word of advice - don&#39;t be pretentious by calling yourself a speciality coffee house.

Fruity waffle topped with delicious bananas, strawberries and blueberries', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Fruity waffle topped with delicious bananas, strawberries and blueberries'}]
text: I absolutely love this place. <br><br>When I first saw this cafe on burpple, I went onto their website and looked for the menu. One look at the menu and I knew I had to try it out. So I did. And I was not disappointed.<br><br>I had their Fruity Buttermilk Waffle ($15-$16) and a regular sized Chai Latte ($5). <br><br>It took a while for the waffle to come out but it was definitely worth the wait. The waffle was topped with bananas, blueberries and strawberries along with maple syrup. It was superb! Also, the Chai Latte was one of the best Chai Latte&#39;s i&#39;ve had in Singapore. My first Chai Latte was in Tokyo&#39;s Dean and Deluca and nothing has lived up to their standards. But this did. I was delighted to have finally found a place which serves good Chai Latte. ahahaha<br><br>On the downside, I wished they had a few comfy chairs so I could chill there with a book and also served muffins!!<br><br>However, the atmosphere was real cosy, perfect for working or studying! :)

Delish Banana Upside Down cake!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Delish Banana Upside Down cake!'}]
text: Chance upon this cafe when getting a couple of stuff from a supermarket nearby. Felt right at home with the industrial chic interior. Love the lighting and quirky deco. Friendly service. Though young lady serving me tried to entice me with an early dinner, I wasn&#39;t put off by her attempt. <br>Wasn&#39;t disappointed with my cappuccino. One of the better ones I have had. Was lucky to be there for their not so often made Banana Upside Down cake. Nothing fancy, but the taste and texture - pure comfort. It was delish!<br>Would I return to try their mains? Most certainly would ;)

Salted Caramel Popcorn', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Salted Caramel Popcorn'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/yG2DFhlSeEcTYdcNviMQQw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/craftsmen-specialty-coffee-singapore?reviewid=hrKF9Kx_kw0fE9gLLIJT5A&select=yG2DFhlSeEcTYdcNviMQQw', 'altText': 'Photo of Craftsmen Specialty Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Flat White', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Flat White'}]
text: Craftsmen Specialty Coffee is now open!<br><br>Yes! After a temporary closure due to staff training, Craftsmen Specialty Coffee, which specializes in coffee and cakes, had a reopening just few days ago.<br><br>Besides from the food options, they also have appliances for sale here.<br><br>Dutch Colony Coffee Co.&#39;s blends are used here. The Flat White ($4.50) tasted strong and firm, yet has a low acidity that everyone can enjoy.<br><br>The bakes and pastries here are supplied by online bakery Fathiscakes and Bonheur Pattiserie. The Salted Caramel Popcorn ($8.90), one of the cakes baked by Fathiscakes, is firm and satisfying. The caramel taste is just right; flavourful and not too sweet. Add a pinch of salt with popcorns on every mouthful and this will became a delightful cake to have.<br><br>The location also meant that it is a quiet respite for people to relax with a cup of coffee or to study in during the day. With its reopening, the Siglap / East Coast area has now yet another cafe to be added to its list.

Can&#39;t complain about the lack of coffee spots in the East anymore with so many sprouting like mushrooms! I actually visited Craftsmen Specialty Coffee at Siglap V, just opposite Siglap Centre, when they first opened (that was months back). Well, it took this long because well.. it&#39;s just another cafe... who gets its beans from somewhere else, and in this case from Dutch Colony Coffee Co., which opened its outpost a few streets down... And as the story goes....<br><br>First, the coffee. The Craftsmen blend is 40% El Salvador Finca El Carmen, 30% Ethiopia Konga natural Yirgacheffe and 30% Sumatra Triple Picked Mandheling. You get balanced notes with a hint of ripe lemon and dark chocolate finish. The coffee was bold and robust, just the way i like it. <br><br>Drinks are in the $4-$5 range. Our latte and flat white were both $4.50 each. To differentiate itself, Craftsmen also has a brew bar which does V60, Chemex, Siphon, Woodneck and French Press coffees ($6-$8).  You can also get your hands on the usual coffee making products- Hario, Bodum blahblah.<br><br>Food wise, we weren&#39;t impressed. Quiches ($9) and sandwiches ($15-16) are made in house. We had the Pulled Pork sandwich ($15), which was MEH. The meat wasn&#39;t seasoned well. It tastes of meat that&#39;s bland and tough. Where&#39;s the spice man? The choice of bread was also kinda off with a thin waxy brown skin and a strange center with a chewy pull. Well because the meat was so dry, it remained separated from the bread.<br><br>Thankfully, they chose the right cake and pastry supplier, Fathis, who apparently supplies to many cafes (i can&#39;t be sure of that) but anyhoo, i was thoroughly impressed with their moist and chunky banana walnut bread with a dollop of of cream cheese frosting. Other cakes available include a Salted Caramel Popcorn and Blueberry Cheesecake, and they look really hearty!<br><br>So well, head over to Craftsmen for coffee and a piece of cake if you&#39;re in the area. After all, it beats having the usual Coffee Club mudpie, or Udders ice cream.

With Craftsmen open right in front of my doorstep, there&#39;s really no more reason to spend time searching for new cafes ;)<br><br>Coffee? Check. The good people at Craftsmen use Dutch Colony beans, which are one of my favourite beans (apart from Sumatran!). The many times I&#39;ve been here, I&#39;ve never been let down by their coffee thus far - I recommend their cappuccino, their lattes, their mocha - heck, try it all.<br><br>Food wise, nothing that special. I&#39;ve tried their poached eggs on english muffin, wasn&#39;t wow&#39;d by it. However, I haven&#39;t really tried much else so don&#39;t be deterred by that. My only irk is that due to the interior decor (minimalistic, high ceilings, enclosed), it tends to get rather noisy and sound echoes a lot.<br><br>I&#39;m still a sucker for their coffee ;)

text: The coffee is not bad but, unfortunately, the ethos of the place is not sufficiently customer centric. We had been waiting for our coffee for 20 minutes) which was okay as they were super busy. Then the owner arrived and was immediately given priority - they made him a coffee in less than a minute. When challenged they stated, &#34;but he&#39;s the owner...&#34;. His fault, not theirs. We now go elsewhere!
Ordered 2 coffee drinks when the place was not crowded ... Took 10 mins to get my coffee :( ambience is nice but the pace is really slow ...

text: I was surprised at how good the cappuccino was. I did not expect that as it was fairly empty when I was there on a Saturday morning. Maybe it was the weekend. There was a promotion for a cake and coffee set. <br><br>So I also had the ondeh gula melaka cake which was delicious. The cake was moist and soft and full of gula melaka goodness. <br><br>The only drawback was the fact that they do not serve water at all. I mean, sometimes you do want water to wash down the cake and coffee, just like you need water after ice cream. <br><br>I solved the problem by buying bottled water from Guardian Pharmacy which was across from it.

Greens Pasta (1/2 portion)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Greens Pasta (1/2 portion)'}]
text: Love their service and especially their sticky date pudding. One of the most value for money sticky date pudding I&#39;ve had and the portion and taste is awesome! The way the sticky date pudding is served is also rather different from any others out there. You have the ice cream sandwiched between 2 slices of cake and the sauce around. A good way to have a spoonful of all the goodies in one mouth. <br><br>They also serve half portions for pasta and sandwiches. Check with the server to get more info on that. <br><br>Do note that it&#39;s really crowded during meal times so go during off peak to enjoy your meal in peace.

text: My family&#39;s favorite breakfast place. We love the coffee, break, eggs, shaved gam and avocado plate. My kids love the chocolate shake and my husband loves the tuna sandwich. We just can&#39;t get enough of the food at thus cafe:)

Very convenient cafe restaurant.  They serve sandwiches, pasta, pizza, etc.  Pizza is near Roma type, but tastes good.  Very reasonable and makes you stop by when you want a tea and snack.  Try the lasagna, it&#39;s great!<br>カフェの延長ですね。食べ物はピザが一番無難かな。アイスチャイを頼んだら失敗したので要注意。チキンアボガドサラダはボチボチ、あ、ラザニアは小さくてパスタも薄いけど挽肉の味付けがかなり美味かった！2015/11

Affordable fare (at least in the area) and decent enough. We had the beef sandwich, garlic prawn pizza, smoked salmon salad, ravioli and lasagna for dinner.<br><br>The beef sandwich was pretty decent and the other items were acceptable. Nothing fantastic but not badly executed either. I wouldn&#39;t mind coming here again if I were stuck in Tanglin Mall, given the dearth of options.

text: had a coffee pow wow here with none other than our CM!:)<br><br>nice environment.<br>no wait for table.<br>menus promptly given and left me alone to decide.<br><br>not sure what the deal is with tanglin mall but the last time i was here there was a fire alarm test.<br>today again, they had a fire alarm test!!!???<br>can be annoying when you are trying to chillax.<br>i pity the poor mommy trying to nurse her baby next to me!<br><br>not sure whether marcus was lunching here, so i ordered a latte whilst i waited for him to arrive.<br>texted him and ordered a latte for him too!<br>my latte art was missing.<br>his arrived with a nice heart shape and he timed his entrance to perfection!<br>so much so that, i didn&#39;t even had a chance to point and shoot at his!:(<br><br>to me their latte is good.<br>organic coffee by aroma.<br><br>hopefully, no fire alarm test the next time i come?

good food. but do not expect good service. <br><br>love the ciabatta/turkish toast. <br><br>they let you customize the order as much as possible...i.e. half portions (at half the price), good for eating out with kids.
