text: Café Beviamo is a nice café to grab a bite in Tanglin Mall. The busiest times there would be during lunch and sometimes you may have to wait for a table. Its frequented by a lot of expat housewives that live around the area. <br><br>The food is really good here though. My favorite thing to get would be the all day breakfast. Perfect scrambled eggs served with buttered toast and tomatoes. They also have a sweet vanilla risotto served with stewed apples which makes for an interesting alternative to oatmeal. <br><br>They have numerous sandwhiches which are all freshly made on their rustic ciabatta or soft brown bread. Desserts here are pretty good too, try the sticky date pudding with vanilla ice cream. <br><br>And a must have is the soy chai tea latte--the best in Singapore.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=QZqj0zcaOXV63mVVVLAhhQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/x5r99h9GAwEtB_JLWsLe5Q/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/x5r99h9GAwEtB_JLWsLe5Q/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/x5r99h9GAwEtB_JLWsLe5Q/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/x5r99h9GAwEtB_JLWsLe5Q/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/x5r99h9GAwEtB_JLWsLe5Q/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/x5r99h9GAwEtB_JLWsLe5Q/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'PJ R.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'PJ R.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=QZqj0zcaOXV63mVVVLAhhQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 1, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 33, 'eliteYear': None}
text: On the main level of Tanglin Mall, Caffe Beviamo is always jam packed with mainly expats from morning tea onwards into late afternoon. Very simple straight forward café food here, nothing really inspiring or funky on the menu, just comforting café classics like bruschetta, sandwiches, bolognaise pasta etc. <br><br>They also have a wide selection of cakes, cookies and other nibbley bits. Has an Australian influence throughout the menu, lamingtons, rocky road etc. This is great for someone like me that misses home from time to time, though a lamington that isn&#39;t filled with jam and cream!!! That just cannot be!, as an aussie in my book it should be a criminal offence to do a lamington which isn&#39;t wedged with both jam and cream, saying that though it is a pretty decent piece of cake. Service while not the most knowledgeable is always cheerful and helpful. Good place for a cheap comforting lunch.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hWm5z3nBb4q6-fuNsyr0kg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-marmalade-pantry-singapore-4?reviewid=gJ0QNboxLIBIRGpLlcknrA&select=hWm5z3nBb4q6-fuNsyr0kg', 'altText': 'Photo of The Marmalade Pantry - Singapore, Singapore. Chocolate pudding with vanilla ice cream ($14)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Chocolate pudding with vanilla ice cream ($14)'}]
text: Aug 2017<br><br>Spinach and kale salad ($24) - 3.5 stars<br>It was nice that they included the salads in the Entertainer promotion but the portion was small. This wouldn&#39;t have filled me up as a main.<br><br>Beef cheek paparadelle ($26) - 3.75 stars<br>The beef was soft and tender though it had a bit too much of a gamey taste. Have to agree with my dining companions that the black pepper sauce was a bit odd, like a black pepper beef hor fun and the paparadelle noodles an odd type of kway teow.<br><br>Crabmeat pasta ($24) - 4 stars<br>The pasta was al dente and the sauce was well flavored, though a bit too spicy for me. Good amount of crab as well.<br><br>Chocolate pudding with vanilla ice cream ($14) - 3.5 stars<br>Nice soft chocolate cake but the chocolate flavor wasn&#39;t very strong. It was very small. The vanilla ice cream was alright, better than your Walls but not as good as Haagen Dazs.<br><br>========================<br><br>Jan 2017<br><br>Caprese sandwich - 3.5 stars<br>The mozzarella didn&#39;t have much flavor or richness, the basil didn&#39;t taste very fresh, and the tomatoes lacked flavor too. The focaccia was good, and the fries were pretty crispy and spicy but I don&#39;t like fries much.<br><br>The Marmalade Club - 3.5 stars<br>A little better than the one above because the ingredients were naturally more tasty - egg, ham and I think what was a chicken salad. Came with sweet potato fries, which was a nice addition.<br><br>Ambience 3.5 stars<br>It was a pretty quiet and nice place for lunch but too dim to work at.

GOLD MOSCATO', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'GOLD MOSCATO'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vaUaJ3yAplgfpaYP1akGfQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-marmalade-pantry-singapore-4?reviewid=Kvj7Rzyu-e-xJZP2s4e4gg&select=vaUaJ3yAplgfpaYP1akGfQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Marmalade Pantry - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/x7XTRS-lMEd0N5dD2PCmjg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-marmalade-pantry-singapore-4?reviewid=Kvj7Rzyu-e-xJZP2s4e4gg&select=x7XTRS-lMEd0N5dD2PCmjg', 'altText': 'Photo of The Marmalade Pantry - Singapore, Singapore. LOBSTER BARLEY RISOTTO', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'LOBSTER BARLEY RISOTTO'}]
text: The restaurant was located at the first floor of the hotel, looking like the usual hotel&#39;s coffee house. The dine in area was quite wide, much bigger compared to its ION outlet.<br><br>LOBSTER BARLEY RISOTTO ($32.00)<br>butternut, carrots, onion, garlic flower, lobster chunks, lobster braised barley, parmesan, sour cream and tarragon<br>Instead of the usual rice for risotto, barley was used here, which soaked up the flavours nicely and gave a kind of bounchy texture.<br><br>MISO LOBSTER ($34)<br>lobster chunks in tobiko and miso mayo with cucumber and red radish on sesame bun with shoestring fries<br>I was slightly disppointed that it served on burger bun that had not been toasted or fried with butter. The lobster was chunky and well marinated.<br><br>GOLD MOSCATO ($7.50++)<br>White tea with gold dust<br>It was light and refreshing.<br><br>PURIFY ($9.50++)<br>kiwi, orange, papaya, mango<br>Detoxifying, cleanses the internal system and aids digestion<br>The freshly squeezed juice was thick and rich.<br><br>I was using AMEX platinum which was suppose to have 50% discount when dining for 2 paxs, but turned out only 50% off for the 2 main couses. Felt slightly cheated by the promotion.

Vongole clams spaghetti', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Vongole clams spaghetti'}]
text: The general quality of food is good! Especially on my recent visit, thoroughly enjoyed the great value of my delicious clams vongole which came with a lot of tasty gravy - fragrant, appetising and a nice balanced tinge of lemon grass sourness, all that at a very affordable price using the one for one deal from the entertainer app. Thumbs up for the excellent service as the waitress gladly complied with my request for additional gravy which pretty much became soup for me, as a passionate soup lover. The recent experience totally made up for an earlier visit where I was slightly disappointed with the pork chop that felt rather stiff, perhaps overcooked. My friends and I enjoyed the recent meal together very much as a whole, at a comfortable cosy ambience.

Stuffed chicken entree', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Stuffed chicken entree'}]
text: Inside the Oasia Hotel, this medium size restaurant offers a great breakfast buffet, full bar and lunch and dinner menus. We came here on a business trip and our sleep schedules have been completely off (as expected) so we decided to just have dinner here one night since we wanted a break from noodles and street type of food. Got easy seating about 6pm but it did start to fill up after 6:45pm. They did offer us happy hour on drinks. We ordered the Chicken stuffed with sundried tomatoes and spinach served with a buttery whire cream sauce and a side of carrots, potatoes and asparagus. The dish was divine. The chicken was seasoned so well and it was moist and everything was cooked perfectly. Also ordered the sweetpotatoes and pork belly and again everything was cooked well and we scraped our plates. For dessert we ordered the pear bread pudding with vanilla icecream and it was one of the best desserts I had in a long time.  I took pictures of both. Singapore has not disappointed us with the food. Everything is packed with flavor but this little gem gave us that nice meal we wanted without breaking the bank and just downstairs. Definitely give it a try!

text: Elegant, understated dining room - not open like at ion Orchard. The food is innovative and quite good, albeit not reaching any wow level. Service staff are all friendly and helpful. Not sure about the kitchen staff, as the wait for the food can take forever, which is understandable for my Kurobota char siew, but also for the pastas or egg &amp; sausage brunch dishes of neighbouring patrons. Pricey for a non-fine dining restaurant; worth it only with the Entertainer 1-for-1 offer.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=A_ivP9MrMxD5BXpY0Dhbvw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Sunil K.', 'displayLocation': 'Bukit Batok, Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Sunil K.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=A_ivP9MrMxD5BXpY0Dhbvw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': 3, 'reviewCount': 29, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Had the tomato soup, French toast and Mac&amp;Cheese.  All the dishes were well cooked and tasted good.  I&#39;ll definitely try this place again!

Valle is something of a well kept secret. Tucked away at the end of the row of shops including Haato and E-Sarn at Ridgewood Close Condominium, I would not have known about it myself if a friend hadn&#39;t brought me there. Valle is a nondescript neighbourhood bar, but don&#39;t let appearances fool you. The bar is stocked with a smorgasboard of beers, ciders and ales from all over the world. I was shocked and delighted to find Paulaner Munich on tap for $12 a pint. In fact, all the drinks are priced super reasonably. You can get Rekordlig for $12 compared to the $15 you usually see it sold for at the bars in town. You can refer to this page <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.valle.com.sg%2Ffullmenu.html&amp;s=ec5330c1c18a2a22149b8bc75e763fc8ee09006bfcd73b4434c79941498afea8" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">valle.com.sg/fullmenu.ht…</a> for the incredibly comprehensive menu. The prices listed are delivery prices (yes, they offer delivery) but I believe the prices at the bar are $1 or $2 more. Needless to say, if you&#39;re an avid beer drinker, you will really like Valle. I also like the low key and casual vibe of the place. It really is your friendly neighbourhood bar where you can hang out and with your friends while enjoying a really good beer. Sadly, I&#39;ve heard that the condo management has been forcing Valle&#39;s owner to revise the closing time earlier and earlier. While they used to close at midnight, they now have to close at 10pm, I&#39;m guessing because of residents&#39; complaints. This is probably why Valle&#39;s happy hour ends at 6 as the owner wants to encourage people to visit in the day. I do think Valle would be a really nice spot for a quiet afternoon drink as well.

Three stars would have been a generous figure. The service is agreeable- the staff are attentive, consistent and knowledgeable about the menu. There was slight hard selling in the form of aggressive and rapid rambling off the profile of the desserts and the available accoutrements in order to get you to cave. I don&#39;t think I needed the $6 chocolate dip for my churros, thanks. <br><br>Now the main reason for the rating- the quality of the desserts are not commensurate to the prices charged. I can appreciate the concept behind the desserts and the intended nuances, but the fact is the taste did not meet the price tag or the hype. <br><br>Seating is limited and nucleated, albeit with warm lighting and speakeasy style music. One big issue was the fact that the smell of fried fish greeted you as you entered the premises. This is a dessert bar. Not a good start. Also, very noisy and slightly rowdy, with the crowd veering to the younger, more affluent (and slightly pretentious) crowd. <br><br>Insta-friendly but it ends there. Not the place for me.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=TGVTWLNSyORFAN8Zc2D_uQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Daniel Z.', 'displayLocation': 'Ithaca, NY', 'altText': 'Daniel Z.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=TGVTWLNSyORFAN8Zc2D_uQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': 19, 'reviewCount': 111, 'eliteYear': None}
text: A nice dessert bar that captures the high-end experience with pretty reasonable prices. There&#39;s a $15 min. per person, you will easily hit that if each person orders a dessert (which runs anywhere from $15 - $25). We got the churros which one serving was more than enough for the two of us. They were warm, doughy, and very tasty, albeit too much sprinkled sugar. We also ordered the cheese cake. Tasted fine and came with a hodgepodge of jello, marshmellow and fruit bits. Didn&#39;t do much but was nice. As others have commented, the service is a little lacking. We sat at the bar and besides the initial order we had zero contact with the staff. Even when we left, no one said anything. Sophisticated vibe does not mean you need to sacrifice small customer touch points.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=_R7JAPiYofY3rNpjTNAR1w', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Mac Daniel D.', 'displayLocation': 'Saint Helena, CA', 'altText': 'Mac Daniel D.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=_R7JAPiYofY3rNpjTNAR1w', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 3, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I came here last night, 03/23/2018, as part of my to experience list while I was in Singapore. To be totally honest, I was expecting to be wow&#39;ed and mind blown. You can imagine my disappointment when it was all said and done. My sister started with a sorta pink cocktail that I can&#39;t remember and I had the mist. Both were excellent. Then, we had the 3 course menu each without pairing because the spring menu was not available due to the ingredients not being available during this time.<br><br>SERVICE:<br><br>  The service was not terrible but bad. They weren&#39;t very hospitalable and much to our surprise, clueless about the beverages and menu. I asked our server how dry or sweet the bottle of champagne we are ordering and she looked at me like I was speaking alien. So I asked if it was brut or demisec. She says not brut but sure enough when the bottle came it was brut. For some reason I felt like they looked down on me and my sister. Never have I ever felt so different in a restaurant. <br><br>DRINKS:<br><br>cocktails were excellent and the sparkling/ champagne were great for the price.<br><br>DESSERTS:<br><br>Recap<br>I had the Zen menu and my sister had the playful menu.<br><br>Plating wise, it was a hit and miss. <br>The pistachio and stone desserts looked great while the matcha tart looked terrible, pretty nice quenelle tho (even tho there was a gaping hole on its side) and so on and so forth.<br><br>Flavors<br>The taste is what the menu says. There was no complexity in terms of flavor. Like I said, bland.<br><br>To summarize it, I was sadly disappointed. Maybe next time?

Tucked at the end of the road in a pretty trendy neighborhood lined with a mix-match of eateries lies 2am. It is easy to miss in its nondescript building with its sign in the window. Come here for the final course of the evening: dessert. It is an impressive collection of sweet treats that are a beautiful end to an evening. Skip the dinner items and the service leaves a lot to be desired. <br><br>We should have gone to another local restaurant in the neighborhood for dinner. The savory dishes were rather lackluster. Everything we ordered seemed to be missing a final touch to make it a good dish. The mac and cheese lacked the truffle essence while the popcorn chicken seemed dry. The tacos were alright, while the sliders were simple and make you say &#34;i&#39;ve had better.&#34;<br><br>The desserts are the showpiece and the reason you come here. The selection is pretty impressive and go with a group if you are willing to share and get a bite from each. The churros were pretty fantastic, especially with the hot chocolate dipping pot. Cheesecake was light but offered a pretty nice contrast in flavors from the baileys and the passion fruit, while the chocolate pop-rocks cake was a nice play on a childhood favorite.<br><br>The ambiance is rather dark and contemporary. It comes across rather cold and a throwback to a 90s design aesthetic. Its ok, but not something you your mom and dad would appreciate. Service was rather uncomfortable and they seemed to lack a confidence in their knowledge of the menu while they watched to the point where you couldn&#39;t really chat with your friends. At the end of it, the ambiance and service present a feeling: cold and unwelcomed.

Hanasakura', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Hanasakura'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/4ZmVlX5_LU-QYHUSItDyaA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/2am-dessert-bar-singapore?reviewid=ajtYaMLp3L2m-rPU4r8Q3Q&select=4ZmVlX5_LU-QYHUSItDyaA', 'altText': 'Photo of 2am: Dessert Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/xOPSFrrxD2T4sT3OnsAUfw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/2am-dessert-bar-singapore?reviewid=ajtYaMLp3L2m-rPU4r8Q3Q&select=xOPSFrrxD2T4sT3OnsAUfw', 'altText': 'Photo of 2am: Dessert Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/TXGjQPf0V21Bt7NplTm-Aw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/2am-dessert-bar-singapore?reviewid=ajtYaMLp3L2m-rPU4r8Q3Q&select=TXGjQPf0V21Bt7NplTm-Aw', 'altText': 'Photo of 2am: Dessert Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: Creative desserts with several layers of flavor. I enjoyed looking at the desserts and admire the creative process and thinking that went behind the dessert.<br>Janice Wong owner,pastry chef is the artist /chef/owner behind this dessert bar.<br>Ambiance is cozy. Reservation is recommended.

Award-winning dessert chef!! Desserts that cost less than some cocktails in Singapore!! <br><br>Cassis Plum is her signature dessert, so had to try this one first. It was a refreshing dessert that achieved a nice balance between tart and sweet. The yuzu pearls added a fun additional texture and flavor.<br><br>Almost ordered the Cacao Forest, because earl grey, miso, whisky, and cotton candy in one dessert?! Unlikely, adventurous pairings such as these intrigue me. <br><br>Also ordered the ever-popular churros, because, why not...it was just too tempting. They were actually quite heavy and oily. Need to be eaten immediately or the oil just takes over, and it becomes a wet sponge.<br><br>There&#39;s also a short list of savory items, but dessert comes before savory on the menu. Not too often you can find an entire restaurant featuring innovative desserts, so hats off to Janice Wong and 2am.

This place salvages a three star rating because of the atmosphere. The desserts are way over-hyped in my opinion and priced far beyond what they&#39;re worth. The churros and hot chocolate were the best dish we had but were nevertheless underwhelming and exceedingly bitter. The chocolate forest dessert was such an odd selection of flavours it was impossible to discern what the goal was. It is almost as if so much is attention to distinguishing the look of the dishes that the flavour profile is just sort of thrown together. I am sad to say this feels like a place seeming high-class by making its dishes rather obscure just for the sake of appearance.

Chocolate H2O', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Chocolate H2O'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/wfkJy2zCqQY9u2aPwfm1vQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/2am-dessert-bar-singapore?reviewid=m4VkNhG-CVB7j_X7RIEPcQ&select=wfkJy2zCqQY9u2aPwfm1vQ', 'altText': 'Photo of 2am: Dessert Bar - Singapore, Singapore. Hot chocolate with churros', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Hot chocolate with churros'}]
text: Over hyped desserts? I think that&#39;s what it was for me. I was actually so excited to visit this place on my trip to Singapore but sadly, it didn&#39;t fulfill my sweet tooth. I wasn&#39;t impressed with the taste since I expected it to be an explosion of different flavors that blended well with one another. I think I had too high expectations which did not translate well. <br><br>Chocolate H2O: ($22) Once again, presentation 10/10. It was on the dark side and tasted the same (like dark chocolate) throughout. The texture was nice but it didn&#39;t wow. Every bit was mushy like mousse. I don&#39;t know why I thought it would be layers of different flavors. The yuzu sorbet on the side was lovely though. <br><br>Strawberry capresse: ($24) Quite liked this one. It was my favorite because I like yogurt and strawberry, and it tasted like both! Presentation was a 10/10 like usual. My friend was not impressed since it tasted like strawberry ice cream with strawberries and tapioca on top.<br><br>Churros &amp; hot chocolate +extra: ($15) the churros were nice, but the hot chocolate tasted like bitter milk to me. The chocolate taste itself was not very strong, and I think they could have added more chocolate. <br><br>Cheesecake: ($17) My friends all loved this one. Enough said.<br><br>If you like fancy desserts with a more expensive cost, then yes, this is a place for you. Presentation was a 10/10 for me, and I do believe the desserts took a long time to make since they were beautiful. However, my friends and I were not impressed with the taste. The atmosphere was super chill and upscale, like a more expensive bar. The location was a little bit hard to find, and portions are small. If I had the chance, I would come back and give it another try since I usually try things twice before I decide my true opinion on it.

text: Best cocktails in Singapore. Period.<br>There is a Mexican barman - the guy is an artist. Dont worry about looking at the menu, just tell him what you like and he will create something for you.<br><br>Food was ok, we only had chicken pop corn, it was last order (after kitchen was closed) so its ok.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oRilEpLN74sjSFi-ZWclYQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/2am-dessert-bar-singapore?reviewid=6BvutAN7KEgX7A2CPxuw9Q&select=oRilEpLN74sjSFi-ZWclYQ', 'altText': 'Photo of 2am: Dessert Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/VCfEn_pM8PdTHOEz9NkHow/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/2am-dessert-bar-singapore?reviewid=6BvutAN7KEgX7A2CPxuw9Q&select=VCfEn_pM8PdTHOEz9NkHow', 'altText': 'Photo of 2am: Dessert Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: 3.5<br><br>Loved the atmosphere, very siimlar to the bars we used to frequent in New York so I instantly bookmarked it for dessert places to take visitors. it&#39;s located right across from the popular thai joint we frequent in Holland V. <br><br>We got the Churros and Hot chocolate dip, sold separately, and it was good enough, except that the churros kept falling apart and was a bit over fried. but you really can&#39;t go wrong with churro + chocolate, so it was satisfying enough!<br><br>The fail of a dish was the Purple, with blackberry sorbet and lavendar marshmallows, which we expected more from the price and by the raving reviews on Yelp. We had better desserts elsewhere for much cheaper- it was basically Manhattan prices with child-size portions and no wow-factor. Another downer was the sad waiter in his 20s- he looked as if he hated working there and didn&#39;t&#39; say ONE word when handing us/collecting the check and as we were leaving. It was just an odd sight to see at such a hip bar but hopefully next time he&#39;s in a better mood. overall, great place to go with friends for the atmosphere and perhaps drinks, but not for the dessert alone.

Award-winning dessert chef!! Desserts that cost less than some cocktails in Singapore!! <br><br>Cassis Plum is her signature dessert, so had to try this one first. It was a refreshing dessert that achieved a nice balance between tart and sweet. The yuzu pearls added a fun additional texture and flavor.<br><br>Almost ordered the Cacao Forest, because earl grey, miso, whisky, and cotton candy in one dessert?! Unlikely, adventurous pairings such as these intrigue me. <br><br>Also ordered the ever-popular churros, because, why not...it was just too tempting. They were actually quite heavy and oily. Need to be eaten immediately or the oil just takes over, and it becomes a wet sponge.<br><br>There&#39;s also a short list of savory items, but dessert comes before savory on the menu. Not too often you can find an entire restaurant featuring innovative desserts, so hats off to Janice Wong and 2am.

Great selection of atas desserts, very creative with the naming, ingredients and arrangement. I went with a couple of friends and we shared Purple, Cassis Plum bombe and Truffle Infinity. I also tried the Umeshu Elderflower cocktail and that was delicious (anything with elderflower is delicious I realized, I&#39;ve never seen the plant in real life but I imagine if I did I&#39;ll eat it all up).  <br><br>We were joking about what if Truffle Infinity, which was a chocolate-based dish, really contained the fungus sort of truffle instead of chocolate truffles, but I guess joke&#39;s on us because we really tasted the truffle fries sort of truffles in the middle of all the chocolate. It&#39;s a very interesting flavor especially with the basil sorbet at the top, I doubt I&#39;ll ever find something like that again, so props to the place for its imaginative pairing. <br><br>The Cassis bombe was a round hollow cassis cake filled with yogurt. It has a very tart flavor, not recommended for those who like their desserts rich and sweet. Very refreshing though, especially with the plum flavored jellies in various shapes around it.<br><br>Purple was an arrangement of tiny purple semispheres of parfait and sorbet. I think it&#39;s adorable, but more like a piece of art than dessert. <br><br>Would come back here again for the drinks and try out other desserts

3 stars at best.<br>Presentation and creativity deserves a 5.<br>The flavors just didn&#39;t go well and for it to be pricey it&#39;s just not worth it.<br>You must spend a minimum of 15sgd per person which the waitress repeated 3x. Ok I get it.<br>The pastry chef wasn&#39;t there herself so maybe that&#39;s why?<br>The purple was sour, there was a black sesame one which was not bad, and the chocolate h20 was horribly bitter.
Great deserts with really good service. <br><br>We sat at the bar and watched how they hand crafted each dessert. They are true chocolate artists :).

text: In my opinion, every famous posh place faces a lot of scrutiny and criticism. I&#39;ve heard so much of 2am dessert bar in the last few years that I&#39;m amazed I never actually went. Today being singapore&#39;s 50th, I simply had to honour the day with a little patriotism and find out what all the fuss (about chef Janice Wong) is about. <br><br>Since I&#39;m sure there are plenty of reviews on this place, I&#39;m going to write this one a little differently. Here are some things I&#39;ve heard and my opinion:<br>1. Overpriced, atas, not worth the price: I&#39;ll admit it is expensive but tonight was the first night my hippie of a boyfriend said an expensive high end place I brought him to was worth the price and he&#39;d bring his parents someday. This is the first among a string of award-winning, rave-reviews-earning restaurants around parts of the world we&#39;ve lived in or travelled to. So, you can decide for yourself if it is overpriced after trying it out too! The chances are that you&#39;ll come to the same conclusion as us. There is a minimum spending per person on certain days though!<br>2. Tacky: I don&#39;t know what classifies as tacky anymore, what with the hipsters thinking everything is tacky if it is not old in a cool way, so if you ask me, this place is about as cool as it gets. It has a nice bar vibe without being too noisy or busy.<br>3. Overhyped: Chef Janice Wong is good, quite simply put. I didn&#39;t believe I could be so in love with every dish I had but I am. I wish I could be her, making pretty confectionery and insanely creative food installations.<br><br>The great positives that earned that last star on the review:<br>1. They mixed up our order and gave us a free tart. We ordered the green tea tart, and they gave us the chocolate tart on the house. They could easily have taken it back, but I&#39;m glad they did not because it was good and I&#39;ll go back for more now.<br>2. The wine/cocktail pairings were quite on point. A rich chocolate dessert balanced with sorbet and served with a decent red wine was just such a great combination. <br>3. They apologised for any inconsistency even though we would never have known or minded anyway. These apologies included the different plate used from the norm for one dish and change in flavour of the cocktail. <br>4. Interesting and well-paired flavours in each dish ensured that my impression wasn&#39;t marred by the fact that one dish was simply too weird, boring or terrible. The lavender marshmallows were subtle but still had a hint of lavender, ideal for such a strong flavour, while the strong matcha was lightened by the rice sorbet and the dark chocolate was made less intense and rich by the evian.<br>5. They have $5 churros that were actually decent and tasted like what you&#39;d get in Europe. Enough said.<br>6. The very friendly staff were constantly smiling and made us feel really welcome and comfortable. <br><br>If you have never tried this place, I&#39;d strongly recommend heading down maybe for a special occasion if you can&#39;t justify the spending. The place is small but I don&#39;t think it&#39;s too busy. Even on sg50 night, we didn&#39;t have to wait for seats. There isn&#39;t a dress code either thankfully, and is very aptly relaxed and friendly; I wouldn&#39;t call it too posh at all!

Tiramisu', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Tiramisu'}]
text: I love 2am Dessert Bar!! <br><br>The perfect place to go to unwind after a long day over gourmet cocktails and specialty dessert. <br><br>Sure, it&#39;s a little pricey but hey, you definitely get what you pay for. Almost everything I&#39;ve tried here has been amazing (my personal favorite being the Churros + Hot Chocolate dip, the ultimate comfort food!). Cocktails are amazing too and, wait for it... strong (don&#39;t you just hate when it tastes like nothing but juice?)<br><br>All the desserts and cocktails are brought out and explained to you (e.g you have a warm tart base with blah blah and blah blah drizzled over with... you get the drift), the service is impeccable (I love the angmoh guy who works there, I&#39;m not sure if he&#39;s the owner/manager but he pretty much runs the place), and the ambience is spot on. <br><br>Definitely one of my fav late night spots for whenever I&#39;m back home in Singapore!

text: This dessert hideout at a secluded corner of Holland Village had been on my list since it was opened years ago. The chef-owner Janice had won numerous awards for her pastry creations. However, there seemed to be less positive reviews than negative ones. <br><br>Some felt that the quality/portions of the desserts did not justify the expensive price tag while some felt the service was lacking. Finally mustered the necessary courage to visit and well, our experience was not fantastic but not too bad.<br><br>The Red Miso Caramel ($15) with mustard crumble sparked my curiosity as saltish desserts often excelled better than purely sweet desserts. The miso lemon foam was robust enough to pair with the slightly tangy mustard yuzu meringue, though my partner found the match rather odd. <br><br>This interesting dessert would not dull your taste buds, even though the mustard taste was faint. <br><br>This Southeast Asian style dessert is named &#34;Shades of Green&#34; ($14) had nothing to do with trees but 2Ps--pistachio and pandan. The pistachio sponge and coconut mousse were quite forgettable, but what I remembered was the sweet and aromatic pandan gula melaka custard. Overall not too dense nor overly sweet. If you like kaya toasts or nyonya kuehs like ondeh ondeh just like me, you might love this one<br><br>There was a petite tasting menu, from which we ordered the sticky toffee pudding. But at $10 for a small slice, it was pricy and I should have stuck to the regular menu.<br><br>With some wacky combinations of ingredients, I would not say that the desserts are extremely overpriced but more or less, on par with most western restaurants and even cafes here.<br><br>At least they are not boring repetitions of molten lava cake, creme brulee or apple crumble. That said, don&#39;t be like me who wanted to save money by ordering the cheaper petite tasting creations. If you wish to go, do check out their website calendar as their opening days are irregular.

text: I like it that they have wine and dessert pairing suggestions. I tried the kayambe and suggested wine today. The kayambe is interesting, many layers of flavour and the wine selection is good! <br><br>This place is dead serious about dessert ! I&#39;ll definitely come back again.

text: I came here last night, 03/23/2018, as part of my to experience list while I was in Singapore. To be totally honest, I was expecting to be wow&#39;ed and mind blown. You can imagine my disappointment when it was all said and done. My sister started with a sorta pink cocktail that I can&#39;t remember and I had the mist. Both were excellent. Then, we had the 3 course menu each without pairing because the spring menu was not available due to the ingredients not being available during this time.<br><br>SERVICE:<br><br>  The service was not terrible but bad. They weren&#39;t very hospitalable and much to our surprise, clueless about the beverages and menu. I asked our server how dry or sweet the bottle of champagne we are ordering and she looked at me like I was speaking alien. So I asked if it was brut or demisec. She says not brut but sure enough when the bottle came it was brut. For some reason I felt like they looked down on me and my sister. Never have I ever felt so different in a restaurant. <br><br>DRINKS:<br><br>cocktails were excellent and the sparkling/ champagne were great for the price.<br><br>DESSERTS:<br><br>Recap<br>I had the Zen menu and my sister had the playful menu.<br><br>Plating wise, it was a hit and miss. <br>The pistachio and stone desserts looked great while the matcha tart looked terrible, pretty nice quenelle tho (even tho there was a gaping hole on its side) and so on and so forth.<br><br>Flavors<br>The taste is what the menu says. There was no complexity in terms of flavor. Like I said, bland.<br><br>To summarize it, I was sadly disappointed. Maybe next time?

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/3UL1lDHWm7xz4NOCt6rq7w/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/2am-dessert-bar-singapore?reviewid=0sjanbq9bYdCbkQtf5TLSg&select=3UL1lDHWm7xz4NOCt6rq7w', 'altText': 'Photo of 2am: Dessert Bar - Singapore, Singapore. the mediterranean', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'the mediterranean'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WSRsH83UtGtAk5_sbO-crQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/2am-dessert-bar-singapore?reviewid=0sjanbq9bYdCbkQtf5TLSg&select=WSRsH83UtGtAk5_sbO-crQ', 'altText': 'Photo of 2am: Dessert Bar - Singapore, Singapore. kayambe h2o', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'kayambe h2o'}]
text: the 2am:dessertbar (ah, the days when punctuation oft made its way into titles and store names) has a marked place on the asian san pelligrino award list, and a blurb much lauding the skills of its head chef.<br><br>and was it good? I certainly thought it was on par with many of the innovative, deconstructed desserts I&#39;ve had at good (and expensive) full-fledged restaurants (as opposed to this slip of a place serving up only drinks and sweet constructions) - which already puts it at an enviable standard. whether she&#39;s the best pastry chef in asia - that&#39;s certainly subjective.<br><br>it was an experience observing the action at the bar counter in full view of the plating action. the restaurant has bar seating, slouchy couch type seats (reserve these if you must, as these go quickly) and high tables - the first and second best for couples, the latter good for groups.<br><br>it&#39;s an interesting concept, as you realize the chef doesn&#39;t really do much interaction with guests (which is often the point of bar seating), but instead spends the time speeding back and forth getting her components ready since she&#39;s running the show solo (waiters aside).<br><br>we took two desserts: the mediterranean (olive oil ganache, white peach and rosemary) and the kayambe h2o (a chocolate connection of frozen dark chocolate mousse).<br><br>they both arrived as works of art - it&#39;s undeniable the effort that must go into the preparation of the individual components, and you certainly see the involved plating involved - but after such an incredible wait, our experience was tempered both by impatience and hunger.<br><br>but both plates were delicious, and definitely special. it&#39;s a level of dining you&#39;d expect in a five star establishment as part of a kitchen filled with patissiers and sous chefs running about, not in a tiny bar in holland village. the mediterranean especially for the rosemary air - which was some sort of slightly frozen, melt-in-the-mouth confection that was incredibly savory (and yet not out of place on a sweet plate) - though not to forget mentioning that every component played well together (I would go so as as to suggest rationing components out so they last till you finish).<br><br>but service is slow, desserts aren&#39;t cheap - so it&#39;s best for a date night, not a dessert pig-out.

text: Good things come in small packages. This hidden gem hosts beautiful decor, a small but solid menu, and a laid back vibe.  Yes, it has a hipster vibe, but is also very minimalist (think gray and beige) with succulents scattered throughout.<br><br>The food<br>The nam ban bao is the standout here.  A perfectly fried piece of tender chicken is nestled between the fluffy bao for a few perfect bites.  The salted egg yolk shrimp had a nice crunch, but could have used a little more seasoning.  The pork belly brings me back to traditional braised pork belly I loved as a kid.  It&#39;s served au jus style with a side of stock!  The truffle fries were wonderfully salty here too.<br><br>I&#39;d definitely return for the good vibes, relaxed atmosphere and good food.

text: This place was really awesome!! Great ambiance, and amazing bao. We were craving bao on our trip and found it online and absolutely were not disappointed. We tried 6 different bao and loved all of them--my favorite was the crab! Also in a fun part of Chinatown so you can grab drinks after dinner.

Peach iced tea, $6.50', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Peach iced tea, $6.50'}]
text: Such a cute little spot on Horne Road. I appreciate that they focus on giving baos a bit of a twist.<br><br>The baos are all Asian inspired, with flavours like bulgogi, salted egg shrimp, and teriyaki chicken. I stuck with the classic (slow-braised pork belly) and the nanban chicken, which was a deep fried chicken with Japanese tartar sauce.<br><br>The classic had all the right flavours involved, however I found the meat a tad dry. I still think Ubin Kitchen on Joo Chiat Road holds the title for best classic bao in SG! I really liked the nanban chicken, though- perfectly deep fried and the sauce paired well.<br><br>Ambiance is simple, though it can get a bit loud and echo-y when there&#39;s a lot of people. Other than that, a cute cafe worth checking out if you&#39;re looking for something a little different!

Banana cake walnut sundae woo', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Banana cake walnut sundae woo'}]
text: I actually really like this place, despite my distaste for most hipster things in Singapore these days. They take reservations online, accept credit cards, have great service, and free wifi.<br><br>Food-wise... I got two buns; the salted egg shrimp and the nanban along with a side of salad. Gosh! I LOVE the nanban. Freshly fried with some lettuce within, with an awesome tartar sauce. I should have gotten two nanbunsss. The salted egg shrimp was okay - could have been better if the shrimp was deep fried and the sauce could actually coat the shrimp, instead of dripping everywhere. The bun itself was soft and slightly sweet. Yum!<br><br>I finished off with a banana walnut sundae, quite delish. Would return.

text: The Bao Makers took over the colourful Windowsill Pies shop that moved to Upper Thomson. Instead of keeping the similar type of decoration, the Bao Makers stripped everything to white. From the outside the café stood out quite well due to the colour.<br> <br>On the inside, they also kept the minimalistic industrial look with the cemented walls and wooden furnitures, perfect for hipsters to hangout.<br> <br>We visited the Bao Makers on the last day of our holiday when we were quite full from our previous dinner, but at the back of my mind I always remembered my conversation with Em that I&#39;d go and try the bao at this place. So without further contemplation I dragged hubby in and ordered two baos, the chili crab and Korean bulgogi pork.<br> <br>I like both but the succulent and spicy chili crab definitely delivered more flavour especially with the crispy golden bao. I really like the idea of infusing the local dish into the bao, something that I never seen before at other places. The filling for both baos were sufficient.<br> <br>Since Hubby was craving for dessert he also ordered a pretty serving of lemon meringue sundae. The meringue came as the topping in the shape of rose, the rest of the ingredients were lemon sponge, lemon curd and vanilla ice cream with almond slices. It was delicious but a bit awkward to be called a sundae except if you break the meringue and the sponge cake, then mix the whole thing together with the ice cream. <br> <br>We had a good time at the Bao Makers and we hope they will be a one stop shop for bao and able to come up with a lot of different fillings next time we go to Singapore.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/LDXRr24SYiHKbFjRWqkULQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-bao-makers-singapore?reviewid=ijAxENnflAczXy6XR7Tp_w&select=LDXRr24SYiHKbFjRWqkULQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Bao Makers - Singapore, Singapore. Chilli crab and fried chicken pao', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Chilli crab and fried chicken pao'}]
text: Nice space but average food. A 2.5 stars review.<br><br>The baos are tiny for the prices that they are charging - about $5.50 for one depending on the fillings. You&#39;ll need  at least 2 to fill you up (they also require a min of 2 baos per order). So a meal here will set you up for more than $10. <br><br>Aside from the price, the taste doesn&#39;t quite make the cut. While the nanban chicken (fried chicken) is nicely fried and served out piping hot and crispy, the marinate on the chicken doesn&#39;t come through and there is also too much mayo with the tiny piece of chicken.<br><br>The chilli crab bun is a take on a Singaporean favorite. While it is full of real shredded crabs, the accompanying sauce is a diluted chilli liquid that has nothing of the usual eggy crabby gravy of a good chilli crab sauce. <br><br>Place is typically hipster with nice simple decor but the taste and value of the food is not enough to bring me back.

Nacho fries', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Nacho fries'}]
text: As I rarely come to this area, I have no idea the existence of this cafe, thanks to Natalie. From Lavender MRT station, the walk takes around 10 minutes, but do bring an umbrella if the weather forecast is rain as there is no shelter for most parts of the walk: <br><br>When I think of &#39;Bao&#39; (Chinese bread), I expect a Chinese style cafe or something like that but when I entered the cafe, it was different from what I expected. I didn&#39;t read the review or find out about more this cafe as I wanted to get an element of surprise and I did! The cafe is quite spacious as there is good amount of privacy between you and the other customers. If you are in a big group (around 6-10), you be pleased to know there is a Long table and if needed, they just add a table or two. Perfect for some catching up as its quiet and not crowded for most of the time, according to another Yelper. <br><br>Orders are self service and free wifi is available but you have to ask the staff for the password. It would be nice if they could leave the password either on the table or on the receipt. Staff were friendly and more importantly no sign of impatience or pressure to leave the cafe even though the group had finish the food for quite some time and got lost in the wonderful conversation. <br><br>I ordered the Namban Chicken and Classic (check my photo of the menu for more information) and I find them to be my liking for my taste bud. Not the best but decent enough for me to make another trip back to try out the other flavours. Prices is reasonable and portion is definitely value for money. <br><br>Overall, this is a great cafe for catching up and enjoying the &#34;bao&#34;! Do drop by if you are nearby or have a craving for &#34;Bao&#34;.

text: Ambience is chic and hip. Love the mix of raw cement walls and wooden floors. Interesting menu although the helping size seems a tad small. The lobster roll and salted egg shrimp Bao were better than the seafood carbonara. The shake mentaiko rice bowl met with immediate approval complete with the onsen egg!

My new favorite neighborhood spot. I love places that just make a few things but do them well. The Nanban Chicken bao was my favorite. The chicken is juicy, and the skin perfectly crispy and light, and the Japanese tartar sauce is just right. <br><br>My wife had the classic pork belly and salted egg shrimp bao, which were also both excellent but not quite as good as the chicken for my taste. Lastly, their truffle fries were a bit on the salty side, but full of cheesy truffley goodness. <br><br>Besides the food, the decor is right up my alley. Clean and modern, wide open spaces and gray and brown accents. <br><br>Service was super fast, which is another big plus with places that have small menus. We had our bao in less than five minutes after ordering, which is great for a case of mid-afternoon munchies.

text: clean and open concept cafe. Finally a cafe where there is actually space and i don&#39;t feel claustrophobic. Headed straight in. Ordered an Ice- Latte to start, 5 minutes later its done and i have to say its really pretty good. Being at a Bao place. You&#39;ve got to try the baos right? so i went straight for the shrimp with salted egg yolk one. The bummer was that it was a minimum order of 2 baos, and i really had wanted to sit down and relax and not stuff myself with 2 baos. But i understand the procedure as steaming just one bao would be quite a waste of steam i suppose. so i had to go for the traditional one. The classic &#34;kong bak&#34; bao/pork belly. The shrimp one could do with a more stronger salted egg yolk sauce, but all in all, the shrimp was fresh and crisp. As for the pork belly bao, it would be nice if it had a thicker sauce around the meat. <br><br>The staff here are friendly and would go the extra mile to help. So the next time you&#39;re around horne road or going to catch a soccer match at the jalan besar stadium. Come over and get yourself a great cup of coffee and some baos. A great place for an afternoon snack, brunch or a light dinner.

text: A very cosy and low key pub restaurant. They sell quite a lot of alcohol and the environment is quite chill and quiet. Their cafe is rather new, maybe less than 2 years. Food is alright and have lots of room of improvement. Will come back again after the CB to try.
Decent coffee, indifferent service.

Ginseng Ade', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Ginseng Ade'}]
text: I had a hair service at the Walking On Sunshine salon. After 3 hours later (yes!! It was that many hours. The vanity just got the best of me :( )<br><br>When I finally got out and joined my sister for lunch at the café, I sat down and flipped through the menu. Before I texted my sis before to go ahead and order first. A bespectacled server came to me, demanded rudely that if I was not planning to eat anything, I must put on a mask. Was she kidding?? Why must she be so rude?? <br><br>I countered back &#34;Yea!! I am eating!!&#34; <br><br>During Phase 2 after the &#34;Circuit Breaker&#34; (aka shelter in place&#34;, everyone in Singapore still needs to wear a mask when they are out and about. People can now dine in restaurants with social distancing procedures in place. <br><br>Back to that server, why must she used that kind of tone to talk to me, a customer?? Ugh.. again I have to say this.. is it that hard to be polite to paying customers (Reminded me of that rude server at TCC restaurant @ Marina Bay Sands last year) ? Where was her service or manners?? She should simply say this:   &#34;Hi there! Sorry, if you do not plan to be eating, would you please put on your mask? Thank you for your understanding!&#34;<br><br>It is NOT that hard!!!!! <br><br>My sister just asked me to eat whatever she ordered which were already served at the table. I may not kick a big fuss there, I surely not going to let this slide. I would throw hands the next time I visit there. I really wanted to try the soufflé pancake!<br><br>My mood was ruined but I had to say the seafood pancake was really good! There was also this basket of korean chickens which was not bad either. The ginseng ade was really good!<br><br>Ambience here is definitely 5 stars. Service was a 0 (the owner should thank their rude staff). I would give the food a 4.<br><br>Will come back and update after I return for their soufflé pancake.

text: Food was probably the only redeeming quality about the cafe. Their soufflé pancakes were nice and fluffy; if I ever do come back, it&#39;ll probably be only for that. Their garlic mushrooms and eggs were literally just assorted mushrooms and eggs; Would not recommend you order that. <br><br>Service was pretty much dismal; one of the hostesses basically waved us off and let her colleague (who was super nice) sit us. <br>The cashier buzzed us to indicated that our drinks were ready for collection, but he tried to give us the wrong one. (The layout doesn&#39;t make it easy to move around so I was a bit ticked when that happened because I knew I had to come back again)<br><br>Other than that, if you&#39;re into IG, this is the cafe for you! Because aesthetics wise, it was very pretty

text: Feel like being Toasted before your meal then go visit Toast Box. Have this bad experiences 2 times, so I can&#39;t tolerate it anymore. Do you think asking before ordering is weird things to do, YES if you order your food at Toast Box 313 Somerset. The staff cashier will bark at you madly because you ask too much before order, weird eh? not for them. Then after she shared her foul mood to you, she skipped you and serve the other customer who stands before you. What an uneducated person whom they placed as a cashier to serve their valued customers.<br>Their food is nothing special, actually.. you can find those kinds of foods at any Singapore hawkers all around the country, with nicer and friendly stall owners who can befriend with you. <br>Then no more for me and my relatives to visit ToastBox again.<br><br>Thanks for already ruin our mood ! <br>WE SAY &#34;NO MORE FOR TOAST BOX !&#34;

text: Service extremely poor. Unapologetic for being out of beverage (sour plum soda), gave my partner warm tea when she ordered an iced one, didn&#39;t charge or place order for my laksa requested. All in all felt like a number who wasn&#39;t cared for. Never visiting a toast box again (first time and burnt bad by experience)

text: Bungy Bar, next to the bungy at Clarke Quay, very clever and original choice of name?? :P Though seriously, great bar, I  have had many a good night here with mates, always a good atmosphere out in the open air by the river, though add a good game of rugby, some cold beer and plenty of expats who barrack for opposing sides and this feels like that little slice of home. Prices are really reasonable, happy hour is not to be missed, and only a couple of visits and you&#39;ll be on first name basis with their friendly staff.<br> <br>The unexpected screams followed by the fear of flying vomit as the bungy fly&#39;s upwards can be a little annoying once you&#39;ve had a few drinks if I want to look for negatives, though this is a fantastic spot to start a big night out, or catch up on some good Aussie sport.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/tc0HmYPCdISWjwPGbnnPMg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/bungy-bar-singapore?reviewid=fZ5UciYJ_Ct42j2_Sf6qug&select=tc0HmYPCdISWjwPGbnnPMg', 'altText': 'Photo of Bungy Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Pk5NvB4jfx3O6yQcznoFPg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/bungy-bar-singapore?reviewid=fZ5UciYJ_Ct42j2_Sf6qug&select=Pk5NvB4jfx3O6yQcznoFPg', 'altText': 'Photo of Bungy Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/IKlc36k25MAzCNznGMj0rA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/bungy-bar-singapore?reviewid=fZ5UciYJ_Ct42j2_Sf6qug&select=IKlc36k25MAzCNznGMj0rA', 'altText': 'Photo of Bungy Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/4VaEmClozIIjOg-gLKAikQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/bungy-bar-singapore?reviewid=fZ5UciYJ_Ct42j2_Sf6qug&select=4VaEmClozIIjOg-gLKAikQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Bungy Bar - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: I&#39;m in two minds about this place. In one sense it was a pretty decent, and somewhat grungy, pub, but in another sense it was, well, not all that impressive. Okay, the huge bungy cord sling shot next to it probably does set itself apart from your typical bar, however I&#39;m not all that keen on being tied to a chair and thrown up into the air for little more than an adrenalin rush. The staff were nice, and the prices rather average, but other than that there wasn&#39;t anything about this place that really stood out to me.

A great bar to chill and hang out with mates. They also take a big role in sponsoring the local sporting teams - Bedok Kings for example. Right next to the Reverse Bungy and the Swing, come and check it out.

Staying in the vicinity of Suntec City, there&#39;s not a great deal of good coffee. We all know coffee at breakfast in 5 star hotels outside Australia generally isn&#39;t good either.<br><br>I saw this place on another app - Beanhunter - with lots of positive reviews by Australians, so thought I&#39;d swing by on the walk to work one day.<br><br>I was surprised it&#39;s part of a furniture store, but at 8 or 8.30am the furniture store is closed.<br><br>On to the important stuff. I drink long blacks, so the coffee matters. It was great - I returned three times. The &#39;free&#39; cookie is small, but oh so chocolaty and worth asking for a second (they said yes). When next in Singapore, I will return.

The biggest bummer about Commune is that it&#39;s in Singapore and I cant buy the furniture and send it home! :( They have some really gorgeous unique pieces here - modern but with warm character. They also had a lot of nice smaller decor items so if you&#39;re in the market for that definitely pop by.

Earl grey chocolate cake', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Earl grey chocolate cake'}]
text: A nice, quiet cafe to chill in town especially on weekdays! What makes this cafe unique is that it is an extension of their furniture shop-great for kids to wait with a cuppa while their parents shop for furniture, or simply to experience the furniture and style the shop offers. I would recommend getting the cake set (a drink and a cake for just $10). The icing on the cake (pun intended) is definitely the warm and friendly service of the baristas! Definitely a favourite of mine :)

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/IsbNruo7rpwfhpHg33P0cA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/commune-singapore?reviewid=3w8Mywt3TbHCSzTYS6nd-g&select=IsbNruo7rpwfhpHg33P0cA', 'altText': 'Photo of Commune - Singapore, Singapore. Late photo. Bubbles already forming on my cappuccino', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Late photo. Bubbles already forming on my cappuccino'}]
text: Lovely little tucked away cafe on the second floor; an extension of the furniture store of the same name. Very limited seating and strange glass enclosure that traps and amplifies your neighbors conversations as well as limiting airflow. Don&#39;t understand why it is there but it detracts from the overall experience. <br><br>Service could be improved. Highlighted by server that we were allowed only 2 complimentary cookies per customer even though she had put none with our coffee order. Suggest you do not place the jar on the counter or put a sign next to the jar if patrons are overstepping and taking advantage of your generosity.<br><br>All of this is in complete contrast to the quality of the coffee and cakes they serve. The red velvet cake is delicate and moist and the icing is creamy. Perfect complement to my cappuccino. The coffee has a deep, rich, roasted flavor that is smooth and all so lovely for an afternoon break. <br><br>I would recommend you grab a table away from the glass enclosure and let their coffee take you away to far off lands..

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/qWzHq-9wQP34XAbzqkAkRg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/commune-singapore?reviewid=os9qfGYmtEhXLg81jq4zVQ&select=qWzHq-9wQP34XAbzqkAkRg', 'altText': 'Photo of Commune - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: I&#39;ve been to this store several times, and was surprised by its introduction of a cafe just the last time I visited. Starting on the store itself, they sell some very contemporary and modern pieces which I believe are all hand crafted and designed by commune. You won&#39;t find any tacky or over-done pieces here, everything is very tasteful and professionally designed. You can see that the designers truly have class through their designs. It is a little on the pricey side, but definitely worth the cost. The staff are very well trained and are able to answer whatever questions you have about the furniture. They are not too pushy and gives ample space between you and your shopping experience, which I truly appreciate. <br><br>The cafe next door also is very impressive. Using warm colours and a charming design it is a great place to settle down for a good cup of coffee.

I think Commune is a unique concept, as it&#39;s both furniture store and a small café! The café space is really tiny, and since the furniture occupies most of the store space, the seating for the café ends up being outside of the store. Strange set-up, but who am I to judge?<br><br>Café aside, the actual furniture store is pretty neat. Describing styles of furniture isn&#39;t my strong suit, but I&#39;d say it&#39;s a mix of modern and vintage, and totally my type. The couches and bed frames remind me of the styles you would see at a West Elm.<br><br>Since I&#39;m not in the market to buy any big-ticket items, I decided to check out their smaller home accessories. I fell in love with one their wine bottle racks, and I believe it was pretty affordable at around $90. Most of their decorative items are well priced, considering it&#39;s good quality.<br><br>This is a great place to check out if you have some money to spend, and want an upgrade from IKEA!

text: Yes I love the Okinawa tea.  Owner is very friendly but so sad this cafe has already closed.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/YEPoAp8173IgWeVJYIQAow/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/moly-cafe-singapore?reviewid=MDV-nY88zkyyxVuAntTBWQ&select=YEPoAp8173IgWeVJYIQAow', 'altText': 'Photo of Moly Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: I suspect the storeowner of Moly Café will be very excited to see this review. He&#39;s one of the most enthusiastic and passionate and chatty &#39;guy behind a bubble tea counter&#39; I&#39;ve ever met. He strikes up conversations with ANYONE who walks past. The shop has definitely made an impact to the neighbourhood which is also one of the reasons why I want to see Moly Café do well.<br><br>The boss labels each tea with a sticker that records your order, including the sugar level. It&#39;s an effective method of preventing wrong orders during peak periods. There&#39;s a wide variety of drinks available, the storeowner has come up with a signboard that shows you the Top 15 must try drinks at Moly&#39;s. My favourites are the iced French vanilla latte, and pudding taro milk tea. <br><br>The tea tastes very home-brewed, way better than the powdered ones in the previous wave of bubble tea shops. The prices are affordable, to get discounts you can earn stamps to redeem free drinks.

text: They have the most friendly staff who really answered every queries I have regarding their available roasted beans for my espresso shot. Good place to stop by when you&#39;re in chinatown

text: Everton Park -- we checked out the whole lot of cafes down this place today. All thanks to my colleague who&#39;s so knowledgeable about the area. Eventually, we settled down at this quiet cafe for a quick coffee and cake.<br> <br>I had Mocha, and she had their Hazelnut Latte. Coffee was real good. The first time I&#39;m seeing the both of us drinking our coffee till the last drop. Although the Lava Cake I felt was a bit overcooked. It had that &#39;burnt microwave&#39; taste.

text: On yet another planned visit to Everton Park, I initially wanted to go to Nylon Coffee Roasters but they were closed by the time I had reached there so I went to Cozy Corner Coffee. Starting out with selling coffee and sandwiches, they eventually expanded to include certain mains such as pastas into their menu.<br><br>The Flat White ($4.50) tasted not bad with the right amount of milk added. However, it got slightly bitter near the last drop and I also noticed that the staff used Meiji Fresh Milk that is stored in its original bottle to be added into the espresso, which leads me to think whether the milk was steamed before being added into the espresso. Nonetheless, it didn&#39;t affect much of its taste.<br><br>Consider this place for their sandwiches and mains if you are around here (but not the coffee as there are better alternatives to choose from around Everton Park unless they are closed)

text: The cafe was located just in front of the Sixth Avenue MRT. The first level is for dine in while the second level is the shop. The place offered healthy fusion dishes with options for vegans, vegetarians and gluten free.<br><br>6th AVENUE ROSTI ($18.50++)<br>herbed sweet potato rosti, smoked salmon, asparagus, onion, poached egg, wasabi aioli <br>Although the serving looked small, I was quite full after having it. The rosti looked quite thin and dry but there was a sweetness which came from the sweet potato in it.<br><br>SKIN SMOOTHIE ($8.50++)<br>banana,orange, raspberry, strawberry, soy lecithin<br>Ice blended, the drink was thick, smooth and fruity in taste.<br><br>Overall food was delicious and the place was quite cozy there was only a couple of tables occupied during sat morning.

Food is healthy and tasty, but prices are ridiculous, even for Singapore. Service has room for improvement as well.<br><br>I ordered the Veggie Nori Roll, which was supposed to come with cashew mayo. After eating two pieces and finding them totally dry and uninteresting, I realized the cashew mayo was missing! The server agreed to bring me a side, but then returned telling me that the kitchen claimed to have already put some on. I showed her the remaining rolls, turning one over and showing they very clearly had no mayo. She reluctantly agreed to bring some, and returned with a thimble-sized dish. It definitely improved the flavor, although I had to beg for another thimble to get through the remaining two pieces.<br><br>Tiramisu was delicious, but a tiny precious serving. The bill ended up coming to over $40 for what could only be considered a snack.<br><br>Atmosphere makes for a pleasant space to relax, but with the exorbitant prices, stingy portion sizes and miserly service, it&#39;s not surprising the place was empty the whole time I was there. I&#39;m giving them an extra star because I&#39;m rooting for the vegan movement to catch on, though their price point creates a counter-productive elitist barrier which ultimately cancels out any positive gains.<br><br>Secure wifi, credit cards accepted.

text: Feeling like raw, fresh, vegan food? Come here!<br><br>We came here on a Friday night for dinner, for two. This place doesn&#39;t get that crowded, so no reservations were needed when I called to check. We got the veggie brown rice bowl, zucchini pasta with pesto, and mushroom soup to share. We felt sufficiently filled as their portions aren&#39;t stingy.<br><br>I really enjoyed the brown rice bowl, because it was topped with a mix of veggies, chirashi style, and had a choice of two sauces over it. Tasted like a brown rice topped with guacamole ingredients - so yum! Our mushroom soup was filled with the goodness of mushrooms, and because this place is dairy-free, this soup is not the run-of-the-mill cream of mushroom, but rather, a blended, chunky emulsion of mushrooms. Very tasty. I really enjoyed the zucchini pasta, which is spiraled raw zucchini, tossed with a pesto. Carb-free, guilt-free, and raw.<br><br>We finished it off with a raw chocolate &#34;cheesecake&#34;, which had a nut base, and the &#34;cheese&#34; in the cake wasn&#39;t very apparent, but it was a pleasant chocolate &#34;custard&#34; of sorts. I really enjoyed my meal here, without feeling that something had to give for the dairy and meat that was missing. I would revisit again with no qualms!

text: There is no place for arrogance in the restaurant business. While 3 of the food items we order were very good, the avocado cucumber soup was basically uneatable as it had such contrasting and spicy tastes, neither my wife or I could eat it.  We told the inexperienced, young server about it and she had no reaction, just took it away. When the bill came, they refused to give any restitution for it. That is a bad business practice in the service industry. Shows a lot of arrogance. We certainly won&#39;t return again. <br><br>Way to pricy for the quality of food too!  Guess you can&#39;t believe all the reviews all the time.

text: If you&#39;re a health concious homo sapien living in Singapore then this will be your holy shrine. Literally the BEST place that I recommend any of my health loving friends to visit in Singapore.<br><br>First off - the staff are so friendly. I would come here to eat lunch everyday in Singapore if I could. They are just so bright and cheery. The ambience is very chilled and laid back and the food is wonderful. There is no booking so if you&#39;re coming for a weekend brunch, I would recommend coming early because the place does fill up very fast.<br><br>There is a lot on offer to order on the menu and I feel there is something for everyone. If you&#39;re vegan then this is heaven on earth but if you&#39;re not, you won&#39;t think your friend has just brought you into hell either. There are burgers and meats on the menu but I feel The Living Cafe has gone out of its way to offer the best quality food possible for each category. No hidden nasties here.<br><br>They also have a big fridge filled of yummy raw treats! I remember how excited I was to find The Living Cafe in Singapore after having discovered raw treats in the US and the UK. This place had become Utopia. <br><br>Upstairs you will find a huge selection of books which make excellent additions to any food lovers library. They also sell bits and bobs that health freaks (me) in Singapore generally have a hard time finding such as Bee Pollen, Coconut Oil, Spiralizer, Vitamix..<br><br>Even if you&#39;re not that &#39;into&#39; being healthy I would definitely give this place a go to see what its all about. And if you&#39;re brave enough, try one of their Wheatgrass shots. Take them instead of Tequila. Same bitterness but the after effect out weighs it, I assure you! ;).

text: As an organic, soy free, gluten free vegan traveling abroad this was a great option! The food was well prepared and came out relatively fast. Pricing is fair for what you receive. <br><br>I ate here multiple times and preferred the quinoa burger both on a gluten free bun (which was amazing given the often tough texture of gluten free breads in Singapore), as well as on lettuce. <br><br>It&#39;s a quaint place that&#39;s not crowded with a good ambiance. Easy music and free wi-if make it a good relaxing spot as well. <br><br>They offer multiple deserts and food for dinning in or to-go. I haven&#39;t tried the sweets because I avoid most sugars but many of their ingredients are listed with coconut sugar or dates - most of which are raw. <br><br>I am a very picky and health conscious eater but I will definitely come here again whenever I&#39;m in Singapore.

Having been surrounded by vegan options in Los Angeles, it can be a challenge to maintain such a diet when traveling in Asia. Thus it was such a pleasure to discover Living Cafe. Dining here felt like I was back in the LA vegan scene. I thought of it as a cousin to Cafe Gratitude. <br><br>I started off with a Pure Green (wheatgrass, celery, spinach, parsley). It&#39;s a drink for those who chase after nutrients as opposed to flavor. <br><br>The Zucchini Pesto Pasta also tasted healthy. It&#39;s for those who enjoy bland dishes. I am one of those people so I liked it. <br><br>The desserts and smoothies are sweet. Try the yummy Spirulina Mintball. The mint is the superstar ingredient. The heart-shaped cookies made of dehydrated raspberries were an unguilty pleasure. The Chocolate Monkey (cashew milk, banana, dates, cacao) made a delightfully filling post-dessert. <br><br>Will definitely be coming back to Living Cafe for more nutritious goodies!

text: I love the living cafe so much, I could cry. <br><br>Located on Bukit Timah and 5th Avenue, I&#39;d be here day after day if it weren&#39;t so far and out of the way from where I lived. <br><br>As I try to get away from the plethora of oil laden carb heavy hawker food and onto the raw foods wagon, I start to realise how much Singapore is lacking in it&#39;s healthy, organic, gluten/dairy/refined sugars free cafes. In fact, if I&#39;m not wrong, The Living Cafe is the only of it&#39;s kind so far here in Singapore (if someone knows of another raw cafe, please let me know!)<br><br>The Living Cafe specializes in food that nourishes your body, from the inside out. Most of their menu is raw (meaning, they are all raw vegan foods that have not been heated above 115 degrees fahrenheit in order to preserve it&#39;s nutrients). I know, sounds like they&#39;d only serve salads, correct? Wrong. <br><br>My favorites on the menu include their Zucchini Pesto Pasta (note: this isn&#39;t actually pasta but zucchini shredded to look like spaghetti and pesto sauce homemade uses herbs and nuts), their Raw Lasagne, Raw Vegetable soups (cold - perfect for a hot day), their Living Rolls (rice paper rolls), Tofu Avocado Rolls, Raw Zucchini Dip (with Flaxseed crackers to dip) and not forgetting their AMAZING AMAZING raw/gluten/refined sugar free desserts. Honestly, the desserts in itself make a trip down here worth it (imagine tiramisu that actually tastes like tiramisu but made solely out of coconut, dates, nuts and other whole ingredients that give you a sugar fix WITHOUT the sugar high)<br><br>I love raw foods for it&#39;s long term benefits as well as for how good it makes me feel right away, however, making raw foods is truly an art and without the proper knowledge and creative skills, you&#39;d end up eating salads everyday. The Living Cafe truly makes it easy to eat raw from time and time with their creativeness and amazing sauces that liven up otherwise tasteless vegetables. <br><br>On top of that, service is very friendly and the space is nice (nice enough to sit all day with a book) with a small area for your kids to play while you enjoy lunch too. <br><br>My advice? Go for lunch (they close for dinner), get dessert and take a look at their little store upstairs after (they sell things like the Vitamix, Raw Cacao, Chia Seeds, the Zucchini Pasta maker and much more!)

text: i really want to like this place, given that it is started by Dana Heather, a master nutritionist, i have high expectations on its food. i came here on a sunday after a long morning jog, working up a big appetite, however was left speechless when tasting the food.<br>First we have to wait for quite a bit for the food given the short-staffed situation. And the air conditioning system needs some servicing too as it feels like we are on a fan ventilated room instead. decor is nothing original but passable. location wise it is on a row of shophouses, with construction going on next to it, so it is not a prime hang out location.<br>Onto the food. Never order the cake! we ordered 2 brownies and that must be one of the worst dessert i have had in recent years. and for an indiscriminating chocolate lover, i really find those brownies hard to swallow! <br>freshness is definitely a key issue, i could taste (and smell) distinctly more refrigerator coolant/ refrigerant than chocolate! <br>i wonder if that&#39;s their attempt at fat-free brownies (not mentioned anywhere that it is fat-free), or aged brownies. these goodies should have been tossed! <br>the quinoa salad i have fared better in term of freshness, yet the dressing left me in astonishment! <br>i could taste only soy sauce for the dressings!!!<br>being famished after our morning jog, i have hardly the energy to complain then. But the memory of that awful brownies, is enough to kill off any chocolate cravings I have. It&#39;s such a pity, i really love the concept, the menu, the staff, sigh~

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/_r_kDV7hXnMrBv9rQt1pRQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/living-cafe-and-deli-singapore?reviewid=e1-iHSy6GPavymXa31elVg&select=_r_kDV7hXnMrBv9rQt1pRQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Living Cafe & Deli - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: At the heart of TLC menu is RAW Food or RAW-Fusion Food. It uses no red meat, no cow dairy, no white sugar, no preservatives, no additives, no artificial colorings and include gluten free alternatives. So if you are quick to spot the (loop)holes, this place is not entirely vegan, as it serves things like salmon and goat cheese.<br><br>Starters were the hand-cut Sweet Potato Wedges ($4) that were earthy and good. Lightly baked with olive oil, it did not had the tempting smell of fries from fast food outlets but an alluring scent of coriander seeds. Some might find it rather firm but these were perfect for napping in the home-made mayonnaise (made of cashew nut milk, lemon juice, water, olive oil and salt but no egg yolks.)<br><br>Follow that up with TLC cheese burger ($15): a dehydrated patty of portobello mushrooms, almonds and sunflower seeds, topped with tomatoes, sprouts and romaine lettuce. I stared in disbelief at the bun-less burger as those burgers from the opposite tables had buns and cheese.Though the mushroom patty had a robust aroma, it was tough and dry, not aided by an unidentified bland orange sauce Wished it was a simple grilled Portobello mushroom with garlicky herbs. But there were good things like the Mexican-inspired Raw Taco Boats ($12). My trepidations of greasy wheat glutens dissipated when the two large sized mock meat turned out to be made of dehydrated walnuts. <br><br>The light guacamole and mango salsa sauce had a touch of Indian flavors, probably because this dish used similar spices such as cumin.  While the savoury food were wholesome, it was the RAW desserts that blown us away. Each had their own merits and everyone declared our own favourite item. <br><br>I love the Raw Dark German Chocolate Cake ($8.50) made with Dates, Zucchini, Coconut oil, Cacao Powder, Irish Moss Honey and Macadamia. It was compact and chocolatey, not too sweet despite a toffee-lookalike honey layer on top. The shards of fragrant toasted coconuts were a bonus.<br><br>As for the Raw Blueberry Cheesecake($8.50)made with coconut oil, agave, cashew and lemon juice, we could not be bothered by the alien-sounding ingredients such as psyllium husk, soy lecithin, Irish moss, as we dived straight into the delicate mousse and crunchy base. A bit of sweet and a bit of summer fruity flavours, we did not miss the sharp tang of cream cheese.<br><br>Tiramisu (actually we all did)  was made of natural coffee extract and sitted on chalky and fragile almond-flour cake base. This is literally an authentic tiramisu sans the fats from Mascarpone Cheese and Raw Egg Yolks (Yes, tiramiusu is made of raw eggs too). And who says tiramisu must have the alcohol to taste good? Honestly, I left the place feeling more satisfied than I had expected (perhaps it&#39;s due to eating &#34;Real Food&#34; ).<br> <br>However, the fact that nearly every dish were full of (grinded) NUTS, drove me nuts a little. Perhaps I would still pick Indian/Chinese style vegetarian food from Raj Restaurant over TLC.  <br><br>That said, don&#39;t leave without trying TLC&#39;s desserts which had not been compromised on flavours. Hoping that they can satisfy my sweet tooth while bring less harm to my health, I happily dabao (takeaway) more items home
