text: Surprised with this find! Very healthy food and it tastes pretty damn good too. I&#39;m not a fan of vegetable but consume them for the vitamins and fibre. Had the zucchini pasta, it is made entirely of zucchini and has some alfalfa sprouts as garnish. Looks great and tastes refreshing but since it&#39;s cold it can take some getting used to. For those craving something warm, go for the sweet potato wedges! Highly recommended. We had the chocolate ganache tart too but the taste of coconut overpowered any taste of chocolate but presentation was flawless. Will be coming back for more! <br><br>Service was pretty good especially the female waitress I had. Friendly with a smile! <br><br>About $48 for 2 zucchini pastas, 1 sweet potato wedges, 1 chocolate ganache tart, 1 flat white coffee with hazelnut milk and 1 puri tea.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/wllUxOJKtb4qdeYPXmXGxA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/living-cafe-and-deli-singapore?reviewid=tkrnjY6J1uvhrCBpxtvbdg&select=wllUxOJKtb4qdeYPXmXGxA', 'altText': 'Photo of Living Cafe & Deli - Singapore, Singapore. The raw zucchini lasagne with the living cafe roll in the background', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The raw zucchini lasagne with the living cafe roll in the background'}]
text: Let me start off by first saying that I&#39;m a red-blooded, meat-eating American who was just looking for a healthy change for a weekend brunch. I usually can&#39;t get too full from just eating vegetables and had to order a number of items to feel satisfied here.<br><br>We started with the living cafe roll, which contained an assortment of fresh vegetables, wrapped in daikon sheets and had two splotches of different sauces on the nicely-presented sides of our plate. While clearly fresh and juicy (and the creaminess of the avocado was a good complement to the fresh peppers and lettuce), I feel like the sauces needed to be either thicker or just marinated into the vegetables-- as I needed to dip my pieces several times to get a flavorful bite. And because there&#39;s no real binding agent, the pieces also fall apart fairly easily, unless you put a whole piece into your mouth-- which can be a bit challenging.<br><br>On the other hand, the raw zucchini lasagne was flavorful and fresh, but a bit small in its portion.<br><br>I also ordered the acai kickstart, which was a very tasty balance of bananas, oats, honey and acai-- until you ate past the top inch and are left a bland layer of with frozen acai filling up the bottom 2/3 of the cup.<br><br>Because I still wasn&#39;t full after the three orders, we also had the poached fresh salmon-- which has pieces as small as you&#39;d find in sushi nigiri and was clean and unsalted-- and the hand-cut sweet potato wedges-- which were huge potato segments (they used both the traditional orange sweet potato, along with a purple variety) that were pretty decently fried, without being oily.<br><br>The flat white coffee with soy milk is pretty decent (although they had run out of the hazelnut milk that we had initially wanted to try).<br><br>Overall, I wasn&#39;t a huge fan of the place, but I think that it lives up to its concept and will please raw foodists and other healthy living enthusiasts in Singapore.<br><br>Very nice, casual atmosphere too with very clean, polished setup. The crowd seemed to consist of a lot of Caucasian mothers who took/take prenatal yoga classes.

The living cafe roll.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The living cafe roll.'}]
text: This place is quite interesting. It&#39;s an eatery under a wellness center. They provides fruit and veggie juices with ingredients that are hard to come by in many healthy restaurants I&#39;ve been to. They have juices with coconut water, goji berries, cilantro, wheatgrass, etc., but they also add supplements to some of their juices like Vitamineral green, lecithin, maca powder, etc. Their smoothies and shakes are vegan, made with nut or rice milk, a refreshing change if you want to cut dairy out of your diet. <br><br>The food menu, however, is not 100% vegetarian. They have chicken and fish on the menu from what I remember. The night I went, I had the TLC roll and the TLC Cheeseburger, both of which are vegetarian. The roll did have homemade mayo so I&#39;m not sure if its totally vegan, but the quality of the ingredients are definitely very good. The price sort of matches that, reasonable. I paid $40 for a fruit and veggie juice, a roll, the cheeseburger and a vegan/gluten free chocolate cake.<br><br>This place also sells supplements, tools to make things at home like a nut milk bag, mason jars and the like, as well as ingredients like salt, vanilla extract, palm sugar, etc. Not gunna lie though, those items were expensive and I know that I can get these same items for cheaper back in the states or even in other shops in Singapore.

text: Delicious healthy food. A bit expensive, but worth it once in a while. The vegetarian, vegan, and gluten free options here don&#39;t taste like rabbit food (which is sometimes how they taste), but are wholesome, filling, flavorful meals. The servers are incredibly pleasant and efficient. I will absolutely be returning for another meal.

Somehow, it&#39;s really hard to find genuinely healthy food options that aren&#39;t salad or the healthy afterthought on a menu. But this place has got it all - raw food, vegan, vegetarian, gluten free, and nut free items. Literally everything here is healthy (perhaps except the desserts, which while made with natural ingredients, are still sweet).<br><br>The kids menu is healthy too - none of those burgers and fries stuff. Wholewheat bread, brown rice, etc.<br><br>Good stuff. Your heart will thank you.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/R4yn7LyMgGHsdUVI_yCfqw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/living-cafe-and-deli-singapore?reviewid=cn5DrKUqBFMIMZujHgvC-A&select=R4yn7LyMgGHsdUVI_yCfqw', 'altText': 'Photo of Living Cafe & Deli - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: The menu is about a half raw and half cooked dishes with lots of vegetarian selection. There&#39;s enough on it to keep you coming back to try things even though it&#39;s temping to re-live delicious dishes. I&#39;m not a raw foodist but I&#39;ve certainly been to raw restaurants all over the world and would say this is a good one. Also having it not exclusively raw is nice for feeding diverse groups of people.<br><br>The service is... well Singaporean... I&#39;m not sure what happened but it went from surprisingly good to quite poor over the period I&#39;ve been going there. So that&#39;s sad but not unexpected.<br><br>They also sell raw food ingredients, desserts-to-go, juicers and they give raw &#34;cooking&#34; classes. Lots going on here and while it&#39;s never packed when I go in, it&#39;s certainly never empty either.

My only conclusion as to why this cafe is rated almost 4* on Yelp vs the sub par experience I had on Saturday was this:  the standards for service are low and people are desperate for a semblance of raw/vegetarian food that they will overlook a lot of shortcomings.<br><br>I live in the area and have driven past the Living Cafe and it looked like a place I should try because I enjoy eating clean and I am willing to pay higher prices for quality (and some serenity even). My better half is also a gluten-free eater. Well I walked in on a Saturday morning and there was one table occupied. No one greeted me and so I figured I&#39;ll just sit down and wait for service. 20 minutes later I was still ignored while another party came in, sat at the table at the back of the cafe and was waited on immediately. I also observed the same for the next two tables that walked in. The cynical part of me would say maybe I wasn&#39;t the right skin color, but nice let&#39;s-give-them-the-benefit-of-doubt side would argue maybe the service just is bad.<br><br>So I got myself a menu and managed to order my food by getting one waiter&#39;s attention. Service was better from there as said waiter was efficient in delivering the food, but that&#39;s about it. I ordered the granola crunch bowl, pancakes and vegetarian omelet. When the food came, I got the same surprise I had a few months ago at the other cafe down the street, the LITTLE diner. Yup folks, small portions for not so small prices. And it was not like I was eating anything particularly unique or outstanding. The pancakes were on the rubbery side with a *sprinkle* of blue and strawberries and a sparse drizzle of what tasted like honey. The omelet was tasty and went well with the multi-grain bread but again, I felt kind of ripped off because this was easily something my mum could make, bigger and for cheaper.<br><br>I guess this places is a convenient snack place after yoga class but I really wouldn&#39;t make the effort to eat here otherwise. Onaka, 7 Sensations and even Whole Earth offer much better value considering the creativity that&#39;s put into reinterpreting dishes, the portions and the quality of ingredients.

If there&#39;s one thing exceptional about my palette, it&#39;s the fact that I don&#39;t like vegetables. Nadda, not one vegetable. There is no exception, I might eat the occasional veg if I&#39;m too lazy to pick it out of my noodles and its soft, but otherwise, I really don&#39;t like vegetables. Something about the texture and taste as a whole.<br><br>So for me to visit a place that specializes in raw vegan food... definitely an experience.<br><br>Eating uncooked food is quite an acquired taste - I am Chinese and I like my food hot, thank you very much. There was a raw mushroom soup I attempted - think uncooked mushrooms pureed into soup-like texture akin to Gazpacho with a really strong raw mushroom smell. I only managed one scoop of that. There are also raw pizzas and raw pastas (it&#39;s sliced up zucchini!), and even cakes for those who like this sorta thing.<br><br>Thankfully, there are options for the less refined palettes, I had a cooked pizza with a mysterious &#34;cheesy&#34; sauce, inverted commas and all. While cooked, it was healthier with a whole wheat base that reminded me of digestive biscuits, but overall quite yummy.<br><br>Raw vegan food does come at a price though - the portions are not very big but the prices are still the pricey bistro sort. Also, make sure you have time because the food is all freshly prepared and takes quite awhile to come.

text: I LOVE that they have a raw food menu as well as a gluten free menu!  These are two concepts that are ridiculously challenging to find in Singapore, and I commend the Living Cafe for having put in the effort on both fronts.  <br><br>Having moved to Singapore from Los Angeles where gluten-free and raw food restaurants are aplenty, I must admit that the food at Balanced Living is lacking a bit of creativity.  Their raw pizza is nothing more than a salad atop a flax crust.  The salad menu is much smaller than I would expect from a health food restaurant.  The raw zucchini pesto pasta is quite nice.  Their raw desserts really do hit the mark:  raw cheesecake, raw german chocolate cake, raw chocolate mud pie, raw apple pie, raw chocolates, raw spirulina balls,  etc.   <br><br>I like that they actually do have meat as an option.  My husband loves coming here because he can still get a &#34;real meal&#34; while I enjoy my raw food!<br><br>Hopefully more people will go to the Living Cafe and they will be able to both grow and refine the menu a bit!

text: I&#39;ve been twice, and both times the food was bland and tasteless - especially the pistachio salad. Nice atmosphere though.

It&#39;s my first experience with RAW food and<br>I went in really raw and clueless about what it is all about. Don&#39;t worry, they don&#39;t expect you to dine a la neanderthal style, bloody meat and all. The raw part comes from the emphasis on raw vegan cuisine, no dairy or meat products, food cooked below 48deg Celsius. It&#39;s all quite healthy really and of course the food would preserve more of the vitamins and nutrients when it&#39;s not overheated. <br><br>What I had was a special kiwi menu created by The Living Cafe but that kinda gave us the idea how food is prepared here. A lot of nuts are used, in making dehydrated crackers and tart base. It gives it a crunchy texture which I like. If you have allergies, pray stay away.<br><br>There are also cooked food available and different cuisines as well. Italian and Thai are among them. <br><br>It&#39;s not that intimidating trying raw food and I think TLC makes it really easy for you to forget its even raw in the first place. Do give it a try. <br><br>TLC is part of the Balanced Living Asia group located at the same compound. You can find out more about the benefits of RAW food here.

text: Another true gem hawker stand...no long line and no tourists, very quiet and calm location. There&#39;s even a parking lot across the street. <br><br>I had some great breakfast here, carrot cake (2 flavor), dumplings, Indian food...and can&#39;t start a day without good kapi!<br><br>With all the food I spent less than $20. Why would I go to breakfast at Hotel which charges $40!?

text: Located in Novena this hawker food center is one of the smaller ones by definitely more airy and less traffic!<br><br>I got a bowl of prawn mee and a plate of cockle kway teo for around $4 USD!<br><br>Also! On the other side of the food stalls there is a local market that have a lot of fresh produce as well!

text: Had a great breakfast here. Local spot. Quiet area. Here 7am, place was busy with locals having breakfast. It was nice to see locals in their daily life.

5 star for the cheap and tasty food in this market!<br><br>I may be biased since I only tried a few stall here but those few stalls were all good hence I&#39;m convinced most food in this market will be good.<br><br>If you are first time here, you HAVE TO try Sheng Sheng Hokkien Mee. They are one of the best I had so far. For $3 you will get a big plate of fragrant noodle coated with savoury gravy plus 2-3 prawns and squid. To me, it&#39;s the perfect consistency, not too wet neither it&#39;s too dry for my liking. Don&#39;t be defeated when you see a long queue. It&#39;s worth the wait.<br><br>I was salivating when I saw my friend&#39;s plate of kuay chap from Double Spring Teochew Lor Duck Kway Chap. All the ingredients were braised well enough, soggy + brown and they were truely tasty! <br><br>Things that I wish to try the next time I come:<br>Wah Kee Big Prawn Noodle, Mee Jiang Kueh, Pek Kio Seafood delight, Tan Kee&#39;s roasted

text: Few good stalls at reasonable price. Famous wah kee prawn noodles started here. My fav chicken rice also nobody covers but at $3, duck at $3.50, no where to find tasty yet so affordable chicken duck rice stall. Except the queue is always at least 45 mins.

text: What makes a hawker centre stand out?<br>Interesting and well executed food that keep the masses coming back for more!<br><br>i&#39;ve sampled food from a variety of stalls and find the staples - nasi lemak, carrot cake, and a surprise one, cheong fun - to be delicious!<br><br>The food:<br>It&#39;s always about the long queues or famous stalls right?  Here the heavy hitters are a carrot cake (good spice I think) which has very hearty and eggy carrot cake though I wish they could add a pinch more salt.  The nasi lemak at the back though is full of flavor with a heavy dose of coconut milk and crunchy accompaniments of fried chicken, fish cake or braised cabbage. The famous &#34;hong kong style&#34; cheong fun stall is really unique and they make fresh cheong fun.  Liquid rice flour is poured onto metal steaming sheets for each order and a variety of toppings from fresh shrimp to scallops  are added.  Another person folds and cuts each order. I recommend the sweet shrimp, but any order is full of the lightest cheong fun around.  It is quite a wait, but definitely tasty!<br><br>Next time you are around Farrer Park, check out one of my favorite hawker centers.  Get there for brunch and chow down on some tasty local food to start your day (that and some stalls close early!)

text: Good greasy food, lots of commando style pigeons looking to get lucky. It aint fancy but the food is comforting, fresh and full of fatty savoury goodness! So far like the bak chor mee (Soon Lee), the famous roast pork char siew stall (I always order extra veggie to moderate my guilt), the hokkien mee is pretty good (but I prefer the ABC Market one)..and the drink stall in the corner at the opposite end of the carpark entrance (Seletar something) has tea that is not overly sweet for 90cents!! (hot or cold)<br><br>It&#39;s also near Rangoon Road if Liberty Coffee happens to be open on a Saturday for me ;)

My favourite hawker center in Singapore, hands down. Yeah, Tiong Bahru, Maxwell, Old Airport Rd, Gluttons Bay, whatever, are more famous, but this gem holds a special place in my heart. I come here every week though I live quite far away. It&#39;s also the only hawker center I never fail to see someone (usually a couple of people) I know when I visit. Different people. So maybe it&#39;s not that unknown after all.<br><br>Price wise, I think it&#39;s one of the hawker centers that have not had ridiculous inflation, you can still find eats for $2-$3. Don&#39;t forget it&#39;s located in a really central location, so this is rare. There&#39;s good spice carrot cake ($1.50, 2, 3 4), which I&#39;ve grown up eating. There&#39;s also another carrot cake stall that&#39;s not bad, though it has been closed for a while. There&#39;s also the famous big prawn noodle, though I&#39;m not so hot on that. A lor mee stall just opened, that&#39;s not bad, though portions have been shrinking rapidly. The chicken rice store is also extremely popular, but I think it&#39;s by virtue of being around super long, and growing into a habitual taste. It&#39;s only so-so. I dabao it home for dinner every week too. Good kuehs and pancakes to buy as well, but I forget which stall. I always ask for the corner piece :)<br><br>Just try everything man. I usually spend 3h there, starting with meesiam (most would say it&#39;s so-so only, but I like its super lightness :P), lormee/fishball noodles, carrot cake, giam tao roti and whatever else I feel like eating that day. It&#39;s a super dynamic place. Some stalls come (watch out for even 1.50 promotions lol, happened a few times this year), some go, some branch out, the staples stay... not too many stalls that it&#39;s overwhelming. Love this place. Also, they have some bazaar with stalls selling random stuff every month. May be the first or last Sunday, I always forget.<br><br>Last, this is a morning place, some things sell out around noon. At night, there isn&#39;t much accept those black/white noodles/lwayteow stalls.<br><br>This place cannot be beat for price/location in Singapore. That I&#39;m pretty certain. If you&#39;re bored of the hawker center, there are foodcourts a stone&#39;s throw away as well, but they are not as popular.

text: Booked the place for Christmas eve dinner and the restaurant was having Sunday Roast Dinner. There was 3 different dining slots for dinner. I selected the earliest which was 5.30pm and the 2 of us were given the kitchen counter seats where we had a great view of happening in the busy place. Sitting next to us was the head chef&#39;s mother who shared with us who was visiting Singapore. Watching the kitchen, I realized the roasted turkey was faster than one usually expected.<br><br>We started the meal with <br><br>Pork Terrine (S$15++)<br>Served with homemade pickles and clementine jam<br>The light crispy toaste, spread with the chunky terrine, and topped with some pickles such as onion, and beetroot, quite peaked up the appetite. <br><br>Beetroot &amp; Gin Cured Salmon (S$15++)<br>Served with cucumber potato salad and herb mayonnaise<br>The salmon tasted just like sashimi that one would not felt that it was cured version.<br><br>The meal was followed by huge serving of main courses. <br><br>Roast Beef  (S$25++)<br>Served with sides of red cabbage, buttered green beans, duck fat fried potato, and bread sauce<br>While the meat looked rather raw, it sliced easily and tasted delicious. The sides were good too, except for the bread sauce which one felt it was too starchy.<br><br>Roast Turkey ( S$25++)<br>Served with sides of red cabbage, buttered green beans, mashed potatoes , and gravy<br>One would thought that the meat would be rather tough and dry, but the version here was kind of juicy and went quite well with the light but flavourful gravy. Topped up with the well braised slightly sweet cabbage, it tasted even better.<br><br>Accompanied with <br>Christmas stuffing (S$3++)<br>Pork mince, pine nuts and thyme.<br>I was not a fan of christmas stuffing as I always felt it was rather strong in herbs taste. The version was more like meat loaf with a bit of nutty texture.<br><br>Ended the meal with a couple of Christmas cookies topped with cream cheese topping, complimentary from the chef.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eHINtO3PmNa0B1MUXsbMNQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=WhLo8_Vr6H_3QddrtoLAoA&select=eHINtO3PmNa0B1MUXsbMNQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore. The spread!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The spread!'}]
text: Slightly overpriced but oh so damn good! I&#39;m a fan. <br><br>I&#39;ve been to Lokal a couple of times the past 6 months, both for brunch. They keep it simple and sweet with the menu, with only a few mains and daily specials written on the board above the open kitchen. If you&#39;re a glutton like me, who always wanted to try a little bit of everything, then &#34;pimp your breakfast&#34; might be your jam. You can order small plates to add on to your main course, eg sauteed mushroom ($5), smoked salmon ($6) and so forth. <br><br>I had the toasted banana bread yesterday and it was so damn delicious. The price might be slightly expensive, selling at $14 piece, but it was all worth it. The banana bread is topped with toasted macadamia nuts, drizzle lightly with honey and sit in a pool of vanilla yogurt. My friend had the &#34;toastie&#34; and it was good too. Light, not too cloying with the right amount of filling. The toastie also comes with a side of fresh pickled salad (i think?).  And what&#39;s brunch without coffee you ask? Lokal serves pretty good coffee from both my visits and had been consistent with the quality. <br><br>If you&#39;re planning to visit on a weekend, come early as the crowd can get overwhelming towards 1130-ish to 12pm. No reservation unfortunately so just walk in!

Got the opening time wrong so got here at 8:30am on a Sunday.  As soon as the door opens at 9, the restaurant fills up rather quickly.  We got the Lamb Eggs, Avocado Toast with a Waldorf.  Service staff very smiley and friendly.  Even brought extra plates without asking!!! Now that is service!! Nice interior clean setup.  Downside $1 for water. Pork Sausage wonderfully done and tasted spectacular.  In terms of value for money think common man would fair better.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/B8TH9FopyN1E7uqcix1J-g/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=pDz3vv7aNFAf0QzKTqDsUA&select=B8TH9FopyN1E7uqcix1J-g', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore. The muffin top', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The muffin top'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/yVTnZv4p-JdTjSTIsZ0vrA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=pDz3vv7aNFAf0QzKTqDsUA&select=yVTnZv4p-JdTjSTIsZ0vrA', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore. Flat white &amp; blueberry macadamia muffin', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Flat white & blueberry macadamia muffin'}]
text: It will be 3.5 stars.<br><br>Maybe the kitchen was having an &#34;off&#34; day as several of us (Yelp Brunchers) were there for breakfast from 9.30 am on the same day and most were underwhelmed by the food. <br><br>The menu while limited looked good and it made me want to order many things. I do like that you could pimp your breakfast (choose what you want) and you are not face with the same generic choices in so many cafes now. Just unfortunate those who had the sandwiches, burgers or breakfast selection did not enjoyed it. The sweet stuff like banana bread or brownie was rated good. I did try some of what the others ordered and they were ok, just not mindblown. The main discontent was the bacon which was very hard and chewy and tasty. Maybe we were used to the salty bacon from the supermarket or other places, and thus might not appreciate it when it was cured in-house? <br><br>As I finally decided on the blueberry macadamia muffin and a flat white, I actually did enjoy my breakfast. The muffin was big in Asia&#39;s standards, with a nice muffin top. I am used to Mmmarvellous Mmmuffins&#39; type of muffins so most muffins won&#39;t get me excited. <br><br>Service was good. I requested for my muffin to be heated up as it was cold and they actually gave me a new muffin. I had already sliced the muffin in half and took a bite before realizing it was cold. So kudos for that. The home made butter was nicely whipped and perfect on the muffin. It was not overly sweet though certain bites were sweeter than others, but overall I liked it. <br><br>The flat white was so-so. Then again I am not a coffee connoisseur. The coffee was not creamy like other flat whites I had in other cafes. This version was lighter and the slight bitter taste was prominent. <br><br>I may visit the place again as it does have a nice vibe and may be a good place to chill when it is less busy. Hopefully the savory food will be better another day too.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/e4NqO_mi83L9d16Z_EeGGg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=kRJRpszfPcoDyuCtjGvaKg&select=e4NqO_mi83L9d16Z_EeGGg', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: We waited for close to 45 mins for a 2 seats on a Saturday around 1+, so it might be a good idea to reserve seats before coming on a crowded weekend! The were benches outside for waiting and an organised queue system which eased the wait. <br><br>We had the banana bread ($15) which had been widely raved about by many bloggers and cafe goers. The bread was soft and moist and paired well with the yogurt and nuts, but was nothing extraordinary and was a bit steep for its price tag of $15. A plus point would be that it was not too sweet and hence rather easy on the palate. <br><br>For dessert, the sticky date pudding was a pleasant end to the meal. In fact, I&#39;d say skip the banana bread and have this instead. The sticky date pudding pairs well with the vanilla bean ice cream and the degree of sweetness depends on the amount of syrup you choose to dip your pudding in. Warm and sweet, it&#39;d definitely satisfy those with a sweet tooth!<br><br>The coffee was particularly disappointing. With beans from sarnies, it failed to provide the kick the usual Joe from sarnies does and lacked depth. It was also rather acidic with a distinct difference between the milk and espresso, failing to come together as a whole.<br><br>Overall, a nice place to try if you&#39;re in the area, but personally not worth the wait given it&#39;s higher price tag and the availability of better options in the vicinity.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/zBEe8e7rYEhXaOteU9ZjnA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=RVyCfKI16Tr8NZA0GyaPrQ&select=zBEe8e7rYEhXaOteU9ZjnA', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore. Here are a thousand words. Go figure.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Here are a thousand words. Go figure.'}]
text: Thoroughly disappointing. The evening kicked off with the service staff&#39;s recommendation of a light, easy-to-drink red wine that was overly chilled and truly awful. Tasted like the watered down juice you sometimes get when they run out of Welch&#39;s grape juice on Communion Sunday. Thankfully, they made good with a couple of glasses of another mediocre wine which were drinkable but also over-refrigerated and  unimpressive. Perhaps the bottled ciders might do better. <br><br>The food was also painfully mediocre. Marco Pierre White once said that generosity is the greatest garnish. I don&#39;t think we had any Marco fans in the house and I feel like they don&#39;t like salt either. Under-seasoned, uninspired. <br><br>Needless to say, I&#39;m not going back.

I called up around 12.20pm on a Sunday and they said it was a 15-20 min wait. When I got there about 30 min later the queue system said it would be a 15-30 min wait. It ended up being a 45 min wait! Honestly, I don&#39;t think it&#39;s worth a 45 min wait.<br><br>The Lokal Beef Burger ($25++ = $29.25) - 3.5 stars<br>Pretty good but there was quite a bit of fat in the patty and the burger wasn&#39;t special - cheddar, tomato sauce, vegetables. I got salad instead of the fries so can&#39;t comment on the fries. Good portion.<br><br>Soy Chai Latte ($6 + $1 iced + $1 soy = $8++) - 3.5 stars<br>Expensive!<br><br>Roast Pumpkin Salad ($18 + $8 for smoked salmon) - 4 stars<br>My friend enjoyed this!<br><br>Red Berry Smoothie ($10) - 2.5 stars<br>We decided we could make it at home.<br><br>Even after the Entertainer app, it ended up being $55 for 2 mains and 2 drinks. Guess it&#39;s the GST and service charge.<br><br>Service - 5 stars<br>Shout out to Satia! Other staff were great too.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/zxwFVYcHclrWWEJevTrQjQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=KNxj_XGo7XK21en13DC1EQ&select=zxwFVYcHclrWWEJevTrQjQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/kpK5yqlg7VN8w3xkh8cr5Q/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=KNxj_XGo7XK21en13DC1EQ&select=kpK5yqlg7VN8w3xkh8cr5Q', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/1gS9IvNZUpNJ6VkhkU5ZvQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=KNxj_XGo7XK21en13DC1EQ&select=1gS9IvNZUpNJ6VkhkU5ZvQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eJu08CYSVbTWV0vhqyCfoQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=KNxj_XGo7XK21en13DC1EQ&select=eJu08CYSVbTWV0vhqyCfoQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: You may be mistaken by the German word &#34;Lokal&#34; thinking that it serves more on German Cuisine but in fact the Lokal is an Australia Style Cafe than offers more than just German flavours. Taking the business name, it kind of already suggest that its more on the Local, more like internationally influenced style. They are located at a corner of the intersection of Bukit Pasoh and Neil Road where you can find Goethe Institue nearby. It&#39;s quite easy to get here as they are within minutes walk from Outram MRT Station.<br><br>It&#39;s causal and welcoming atmosphere had kind of remind me of a cafe in Edinburgh Bus Interchange. Interior was rustic with a hipster interior that keep up with the cafe trends in Singapore.<br><br>We requested the coffee based dessert to be served first. This looks really cool with a scoop of vanilla ice cream topped with shot of espresso.<br><br>Affogato - $6.50<br><br>While waiting for the food, I had a glass of chai latte. Chai fragrance was average and all was down in my stomach even before the food was served.<br><br>Chai - $6.50<br><br>Starters was good with 3 ways Cauliflower served on a traditional Chinese metal plate. Cauliflower comes in 3 different forms and beautifully presented. With puree as its base, stacked by leafy greens and cabbages with tumeric infused cauliflowers, fried cauliflowers, as well as Ricotta &amp; almond makes it special. Recommended.<br><br>Cauliflower 3 ways - $13<br><br>Another starter we had was great and perhaps suitable for those who want a lighter meal instead. Roasted beet roots was juicy and mix with quinoa, green beans, blue cheese &amp; honey walnuts. I&#39;m not really a fan of blue cheese, fortunately, the taste of the blue cheese was not that strong as I would have thought.<br><br>Roasted Beetroot Salad - $13<br><br>Torn between the Braised beef cheek and Cape Grim Sirloin Tagliata, I end up with the latter as per recommended by the server for its popularity. Served on a wooden board with scrumptious beef cubes cover by watercress with Asiago cheese and cheery tomatoes pairing.<br><br>Cape Grim Sirloin Tagliata - $28<br><br>The beef were cut into cubes form cooked to the default perfection by the cafe. Simply love its charred exterior and the juicy tender mild bloody meat.<br><br>Ending the session of the night with sticky date pudding as dessert on a good note. The warm pudding was velvety coupled with a generous scoop of vanilla ice cream and yummy caramel sauce. The best part of the dessert was that with the sticky date and sauce, the entire dessert was not too cloying and one won&#39;t feel the excess richness and sweetness in them.<br><br>Sticky Date Pudding - $10<br><br>As a whole, service was friendly with a good atmosphere around. Even though they have limited items on the menu, fred not as they have daily specials, so do check out what&#39;s on their black board.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/YG2UM5zTKulPhLHt_axVQw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=aUKa9bOj5KxGfJ-vatHtBQ&select=YG2UM5zTKulPhLHt_axVQw', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore. $22 slipper lobster roll', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': '$22 slipper lobster roll'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/2XtC3rq3R3cdUjIXzzZExg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=aUKa9bOj5KxGfJ-vatHtBQ&select=2XtC3rq3R3cdUjIXzzZExg', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/56M84DTg_fm57qht9lkk7g/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=aUKa9bOj5KxGfJ-vatHtBQ&select=56M84DTg_fm57qht9lkk7g', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/VFWoFsH7j6niomeq-_EVvA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=aUKa9bOj5KxGfJ-vatHtBQ&select=VFWoFsH7j6niomeq-_EVvA', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore. Brek.. Lobster roll', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Brek.. Lobster roll'}]
text: 1) Lobster roll $22 - generous chunks of lobster. Soft fresh bun nicely toasted. Bit rich for breakfast for me so I won&#39;t order it unless I&#39;m sharing.<br><br>2) Pumpernickel bread and sourdough - The former is softer and served thinner. The sourdough tastes heartier and bit more rustic. Bread if you order on its own comes with 2 slices at $1.75. But order it for $6 and you get 3 slices of bread and unlimited and free choice of house-made butter, jams, peanut butter or vegemite. Bread slices size here is smaller than average cafe.<br><br>I like vegemite and it&#39;s an Aussie thing which suits this cafe which is opened by Darren Farr from Sydney. the peanut butter is unusual in that it&#39;s very dark in colour and thick and tastes like sesame seed paste.<br><br>3) Scrambled eggs here are creamy and buttery and fluffy. A big portion. $6<br><br>4) I&#39;ve had the ricotta (also housemade) a few times just with toast. $6<br><br>5) Smoked salmon. Again this is done inhouse and hot smoked and a highlight.<br><br>6) Coffee is from Common Man Roasters - 22 Martin Rd blend is the house blend but I always ask for the single origin as I do not like the 22 Martin one whether made at Common Man Roasters or here. No extra charge. $5<br><br>Other things I like - There is free wifi. The place is quiet in the mornings on weekdays with ample parking right outside. I&#39;ve been several times and seen Chef Farr there many times so it&#39;s nice to have a place where the original chef owner is actually on the floor and in the kitchen regularly. In fact, this morning he sent over some of their (housemade of course) kaya and we all really liked it! More subtly flavoured with a light caramel taste.<br><br>What&#39;s missing for the last star. The place looks nice but the atmosphere of it isn&#39;t quite that relaxed Aussie feel. The coffee if from the single origin tastes not bad but isn&#39;t as good as Common Man Roaster&#39;s rendition. I think it could be a little fresher. It&#39;s kinda slow to come. Service can be up and down but I decided to review because recently I find that service has improved. They have some new staff that seem quite enthusiastic which is nice. They seem to take a bit long to get the bill ready even though it&#39;s not that crowded on weekday mornings and some of us need to get to our real jobs!

Reuben sandwich special', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Reuben sandwich special'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/keWbRDiUftTcysn0DA1z_g/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=LLZRAr7zF5VpTSb2dhv0YA&select=keWbRDiUftTcysn0DA1z_g', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore. Packed!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Packed!'}]
text: Back again at my fav cafe. But to be honest, calling Lokal a cafe really doesn&#39;t do the justice as its food standard is one of the highest in SG. <br><br>Unlike the weekday mornings, the place was PACKED. They had a waiting list of people to be seated around 11:30am. But I was able to grab a seat at the chef&#39;s counter and gawk at all the delicious foods that were coming freshly out of the kitchen and enjoy my food. <br><br>I started off with English breakfast tea-- not bad, but nothing exceptional. But I wish there was an option to have the tea set out of the pot as the tea got way too bitter towards the end of my meal. <br><br>Then I had the roasted pumpkin salad  (5/5 )which just AMAZED me. One of the best salad I&#39;ve had. It&#39;s flavorful without being drenched in dressing and just the right heartiness with well-cooked, yet still firm pupkin, healthy mix of quinoa and nuts, and fresh beans. It is definitely a must try.<br><br>Then finished the meal with the chef&#39;s first attempt at anzac cookies (4/5; Australian traditional cookies--made with coconut and oats) and my gosh. I&#39;m generally not a huge fan of oat cookies, but this sweetness was just right. And for that I had to order a cup of long black (I&#39;ve come to not call it Americano anymore while in Singapore) to go along. I was told the beans were roasted by Sarnies and the blend was created in-house, and was called fuzzy wuzzy (4.5/5). But boy did they do a good job. The aroma and the finishing note of the coffee well-complemented the cookie. <br><br>Really aiming to come for dinner in the upcoming weeks.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/zxwFVYcHclrWWEJevTrQjQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=KNxj_XGo7XK21en13DC1EQ&select=zxwFVYcHclrWWEJevTrQjQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/kpK5yqlg7VN8w3xkh8cr5Q/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=KNxj_XGo7XK21en13DC1EQ&select=kpK5yqlg7VN8w3xkh8cr5Q', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/1gS9IvNZUpNJ6VkhkU5ZvQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=KNxj_XGo7XK21en13DC1EQ&select=1gS9IvNZUpNJ6VkhkU5ZvQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eJu08CYSVbTWV0vhqyCfoQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=KNxj_XGo7XK21en13DC1EQ&select=eJu08CYSVbTWV0vhqyCfoQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]

Chai fragrance was average and all was down in my stomach even before the food was served.<br><br>Chai - $6.50<br><br>Starters was good with 3 ways Cauliflower served on a traditional Chinese metal plate. Cauliflower comes in 3 different forms and beautifully presented. Recommended.<br><br>Cauliflower 3 ways - $13<br><br>Another starter we had was great and perhaps suitable for those who want a lighter meal instead. Roasted beet roots was juicy and mix with quinoa, green beans, blue cheese &amp; honey walnuts. I&#39;m not really a fan of blue cheese, fortunately, the taste of the blue cheese was not that strong as I would have thought.<br><br>Roasted Beetroot Salad - $13<br><br>Torn between the Braised beef cheek and Cape Grim Sirloin Tagliata, I end up with the latter as per recommended by the server for its popularity. Singapore has no shortage of brunch places. Some have the typical eggs benny and french toast on their menu while others serve fancy coffee prepared using science lab equipment. The Lokal gives us a nice balance adding subtle touches to the usual favourites along with daily specials (i.e. Sunday Roast) that keeps regulars coming back while brewing a good cup of no-flash coffee. Only draw back is that because it&#39;s so popular, you occasionally have to share tiny tables. Although slightly on the pricier end, would definitely recommend this place for those brunch die-hards.

text: We went here for breakfast. This place is definitely over rated. Their menu is really lacking. They had some really amazing smoked salmon, but their avocados did not seem fresh what so ever. Their scrambled eggs were also very mediocre. They also didn&#39;t have hotdogs, what kind of place doesn&#39;t have hotdogs

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eHINtO3PmNa0B1MUXsbMNQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-lokal-singapore?reviewid=WhLo8_Vr6H_3QddrtoLAoA&select=eHINtO3PmNa0B1MUXsbMNQ', 'altText': 'Photo of The Lokal - Singapore, Singapore. The spread!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The spread!'}]
text: Slightly overpriced but oh so damn good! I&#39;m a fan. <br><br>I&#39;ve been to Lokal a couple of times the past 6 months, both for brunch. They keep it simple and sweet with the menu, with only a few mains and daily specials written on the board above the open kitchen. If you&#39;re a glutton like me, who always wanted to try a little bit of everything, then &#34;pimp your breakfast&#34; might be your jam. You can order small plates to add on to your main course, eg sauteed mushroom ($5), smoked salmon ($6) and so forth. <br><br>I had the toasted banana bread yesterday and it was so damn delicious. The price might be slightly expensive, selling at $14 piece, but it was all worth it. The banana bread is topped with toasted macadamia nuts, drizzle lightly with honey and sit in a pool of vanilla yogurt. My friend had the &#34;toastie&#34; and it was good too. Light, not too cloying with the right amount of filling. The toastie also comes with a side of fresh pickled salad (i think?).  And what&#39;s brunch without coffee you ask? Lokal serves pretty good coffee from both my visits and had been consistent with the quality. <br><br>If you&#39;re planning to visit on a weekend, come early as the crowd can get overwhelming towards 1130-ish to 12pm. No reservation unfortunately so just walk in!

Brek.. Lobster roll', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Brek.. Lobster roll'}]
text: 1) Lobster roll $22 - generous chunks of lobster. Soft fresh bun nicely toasted. Bit rich for breakfast for me so I won&#39;t order it unless I&#39;m sharing.<br><br>2) Pumpernickel bread and sourdough - The former is softer and served thinner. The sourdough tastes heartier and bit more rustic. Bread if you order on its own comes with 2 slices at $1.75. But order it for $6 and you get 3 slices of bread and unlimited and free choice of house-made butter, jams, peanut butter or vegemite. Bread slices size here is smaller than average cafe.<br><br>I like vegemite and it&#39;s an Aussie thing which suits this cafe which is opened by Darren Farr from Sydney. the peanut butter is unusual in that it&#39;s very dark in colour and thick and tastes like sesame seed paste.<br><br>3) Scrambled eggs here are creamy and buttery and fluffy. A big portion. $6<br><br>4) I&#39;ve had the ricotta (also housemade) a few times just with toast. $6<br><br>5) Smoked salmon. Again this is done inhouse and hot smoked and a highlight.<br><br>6) Coffee is from Common Man Roasters - 22 Martin Rd blend is the house blend but I always ask for the single origin as I do not like the 22 Martin one whether made at Common Man Roasters or here. No extra charge. $5<br><br>Other things I like - There is free wifi. The place is quiet in the mornings on weekdays with ample parking right outside. I&#39;ve been several times and seen Chef Farr there many times so it&#39;s nice to have a place where the original chef owner is actually on the floor and in the kitchen regularly. In fact, this morning he sent over some of their (housemade of course) kaya and we all really liked it! More subtly flavoured with a light caramel taste.<br><br>What&#39;s missing for the last star. The place looks nice but the atmosphere of it isn&#39;t quite that relaxed Aussie feel. The coffee if from the single origin tastes not bad but isn&#39;t as good as Common Man Roaster&#39;s rendition. I think it could be a little fresher. It&#39;s kinda slow to come. Service can be up and down but I decided to review because recently I find that service has improved. They have some new staff that seem quite enthusiastic which is nice. They seem to take a bit long to get the bill ready even though it&#39;s not that crowded on weekday mornings and some of us need to get to our real jobs!

text: Great coffee + Great ambience = Great place to chill. <br><br>Located at the corner of the Goethe Institute, this quiet corner offers simple but great coffees. Its extensive bar suggests it has a probably a bit more to offer thru its drinks offerings (have not tried it except for its strawberry basil soda).<br><br>Food offering was the normal standard fare of cafe food, altho it did try to be innovative with respect to its &#34;localised&#34; presentation and taste. I wasn&#39;t impressed with its pasta of the day - an interesting interpretation of penne with cream and some sort of local soy-sauce base. Ermmmm ......

text: Back again at my fav cafe. But to be honest, calling Lokal a cafe really doesn&#39;t do the justice as its food standard is one of the highest in SG. <br><br>Unlike the weekday mornings, the place was PACKED. They had a waiting list of people to be seated around 11:30am. But I was able to grab a seat at the chef&#39;s counter and gawk at all the delicious foods that were coming freshly out of the kitchen and enjoy my food. <br><br>I started off with English breakfast tea-- not bad, but nothing exceptional. But I wish there was an option to have the tea set out of the pot as the tea got way too bitter towards the end of my meal. <br><br>Then I had the roasted pumpkin salad  (5/5 )which just AMAZED me. One of the best salad I&#39;ve had. It&#39;s flavorful without being drenched in dressing and just the right heartiness with well-cooked, yet still firm pupkin, healthy mix of quinoa and nuts, and fresh beans. It is definitely a must try.<br><br>Then finished the meal with the chef&#39;s first attempt at anzac cookies (4/5; Australian traditional cookies--made with coconut and oats) and my gosh. I&#39;m generally not a huge fan of oat cookies, but this sweetness was just right. And for that I had to order a cup of long black (I&#39;ve come to not call it Americano anymore while in Singapore) to go along. I was told the beans were roasted by Sarnies and the blend was created in-house, and was called fuzzy wuzzy (4.5/5). But boy did they do a good job. The aroma and the finishing note of the coffee well-complemented the cookie. <br><br>Really aiming to come for dinner in the upcoming weeks.

Awesome truffle chips!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Awesome truffle chips!'}]
text: It was a Wednesday evening, standing along Neil Road, my friends and I were trying to locate the cafe. Though the entrance was huge, somehow we couldn&#39;t see it. The three of us stood outside Gothe Institut scratching our heads, where&#39;s The Lokal?<br><br>A quick phone call and one of the service staff came out to &#34;pick us&#34;. Somehow the diagonal entrance escaped our eyes. <br><br>Walking into the cafe, it was fairly empty. At around 7pm, there were only 2 tables filled. The full fledged bar welcomes us as we entered then the open kitchen at the back. As we had made reservations, we were seated where the nice cushion seats were. Tucked in a cosy corner, it was the perfect place for 3 girls to hangout and share our hearts out.<br><br>The menu came and we were told that the mains &amp; appetizers are changed regularly. Since we decided on a side of truffle chips, we gave the appetizers a miss and ordered our mains. Recommendations from the service staff were the pork belly with Apple sauce and lamb shank in crispy wrap with cous cous. We ordered 2 pork belly and a lamb. To conclude our meal, we had the Sticky date pudding.<br><br>The Truffle chips were served first, pipping hot with a huge serving of shredded cheese on top. The fragrance of the truffle oil was immense, totally tickled our nostrils.<br><br>The pork belly was tender and literally melts in your mouth. The sweetness of the apple sauce nicely complemented the pork belly, lifting the palette from pleasure to joy. The portion was a little too much for me but a regular dude would have consumed it completely in glee. I didn&#39;t get to taste the lamb but I to say that it&#39;s not for the faint-hearted. The lamb is pungent (not in a bad way) so non-lamb lovers, beware. <br><br>Now comes the sticky date pudding, the divine one that we all three swore we will be back when we need a pick-me-up. Rich and thick dark caramel sauce, coupled with a large scoop of vanilla ice cream and a really warm pudding, our tongue was dancing between the sensation of hot and cold and the sweetness from the sauce was balanced nicely with the ice cream. The pudding was moist and lovely.<br><br>Dinner ended on a high note as we leave and were sent off with &#34;thank you&#34;s from the staff. <br><br>So coming back for the sticky date pudding!

Terrible customer service. Came in thinking we wanted to try the food, took 10 minutes before anyone greeted us or said anything to us AFTER we got their attention ourselves. We were put on a waiting list and waited in the restaurants for 30min before we finally gave up. The staff are rude and unattentive. There were empty tables in the back, and staff would leave them empty for 15min before they sat anyone down. Skip the wait and the disappointment.

Singapore has no shortage of brunch places. Some have the typical eggs benny and french toast on their menu while others serve fancy coffee prepared using science lab equipment. The Lokal gives us a nice balance adding subtle touches to the usual favourites along with daily specials (i.e. Sunday Roast) that keeps regulars coming back while brewing a good cup of no-flash coffee. Only draw back is that because it&#39;s so popular, you occasionally have to share tiny tables. Although slightly on the pricier end, would definitely recommend this place for those brunch die-hards.

Got recoomended from a friend. Food and coffee are both good. The menu is quite unique

Their scrambled eggs were also very mediocre. They also didn&#39;t have hotdogs, what kind of place doesn&#39;t have hotdogs

text: Beautiful space, delicious food. Have them drop you off at Fort Canning Center and walk straight for 2min. Quite easy to find. <br><br>Closest MRT stations are fort canning and raffle city

text: I went to Food For Thought for a small meal during my visit to the National Museum of Singapore. I tried the Platter For Two, which had fries made of luncheon meat, wings, and fried mushrooms. The meat fries were unique, though I might prefer normal potato fries. The mushroom was pretty good. I also got the Ondeh Ondeh Special Cake. It tasted similar to green tea with a little coconut flavor.<br><br>For my drink, I got the Lychee Lemongrass Cooler. This had a refreshing lemon taste with a slight lychee flavor. The soda in the drink was not too fizzy, which I liked. The service quality was fine.<br><br>Overall, if you are visiting the National Museum and hungryI would recommend going to Food For Thought out of the combination of convenience and food quality.

Afternoon tea set ($10) - Hot dark chocolate and chocolate fudge cake', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Afternoon tea set ($10) - Hot dark chocolate and chocolate fudge cake'}]
text: Double chocolate muffin ($4) - 2.75 stars<br>Not too sweet and had a good bittersweet chocolate flavor, but it was a bit too dry. I&#39;d get it if, like today, I really wanted a jumbo chocolate muffin.<br><br>Update 25 Apr 17<br>Afternoon tea set ($10) for a cake and coffee. Options: NY baked cheesecake, Oreo cheesecake, rainbow cake, carrot cake, chocolate fudge cake. Apple pie not included.<br><br>Hot dark chocolate with mini marshmallows - 4 stars<br>The mini marshmallows melted too quickly! And the foam dissipated quite quickly so the actual amount of hot chocolate wasn&#39;t that much. But I liked the taste - not too sweet!<br><br>Chocolate fudge cake - 4 stars<br>I liked this cake! They warmed it up but it was only slightly warm and quickly cooled down to room temperature. It tasted better at the start. Soft and quite moist. A bit later the fudge icing melted and got too runny so my top layer of cake fell off. Still good though.<br><br>Might try the cheesecake the next time. Wanted to get it but it looked too smooth and not cake-y.

After visiting the National Museum of Singapore, we decided to stop for a bite to eat at Food for Thought. It is adjacent to the gift shop in a bright sunny area on the ground floor of the museum My friend was hungry for a snack and ordered a piece of cake  and a coke. I got a cup of coffee-a flat white. We did not order real food while we were there so I cannot comment on that. The staff was accommodating and attentive and the pricing for what we ordered was reasonable. I would recommend.

text: It&#39;s difficult and probably not fair to review a venue based on one visit and one meal, but I&#39;m going to! <br><br>I enjoyed my quick lunch here, the Chinese Caesar salad was super tasty with some yummy Asian spice. The crunchy, crispy fried anchovies were full of flavour and along with the egg the only reference to a classic Caesar but I enjoyed the asian twist. <br><br>Nice location and a good way to rest a little in the cool before starting a tour of the museum.

text: Located inside the Singapore Botanic Gardens on Cluny Road, Food for Thought at Botanic Gardens  possesses a truly tranquil atmosphere. The place looks modern and well-decorated with brick styled counter, wooden tables, clear white chairs and an innovative ceiling. Kids can hang out in the close-by playground while adults are having meals. Especially, a catchy 5-step slogan sitting comfortably on a white long wall is something you can&#39;t miss for a wonderful selfie.<br>Recommendation: Banana Walnut Crepes, Full Breakfast/Brunch Platter<br><br>For more, visit us as: <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thecoupleeats.com%2Fsingapore-food-diary-7-places-eat-first-time-visitors%2F&amp;s=b318345faa43f47c2cc5838f381314be08d4dc396a1749d7fcc6aec9a2c56019" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">thecoupleeats.com/singap…</a>

text: A nice place in the botanic gardens; nice ambience great for brunch and a quiet gathering <br>Very spacious space; great for events <br>The food was passable ; not extremely fantastic but still pretty good. <br><br>Had the pulled pork pasta - pork was a little too salty; wasn&#39;t spicy enough and slightly too oily : however it was okay <br><br>Latte was Normal as well; so was the carbonara - nothing too memorable. <br><br>Wouldn&#39;t go back especially for the food but is a good chill and nice hang out place after a run in the botanic gardens or for brunch out of the city

text: A casual place that is good for family time due to the large space and playground outside to occupy the children.<br><br>Food is decent but nothing special to be honest. Maybe except the Gula Melaka granola. <br><br>But prices are more than fair and nett.

text: Surprisingly empty for brunch on a Saturday (reached at 12.30pm). Food was decent but not great. <br><br>Tried their basic breakfast ($9) and my friends got the full breakfast ($22) and their special of the day, banana walnut toast ($12). The banana walnut toast that came topped with yogurt was too sweet for my liking. The toast also tasted more like a muffin. The scrambled eggs and brioche were decent though. <br><br>Not the best brunch place in town, but good for a casual catch up. Also appreciate the lack of GST and service charge. <br><br>Coffee ($5) was out of the machine and not good at all.

Full Works: Scrambled Eggs, Brioche Toast, Mixed Greens, Pome Noisettes, Bacon, Sausage and Sauteed Garlic Mushrooms', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Full Works: Scrambled Eggs, Brioche Toast, Mixed Greens, Pome Noisettes, Bacon, Sausage and Sauteed Garlic Mushrooms'}]
text: Convenient and good portions. My niece and I wanted a quick bite and walked to the Singapore Botanic Gardens. I was expecting a food court but instead, Food for Thought had taken over the space. My niece had the spaghetti bolognese (kid&#39;s meal), and I enjoyed a big breakfast. Scrambled eggs, bacon, ham came with nicely toasted brioche and I loved the sauteed mushrooms. I enjoyed my meal. The eggs were a little on the overdone side, but I did not leave hungry. The decor is a little run down. The servers were helpful once you spoke to them. You have to walk to the order and pay station.

text: Heard good reviews from my church mates for this place so decided to try it out with my friends. <br><br>Was pretty empty on a Thursday night so we were able to choose the high chairs for our seat. As we were there for the first time, I wasn&#39;t really sure on where to order and asked one of the staffs about it. She directed us to the front where you can see the computer.<br><br>Before making payments, what looked good to me was the Lemongrass Galangal Seafood Risotto. And of course, Milo Godzilla pudding for the dessert. My friends ordered the brunch platter for 2/3 pax and grilled barramundi fillet with holy basil almond pesto.<br><br>Food came pretty earlier than what I expected. Mine came first and I started digging in without much hesitation. Was into risotto lately (hmmm).. My food has a strong aroma (which made me even hungrier than before) and the first bite, you can taste the different flavors bursting on your tongue. I love the touch of the ingredients especially the lemongrass condiments and the chilli inside the risotto. Overall, two thumbs up. The downside was that it was on the higher end and the portion wasn&#39;t big. <br><br>Tried the brunch platter - it consist quite a variety (seen on the picture). I always crave for good fries and the fries have a crispy touch on it. I tried hashbrowns and the lemon dill fish fingers has fresh peach on it. The Crispy Chicken Tortilla was also good. All of them has perfect touch of condiments/sauces in them which made the taste last inside the mouth. The grilled barramundi filet wasn&#39;t that wow. <br><br>For the Milo Godzilla pudding, I was searching for &#34;rare&#34; desserts and this one caught my eye straightaway even before my friend announced that she would like to order one portion too. Like a molten lava cake, it has ice cream on top (coconut flavored if I wasn&#39;t wrong) and chocolate cake at the bottom. The chocolate cake was moist. I am glad that we ordered just one dessert as we couldn&#39;t probably finish if we have more.<br><br>Interior design wasn&#39;t too fancy. Open concept kitchen and open concept layout with some modern touches on its furnitures. Price like I mentioned, it is on the higher end but since it is located at one of the touristy places - Botanical Gardens, price range for me was al-right. Will be back for more in the future :)

text: Saw my gf  post on facebook about this place and have decided to give this place a visit.I went to Botanical Garden on a lovely weekend.<br><br>Upon arrival, this place is real big and they have the indoor and outdoor seating. I join the queue and place an order on their breakfast specialty and oh my didn&#39;t realize that the portion was so big. <br><br>Anyway, I have sat there for hours enjoying my reading and food. Overall this place is a gem and its a good place for family hangout and spend your afternoon lazing around.<br><br>Their scone is simply too delicious, im a big fan of scone and I would simply had it for meal. The scone is big and filling and I brought 2 home for teabreak.<br><br>Would visit here again .....

text: Had a lovely brunch out here with friends and kids. <br><br>I had a bangers &amp; mash and it was good! Hub had a pasta with Broccoli and prawn. That was good too! <br><br>Best part is the kids can run outside the cafe and you can watch them play outside while enjoying adult conversations inside with aircon. 2 thumbs up for good food and location.

text: The pulled pork burger was average. The side salad and fries were good. The burger was small (but enough for me) and the pork was not well marinated so it smelt a bit. The service was good. There was a delay with my food and without having to ask about it, the waiter acknowledged the delay and offered me a free drink. Overall it ws decent and convenient for those visiting the museum.

text: A very convenient place to have a bunch in a before going to Botanic Garden.The place is very family friendly (could be a bit noisy for couples tho). Overall the food quality is good. The french toast with bacon is fluffy and yummy with the malaka syrup. The burger is good too. Last year I came here for the full breakfast (Full work) - which is fulfilling but a bit too much for a girl...haha....coffee is lovely too..

Some food for thought.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Some food for thought.'}]
text: Food for Thought is located in the basement of the Botany Centre. It is close to the Tanglin Gate (Napier Road) and is reachable from Orchard Road.<br><br>I did not find anything exceptionally great about the food, but that is not to say that it wasn&#39;t delicious. I definitely wouldn&#39;t want to make a trip to FTT just for the food but I would eat here if I happen to be spending a day in the Singapore Botanic Gardens. I do like the decor of the restaurant though - lots of natural lighting in a very casual environment.
Cool little place to have lunch or a snack while strolling around the Botanic Gardens.  Good variety of options to choose from and a good place to get out of the heat and humidity and cool off.

text: Located right in the botanical gardens in the middle of the city, this place is a lush, tropical oasis where one can seek respite from the heat and get relax in FFT.<br><br>Great ambience here - I especially love the plants growing out of holes in the concrete tables. Its spacious, bright interior is welcoming and cheery, with floor to ceiling glass panels and a high roof. <br><br>There is even a little playground just outside the restaurant, so this place is popular with families on weekends.<br><br>They serve all day breakfast here from 8am to 5pm, and even give early birds a local black coffee or tea offer at $1 when you order local breakfast items between 8am-10am.<br><br>There&#39;s the Full Works breakfast pieces at $18, and it comes with scrambled eggs, bacon, buttered toast, chicken sausage, hash brown, garlic mushrooms and a toasted tomato salad. Nothing mind blowing, but it&#39;s definitely a hearty breakfast! <br><br>They bake their own pastries and desserts here, and I ordered an old southern red velvet cake for $6. The cake was dry and unpalatable, with a weird cardboard aftertaste.<br><br>However I was pleasantly surprised when I brought the cake back. The staff were very apologetic and offered to exchange it for any other dessert, making recommendations for me as well. I chose the passion fruit curd cheesecake, which was quite heavy and but tasty and kept me quite happy. <br><br>Decent coffee is served here, bit when it gets really hot, I order a fresh juice or a San pelligrino to cool off.<br><br>I&#39;ve yet to try the lunch and dinner menu, but would definitely be back for more!

Such a beautiful setting! These guys have made great use of this space with its high, high ceilings and lush greenery around (hey it&#39;s the Botanic Gardens after all), it&#39;s really a treat to come by.<br><br>It was a pretty cool afternoon when I came by for some lunch, so the seats outdoors where actually a feasible option made easier when you find seats within the reach of the fan. Yes, we Singaporeans are so dependent on the wonders of air-conditioning. Okay I am so dependent on the wonders of air-conditioning.<br><br>So back to the space. It&#39;s big. And it feels a little too big sometimes, especially when you have to wander around to: a) order your food, b) collect your utensils, c) find a seat. Almost like a school canteen on your first day... but thankfully the food is better here. Check out the lunch time specials - great deals there, but of course there are lots of other tasty options. Remember your table number!

text: This is going to fast become one of my favourite joints.<br><br>Good grilled portobello salad with ginger and sesame dressing, great pancakes (banana walnut is my usual choice), decent brunch (pick any 3 items from the list of usual suspects for $8 only), decent prices and bread and butter pudding, the last being the clincher. Oh and there&#39;s free Wi-Fi.<br><br>A satisfying bread and butter pudding can be had for a mere $6ish, drenched in milky vanilla over it. This always makes my day.<br><br>(Electronic) parking is ample in the underground Botanical gardens carpark, which means rain or shine, you&#39;re covered from your car all the way to your pudding. <br><br>The fact that the restaurant/cafe is next to a children&#39;s playground and surrounded by greenery with sun shining in makes it that much more pleasing to dine in. Every table has a hole shaped in it for potted plants, and the lights overhead are fashioned from tins. I love just about everything about this place.<br><br>Food for Thought does not charge for service, GST is already included in the listed prices so what you see on the menu is what you pay. So if you dig their service, remember to leave a tip, or choose to donate $2 when you take a glass of free clean water, so an African can be blessed with the same for a year.<br><br>Cool cafe with a great concept. Love it!

Brunch', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Brunch'}]
text: Food for thought is at one end of Botanic Garden hiding at a basement. Along the way, there are no signboard to lead us there. But when you reach the restaurant, it is still filled with people. If you take MRT to Botanic Garden, you may have to walk from one end of the park to the other to reach the place.<br><br>The restaurant is very spacious with nice decor. You can choose to sit indoor or take the out door seats. For us, after a long walk and all sweaty, we went ahead with siting inside without thinking. Orders have to be made at the counter. To speed up the ordering process, the restaurant have two ordering counters.<br><br>The food were average but the ambience was great. You wouldn&#39;t want to go back out under the Sun after finding a place like this in the garden.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WSRnkS_mlOo-7lPWTinQGw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/food-for-thought-singapore?reviewid=rJGUKMmG-rrED_Y3NoucXQ&select=WSRnkS_mlOo-7lPWTinQGw', 'altText': 'Photo of Food For Thought - Singapore, Singapore. &#39;Linner&#39;-ing with my friend Elise', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': "'Linner'-ing with my friend Elise"}]
text: Having been to the spacey, tastefully and artfully decorated Food For Thought @ 8Q, some expectations were set for their rather new Botanic Gardens venture... so after a good 25-minute trek through the Botanic Gardens (my gal pal and I entered from the Bukit Timah Gate, much to our dismay), we arrived in a large, spacious, forest-y restaurant with a large variety of different sized tables (imagine a small table coupled with high stools, and next to it, a giant table with 8-10 chairs)! <br><br>They were working on the AC indoors so it didn&#39;t bring us much relief from the heat (and exercise), but I hope it&#39;s done now!<br><br>Exciting!<br><br>They do the all-day brunch (as with their other branches), and my gal pal got the scrambled eggs with mushrooms &amp; toast, and I went and ordered the Iced Earl Grey Tea with Milk (exhausted from the trek before). <br><br>I had a nibble of her food (thank goodness for small appetites!) and found the scrambled eggs to be really fluffy and deliciouso, and the sautéed mushrooms to be the highlight - salty, bursting with flavour and juice, and uber fragrant! If you&#39;re getting the all-day brunch, I&#39;d highly recommend the mushrooms.<br><br>My drink however, was sub-par and disappointing, and with the $4.50 price tag, it was something I could have done at home - dunk a tea bag in hot tea and heavily dilute it with milk, then pour it on ice. I&#39;d definitely come back, but I wouldn&#39;t get the Iced Tea. That&#39;s a no-no.

text: Nestled in the greenery and trees of the Singapore Botanic Gardens, Food For Thought truly wins in terms of location. The atmosphere is quite nice as well, really green and casual with concrete floors, wooden tables and an open kitchen. On a Sunday afternoon expect to see many families with kids there, which makes for a loud, messy environment. I don&#39;t mind kids, I think they&#39;re really entertaining to watch, but I know some other reviewers complained that there were too many kids....<br><br>The food was also very good! I&#39;ve been getting a bit tired of hawker food, so I was willing to spend a little bit more to get a little taste of home. I ordered the grilled ham and cheese and roasted tomato salad, total was $13. The sandwich was served on ciabatta bread with greens and Dijon mustard vinigrette with sliced roasted ham and ooey goeey melty cheese (havarti, I think). I&#39;m not sure if the sandwich was actually really good, or if I just missed bread and cheese so much that it didn&#39;t matter how good it was. I do think the sandwich could use more cheese- If I knew how little they would put I would have asked for extra, and been willing to pay for it. The roasted tomato salad was good, but not amazing. I was expecting grilled tomatoes on a plate seasoned with lemon and salt and pepper, but the dish was more like half of a sliced mushy tomato on a  bed of greens. It was okay, but I think the dish could use a better dressing and more tomatoes. Being the seasoned eater that I am I can frequently think of ways to make a dish better, but don&#39;t get me wrong, the food here is good.<br><br>I think the cheapest item on the lunch menu is the chicken rendang S$ 9 and on the breakfast menu (served from 8:30-10:30?) is the mee rebus for S$ 5.<br><br>One complaint I have is the people from the milkshake stand out front asked my friend and I three times if we wanted to buy a milkshake. The stand (some university partnership with FFT) is raising funds for children in Cambodia, which is a good cause and all, but I would have appreciated not being asked to buy a milkshake three times in a ten minute interval.<br><br>If you&#39;re in the area definitely see the Botanic Gardens. Food For Thought makes a great reward for your long, sweaty walk though the gardens. :D

Food for Thought is a large restaurant in the basement of the Botanic Garden (not by the MRT side - you have to walk to the other end of the park, or can get here by driving and there is parking available). Serves the typical array of American breakfast foods, from eggs &amp; hash browns to pancakes, some with an extra flare. Two people in my group had the chocolate and raspberry pancakes, which were delicious! I also loved the hash browns I ordered (which were like American tater tots). The other food were tasty too. We came here for brunch so we didn&#39;t try a lot of the lunch menu items. The one I did try-- the ratatouille -- was mediocre. The ambiance was casual.<br><br>They get docked some stars because of the ordering system which is a little confusing. You have to order and pay at the counter, and give them your table number so they can deliver it to the right table when the food comes. We had to make sure someone was sitting at the table so that it wasn&#39;t taken. It was also pretty crowded and busy so the service wasn&#39;t the fastest (although it&#39;s mostly self-service so you have to be pretty proactive about asking the wait staff for what you need). But, overall, we enjoyed our time here and I would recommend it as a nice breakfast or brunch place before (or after) a day out at the Botanic Gardens!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=EHj7DvjCuzkimIhqABpkTQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Natalie S.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Natalie S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=EHj7DvjCuzkimIhqABpkTQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': 3, 'reviewCount': 5, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I have been a huge fan of their beef burger, but the last time I went was for dinner, so burgers weren&#39;t an option as they aren&#39;t available after 5pm. I had an aglio olio which was spicy (bird&#39;s eye chilli/chilli padi spicy) but tasty. They have a wide range of desserts, all of which sound so delicious. I settled on a milo godzilla pudding which is just about my favourite milo dessert now. <br><br>There&#39;s a lot of food to choose from, ranging from all day breakfast to burgers and mains. Ambience is nice and relaxed, a great place for all to unwind although it can get a bit noisy especially when it&#39;s full of kids! <br><br>Prices are pretty average, which makes this place even more worthwhile.

Food For Thought always hold a special place in my palate... the all day breakfast and pancakes are always so delectable.<br><br>The food offering at the Botanical Gardens outlet is slightly different from the one at their restaurant at 8Q but it&#39;s equally tasty. <br><br>For first timers the ordering system may be a little confusing cos it&#39;s mainly self service and the wait staff are mainly there to help serve the orders instead of taking orders at the table. Utensils, water etc are also to be taken by patrons themselves.<br><br>Since this restaurant is much larger than the outlet at 8Q and the atmosphere is supposed to be a lot more casual and relaxing, this &#34;do-everything-at-your-own-pace&#34; system is pretty alright. Finding a seat first may be challenging on a crowded day but hey, lighten up and enjoy the smell of nature! You are afterall, in the Botanic Gardens! :)<br><br>However, the place depends a lot on natural lighting thus it may get a little dim when the sky is cloudy. The lights used are mainly spot lights at the area where the long tables are, thus it may also get a little warm. <br><br>Understand your own preference and choose your seats wisely, I&#39;m sure the overall experience will still be enjoyable.
