text: This is a great little spot for brunch after a walk around the Botanic Garden. Service was quick and impeccable! We&#39;d read about the berry and chocolate pancakes on a blog post and decided they were a necessary addition to American-style eggs, toast and bacon and an order of chicken laksa. The pancakes were tasty but not particularly special for pancakes. The homemade brioche toast was a clear winner, as was the laksa. The lattes were perfect for cooling down after the humidity of the gardens. Overall, a perfect spot to grab a bite.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/D3VbmEw0iFonx-Joi1IoxQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/food-for-thought-singapore?reviewid=jP1KFqxrTZOxjrGiB0dGwA&select=D3VbmEw0iFonx-Joi1IoxQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Food For Thought - Singapore, Singapore. Full works', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Full works'}]
text: Just love the banana walnut pancakes... And the fact that its inside the beautiful botanic garden makes this restaurant a nice place to visit for brunch on weekends.

I came here one late Sunday morning for brunch. And sure enough, the crowd was thick. The problem with a popular place on a Sunday morning is getting seats and I believe they do not do reservations. So the troop of us, about 6 managed to squeeze ourselves on to a single small table in an odd corner of the place. <br><br>The menu is a replicate of the one found in the other branch at Queen St. Nonetheless, the space and ambience fortunately makes up for the lack of a waiting staff. I would imagine that need to hire a lot more if they were to get people seated by waiters, the dining space is sprawling, indoors and out. <br><br>The food, I had the works. And a beer on the side. Yes, Sunday morning beers. Heh. We had to line up at a counter to place our orders and pay for them at the same time. They advised that the food would be served in 30 minutes or less but in actual fact they came in about 10. Very fast and efficient I thought! The food was as expected, good. <br><br>All in, a rather enjoyable Sunday morning for all us.

The service at the Botanic Gardens outlet is slightly different the one at SAM. This is a semi self-service system where you order and pay at the cashier and then the food gets served to you at your table. Even though it&#39;s pretty big, but it takes a while to get a table and then a little more to get your food. I prefer the sit down service at 8Q because at least i don&#39;t have to stand around to grab tables a la food court style. However, Botanic wins in terms of space and the close proximity to nature. Take your pick.<br><br>Food is pretty much the same. Customize your own breakfast set with their creamy scrambled eggs (must order). FfT has one of the better scrambled eggs around because they actually use cream in theirs to give it that runny and buttery texture. I would say skip the Toasts unless you really need carbs. Their spreads are really pathetic though.<br><br>What you should not miss out on is the pancakes. 2 Buttermilk base Pancakes served with Fresh Cream and Gula Melaka Syrup with the choice of different flavors such as Banana and Walnuts, Milk Chocolate, Dark Choc and Raspberries etc. Prices range from S$8 to $12.

average brunch food at the botanic gardens - some dishes (the simple ones) better executed than others. this placeIs rather popular, and I can see why. it&#39;s a large open space, completely casual canteen-seating predominates, and the menu is likewise expansive.<br><br>it&#39;s not the best brunch I&#39;ve had - really, not even close - but I don&#39;t really think that&#39;s the point. it feels rather more like a place you go to to be convivial, or bring your screaming children along - without too more recrimination, with a dash of decent food to help lubricate conversation.<br><br>it&#39;s a casual place, this - you shimmy up to order at the cashier and food gets served to the table. the partner had his mind set on the trio of sliders: the kaffir lime fish, spicy thai chicken and pulled pork. served alongside fries, these were all average - the bread was soft and giving though, and we&#39;ll recommend the chicken: it was tender, moist leg meat, seasoned well.<br><br>I took the salad-as-lunch option. the plate of sugar snap peas came tossed in a soy-sesame mix - refreshing in its simple greenness. the peas are untrimmed though, and I had to remove all the threads myself - avoid this if you&#39;re on a first-date-first-impressions kind of deal.<br><br>the smoked salmon &amp; broccoli plate was a great mix of flavors. chargrilled broccoli, cold hot-smoked salmon and roast beetroot - all delicious.<br><br>I might return. that salad was good, and the place does brunch proud - a vibrant atmosphere, nothing too awe-inducing or surprising for the first meal of the day. comfortable like those old pyjamas you can&#39;t bear to throw away.just don&#39;t come expecting mind-blowing food, and get in on the chillness of it all.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/AEPHv5ya4iXCTMt-eVhcKg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/food-for-thought-singapore?reviewid=PiTqBnkHP17ekOi_oqZTuw&select=AEPHv5ya4iXCTMt-eVhcKg', 'altText': 'Photo of Food For Thought - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Food for Thought started out as a little café in the Bras Brasah area and has now expanded to include a restaurant in the Botanic Gardens. They serve no frills comfort food at a pretty decent price. <br><br>The branch in the Botanic Gardens is huge and it&#39;s a nice place to go for lunch or brunch after a walk in the park. They&#39;ve got a wide array of desserts, Western and local mains, as well as breakfast. <br><br>Most of their dishes have a cool local twist to it. I tried the banana pancakes which was served with gula Melaka syrup. I would come back here for sure for brunch.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=dwgRHXRnv6dMhUTuCw0WPA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'David D.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'David D.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=dwgRHXRnv6dMhUTuCw0WPA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': 7, 'reviewCount': 10, 'eliteYear': None}
text: This was our third visit within a month of moving to Singapore. <br><br>Location is within the grounds of the Singapore botanic gardens and has an interesting concept where you queue and order and then your food is delivered to your table - which are organized by number. <br><br>There is indoor and outdoor seating as well as a nice but small play area for kids. <br><br>Today we ordered the laksa, mee rebus, house breakfast, pancakes with chocolate, and a toddlers egg, bacon and toast combo. To drink long black, flat white, lime iced tea and rosemary blood orange juice. The OJ was particularly enjoyable.<br><br>The food is reasonably priced, super fast and oozes a kid friendly vibe.<br><br>The chocolate pancakes are my daughter&#39;s favorite, two large cakes with a generous portion of chocolate chips that melts as you spread it around!<br><br>The eggs and bacon are pretty standard fare as was the laksa and rebus. <br><br>Overall worth a visit and will be a place we frequent.
tasteless food...<br>though they do look somewhat good.<br><br>the playground is way too small.<br><br>please bring back the old old food court with jalan kayu roti prata stall.

When I first heard that FFT had opened an outlet at Botanic Gardens, I was excited to check it out. Afterall, I was fond of its concept- a cause to support, breakfast components dissected to variable portions and trendy marketing: whats there not to love?<br><br>Sad to say, I was disappointed both times when I went to visit. While the interior of the place is gorgeous (plants growing out of tables, mind you)- I found the ordering system counter-intuitive and user-unfriendly. The restaurant expects you to first find yourself a table, (have someone to) chope the seat, and queue at the ordering counter. When ordering, you are supposed to tell them exactly where you are seated (basically screwed if someone else takes your seat) or they will refuse to let you order until you have found an alternative seat. I can imagine what a hard time this would give single diners, or worse, having to split up lovey-eyed couples by forcing one to queue thereby subjecting them to a painful 20 minutes wait before they reunite! The &#39;choping&#39; mechanism also makes me feel very ugly- I once had to tell someone with a crying baby on hand that basically all the seats around me were reserved. It is also very Singaporean, which surprises me, because Botanics is afterall a touristy place which attracts people whose culture might be vastly different from ours. I imagine this system to be completely indiscernible to them (I have seen foreigners bitch at staff over it).<br><br>Even the food is not comparable to the other outlet. My scrambled eggs came too buttery, it was like drinking oil, but I didn&#39;t even feel like sending it back because it would possibly mean having to wait for another half an hour. The menu is also different from the other outlet&#39;s- so if you are thinking of heading to this one for a specific dish, remember to check the online menu before you make your trip down.

Out of all the Food for Thought outlets in Singapore, this is the least impressive. It&#39;s located a midst the greenery of the botanical gardens - which means it has great potential. Unfortunately, the branch is let down by lackluster service, with the wait staff being under-trained and confused. Food wise - it&#39;s okay. It has greater variety than the other Food for Thought outlets, and is pretty cheap. This unfortunately is insufficient to overcome the terrible seating system they have - which is confusing to locals and tourists alike.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/VJl3mMxGXmWZiMcmpF2KLQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/jewel-coffee-singapore-15?reviewid=3iGmhN8ByANl71ynAh3Z4Q&select=VJl3mMxGXmWZiMcmpF2KLQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Jewel Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Flat white ($6.20)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Flat white ($6.20)'}]
text: Disclaimer: Depends on the barista on duty<br><br>Been a long while since I gave a review but this was disappointing considering the number of coffee shop options in Orchard and the fact that Jewel prides itself as a specialty coffee place. As seen in the photo, the flat white was void of any latte art. The flat white was the exact opposite of thick and creamy and failed to bring out the flavour of the beans.<br><br>Similarly, the cold brew was diluted and failed to produce any distinct notes.<br><br>Overall, a disappointment. If you&#39;re in the area, you&#39;d be better of at the cozy Plain Vanilla nearby which surprisingly serves better coffee.

Lauduree makes amazing macarons. The best part about this location is that there is usually barely a line! This place has no seats, so you should just pick up some to go.<br>The sales girl said that these were the most popular flavors: salted caramel, rose petal, and pistachio. I decided to try salted caramel, pistachio and strawberry.<br>The salted caramel was delicious- it was very caramel-y in a good way. The pistachio didn&#39;t have such a strong flavor, so I am not a big fan of it. The strawberry was my favorite- the strawberry flavor is very distinct!<br>Laduree isn&#39;t cheap but its worth the splurge when you want a good treat! They also have cute accessories such as macaron keychains. <br>Note: if you only buy a few macarons, you get them in a paper bag so be careful not to crush them.

text: I ventured on my own on a Sunday and got here after a brutal walk in the scorching heat and humidity. That is my only con about Singapore; the heat! I was very anxious and eager to try these macarons becaus supposedly they are the best. <br><br>After my $60 purchase and taking all sorts of pictures of the box, bag, and the store&#39;s selections, and my purchase... I can say w/ confidence that these ARE the best I have ever had. The macarons are incredibly light, airy and the filling is smooth, rich, and decadent. I ordered 15. I finished it in 2 days. I had the chocolate, coffee, and salted caramel. <br><br>The girl behind the counter was very patient w/ me, super soft-spoken, and welcoming. I did not intend to buy that many but how often am I going to be in Singapore?! Plus my GM said I can expense my chocolate/dessert purchases. What? I have the best job, the best manager, the best customer, and the best team. <br><br>I did many hours of cardio for these. It was so worth it!!

The special Laduree chocolate macaron decorated in 22 carats gold leaf', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The special Laduree chocolate macaron decorated in 22 carats gold leaf'}]
text: Even if I&#39;m not really in the mood for a macaron, I love to stop in a Laduree store given the chance.  The shop is just so aesthetically pleasing and the macarons in the variety of colors are so joyful.  <br><br>What makes the Singapore Laduree unique is the Special Laduree macaron; a chocolate macaron decorated in 22 carats gold leaf.  They advertised that it was the universal symbol of success, beauty and eternity and was known to give a higher IQ, and possesses the legendary powers contributing to a long and vital life.  But really, they had me at special.<br><br>I forked over the $7.90 Singapore dollars which roughly converts to about $6 US dollars and took a bite (after pictures of course!).  While the chocolate macaron was perfect and divine, I didn&#39;t care at all for the metallic taste of the gold leaf.  Shucks, there goes increasing my IQ.<br><br>Wonderful place for gifts!

text: Macaron or Macaroon???<br><br>There seems to be a bit of confusion, so here is a helpful set of definitions.<br><br>A macaron is characterised by a dome-shaped biscuit made of egg whites and almond meal, hard to the touch with a chewy interior. - This is what is served at Laduree.<br><br>A macaroon is a small meringue cake, typically made of coconut and often dipped in chocolate. - This isn&#39;t served at Laduree.<br><br>Popped in here late last week at the request of Miss S to grab her some world famous Macarons. It seems the hype is well and truly over as I found myself able to walk straight in and place my order (a selection of the entire range currently being 15 in total and one more to make up a circular box of 16 for 58 Singapore Dollars) Although this may have been due more to the fact that I waltzed in around 2:15 in the evening when most potential customers are busy at work.<br><br>Having tried the entire range on offer at the time we came to our judgements. Our favorites went in this order (best to worst) Chocolate Cafe (seasonal), Chocolate, Vanilla,  Salted Caramel, Lemon, Pistachio and Green Apple (seasonal).<br><br>I have to agree with other people on the salted caramel also - whilst we could definitely taste the caramel there wasn&#39;t so much of a hint of the salt. <br><br>Although these macarons were pleasant are they worth the price? At 3.80 Singapore Dollars a macarons bar the golden coated one, it does come in below prices elsewhere so by that reasoning I suppose its not bad value for a world renowned brand.<br><br>Worth a look in if your in Singapore and the surroundings are quite pleasant too.

text: Yeah, so I&#39;m a dude. I waited in a line (the only man there) for 25 mins to pay $3,80 a piece for macaroons, so what... Seriously, there is NO macaroon like laduree&#39;s. They rock my world. I recommend highly! Try rose, pistachio and salted caramel. No man can resist, even though its a chick thing...<br><br>Welcome to SG! Laduree you rock my world!

Salted Caramel, Gold Chocolate, Lemon, Chocolate', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Salted Caramel, Gold Chocolate, Lemon, Chocolate'}]
text: When I heard Laduree&#39;s opened in Singapore, I was like &#34;YAYYYYY...&#34; then I realised... Oh crap, that means the whole damn country is going to populate this place. True enough, the entire blogosphere started talking about the long queues and all that. <br><br>And I thought &#34;Meh... I already tried Laduree&#39;s in London anyway...&#34; <br><br>Then the boyfriend showed up one night after my dance class with a bag of macaroons. <br><br>I squealed with joy, then I wondered what the hell he did that he felt he had to surprise me with a bag of macaroons. But that&#39;s besides the point, I got a bag of macaroons!<br><br>Four. To be exact. <br><br>I ate the gold chocolate one first. Seriously, at $7 a piece.. it&#39;s like... just chocolate with gold dust. That&#39;s it. <br><br>The salted caramel was how I remembered it when I ate it in the sweltering London Summer heat. So was the other chocolate one and the lemon one. <br><br>I have tried Pierre Hermes&#39;s macaroons lovingly flown in from Paris by my stewardess bestie.. but it shrunk due to the air pressure, so I couldn&#39;t judge if it&#39;s the best in the world.. yet... <br><br>So until I fulfill my dream of eating BOTH Pierre Hermes&#39;s and Laduree&#39;s macaroons both at the same time...... I&#39;ll say Laduree&#39;s macaroons will be the best &#39;authentic&#39; Parisian macaroon in Singapore for now.

Im surprised this famous macaron shop in Ngee Ann City has less than 10 reviews o_o<br><br>I guess all the initial hype has died down, so the shop was pretty empty on a Monday at 615pm when I entered. <br><br>Laduree seems to attract mostly tourists, as these were the only customers I saw. <br><br>I ordered a box of 6 macarons and I could pick between 4 colors for the packaging. For $32, I think most of the price probably went into the box and exquisite looking paper bag. <br><br>The macarons though, I guess they are just okay :/ I dont know. I didnt like the salted caramel flavor which apparently was their most popular flavor. Too much caramel, couldnt taste the salt. Could have passed as Caramel macaron. <br><br>Will probably not return again. I think TWG ones are cheaper and good enough.

text: After moving from NY, I was missing Laduree macarons and was just thinking about how I would get some when I go to Paris later this year. The quality of some other macarons they&#39;re selling in SG are just overpriced, not so fresh, and just didn&#39;t show people how good a macaron is suppose to be -- basically a waste of money. Although, the ones at PAUL bakery (same holding company as Laduree) and Antoinette are quite good. <br><br>Anyways, when I heard Laduree was coming to SG, I was so excited! I didn&#39;t go the first week when it just opened (the news reported that lines were crazy), but there was still a bit of a line when I got there this weekend...not too long...maybe 7 minutes. <br><br>The price was pretty on par with what I paid in NY. After buying a box of 8, I took a bite out of my orange blossom and it was slightly disappointing  -- for some reason, it didn&#39;t have that light, airy fresh feeling as the orange blossom I had in NY.   Maybe they weren&#39;t as fresh as the ones that they shipped to NY because of distance...but it was still very good quality though. I would still pick some up again if I&#39;m in the area.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=WdE8eWEeZ7aYcnR8kf6u8A', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7iJSEX_7oTk8NYIehQ9q7A/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7iJSEX_7oTk8NYIehQ9q7A/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7iJSEX_7oTk8NYIehQ9q7A/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7iJSEX_7oTk8NYIehQ9q7A/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7iJSEX_7oTk8NYIehQ9q7A/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/7iJSEX_7oTk8NYIehQ9q7A/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Daniel H.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Daniel H.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=WdE8eWEeZ7aYcnR8kf6u8A', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 87, 'photoCount': 205, 'reviewCount': 300, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I was pleasantly surprised by my visit to this location because I had been wanting macarons ever since my visit to Ladurée in Paris. I find that no other bakery or place makes macarons quite as deliciously as they do there, and there are no locations nearby me in Los Angeles. So on my latest visit to Singapore, I was so glad to have found out about this location.<br><br>They are set up as a macarons only boutique inside the Takashimaya shopping center, and they have a variety of macarons and teas for sale. There were some new flavors here that I was excited to try that they didn&#39;t have back in the Paris location when I visited last December, such as the Marie Antoinette tea and the Green Apple. I found the Green Apple flavor to be particularly delicious, and had I known this when I was making my purchase I would have definitely bought more.<br><br>The macarons are sold in a variety of different sizes. We opted to buy a box of 8 in a &#34;Singapour&#34; Ladurée box for $40 (SGD) and a round container of 15 for $60 (SGD). Prices are quite steep, especially for just a dessert item, but they were delicious and just like the ones that you can find in Paris. It&#39;s a very distinct taste that is only perfected by Ladurée, and taking a bite of the macaron sent me back to Paris! When doing the currency conversion, the price is only slightly higher (by a couple cents) of the cost of a macaron in Paris (one macaron is about 2.5 euros). We also found out that their macarons are flown in and made all the way in Switzerland!<br><br>So overall, definitely a steep price to pay, but in my opinion it was quite worth it! I would definitely love to return here if I ever visit Singapore again, and if you are from the area, I would absolutely recommend that you come try some!

It seems like the hype has died down considerably, and I made off with six macarons at no fuss. Just for the heck of it, I got myself one of those whoopie pies masquerading as macarons from Paul as well to do a taste test. Mad scientist round one!<br><br>Laduree wins hands down, being light, airy and not cloyingly sweet. Chocolate yuzu was an interesting mix of citrus tang and fragrance, and melded well with the chocolate ganache. Having a barbie moment, I picked out the strawberry marshmallow as well, drawn by its saccharine hue. Now macaron fillings are typically jam, cream or ganache and this was an unexpected twist, with the pull of marshmallow providing a slight chew. Somebody&#39;s even more a mad scientist than I am, apparently. And I can&#39;t really recall what was the third one I had, only that it was blue.<br><br>I got six but gave half away as in general I&#39;m not much of a macaron fan - I find the gritty texture rather unappealing. And at almost $4 a pop, I expected angels to sing at first bite. But nope, no heavenly ray of light or haloed choir. Ah well. Luckily it was pay day.

text: well i guess the lines are normal if you go late.<br><br>i was there the other day and there was not a line at all (go to the shop not the pushcart)<br><br>Deco wise i would say it reminded my of paris,  although it was abit too cramped.<br><br>Taste wise, even thou they are expensive but the taste is really worth it.<br><br>Its good for treating yourself and an indulgence.

What&#39;s all the hype about? The long lines, the colourful macaroons and of course the amazing flavours. So the macaroons are delicious. No doubt they are the best  macaroons I had in Singapore apart from the dessert tray at Guy Savoy (MBS). <br><br>But honestly for the long line and price, go to a proper restaurant and enjoy the little sweet treats. The counter staffs are young and often missed the flavors you want. They are inefficient but friendly. <br><br>I only hope for the service staffs to improve or the reputation for this place might just be a take out macaroon place and for the macaroon snobs. <br><br>Good for a touch and go stop or treat to yourself but nothing more.

They rock my world. I recommend highly! Try rose, pistachio and salted caramel. No man can resist, even though its a chick thing...<br><br>Welcome to SG! Laduree you rock my world!

text: This branch is usually minimally staffed. So they multitasks, manning different parts of the stores. Food quality is a little inconsistent, very much depends on whom is making it that day. <br><br>Most of the time when I purchase coffee powder here, the beans will be grind to a perfect texture for my espresso machine. We get a free daily brew when we purchase a bag of beans. We can request for free paper filters for drip machines if needed.
Worst coffee bean i&#39;ve been to.  The orders took 30mins to be served, even for just a salad, and even the place is not that full

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=FQZZsU3J88IGF8n5e3XYZg', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ECJ_n1ZLon7Rsc4c6HBEwA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ECJ_n1ZLon7Rsc4c6HBEwA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ECJ_n1ZLon7Rsc4c6HBEwA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ECJ_n1ZLon7Rsc4c6HBEwA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ECJ_n1ZLon7Rsc4c6HBEwA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/ECJ_n1ZLon7Rsc4c6HBEwA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Jerilyn M.', 'displayLocation': 'Los Angeles, CA', 'altText': 'Jerilyn M.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=FQZZsU3J88IGF8n5e3XYZg', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 332, 'photoCount': 320, 'reviewCount': 126, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Bubble tea craze aside, this is some legit bubble tea. In my opinion, the best bubble tea in Singapore (and LA, not that that&#39;s saying much). <br><br>There&#39;s something about Koi that makes it taste so good, maybe it&#39;s the type of milk they use, maybe it&#39;s the pearls - maybe it&#39;s both. <br><br>The milk just tastes different - slightly creamier and fuller in taste, perhaps? Yet, it gives just the right amount of creamy-ness without being overpowering, letting the flavor of the tea balance the milk out. This gives your Bubble Tea the perfect consistency, every single time. <br><br>The pearls are made the perfect texture, probably the best I&#39;ve tasted (chewy &amp; bouncy but not too hard) and slightlyyy smaller than your average pearl size making it super fun it sip / chew on. The slightly smaller pearl size also gives you the perfect pearl/tea ratio when you sip it up, if that even makes sense. <br><br>My favorites? The regular Milk Tea, Hazelnut Milk Tea or Honey Milk Tea - with pearls! Oh and, if you&#39;re into grass jelly, you must ask for both grass jelly AND pearls! I love that they give you freshly made huge chunks of grass jelly here instead of shredded up pieces like at most bubble tea places. <br><br>There can be a little bit of a wait for Koi, but no where near when the Bubble Tea craze was at its peak. Still, their standards have remained high and I&#39;d pick Koi over Gong Cha or Each-a-Cup any day.

Came here as a last resort with a friend for a quick late night meal after attending a play nearby at around 11:15PM on a Saturday. <br>The place itself is conveniently located just a couple of minutes away from Novena MRT. It has an all-glass exterior and comprises of two levels, as well as an outdoor seating area. The outlet is rather large and spacious, and can be easily spotted. Upon entering, most tables were occupied with customers and their laptops. <br>Not having eaten for the entire day, I was hoping that they were still serving hot food items and was pleasantly surprised that they did! Decided to get myself an Asian Chicken Salad and Cheese Soup, whilst my friend got their Sausage Baked Penne Pasta, coupled with imported bottled juice drinks from the chilled section. <br>The salad was pre-packaged in a plastic container. It had lettuce, baby corn, chicken breast, and broccoli. The sesame dressing that came with was much too little for me and the salad itself was below average, the meat was tough and dry. <br>The hot food however, addressed our hunger pangs. The soup, which came with two pieces of herb bread was flavourful and creamy with chunks of potato in it. The pasta was covered with melted cheese and spicy chorizo sausage. Both dishes were of nice serving portions. <br>I gave them a four star because of its location, 24/7 opening hours, and for a mega coffee chain, they did have some decent food to offer to customers besides the usual sandwiches and muffins. They were also quick in serving us as we had to catch the last train back.

Sure, the cafe looks great after a refurbishment but if customers come on a Sunday afternoon and can&#39;t find a seat because every single available space is filled with students, then that is not a good experience.<br><br>It&#39;s also bad business. Students sit there nursing a single drink for an entire day. Coffee shops are not for hours of studying but unless management does something about this, students will continue to hog seats and prevent anyone else from relaxing with a cuppa.

This shop has become a common study place for students. They occupy the nice and cool indoor seats for hours, many of us have to settle outside under the shade, hot and humid. I would suggest you walk over to Novena Square for a more  comfortable place to better enjoy your frappuccino.

When I want an everyday kinda cuppa, Starbucks is the place! :) this place has recently been redone... Much better! Service is still iffy though. Not &#39;bad&#39;, mind you. Just iffy. Hahaha!! <br><br>Well I&#39;ve got my caffe latte... That&#39;s alllllllll that matters really.

text: Spacious and comfortable, but ditto on the awful and obnoxious staff. Regularly gets my order wrong as they don&#39;t seem to understand the concept of &#34;add milk.&#34;

Cappuccino', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Cappuccino'}]
text: Very beautiful cafe with very friendly staffs. This cafe located at Jalan Besar, 5 minutes walk from Mustafa. Must try the Hot Me Not,  pizza. The pizza are very crispy... Yum... Yummy. <br>Another must try on their menu is smoked Duck Aglio. My friends told me the Grill Bacon Roll is great too. <br>I love the Honey Peppermint beverage is so refreshing! <br>The price on the menu are nett.  No service charge and GST.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/6r46lrh1KPb6Pe61rDMhnA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/brill-singapore?reviewid=gABcTAfXUeBPjQ_EL3jCDQ&select=6r46lrh1KPb6Pe61rDMhnA', 'altText': 'Photo of Brill - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/tnb0E8gl2fhgX5JgOIkfgg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/brill-singapore?reviewid=gABcTAfXUeBPjQ_EL3jCDQ&select=tnb0E8gl2fhgX5JgOIkfgg', 'altText': 'Photo of Brill - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Brill in a nutshell is a small bites and coffee outpost by Simply Bread. Located on the same premises Simply Bread Cluny Court, this outpost offers minimal seating (2 tiny tables to be exact). Aimed more at the take-away crowd, this tiny place is great for catching up on some reading if you do manage to get one of the two tables. Personally, I prefer Brill as it reminds me of laneway cafes that you get over in Melbourne, Australia. The small spaces and privacy are one of a kind! Not to worry if you&#39;re craving sandwiches or mains from Simply Bread, just place your order with the server at Brill and your order will come straight from the kitchen above. A great spot for lazy Sunday afternoons either rain or shine!

A tiny place which I never knew existed until this morning when I saw some people having coffee and pastries outside the store. It is right next to the car park entrance, and easily missed unless you walked from that direction. <br><br>I had the sticky bun which was good and was probably from Simply Bread upstairs. A good place to grab some baked goods, granola or sandwiches on the way to work.

They don&#39;t seem to care too much about either customer service or replying to customer complaints.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': "They don't seem to care too much about either customer service or replying to customer complaints."}]
text: To Kith Cafe:<br>Was just at your Ascot Orchard branch with my last Stoke cup voucher (no expiry dates on them). First told I can&#39;t redeem. Then when I said there is no expiry date they said it was six months. I said there is no expiry on the voucher (I had purchased the cup from this very location ). And finally as if doing a favour to me the manager said - fine I&#39;ll give you a coffee - now bad service is one thing but acting as if you are doing me a favour by me redeeming a voucher that is my right is something extraordinary. You can keep that card for ever and save the 2 bucks.

text: Ikea-type décor; the couch on which you sit is a storage box. The crabmeat linguine is horrible, with mushy pasta. Unlike better eateries, they can only cook burgers medium or well-done; anyway, the buns fall apart too easily. Even with 1-for-1 Entertainer offer, it is poor value. Even if you stay at the Ascott, you should avoid; there are better and better-value joints nearby.

text: Decór is okay, ambience is okay. Generic top 100 pop music. <br><br>We had no idea whether we had to order at the counter or from the table, so service was lacking.<br><br>Aglio oglio was a tad dry and a bit minimalistic in ingredients, but okay.<br><br>Gnocchi was okay, the tomato base was not bad. However the texture and taste was bland all around. It unfortunately looked like it came from Swensen&#39;s as well. <br><br>The loaded fries suck. Cheap western-stall-at hawker-centre quality meat and fries for $14? Bro.<br><br>For the price, it&#39;s a no from me.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=Z7z16B6RiV8XGft4ipBj2A', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/3HYuxqtjJuMU6hzkkKBNrA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/3HYuxqtjJuMU6hzkkKBNrA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/3HYuxqtjJuMU6hzkkKBNrA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/3HYuxqtjJuMU6hzkkKBNrA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/3HYuxqtjJuMU6hzkkKBNrA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/3HYuxqtjJuMU6hzkkKBNrA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'JM M.', 'displayLocation': 'Granite Bay, CA', 'altText': 'JM M.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=Z7z16B6RiV8XGft4ipBj2A', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 1, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 9, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Food was bland. Not good for the price you pay. AND the service was horrible. We are staying at Ascott Serviced Apartments in the same building. My son was very sick with the stomach flu. The first time I went in the girl completely  ignored me and just kept cleaning. All I wanted was a sparkling water. When She came over, she was very rude. Like I was bothering her. <br>The following day, I ordered some gnocchi, and ravioli. The food is not good. Barely any gnocchi and ravioli. Seems to have come straight from the jar. <br>A big issue I have is that they DO NOT care about their customers. They have curry and rice on the menu and I just wanted a side of rice (for my sick 6yr old). They would not sell me a simple side of rice, even after I pleaded that my son was sick and I could not leave the hotel as I had no one to watch him to grab some. They completely ignored me even when I asked numerous times why they couldn&#39;t help me out. There is nothing on the menu to help settle a stomach. All of their menu is greasy or cheesy. <br>They do not care about their customers. <br>This is very rare for a restaurant in Singapore, to not try and help or accommodate a customer. <br>I wound not recommend this place and will never ever eat here again. Zero stars from me!

Menu (partial)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Menu (partial)'}]
text: Good quality sandwiches<br><br>Ate exactly what we had at their other outlet at Marina Square. Consistently good.<br><br>Smoke duck sandwich comes with sourdough, green apple slices, Japanese cucumber, balsamic reduction - yummy! Wish there was more duck but I know duck is expensive and for the price it was sufficient.<br><br>Bacon sandwich - crispy bacon, tomato, lettuce, avocado, poached egg (which we mistook for mozzarella), Japanese mayonnaise on sourdough - lots of bacon! Very nice.<br><br>Sourdough bread is very nice.

text: I love this place. The food is tasty and of great quality. It&#39;s my go-to place for weekday takeouts. Also, the manager of this place is a nice guy - he walked me through a process of how they marinate the meats, prepare pickled veggies and etc. Recommended!

I went to visit this place twice this week because i did not have the time to go out. This place serves a variety of noodle and rice dishes with a Korean touch. Prices range between 7 and 10 S$. <br>I tried the Korean pasta, which was nice but a bit boring , since there were no vegis or meat in it. The other dishes was better - the chicken teriyaki noodle, although a bit too sweet for me.

text: I am in total awe of this store. Like steroidal effects, the colors and packaging heightened me to maximum. Cortisol level was so high, walking thru all the aisles..<br><br>In the basement folks... look for the $6 special Jollibee sign as a cue.. <br><br>Great product and inventory. No bakery. Meat protein section, saba fish etc is extensive

text: FINALLY found that elusive microwave oven.  It is located at ALMOST the EXIT and the mini dining area for Don Don Donki NOVENA location.  ONLY visit this location of Don Don Donki during NON Peak Hours..  I have ever purchased the ready made salad aka Japanese Salad Bowl.  They also sell Cucumbers from MALAYSIA.  Unfortunately the Cucumbers tasted bitter.  Hence NOT all items are from JAPAN.  The tiny salad which was (SG$2.90) is ok and doable.  Shared this item with my Mother.<br><br>From the Japanese Coffee, to ready eat salad or meals and snacks galore.  I will return when needed.<br><br>Recent visit was on Tuesday February 4th 2020 with the Strawberry Cream Mochi (SG$2.00) and Kani (SG$3.90).  In conclusion I prefer my Blueberry Cream Mochi purchase some time back as compared to the recent purchased of the Strawberry Cream Mochi.  Kani was doable and okay tasting - NOT fishy...

Steak &amp; cheese sandwich + coffee', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Steak & cheese sandwich + coffee'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/3tM_6lGcQE6MReF1jMZYGg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-gourmet-food-co-singapore?reviewid=ZTbq6b3yTrDY2lVvFsisPA&select=3tM_6lGcQE6MReF1jMZYGg', 'altText': 'Photo of The Gourmet Food Co - Singapore, Singapore. Australian grain fed ribeye, $4/100g (only!)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Australian grain fed ribeye, $4/100g (only!)'}]
text: It&#39;s a butchery and a diner to satisfy your meat craving any time in the day (not night)!<br><br>I find that it&#39;s a little low profile on the shop front, which might mislead some passerby to imagine it as just another meat store. However, they have an interesting concept here!<br><br>In the store, you can choose the type of meat you&#39;d like to go for, and the expert will do the cut and serve it hot for dine in with a extra handling fee of $8 which comes with 2 side dishes. The people in store definitely know their stuff, so I can trust them on the food delivered. You can also purchase wine and other beverages here. For lunch, they serve gourmet sandwiches as well with coffee/tea. Desserts are also available in their fridge.<br><br>First visit and I had an Aussie 90 days grainfed ribeye stinky $4/100g!!! DAMN SHIOK AH. I returned subsequently a couple of times to bring my colleagues for meals too. Go early for lunch as there&#39;s really limited seats inside (just 1 counter top if I remember correctly).<br><br>So yes, this is a also a fresh meat supplier store. For days when we require meat for parties, I&#39;ll get the whole slab of good quality meat back home to serve. The price is reasonable and you can be guaranteed on the quality! The frozen section sells frozen USDA meat and seafood as well, which I rarely check them out.<br><br>Give me quality meat at low cost and I&#39;m a happy customer!!

text: Great coffee! I usually use milk with my coffee but this coffee is delicious as it is. The pancake souffle is moist and the marron flavor introduces the right amount of sweetness. The pancake souffle and coffee is a good combo. A single order is quite filling already. I think I&#39;ll come back for the matcha souffle :)

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=InOoHsNe5XDyIsTK_zEong', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/vLF35Ijf8GInoKq96meWAw/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/vLF35Ijf8GInoKq96meWAw/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/vLF35Ijf8GInoKq96meWAw/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/vLF35Ijf8GInoKq96meWAw/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/vLF35Ijf8GInoKq96meWAw/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/vLF35Ijf8GInoKq96meWAw/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Alice M.', 'displayLocation': 'New York, NY', 'altText': 'Alice M.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=InOoHsNe5XDyIsTK_zEong', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 111, 'photoCount': 175, 'reviewCount': 159, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Toast box is a subchain of the overall bakery - Bread Talk. If you walk around the mall, you will see a lot of bakeries selling various types of asian bread. Toast Box specialize in recreating the ambience of Singpaore in the 70&#39;s/80&#39;s.  Obviously I am not from the era so I cannot judge if the food is a good representation of that period but overall, I do like the food. Kaya toast is kaya spread &amp; butter sandwiched in two thin slices of toasted white bread. Kaya is a green  or brown paste ( the color depends if yours had panada leaves in it) made out of thicken coconut milk and sugar, reduced into a paste. So yes, it is extremely bad for your health to consume this in huge quantities, especially since it goes together with thick slabs of butter. But, the warm melty goodness is worth it

Love the place here. Always a favorite with some of the nicest folks around.  It&#39;s a &#39;cheers&#39; type bar where everybody will eventually know your name. <br><br>Beer is inexpensive.  And the clients are mostly &#39;white&#39; folks as oppose to the Asians. Best part about this place is that you don&#39;t have to &#39;play&#39; pub games.  The ladies at the bar is usually spoken for and its just a really good ol place to hang out and enjoy some nice company. ;)

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=fBfMU89ASy0aaPP3qczrsw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Shi Qing P.', 'displayLocation': 'Financial District, Manhattan, NY', 'altText': 'Shi Qing P.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=fBfMU89ASy0aaPP3qczrsw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 2, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 1, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Very poor customer service. Called 20 times without getting any pick up. Never come to this bar!

Dog &amp; Bone is a neighbourhood pub with a primarily expat clientele. If I&#39;m not wrong, the owner is an Englishman who has made the overall vibe here unlike a typically Singapore pub, which is very casual and unassuming. They show live games here such as cricket and Australian-rules football and rugby, which is refreshing as many pubs solely concentrate on airing soccer matches. <br><br>The drinks are cheap and reasonable, with some English offerings as well, like Pimms and Boddingtons beer. Only downside is that it closes pretty early at 12-ish am for last drink orders, and they don&#39;t inform you for last orders.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=wg_XTwVmICAj_2c6IL3Rig', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Gideon J.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Gideon J.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=wg_XTwVmICAj_2c6IL3Rig', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 5, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Great staff and a really friendly atmosphere.  All walks of life are welcome even though most of the patrons are British.  Stella Artois on tap and a large selection of beers and liquors reasonably priced for Singapore.  Food is decent.  I believe Thursdays is Thai night and the Thai food is amazing.  Menu is mostly British food, but also includes a little American and Asian diversity.  There is a dart board, and dart nights are Thursday.  Would definitely recommend stopping in if you want to catch any sports or just chill and have a drink.

text: This place is overpriced for what they offer. For these prices you can go to a cafe that actually knows what they&#39;re doing when it comes to western food!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/6mE9ZQSFhHBCbHN5pwZXHQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/simply-bread-singapore-3?reviewid=BNYruPRwvEw8LQXwFNSa0Q&select=6mE9ZQSFhHBCbHN5pwZXHQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Simply Bread - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Simply Bread is one of the few bakeries around my neighbourhood where you can find a good selection of gourmet breads, pastries and sandwiches. I&#39;ve always liked the minimalist concept of this chain. Their blithe cement floor provides interesting contrast against the wooden benches, giving the place a very laid-back vibe. Décor is minimal, with lines kept very clean and the space kept very neat.<br><br>What I really appreciate is the way the food items are being displayed- each bread is showcased behind a clear panel and labeled with flags. I am mostly a creature of habit (meaning I keep going back for the same stuff all the time), but the labeled items do sometimes catch my attention and I find myself more willing to try them especially if they have an interesting name or contain an interesting ingredient.<br><br>While the menu is not extensive (mostly sandwiches and some breakfast items), I can safely say all of the items are worth a try. My favourite has to be the Tuna Croissant (~$6 I think)- they have the fluffiest buttery croissant, freshest lettuce and the tuna filling is so melt-in-your-mouth good. On days when I get crazy carbohydrate cravings, I find myself gravitating to the Peanut Butter and Banana sandwich- so rich and so comforting. If you are a fan of yoghurt or are looking for something light to clear your palette, I also recommend their home-made yoghurt, topped with jam and muesli.

Simply bread is an after school &#34;snack store&#34; where my friends and I would go just to get a couple sticky buns. Till now, it&#39;s still the sticky buns that keeps me going back. Some mornings when I am nearby I&#39;ll grab breakfast in house. The eggs and toast is rather reasonable for under $8. Scrambled eggs are always good. The muesli is really good, complete with grape juice that is fresh. <br><br>But no doubt, it is a pricey eatery. The sticky bun&#39;s the only thing worth my cash, and I wouldn&#39;t travel all the way unless I&#39;m nearby.

There are fans of this place, but I&#39;m not so much of one.<br><br>The breads aren&#39;t bad, but they are PRICEY. I got a sandwich for lunch some time ago - salt-cured beef - and I remember being appalled by the size of the sandwich, and more so by the slivers of meat masquerading as beef.<br><br>The Girlfriend loves the sticky buns though, so that&#39;s pretty much the only thing I eat from there now.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=Cd8OdDB6wJxurtAgU-IgHA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'K R.', 'displayLocation': 'New York, NY', 'altText': 'K R.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=Cd8OdDB6wJxurtAgU-IgHA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 258, 'photoCount': 191, 'reviewCount': 236, 'eliteYear': None}
photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/joWkVItX8_60NCTGlGvg8g/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/simply-bread-singapore-3?reviewid=w-lt-etgyGeq23RMm6Gzkg&select=joWkVItX8_60NCTGlGvg8g', 'altText': 'Photo of Simply Bread - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FuUOidadxgEj8s8qdd7PWg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/simply-bread-singapore-3?reviewid=w-lt-etgyGeq23RMm6Gzkg&select=FuUOidadxgEj8s8qdd7PWg', 'altText': 'Photo of Simply Bread - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: I go to Simply Bread on a regular basis as its right in my neighborhood of Bukit Timah. Best thing there is the all-day breakfast, which I seem to crave at all hours of the day! <br><br>Chose from omelets, eggs any style, French toast, muesli and my favorite--cinnamon toast. Its two chewy pieces of buttered toast topped with cinnamon and sugar.  Chose to add cheese, mushrooms, peppers or ham in your omelet. <br><br>They also have a variety of sandwiches and salads (go for the ceasar salad, its homemade and none of that store bought stuff) and they give you the option to add avocado to any sandwich or salad. Take home their fresh pastries, rolls, foccacia, sliced bread, ciabatta and sticky buns. <br><br>Probably one of the best places in Singapore to get fresh and rustic breads. A great place for a casual breakfast, brunch, lunch or snack.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=WjVcI874wgGopzaG0bA-5Q', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/DlRJv20O02RCo7ssdUWDzg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/DlRJv20O02RCo7ssdUWDzg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/DlRJv20O02RCo7ssdUWDzg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/DlRJv20O02RCo7ssdUWDzg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/DlRJv20O02RCo7ssdUWDzg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/DlRJv20O02RCo7ssdUWDzg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Crystal M.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Crystal M.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=WjVcI874wgGopzaG0bA-5Q', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 111, 'photoCount': 8, 'reviewCount': 69, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I come here once in a while when I don&#39;t feel like cooking lunch. <br><br>The brunch comes with a decent sized piece of ham, scrambled eggs and bread. Nothing out of the ordinary. <br><br>I like some of their special lunches like their pulled pork sandwich... too bad that it isn&#39;t served more often! I also like their GHC, grilled ham and cheese with dijon mustard. Sandwiches run about $10 and come with a side of cole slaw. <br><br>Three stars because for the price of the food the serving is quite minimal while the taste is not necessarily &#34;restaurant worthy&#34;. At least a side of crisps would be nice! Service is usually friendly. Bread does not go on sale in the last hour. But overall pretty good.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hhZ8K7UBJSztdz5kZSOD1Q/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/238-coffee-stall-singapore?reviewid=XoqVv485zTV8NeKE7_IFyA&select=hhZ8K7UBJSztdz5kZSOD1Q', 'altText': 'Photo of 238 Coffee Stall - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: This stall offers the best &#39;homemade&#39; iced lemon tea in Tiong Bahru Market.<br><br>I&#39;ve actually tried the iced lemon tea at every stall, and personally hate the ones where they add that lemon/lime syrup drink to enhance the citrus flavour.<br><br>Not here. Here it&#39;s just brewed black tea, already refrigerated and portioned, topped up with ice, and then jazzed up with a freshly squeezed lemon wedge and a slice of lemon. It&#39;s sometimes a wee bit too sweet (they&#39;re not always perfectly consistent), but generally it really hits the spot.<br><br>The sugar cane is also very good. <br><br>If you can&#39;t find it, it&#39;s basically the corner stall that&#39;s on your right as you come up the escalator.

I&#39;m usually adverse to hawker centres because they are such warm, crowded places. So for me, there&#39;d better be darn good food to be worth the trip down, and a great stall with iced drinks. Thankfully, I&#39;ve found 238 to be consistent each and every time I&#39;ve visited. While people swear by the kopi, I just can&#39;t because it&#39;s simply too hot. Instead, I always opt for the sugar cane with lemon, freshly squeezed and strained on the spot. I&#39;ve tried all the sugar cane stalls there are at Tiong Bahru Market, and 238 still remains unsurpassed. Icy, sweet, tangy, and importantly, sugar cane fibre free. The server inside will first pick out a fat wedge of lemon and squeeze the juice into a plastic cup filled with ice before plonking the squashed lemon body inside. The cup is then filled to the brim with sugar cane and handed over to you, while you dish up your measly $1.40. It&#39;s a small price to pay for a refreshing cup full of temperature regulating joy.

text: The Skinny: Opens at 10am, has very limited food menu (basically savoury/dessert waffles and other cakes/sweets). They don&#39;t really do breakfast. The coffee is not barista-level.<br><br>The Review: This place is literally a 2 minute walk from my front door, so is extremely convenient and although this is my first visit I will no doubt be back many times. Whilst they do have a wide selection of coffee, it is not a great brew. I had the Expresso Macchiato (apparently that variation of the word is correct), and a Long Black (times 2). The first was good, the second was OK. I&#39;m used to high quality coffee so I found these just OK, but the pricing is good.<br><br>The ambience of the place is very chill; they have a laid-back playlist on in the background which is not too loud and not too soft. During my visit from 10-1, the place had about 7 people in it, which is about 1/4 full.<br><br>The lounges give you the opportunity to have a relaxing coffee - they also have wifi and power outlets and make an ideal working space for those interested in a chilled workspace.<br><br>Overall - not a bad place to stop, catch your bearings, or do a spot of work.<br><br>Upon leaving I walked past the coffee shop next door which was much busier and tempting.

Love the interior', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Love the interior'}]
text: Visited the cafe twice in the past 2 weeks. Enjoyed my visit on both visits, staying an average of about 2 hours. I&#39;m giving it a 3 Yelp stars based on the following factors:<br><br>1. Ambience: 4/5. Very comfy seating with multiple configurations to choose from - conventional height round and rectangle tables with chairs and 3 sets of sofa seats. <br><br>Most impressed with the living room setting at the back of the cafe: long faux leather sofa with TV, side table and bookcase. Talk about making you feel right at home? They&#39;ve done that well.<br><br>I ended up sitting in the same sofa seat on both visits because that&#39;s the one with the window view - cos I love to people watch.<br><br>2. Service: 4/5. The front counter staff was really friendly and most helpful with suggestions when I couldn&#39;t decide where to sit during my first visit (I prefer seats that are comfortable, not too cold/hot and ideally with a view). <br><br>We also had a nice convo during my 1st visit and she was very eager to give me info regarding the concept of the cafe (integrated cafe-retail-interior architecture). She remembered me when I visited again which was definitely very nice. <br><br>3. Food &amp; drinks: 2/5. Unfortunately, the quality of their coffee is really sub-par. I had rose latte and savoury waffles during my first visit - rose latte did not taste good and the waffles was just average.<br><br>The long black that my friend and I had on my 2nd visit was still ok, but the red velvet cake that we had was really bad. I&#39;ve not had such bad red velvet cakes in a while. <br><br>4. Cool integrated concept: 4/5. Interestingly, the cafe is integrated with their interior architecture office, so, customers get to see the staff working at their tables at the back of the cafe, and the staff get to see some of the customers too. <br><br>Though, I&#39;m not too sure whether this integrated space is really good for productivity? Won&#39;t the staff be disturbed by noisy customers? I&#39;m not sure, maybe I&#39;ll ask the friendly front counter staff next time.<br><br>I hope they do something to improve their food and drinks quality. It&#39;s a shame as they did up the interior very well and it&#39;s really cosy, so, they really should do justice to the place.

text: I saw two cafes next to each other and I picked this because it looked inviting. The venue is nicely designed. Rating is based on espresso. It&#39;s Starbucks bad and I swear I&#39;m tasting a mold aftertaste. Too bad as the cookie with it is very nice. <br>Come for the free wifi(8.55mbps) and ambience. Stay clear of the coffees or maybe just the flavored coffees. Someone told me the iced hazelnut is good.

text: This place just opened in UE Square, replacing an Italian restaurant. Epicurious is friendly and nice, fairly welcoming. We were there during a soft-opening weekend, which meant they were still waiting for some electrical work to be finished and, thus, some items on the menu couldn&#39;t be made. Still, breakfasts looked quite attractive.<br><br>I had the eggs benedict while my wife had scrambled eggs on green pesto. Both were good and did the job, but were a bit lackluster. We ended up with an uneasy feeling, that there was something missing. I mean, food tastes good, but is far away from spectacular, and that&#39;s when Epicurious starts losing points. There&#39;s no &#34;wow! factor&#34;, nothing that would make us be anxious to go back. The bill just confirmed this uneasy feeling. We realised that for the same amount we could walk a few blocks and have a dazzling breakfast, or a much more memorable breakfast in Tiong Bahru. Even on UE Square itself, we can get a much more thrilling breakfast for less.<br><br>Our friends at Epicurious do a good job and are clearly making an effort. Unfortunately, the food ends up being average while prices are not. I wish they can overcome this gap, they surely deserve better.
